2010: Same with a little more spicy. Extra long finish...

THE beer to taste!

Pours a hazy, extremely effervescent ,dusty amber with a huge, chunky light biege head that nearly exploded from the top of my glass by the time I poured half of the beer out, has good retention and leaves a little lacing. Aroma is stone fruit, dusty grain, fresh sweet grass, canned fruit cocktail, pear brandy and a hint of fresh apples. Ridiculously fruity in the nose. Gets much more boozy as it warms. Flavor is more fruit cocktail, raw bread doughy yeast, underripe and overripe tree fruit, light fusel notes as it warms (very light for a BSA of this alcohol content), and faint dusty, boozy citrus toward the finish. Palate is pretty heavy, moderately carbonated and a bit slick throughout. This stuff smelled really good going in, but it just doesnt taste that good, which kills the experience a bit on subsequent sniffs.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2014 Bottle from 2006 . Pours orange brownish amber with a tiny head. Aroma is huge on the caramelish sirupy port-like sweetness along with notes of some dark ripe fruits and some belgian yeasty esters. Taste of syrup, caramel, spice, overripe plums and bananas, raisin, belgian yeast, light sour notes, warming alcohol and slight rum.

11.6 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is a hazy orange/brown mix with 3 fingers of thick, lasting off-white foam on top.  Nose is pears, candied sugar, bananas, yeast, basement, and a bit of booze.  Taste is right on par, but delivered as a dry, highly carbonated sugar/fruit combination that goes right into the finish; a bit of warming booze also joins in while lingering on the palate.  This is a nice beer that I think is well done, however, it is not a style that I go crazy for.
me laspettavo sicuramente più dolce,e forse piu scura,ma quel piccantino che lascia in bocca è veramente particolare,di certo non sembra avere 12°....

33 cl, bottled October 2009. Pours a cloudy amber (may have poured a bit of lees into the glass) with a nice thin off-white lacing around the outside of the glass. A nice sweet aroma, raisins, bananas, some spices; full bodied mouth feel that coats everything in a nicely carbonated, smooth, creamy and velvet coating. Hops have faded but like how they dry out the finish and leave a very mild bitterness to balance the upfront sweetness. Havent had this in ages but its delicious - with 1.5 years on the bottle the sweetness isnt overwhelming plus everything is balanced. Looking forward to trying another bottle in a year to see how it does.

Massive frothing snowdrift of a head on heavily carbonated copper/gold/yellow beer.  Aroma is light/dry hops, tinge of acidic sour, and subtle candied sugar, and sweet caramel malt.  Taste is clean and dry up front with light, bitter hops followed by a heavy sweet malt/raisin component and a slight sour feature.  Theres some candied sugar and light yeast components as well.  Amazingly clean and precise feel in the mouth for the high ABV.  Extremely drinkable and satisfyingly complex.  Excellent beer.

Appearance: deep, slightly hazy gold; giant fluffy white souffle of a head that lingers forever, slowly shrinking, leaving swathes of cotton candy-like lacing.   Aroma: 	big nose full of fresh pie crust, cloves, yeast, banana, white wine, honey, citrus and fresh-cut flowers.   Taste: darkly sweet malts, with a big hit of spices (cloves, cinnamon), banana, honey, syrup, champagne, orange rind and booze, with some astringent hops to balance.   Finish: very dry, and with a good medium bitterness to balance all that sweetness, fading to a rich, boozy warming sensation.   Notes: A very big beer with tons of flavor and character.  A complex sipper that is not shy about its alcohol, although it doesnt taste or feel quite as strong as it actually is.  Careful, that 12% may indeed surprise you.
bottle.  Pour is dark orange.  Medium head.  Aroma of caramel and yeast.  Flavor is sweet and sharp, nice nugget hop taste.  Some citrus. Great beer.

Anyada 1987. Genial mostra del que pot donar de sí una gran cervesa preparada per envellir. Notes de mel, cremositat, sense carbònic. Per prendre amb postres o com a copa digestiva. Embriagadora, sublim.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2015 pours cloudy dark orange-copper with a decent head. spicy-orange, a tad acidic. butterscotch, loads of caramel-toffee notes, woodsy. belgium spices and good yeast presence, peppery. good supporting hops - citrus and herbal to balance the sweetness. medium body, soft carbonation. EDIT: 95 vintage bottle - rodenbach era - drank in 15. excellent stuff - very pleasant surprise: brettied epaches, tasty apricots, very yeasty, winey (!), red grapes, astringent, bitter citrus peel (9-3-8-4-17)

bottled oct. 2009 on cap poured a copper brown in color with a little covering of white head. aroma has malts, sweetness, spices, and fruit. mouth feel is surprisingly light and there is plenty of carbonation. flavor has an interesting sweetness, light malts, some spice, apricots, fruit, and lots of yeasty character. interesting that such a light beer has such a high abv. and ages so well. super drinkable.

The beer pours a rusty brown with a nice white head, lots of carbonation. The retnetion is good as well as the lacing.

The aroma is malty with spice, honey and star anise.

The taste is nice, doesnt have a ton of the spice but very complex. 

Good feel and drinkability.
Smells Belgiany and estery, banana notes. Pours a huge foamy head. Very sweet malt notes, I expected it to be dry...but the Belgian yeast compliments the malty sweetness in a very nice way.

Bouteille de 33cl. Édition 2009. La bière est ambrée, la mousse a malheureusement disparu plus vite que jécris. Le nez est dalcool et  de caramel. La bouche est chaleureuse, lalcool est bien présent mais tout de même agréable. Le saveurs sont amples et sucrée. Cette bière est vraiment enivrante. 8/10

Surprisingly light, both in color and in body.  I expected it to be darker, sweeter, and more fruity.  What I got was spicier, something like those apples in sauce that you see around Thanksgiving/Boston Market.  Pretty good, easy to drink for 12%, but didnt wow me.

2006 vintage, 12%abv.

It pours a deep reddish brow with a large rocky white head that leaves just a few spots of lacing.

The smell is sweet and seductive. Rich dark fruits dominate, it is reminiscent of a Belgian Quadrupel. It has the scent of red grapes, plums, dark cherries, and red delicious apple. There is a nice candied toffee scent and some spiciness as well.

This one is a sipper, whew. The first drink i quaffed a bit too much of it and it was overpowering. But all in all it is classic Quadrupel. It has layers of flavor starting with a nice bit of tart fruits, then going into a malty and dark bread middle, then it has a kick of fruitiness near the finish with some cherries, and it finishes with a waring alcoholic/sweet pungency. The flavor is soo rich. There is a big alcoholicness and sweetness, but the yeast provides a killer fruitiness that is just accented immensely by the alcohol and caramally sugar.

The mouthfeel is almost juicy, it is such a fruity beer that it reminds me of sparkling juice. It is a very nice mouthfeel actually.

This is an epic beer, I have seen it on the shelf for years now, I am glad I bought it finally.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-31-2010 02:03:36

Picked up at Holiday Market in Royal Oak, MI. Reviewed from notes.

Ppours dark brown with an off white head with a bit of lacing. The nose fits the style quite well with good notes of dark fruits, caramel, and a bit of booze. The taste and mouthfeel combine together quite well. There is a nice creamy character that accentuates the dark fruit and caramel flavors. Overall, a well done beer that I think would be quite a bit better with some age on it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-20-2010

[RATING 2000!!!!!] Vintage 2010 Bottle... Poured a hazy, golden with a thick, fluffy white head. The nose was filled with yeast and spice, mild fruit tartness, honey and wheat-like malt tones too. Lots of dry yeast characters. Apples, dates, apricots and other fruits. Well spiced -- ginger, cloves, and a tiny hop presence. Amazingly refreshing and drinkable in huge gulps for 12%. YUM!

Beautiful, orange yellow beer with a big and blond head. Aroma is very pleasant, fresh fruits, yeast, spicyness, oranges, peachess and fruitfull swetness. Taste is also filled with fruits, yeast, spicys, some bitterness, a hint of alcohol without taste, but with warming feeling. Taste is not so complex than aroma, but it is straightfull and strong. Almost full bodied with lots of carbonation, nice. Very tastefull, fruitfull and strong beer, maybe even too strong. Would this be better and more enjoyable with lower alc.%? What I complain, great beer for slowly enjoying.

(bottle) pours a hazy bright orange colour with a frothy white head and some miniscule floaties. very interesting aroma of breakfast muesli, maracuja, lactic acid and spicy grain. flavour is quite sweet and mostly on the spicy rye side of things, with a lightly sour touch and a light alcoholic finish. heavy-bodied with average carbonation. a definite slow-sipper.

330ml bottle, bottled in nov 2 2009, amber color, with a big frothy white head, with some flakes of lee swirling around, yeasty, fruity, ripe apple, pear, faint candied orange peel, peach esters, with a nice toasted, caramel, biscuity malt, honeyish accent, with a hint of spiciness, and with a light pruney, date puréed note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a warmth, yeasty, fruity, honeyed raisiny, datey, faint juicy pruney, bready, toasted, caramelized, biscuity malt, liqueurish character of Grand Marnier liqueur, with some faint honeyish candi sugar flavours in backbone, with a hint of flowery leafy, candied citrus peels, leading towards a warming, fruity, honeyed pruney, liqueurish finish
2010 Bottle pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is fruity, sweet, yeasty. Flavor is sweet, zesty citrus, bready yeast, very lively in the mo.uth with a touch of tartness.

Hazy Golden Orange Pour with medium white head and some lacing.
Fruity Nose with hints of yeast.
Citrus hops and other fruits and sweet malts (but not too sweet)
medium body. 
quick bitter finish.

Lovely.
Aroma, very fruity, complex malts, opens with time, taste is of a very complex malty belgian strong, alcohol hidden very well, highly recommended

Bottle. Pours a deep amber color with a nice foamy head. Smells of grapes, sugar and plums. Tasytes of figs, fates, nuts and sugar candy. Very nice slow easy drinking beer. Id have it again... And again

Bottled 33cl. Much paler appearane than expected. Apple, plum, pear, raisin and melon showing up in the nose which is yeast accented. Vitamin tablets sneaking in. Fruity. Full bodied. Warming on the swallow. There is a nice bite to this beer. Reminiscence of melon and pear in the finish. Very pleasant but far from being a great beer.

Vintage 2007. Clear amber with a big and lasting white head. Aroma is sweet, dried fruit, yeasty and spicy, pepper. Flavor is very sweet. The finish is dry, soft and warming alcohol. Very pleasant. 291210
330 ml bottle a amber colored beer with a white head aroma sweet malts spices fruits some liqueur and yeast taste sweet malts spices fruits orange some liqueur and some hop

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2011 12/01/2011 - 33cl bottle @ home (2011-15) 
Dark orange to amber coloured beer. Off-white creamy head, non adhesive. Aroma: orange peel, cloves, caramel, yeast. MF: lots of carbon (just a touch too much), full body. Taste: caramel, fruity, cloves, ginger bread, little sweet but not sticky. Ginger beer and anise. Aftertaste: spices, caramel, agrum fruits.

09 bottle. Pours a bright golden with a creamy off white head and whoa, tons of fizziness. Aroma has some nice tart sour cherries with a big helping of Belgian yeast, a nice mixture of varied fruits, a bit citric, rich overripe fruits raisins plums, a touch of sweet honey and vanilla. Flavor also has a great complexity, the citric and dark fruits mesh well and the candi sugars add even more with a bit of earthiness in the finish. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Great Belgian Strong

Orange pour and a small off-white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and grassy, alcohol, vinegar, apples, dried apricot, fermentad fruits. Taste is sweet and boozy with some sourness, caramel, orange liquer, sirup, ash, funkiness. A bit unbalanced booziness. Funky aftertaste. Dry mouthfeel. It´s good but I was hoping for more.

Part of the Weihnachten offering at Känguruh Pub, Vienna. I was served a 2009 vintage bottle - deep, deep amber in color with a sweet nose of caramel, raisins, plums, etc. Extremely smooth drinking with well hidden alcohol. Poured the dregs in the glass at the end and really f*&cked it up... I recommend letting them be :)  My current Christmas favorite.

Bouteille de 33 cl, édition 2008. Arômes de levure légèrement fruitée, touche de pommes vertes et de foin. Robe orangée, beaucoup de particules en suspension, effervescence active et belle mousse. Très ronde et moelleuse en bouche, on retrouve un corpulent malt rappelant le sucre dorge et les céréales légèrement grillées. La levure apporte de légères notes fruitées. Une touche dacidité tente, tant bien que mal, déquilibrer le malt sucré. Lalcool, bien que présent, est relativement bien intégré pour une bière aussi forte. Pas mauvais, mais je mattendais à mieux.

Nose: Typical Belgian nose with fruit and spices.
Taste: A bit oily caramel. creamy and contain traces of nuts.
After taste: Very sweet but very nice.
Sweet fruit aroma.  Orange-amber in color with a slight white head.   Sweet pear with a slight spice.

Enjoyed from an 11.2oz bottle in a wine glass.  The beer pours a slightly hazy light amber color, with an essentially nonexistent head.  The nose shows an ester profile reminiscent of the Westmalle yeast strain; dark fruits, along with a slight continental malty note.  Alcohol is fairly prevalent, but forgivable in a beer with such a high gravity.  The palate absolutely shines, showing a slight bready malt note up front, dark and tropical fruit esters, and a depth adding alcohol presence.  Really amazing complexity.  The finish lingers, with more dark fruit esters, and a slight, but pleasing, residual malt sweetness, along with a tinge of alcohol.  Overall, a great example of the style; certainly living up to the hype surrounding De Dolle.
13th November 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Complex beer. Effervescent sharp frothy start with plenty of sourish fruit. A warming dry finish with the fruit blooming further. Very nice.

Bottiglia 2009. Il colore è uno splendido ramato torbo, con una bella schiuma pannosa persistente. Aroma deciso di caramello e frutta (prugne). In bocca è esplosiva, la potenza alcolica si rivela subito, il corpo è pieno, vinoso, liquoroso. Forse un pò troppo dolce, ma stasera avevo mangiato pesante e mi ha fatto digerire alla grande...

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 2009 bottle. Pours a nice dark orange. Taste is very sweet, fruity, belgian spices, alcohol. Quite a good beer, but probably needs a year or two more to reach its apex. A little too sweet. Will rate up .1 of a point for aging potentilal.

Bottle 2009 edition from Craked Kettle, consumed 2010-12-30 Göteborg
AR: vionos, roated malt, caramel, 
AP: hazy victoria plum/amber, 2 cm thick fizzy light yellowish head diminshing down to 1 cm - steady!
F: vionos, plum, dadles, rasin, sour, nutty fudge, warming feeling, medium bitterness, high carbonation, the body is full and there are loads of diffferent flavors that are going on - Napoleon (mandarin liqueur)

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2013 2009 Bottle. Hazy copper with a huge white head. Before being able to pour, the foam had been flowing from the bottle for several minutes. Aroma: lots of port, citrus peel, spices, but no yeast. Taste: port, dried fruit, raisins, figs or dates?, quite a bit of alcohol, sweet and vinous, caramel, hard candy, fruit, low bitterness and some acidity. Full-bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel. Complex stuff. Really nice now, but could probably be cellared for a few more years. 
2009 bottle, Christmas 2012.
Aroma: orange and other citrus fruit, light earthy and vinous.
Taste: dried tropical fruit and raisins, candy and licorice, vinous, malty, complex, light spicy yeast.

Bottle(2009) at Staminee de Garre in Brugge on 12-07-10 (4,50 euro). Sweet aroma of good bbq ribs. ABV very apparent in taste. Pours a clear amber/orang color with lots of carbonation. So thick and chewy in flavor, yet palatable. Thick rich caramel notes mid body with a clean crisp finish. Interesting and complex beer.

Bottle. Huge two-fingers of lightly tan head; light muddy copper brown hue. Prunes, raisins, candied fruit, toffee and breadiness are all featured in the aroma with some citrus and spiciness.  Lots of fruit in the flavor with pears and apples in addition to the darker fruit flavors.  Malty toffee and warming as hell overall.  Vibrant carbonation with a medium sticky body.  What a great sipping brew for a nightcap.

bottle from Village de la Bière Strasbourg; vintage 2008. Hazy deep golden colour with floaties, enormously large white head, growing and growing. Fruity nose: apples, cider and cellar. Full-bodied, intensive malty base, lots of apples, unfiltered apple juice, with a touch of tartness reminding me of cider. Hints of vanilla and honey. Shy hoppy touch in the lingering finish. The high ABV is extremely well disguised, alcoholic flavours/ester are hardly detectable. A delicious beer for Christmas night.

Bottle @ home. Full of yeast, even while rested, gently poured and left most in the bottle. Aroma is sour fruit, yeast, only faint malt. Infection?
Flavour is a weird malt sweetness with some sourness/metal and more. Thin palate, weird colour. Definitely an infection. Too bad, need to get me another bottle.

Bottle 2008. Amber in color with a lasting khaki colored head. Complex aroma of mainly sugar, alcohol, peaches, honey, and some light funk. Flavor is quite sweet with a small amount of hop bitterness. Palate is explosive and lively with well-hidden alcohol. This beer was highly enjoyable.

Bottle 33cl. A lightly cloudy copper beer with a head that goes quickly. Smell is on yeast and honey like. Very interesting beer, heavy malty syrup taste and sweet associated with a slightly vinous and Champagne like taste which gives fruity notes as grapes and peaches, floral. High bitterness that comes more at the end with honey notes. Surprising beer, with lambic inspiration, long bitter aftertaste associated with tannin.

330cl bottle (2006 vintage).... pours a mostly muddled lemony brown pour (agitated the friggin yeast so not much clarity) and topped with a creamy semim-thin white head... aroma fruity belgian yeast esthers borderlining on a semi-tart nature but doesnt completely sway in that direction.  sweeter malt balances the equation... flavors are much of the same but sweeter overall than what the aroma had suggested.  dried fruits, some dark mostly lighter, mingle freely with richer caramel malt qualities. belgian yeast character remains apparent.  soft to medium prickly carbonation persists with a medium to full body.

Bottle. (vintage 2008)

Hazy orange with a huge thick white head. Aroma of caramel, apples, spices, raisin, yeast and some honey. The taste was nicely balanced, also quite sweet. A wonderful beer, perfect to enjoy for a long time. Complex with a well hidden alcohol.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2012 This is a masterpiece. The most complex beer ever drunk, simply perfect in the mix of hops and malt.
Nice head that lasts some time. Dark gold colour. Malty taste and smell. Hints of hop and koriander. Strong aftertaste.
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2010 Bottle found in Urbains fridge. Nice spices in the aroma and flavor. Slight alcohol in the aftertaste. Very nice beer.

330 ml, bottled Nov.2009, aged for a year, into 180 ml Chimay chalice.
Pours effervescent, viscous, hazy, copperish peachy-amber body with tiny floaties, topped by medium, creamy ivory head with good retention that gradualy sets to a thick cloth. Firm laces on the walls.
As the layers of this utterly complex brew are peeled off more and more aromas are revealed with each sniff : white wine, fruity esters of orange, apple, pear, sultanas, candy sugar, peppery phenolics, toasted bread, minute touch of grassy hops and alcohol.
Soft pale malt embraced flavors of white wine, juicy fruitiness of oranges, apple tartness, pear, sultanas, prominent suggary sweetness, peppery spiciness, hoppy bitterness counteracting the sweet tones and warming alcoholic finish.
The medium bodied beer tends to be airy on the palate yet remains creamy thanks to the high viscosity that bridles the apparently moderate to high carbonation.

In short: A viscous, boozy brew with bittersweet fruity tartness reminiscent of a candied citrus peel.
Bottle at ÖBWF 2010. It poured a hazy golden liquid with a small white head. Sweet flavour with spices, malts and fruits. Nice and complex.
Nose of yeast, cane sugar, peppermint, late malt, feel is mediumlight, carb is mediumweak, taste is very light, almost soda-like, notes of plum, apricot, weak alcohol, yeast

fantastic beer, good balance.
you dont taste the alcohol, but its clear its there, giving this beer its full flavour... love it!

On tap at Plan B, Copenhagen. Pours hazy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma is fruity, spicy and some good caramel. Taste is moderate sweet malty, oranges and tangerine, dries up at the end.Full bodied with a rather sweet finish. Lovely beer.
h.
Tasted this at Mikkeller bar Cobenhagen, pours foggy orange with a distinct fruity citrus aroma. The taste is a bit to sweet, but I guess that is the genuine signature of a Belgian beer.

Wow, over 1000 reviews for this beer and Ive never heard of it before! Pours foggy orange with little head. Aroma of syrup and paint thinner, and mixed in with that are soft citrus notes and lacquer. The Palate is surprisingly light and smooth, making it easy to drink. Yet there isnt much flavour here - I cant identify much upon the flavour radar. Perhaps all of their effort went into masking the 12% alcohol, which this does marvellously, but theres not much else to it.

Bottle. Cap says 2003, assume that is the year this was bottled. Pours a cloudy hazed apricot orange/brown color with very minimal head. What head there is collars around the glass in an off white color. Smells sweet with hints of apricot and pear. The taste is pretty sweet as well with an undertone of alcohol. Apricot flavors is all I have in my mind, in a god way, as this drinks very smooth. Medium/heavy mouthfeel. White grapes in the taste as well. Some lace left on the glass as I drink this down. This is very good, sweet, but good.

New Beer Distributors 11.60z (5.75): I just finished my first bottle of this delightful stuff. It pours a murky light brown color with a not too long lasting head. Sediment floats around especially if you try to repour the empty bottle. The aroma is powerful, even when right out of the fridge. A combination of sugars, yeasts and malts makes my nose happy. However, the taste is the crowning aspect (as it should be). I will say outright that I think that this beer is amazingly good. It is gentle but firm. Perhaps that is another way of saying that it is very well-balanced, but in any case, the whole spectrum of flavors is present here, while at the same time delivering a punch. A lot of winy flavors are present, along with a moderate sweetness. However, there is also a good Belgian hop flavor juxtaposed to the aforementioned flavors. A lot of Belgian yeast in there. Alcohol is covered, but not through the usual mechanisms. I really love this beer. The only downside is that is very expensive.

Pours a deep hazy golden color with just a tinge of coppery red. White foamy head with good retention. Can smell a bit of citrusy orange, sour brett aromas, smooth caramel malt, an overall sweet/tangy/sour aroma.

The funky sour flavor definitely came through along with bitter, citrus, caramel, and metallic flavors and a strong presence of alcohol. My experience with the flavor was not a favorable as some of the other ratings, but Ive had this bottle for close to a year and think the quality may have been compromised. I could taste the potential for a great beer but something was off.

Tap @ Ølbaren, Copenhagen. 2010 edition, I guess. :-P Pours a beautiful deep hazy yellow-orange body with a huge, white crown. Aroma is sour yeasty tones with some brett-like funkiness lurking in the back. Fresh and nice. Taste is also yeasty, with dry, grape-like flavors balanced by a hefty dose of pale malt sweetness. Smooth and filling palate. A very nice Xmas brew in the "biere brut"-tradition from a brewery that really grows on me. De Dolle: I will be coming back for more! ;-)

(Courtoisie de Viper666)  Le liquide dévoile une robe ambrée et voilée.  Un mince anneau de mousse est observable.  Le nez est richement malté avec des effluves de caramel, de sucre dorge et de bonbon.  Présence dun parfum propre à la levure.  Des esters fruités remplissent lespace : un véritable gâteau aux fruits confits.  À travers les fleurs de lalcool, des petites pointes dépices qui piquent avec gentillesse.  Au goût, le liquide est lourdement malté, avec des saveurs fortes de toffee et fruits macérés.  La présence de lalcool se fait rassurante : elle atténue la douceur extrême des malts.  En bouche, le liquide est exubérant avec une effervescence juste à point et une texture proprement épaisse.  La finale est pleine de fruits imbibés dun alcool délicieusement chaud et floral.  En résumé, superbe vendredi soir sur la planète Bière.
Amber with little head. Aroma sweet plum, candymalt. Taste as aroma. Alcohol hidden. Finish slight bitterness. Much better than 2005.

2008.  Ah sweet honeydew!  Also getting some honeycomb and a bit of oak, once warmed up a bit I got a little sting of CO2.  Suspended sediment in a hazy gold and a foamy lively creamy head.  Little strong with CO2 initially followed by more honeydew and white grape and a hot alcohol finish.   Overall Im disappointed.

Aroma has lots of belgian yeast characteristic with the classic flowery sweet touch. This one just has a tad of funkiness that makes the yeast component very interesting. On the malty side there is caramel, grain. Orange peel and a spicey touch, small grassy hop component. Taste is the delicious yeast, very spicy, orange peel, cinnamon. Very good.
A stunning reddy gold with a good creamy head,aroma of fruits,sticky figs,apple sauce,apricots,candi sugar and caramel,slightly bitter,A top brew !

Serving:  330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.
Aroma: The room fills with notes of dried fruit, yeast, fruit cake, dried fig, a touch of dark apple cider, apricot, and more. 
Appearance: It pours a hazy dark amber color with a foamy, off-white head.  I am really surprised that this brew can maintain a head given the high alcohol content. 
Taste: The flavor is big with lots of fruit including the fig, apple, pear, white raisin, and apricot.  The yeast brings a light dustiness along too.  The malt sweetness has a touch of candi sugar and caramel as well.  The light bitterness on the back end helps even things out.  Really outstanding.
Palate:  Rich, yet not heavy.  Lots of small carbonation bubbles help lighten things up.  The finish is medium, a touch fruity, and a touch sweet.  The finish is surprisingly clean.  The alcohol warms just a touch as it goes down.
Overall: I can see why this one is so highly rated.  Tons of layers of flavor, rich without being cloying.  Not hot or boozy despite having 12% alcohol.  I am not sure how you get much better than this.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 330 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu.
Pours a reddish brown colour with a minimal head. Loads of visible yeast particles. Aroma of fresh fruits, yeast and alcohol. Flavour of dark fruits, spices and yeast. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and thick carbonation also. Warming finish. Very tasty. 9-4-8-4-16
330 ml bottle. 2009 version after two years of aging.
Pours a copper colour with loads of visible bubbles. Thick white head. Looks delicious. Aroma of ripe fruits, fresh citrus, caramel and some bread-like maltiness. Flavour of light caramel malts, ripe fruits, citrus such as mandarin orange, bubblegum, some yeast and some very delicate sourness. Full bodied, very smooth mouthfeel and a long, warming, fruity and refreshing finish. Alcohol warms in the finish nicely. Extremely well aged and Im guessing this will improve even more in a couple of years. 9-4-9-4-16

Bouteille 330ml (2009). De couleur dorée-ambrée foncée et voilée. Nez fruité (figues sucrées, léger de prunes et dagrumes, traces de raisins vineux), de sucre bonbon, moyen dalcool (notes liquoreuses), léger de pain avec des notes de houblon herbeux, dépices, de caramel et de sucre brun. Ronde-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse avec des notes liquoreuses. Goût fruité (moyen de figues sucrées, léger de prunes et dagrumes sucrées, notes de pommes, traces de raisins) accompagné de notes dépices (notes de muscade et de clou de girofle) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de sucre bonbon, un moyen goût malté de caramel sucré avec un léger goût de pain et des traces de sucre brun. Parallèlement, lon retrouve un goût dalcool légèrement réchauffant en arrière-goût durant toute la gorgée et qui ressort plus fort en finale, accompagné dune légère amertume de houblon herbeux. Post-goût long, moyennement amer dalcool, de levures fruitées (pelures de prunes, notes de moût de raisins et de zest dagrumes) avec des notes de houblon herbeux ainsi quun goût sucré résiduel en bouche.
2003 bottle.  A little oxidation, but not enough to really effect the taste.  It tasted more like a barley wine with sweet caramel malt, brown sugar, dark fruit, and butterscotch flavors.......

33cl bottle. 2003 edition. Best before 2012-11-10. Golden colour with a small head. Small yeast residue. Aroma is yeasty with heavy notes of alcohol. Notes of toffee and butterscotch. Flavour is massive. Heavy notes of malts, sugar, caramel and alcohol. Very sweet finish. Medium long aftertaste.

Talk about a gusher!  This beer flowed from the bottle as soon as it was opened.  A huge golden head has flakes of reddish yeast.  The beer is very cloudy and active.  Lush fruit and yeast define the aroma.  The taste has that Belgian aspect to it.  That fruit and yeast again and some sugar.  Hops add sourness but just a bit.  Alcohol is tasted but doesnt detract.  This is a classic Belgian with all of the ingredients of a great recipe and it is one that never gets old.

Smells like a spirit made of hemlock, spruce and lavender.  Under the evergreen are some date and fig aromas that are more prevelant at colder temps.  Flavor is deeply mature malts that lends a butterscotch character to the whole thing.  Definately some alcoholic fig in the flavor as well, and its worth noting that it gets more alcoholic as it warms.  Complex and rich when cool, sweet and harsh when warmed, at its best it strikes a great balance between the malts and yeastiness.  Great sherry like mouthfeel and finish.  2009 11.2 oz.  Thanks De Dolle.

A: snifter. very murky, brownish orange. nice huge head, off-white in color. amazing head retention. good lacing that leaves splotches.

S: very sour notes. like sour oranges or lemons. very zesty. I get some spices, but nothing truly stands out.

T: very sour and rather sweet, but kind of expected from the 12% plateau. solid, sweet malty backbone. spices are in play with this one, cloves and nutmeg. no big hop quality. I love the sours in this. Tastes like a champagne.

M: good carbonation level. very thichk and warming.

D: only good for one or two at 12%. great winter beer, with a great use of sours.

25-SEP-2010, 2005 vintage bottle @home, from "Ølbutikken".
Aaarh, I should be more experienced than that...
I open the bottle far from the glass and need to clean the table afterwards. Off course it pours out of the bottle before I can land some in the glass...
...and it looks just beautifull in the glass until I take a closer look and see the yeast floating...
...but apart from that a beautifull cloudy orange/golden with huge lasting head.
Nose is wonderfull - fruitbasket of yeast with orange peel, bananas and more.
Very very creamy and long aftertaste. This is certainly a favorite.
Five years old and a treat.

Unfortunately, there was not date sticker on this one, so Im not sure of the vintage. In any case...

A: The pour is an opaque dark orange color with a dense white head. Fairly good head retention, too.

S: A fairly enticing nose. Lots of sweet, amber candi sugar, pears, bananas, and figs. Some warming spice notes and a mild yeast character. A hint or too of alcohol as well.

T: The initial few sips are nice, and follow the nose well. Candi sugar, and some dark fruit notes up front, but the finish is just alcohol. Very, very hot and ethanol forward after the initial flavor of the beer.

M: The body is nice. A medium body with a very fine carbonation that fills the mouth. Unfortunately, the alcohol sort of ruins this too.

D: Its too bad that this beer was so alcohol forward. Ill look to revisit this beer in the future (possibly with an aged bottle), hoping this was an aberration.

2009 vintage. Pours clear orange/golden with almost no head. Aroma is sweet, fruity, some wood and alcohol (smell reminiscent of dark rum). Taste is sticky sweet, with some sour and bitter notes to cut through the richness. Very pleasant and warming mouthfeel.

Suspended haze-oids in an orange body with next to no head.  Aroma is fruity, spicy and alcoholic with bread and yeast rounding out the nose.  Taste is too boozy with fruit, mainly orange and some spicy yeast.  A bit too much.

Bottle - 330ml. Hazy amber body with some small yeasty flakes and a decent off-white creamy head. Strong malty/hoppy aroma with vineous and apple hints. Alcohol is well hidden. Awesome, well balanced taste that carries fruity, yeasty, and spicy notes. Ends with a long, warming bittersweet finish. Excellent winter warmer.

12oz bottle into Lost Abbey stemware. Pours a golden caramel color with small white head. Lots of caramel and butterscotch on the nose. Mouth feel is thick, creamy with moderate carbonation. Taste of butterscotch and some raisens, goes down smooth with lots of flavor. Beautiful beer.

Bottle. Light murky brown pour with frothy just off white head. Aroma is very winey, lots of white grapes, peaches, honey tons and tons of honey, very pleasant aroma. Taste is very sweet, honey, grapes, figs ect. The abundant carbonation keeps this beer from being too sweet and the palate simply makes the beer taste better it is so good. I love it.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2013 Bottle 33 cl - bottled in May 2002
Medium dark orange colour with a white head.
Clear oxidation effects - makes me think of banuyls & madeira wine. Other impressions: dried apricots & raisins
Full body with massive sweetness, alcohol is present but not interfering with the complex taste. Definitely a beer that is strong enough to undergo ageing!! Have another two in my cellar :-). 4.1/5
-------
Re-r April 2012 - after semi-vertical at Kulminator - vintages 1982 - 1989 - 1999 - 2012. Remarkable!!! 1982 was soooo spot on, this is a fantastic beer for ageing. The 1982 was so rich in taste and more of a wealthy Vlaams Oud Bruin (with the sour notes) more than a strong ale. Flabbergasted by this strong brewing skill. Upped the score to 4.6/5

Possibly the best beer in the world?

Never pass an opportunity to try this rare beer

Didnt have any available when I was at the brewery so I had to wait until later. Maybe it didnt travel well back to the US. It was very good just not as good as I was expecting. Would love to try the aged version. Serving: Bottle

Bottle at home. Clear deep orange color with a thin creamy just off-white head and loads of floaties. Aroma of candy sugar, boozy alcohol, tropical fruits and thick heavy malts. The flavor is an entirely different story, very rich with tropical fruits, honey and sweet malts up front, some licorice and bitter hops in the finish. A real taste evolution with every sip. Very full bodied with a thick syrupy texture and lively carbonation. Alcohol is well hidden in the flavor, just shines a bit through in the lingering aftertaste. Great brew, although I would not have said so judging on the aroma alone.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2012 33cl bottle.
this is my favourite beer of all time.  The aged version of 3 years plus is awesome!!!!!  I would love to brew a clone of this.

1999 vintage acquired somewhere in BE/NL (honestly, I forgot). Nose and appearance are just sublime...deep copper w/ a nice lively look and head for a beer brewed over a decade ago. Nose is light tropical fruit, brown sugar and a hit of pleasantly funky raisin/prune. Taste is a little heavy om the candy sugar by this point, still has nice elements of spicy malt and a touch of bitter molasses, but, taste-wise, thus baby is a little past its prime. Glad to have had it, And still a wonderful creation from a fantastic brewer, but would say 11 years is a touch too long.

Dark blond to amber coloured, very big head, reasonable carbonation. Aroma: barley, wheat, alcohol, candy. Taste is full--bodied, bitter, some alcohol, reasonable finish, fizzling in mouth. Nice, but some dominance of the alcohol.

Pours out amber-orange coloured with a medium till big white head that holds not long enough, a bit sad, the last parts stays... Hoppy and spiced aroma. Good balanced bitter-sweet taste, lots of spices, not bad, maybe a bit to uninteresting, but very drinkeable.

2008 bottle thanks to my son, Keith (fata2682).   The bottle overflowed upon opening and I lost a little bit but managed to pour it into a trappist glass.  Dark orange body with off-white head and tons of floaters of all different shapes and sizes.  Lots of citrus in both taste and aroma.  Was not as sweet as expected based on others reviews, perhaps due to aging, not sure.   Alcohol was noticable but not overpowering.

1 year bottle pours dark blond with small whitish head. Bread, floral hops, candy, bubblegum aromas. Taste is sweet and just a tad bitter and acidic. Complex flavors seem a little bit disjointed, but overall work pretty well.

Rich amber color with light particles; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, yeast, oak, caramel, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums, dates, & cherries), raisons, toffee, and spice; Some alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, very intense - and quite excellent.

Nei vari viaggi in Belgio purtroppo non sono mai riuscito a visitare il birrificio De Dolle ma comunque ho trovato qualche bottiglietta nelle vicinanze.Birra bionda intensa con schiuma bianca tendente allarancio.Aroma di luppolo che va a bilanciare il dolce dello zucchero caramellato.Il gusto poi è completato con un po di acidità dovuta dalla fermentazione.Ottima

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2010 head: small
colour: dark orange/amber , hazy
smell: sour, hops, malts, spices 
taste: bitter, hopy then alcoholand sour spicey end also a bit grassy/earthy aftertaste 
nice beer i love it since first time i drunk it over 3 years ago !

1999 vintage @ kulminator
head: 1 finger
colour: dark amber 
smell: sherry, malt, caramel, licqour, salty, alcohol, smokey, candy sirup 
taste: candle wax, brown sugar, licqour, caramel, toffee, mellowed hops, mellowed malts, earthy/grassy afertatse , so fuckin nice !! 
aroma: 8/10 
appearance: 4/5 
taste: 9/10 
palate: 2/5 
overall: 17/20

stille nacht 2010 version 
head: bubbly,white 
colour: amber/orange 
smell: carbonation, bitter, malts, hops, oranges, irony
taste: bitter, malts, peanuts, sweetcorn,yeasty,peels,aftertaste grassy, end is dry 
appearance: 3/5
taste: 9/10 
aroma: 8/10
palate:3/5
overall:16/20

Murky orangey copper in the glass topped with a frothy khaki head. Rich fruity malt, sour apples and pears, hint of plum. Spicy and sweet.

This ale packs a wallop. Huge pale malt flavors, big fruitiness with the spiced apple and pear again. Incredibly sweet, the candy sugar is very apparent. Sweet buttery caramel and hints of vanilla and toffee. All of this is permeated by a distinct booziness that warms and kicks. Its not harsh but you know its there. Very sweet finish but the alcohol helps to dry that out a bit. Fantastic flavors but very, very strong and rough around the edges.

Ive got another bottle. Maybe Ill crack it open for the 25 Beers of Christmas 09...or 10.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 2009 vintage. Bottle NOV2009.
App.:  Deep orange-amber with many small, suspended flecks and a fairly large off-white rocky foam.
  
Aroma:  Its hard to describe the aromas...some tropical fruits, a fair bit of alcohol, all dominated by this oddly full, thick, savoury, slightly stank note, on swirling there are some very nice biscuity malts and fruitiness, Im not lovin this.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body with fairly assertive, full, rounded effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Very boozy fruits, tropical fruits, tree fruits, big alcohol sting, biscuits, yeast, orange peel and citrus, the indescribable note from the nose is all but gone, maybe cause the alcohol killed my senses; seriously sweet and very boozy with relatively high bitterness for a sticky Belgian and a fruity/malty/boozy finish.

A few of these and the night would be anything but silent.

2007 vintage side by side with a 1998 vintage:
2007 vintage: 330 ml bottle; cloudy dark yellow with thin white head; sweet apples with some fresh hops and sweet malts; apples, brown sugar and an almost overpowering sweetness; candy malts, caramel and apples
1998 vintage: 330 ml bottle; clear dark amber and basically flat; surprising that the level of sweetness is still so in your face; apples and spoiled apricots with syrupy texture and mild oxidation; candy malts, apple juice and alcohol; interesting having these side by side, but in both the sweetness level was a little too much for me

Poured an amber hazy color with plenty of sediment roaming
around. Big sweet fruity booze aroma. Taste was hoppy, fruity and yeasty. Leaves a bit of booze heat on the tongue. Very nice Belgian strong ale. This beer would be wonderful cellared. This was a 2009 vintage.

bottled at sergios world beers; supposedly 2006 vintage sampled in 2010 may.  golden hue with a thick creamy white head, it has intense aroma of malt and banana.  the flavor is bready, this brew is very tasty and hides alcohol well.

2005 Vintage
3/31/2010:  De Dolle Stille Nacht...  Aroma:  Sugary pale malts; ripe pear; hints of apple cider and clover honey; peach jam; dark berries; alcochol in the background.  Appearance:  Dull golden orange color; cloudy/murky; contains a lot of floating debris; thin off-white crown; ample carbonation straining to rise through the thick, viscous-looking liquid.  Flavor:  Substantially malty and pleasantly sweet; reserved notes of caramel; brown sugar and dates; aged citrus; soft mellon; real maple syrup; earthy and floral broken-down bitterness; subtle vanilla characteristics; hefty alcoholic strength can be felt, but it is very well masked in the rich flavors.  Palate:  Medium-full body; coats the mouth very well; smooth and mellow texture; milky mouthfeel.  Overall:  Damn delicious! Excellent, actually; this beer has aged wonderfully and is quite a treat right now! 
11.6 fluid ounce bottle.  Rating #1042 for this beer.
Bottle split with Andrew, Dallas, and Tony. Pour is golden amber. Aroma is sweet Belgian candi sugar. Mouthfeel is very sweet with a dry finish.
2008 bottle. Golden color and a small white head. Sweet aroma of dried fruits and honey. A little vinous. Lacking bitterness and has an almost cloying sweetness.

Cloudy straw colored pour with a ultra large white foamy head, fair amount of floaties.  Nose is fruity, spicy, and and slightly funky.  Light bodied and refreshing mouth-feel.  Flavor is a bit tart and spicy followed by a sweet fruitiness.

Bottle at Bulls Head in Lititz.  Strong orange and alcohol aroma.  Golden amber body with thin head.   Flavor is sweet and of candied malts.  Hint of hops and citrus create a nice balance... alcohol content is evident and has a nice warming power

Bottle:
Small almost white foamy head.
Smell a lot of spices and some alcohol.
Color is amber orange.
Very full tasting body lots of spices pretty much alcohol. Some hops and malts, taste sugars (rock candy), dark fruit, bit grassy aftertaste.
Reminds me of a Christmas beer, how typical.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Pour is golden orange amber.  Belgian candi sugar.  Sweet but a bit dry from all the booze.
Had with the guys. Pour is is a clear orange. Aroma is some alcohol, sweet candy. Flavor is so sweet and aggressive. Some cherry and strawberry.
Bottle from 2008. Hazy golden/amber with off-white head. Flavour is malt, fruit, sweet, notes of alcohol and caramel.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2011 33 cl bottle (2011), Pours hazy golden with a nice head that has good retention, taste is sweet and complex with notes of yeast, caramel and brown sugar long with a note of lactic acid. Varming alcohol that is fairly subtle nontheless. A bit sticky mouthfeel, but a very good christmas beer overall.
Very nice dark peach pour. Very strong raisins in nose. Taste is also strong raisins, brown sugars and heavy breads. Rated 3/4/03

Thanks to the generosity of a fellow beer geek, Jason, I am relishing each moment of a vintage 2004 De Dolle Still Nacht. A pinnacle Christmas beer, make sure to grab a few bottles so that you too can age your own.


As the sun descends slowly unto my glass, golden oranges shimmer with a tinge of haze beneath a miniscule head. Finally sporting a thin collar, I swirl her gorgeous depths to reveal not an iota of lace, but in return I am blessed with a bouquet of aromas so fresh, so rich, so moist that goosebumps race up my arms to stand at a point on the back of my neck. Spiced peaches, apricots, and mandarin oranges (no cans please) are long steeped in booze, spiced, moist, and chilled to suckling perfection. Her nose is light yet rich. Boozy yet gentle. Spiced yet subtle. Fruity yet dry. Orangecello steeps in the background while tutti-frutti whispers gently in my ear. Standing amidst a field damp with rain, her grains weighing heavily, their earthly effort taints the air which I relish with free abandon. Nature truly is beautiful. Add some freshly sliced pineapple, prickly skin included, and I am transported to nirvana where the beer flows freely and the skies are only as sunny as they choose to be that day. My first quaff is thick and rich, a pleasant reversal of fortunes when compared to her nose. Immediately coating my mouth with fruity booze and a dry finish, my thirst is nowhere near the least bit sated. Nay, in fact it is invigorated and eager to be set free. Permeating her palate are peaches, oranges, pineapple, and nectarines long steeped in a boozy mixture of brown sugar and cinnamon. Applesauce and orangecello mingle in the background while a long sweet honeycomb finish completes my first impressions. Almost immediately my being is enveloped in a warm embrace brought on by her selfless generosity. Further along my supping adventure, dry grass and brittle hay brushes her palate dry, creating an amazingly balanced touché of wet and dry, sweet and spiced, fruity and bitter, soothing and stimulating, all following a luscious path over, under, and through every fiber of my grateful being. Dont rush. Sip. Savor. Reminisce.


What her palate lacked in exuberant complexity, she more than made up for in amazing balance and harmony of opposites. Christmas only comes once a year, but if you save enough bottles of Still Nacht from De Dolle Brouwerij, you may enjoy many more Christmas when you so choose, realizing at the same time that the old adage of all good things come to those who wait has never been so true when supping an old Still Nacht.

Bottle bought from De Struise beer shop. Opened at home. Exploded. This is my 200th rate and a special beer to celebrate. I will have to reserve the 3 Fonteinen Vintage 2005 for my 300th. This has been a good journey so far. This is the 2007 edition.

Poured far too aggressively due to explosion. Really annoyed with that. Due  to the aggressive pour sediment appeared. Head is PERFECT. Damn awesome. Poured into ESB glass. 

Sediment is bobbling around in anarchy. A real shame. Aroma of marzepan; citrus and dried fruits. Awesome. Caramel; butterscotch, dried fruits and stringy doughy yeast. Excellent world class lacing. Awesome carbanation and drinkability is through the roof. This is such a good beer. I want to rate it higher but due to the sediment I am not. I love this De Dolle. Damn cant wait to have it on tap. This beer is bloody gargantuan on the senses. Special thanks to MES for informing me of this beers epic quality. Cheers mate. I owe you......yes I know I have your King Henrys Special Reserve....

bottle pour to Oerbier glass gives cloudy orange color with thick very long lasting off-white head.  Outstanding lacing.  Aroma of sweet fruits and spices.  Taste acidy with citrus, light fruits, spices.  There is a heaviness that fools you into thinking a bitter finish is coming but then decides to disappear leaving a smooth finish.  The 12% alcohol is pretty apparent but not distracting.

Overall a very nice beer, a bit more acidic than Im used to in this style but it comes together well.

Fresh 33cl bottle. Like other De Dolle, this is dense, complex, and beguiling in its ambrosial aromas and glassy texture. Look is clear dark amber and ample variegated head (both dense and bubbly.) Irresistablly sour-prickly aromas of tart tropic fruit and lemon and bright hop. Taste dives right into deep sweet and tart fruit with a top of spice and lemon. Amazing full-body texture that could be heavy instead is lifted by peppery spiciness and light acidity. Long fine hops in finish and replays of tart and sweet fruit like hall of mirrors. Magnificent work of art. Very complete, and the slight sweetness may balance with aging so I will try that with bottle B.

Caramel apple color with a fine white head and strong opacity. Nose is sour apple and caramel, hints of barnyard yeast, spiced bread and candy-corn. Flavor starts with nutmeg, ripened bananas, late bitterness and warming alcohol, light honey and buttery-scotch. Smooth, sticky mouthfeel and deceptively powerful. A classic.

33cl bottle. Pours a hazy amber body. Head i large, fizzy, off-white, mostly lasting. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of honey. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet and bitter. Medium to full body with lively carbonation. Alcohol is well hidden. Good xmas ale!

33 cl bottle pours a cloudy orange amber with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of sweet carmel, apple, spices and pepper. Palate was medium bodied and slightly syrupy. Flavors of sweet carmel, apple, honey and spices with a warming lingering sweet finish.

Bottle 2006 Given by plovmand, huge thanks. 
Pours amber with floaties and a off white head. 
Nice sweet malt and caramel aroma with notes of orange peel, prunes and alcohol. 
Flavour is sweet malt-caramel like, balanced nicely with bitter notes and a spicy and vinous hint. 
Great brew.

2005 bottle from MrPickles - Golden amber with a small off-white head. Smells fantastic, with apple juice, bread dough, white grape, honey, and just a touch of alcohol. Sweet, sweet malt, but not cloying. Lots of honey, slight bitter hops, and a subtle sweet boozy notes. Smooth and no sharpness from the 12%--very nice. Syrupy, sticky, and medium-bodied, this is one of the best Ive had from De Dolle--and Ive liked almost everything from them that Ive tried.

Pours a hazy greyish yellow color with a medium to large sized head that consists of tight off white bubbles. Notes of candi sugar, apple juice, yeast, baked bread, earthy hops, cocoa powder, and honey. Alcohol is hidden well, mouthfeel is lively, and this beer goes great with food.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on April 13 2010; eye: copper with a golden hue, hazy, no effervescence, voluminous beige head that falls and turns into a sheet, slight lacing; nose: alcohol, yeast, fruity, malt, lightly concentrated maple water; mouth: malt, light fruity, alcohol, pepper, alcohol warmth, lightly concentrated maple water, Cointreau, finale in alcohol with a light fruity presence, medium body, not much carbonation, alcoholic texture, lightly sweet; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 13 avril 2010; il : cuivrée avec une teinte dorée, voilée, pas deffervescence, mousse beige abondante qui tombe et se transforme en une couverture, très légère dentelle; nez : alcool, levure, fruité, malt, eau dérable légèrement concentré; bouche : malt, léger fruité, alcool, poivre, chaleur dalcool, eau dérable légèrement concentré, Cointeau, finale en alcool avec une légère présence fruitée, corps moyen, peu carbonatée, texture alcoolique, légèrement sucrée; en résumé : bien

Shared this one w/ SkyCop32. Pours a nice dark orangish amber color. Aromas of fruit, and some other hints, maybe some spices, maybe caramel. Flavor is a bittersweet, malty, and a hint of hops with a nice bittersweet finish.

While De Dolle is one of my favorites, the Stille Nacht is just too sweet for me. I think I would prefer it with a year or two of aging. Aside from the sweetness, the flavor (and all else) is perfectly amazing... but as advertised this is a "dense" and extremely sweet beer so grab a partner or two and split a bottle.

Had from bottle at Pizza Port Belgian Beer Festival.  Beer #8 of 1001 in my on-going review series.Pours a hazy yellow/amber with a small, off-white head which lasts a while.  Aromas of fruits, alcohol, and strong sugar/caramel.  Taste is of more sugar, a bit of fizzyness, and malts.  The beer starts and ends sweet, more of a sipping, after-dinner beer, but definitely something that will warm the soul in a long winter.  Finishes with the slightest hint of bitterness and alcohol.
Poured from the bottle. Golden orange color. Sweet aromas. Full bodied and rich in your mouth. Honey, citrus, and sugar. Alcohol presence right up there. Good long finish. Great sipping beer.

Világos és ködös  borostyán sárga színe van amit bőségesen belep a kitöltésnél keletkező vastag,nagy buborékos fehér hab,ami közepes idő alatt enyészik el.Illata alkoholos,édeskés,vaníliás és nagyon hasonlít egy olyan nyíló virágra,aminek a képe előttem van de a nevét sajnos nem tudom.Ízében is erősen ott a vanília,alkoholba áztatott aszalt füge,gyümölcs tea,fahéj,ananász és keserű mandula.Olajosan folyik,jó sűrű és apró kis buborékokkal van tele,az alkohol rendesen zsibbaszt és melegít.Utóíze aszalt gyümölcsös,keserédes és bódító.Apró kortyokban kell fogyasztani és biztosítja a csendes éjt.

Appearance: Pours out a clearish, dark amber body with a somewhat small-sized, off-white head.

Smell: Sweet-scented, boldly fruity nose with a notes of sugary dessert toppings, earthy spices, and fruit-flavored cordials.

Taste: Starts with a dense, sugary sweetness with hints of well-caramelized sugars and heady honey. Slightly toasty. A melange of fruit flavors passes by: apricot, grape skins, raisins. Scant bitterness is briefly felt, as are some spicy accents akin to cinnamon and nutmegs. Fairly yeasty throughout. A couple drops of orange liqueur. Finishes dry and a bit hot.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body, notably smooth. Medium-light carbonation.

Drinkability: Pretty solid. With the intensity of a strong, sweet brew, its definitely a slow-sipper for me and the small, singular bottle is more than plenty.

Pours hazy yellow/light brown with a huge head that quickly fades into some nice lacing up and down the glass. Aroma is a lot like a tripel - citrus, hops, watermelon, oranges, honey. The taste is a lot different than I would have gathered from the smell, its an initial hit of alcohol followed by a bitter sweet orange and honey aftertaste. Very drinkable for being 12% alcohol, even though you can taste it at first the aftertaste is all fruit and hops.
caramel, bread, amber, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, lively, long finish,
Tan colour. Thin head. Sweet marmalade aroma, quite perfumey too. Thick, sticky taste. Bittersweet orangey flavours. Quite oily texture. Very warming and has a dry finish.

0,33 l bottle, vintage 2009, bought at PreZBF, Belgium.
Poured hazy golden with a realy nice, creamy, after a while lacing delicious white head. Aroma is a concentrated caramel and liqueric one with a lot of spicies like vanilla and clove, some citrusses and raisins, honey.. The beer has an oily texture, a spicey character because the feeling of clove, cinnamon and vanilla. Fruity, malt and caramel based flavor with apricot, figs and honey. Harsh, flowery bitter in the aftertaste. Because of the high abv the sweet liqueric taste leads but not rules the taste. Balanced brew.

Bottle. Thanks to fata2683 for the trade! Pours hazy orange-amber, thick persistent white head, nice lacing. Nose is lovely and bready, stale hops, acidity, sweet cake, berries, dates, very complex and rich. Palate is full, yeasty, and mouthfilling, with more bread, tartness, fruit, and great bitterness throughout. If this is a Christmas Beer, this is my new favorite for the style.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange/golden beer with a big white head. The aroma is fruit, yeast, spices and some acidity. The flavor is sweet and fruit. The palate is with alcoholwarmth. Overall a good and complex beer.
Muddy brownish colour with creamy head who stays.Aroma of yeast and apricot nice fruity whit note of caramel and herbs,good full body and flavor of sugar and vanilla.

Bottle thanks to cavie. Pours a cloudy amber with sediment, has a lasting white head. Aroma has some barnyard, fruit, grain, light citrus and musty. Flavor is sweet, fruity, some barnyard, spicy, citrus, a little musty and some horse blanket. Mouth feel is heavy body with lively carbonation that kinda lightens the heavy body. Overall, very tasty brew, it is warming as well. I very much enjoyed!

2008 bottle thanks to cavie.  poured hazy yellow with sediment and white head.  aroma was cinnamon, clove, banana, and lemon zest.  flavor was lemon, cinnamon, and other spices with alcohol and a rather heavy body.

Bottle courtesy of drowland and RCL. Bright orange color with loads of sediment. Nice white head. Smell has big fruity notes. Citrus and spicy grapes. Bit of alcohol bite. Taste is slightly dry with a lovely white grape and spice. Alcohol tingle lends to a dry finish. Like a light bernardus 12. Very good.
Maybe I was not in the right place, I remembered a beer with more aroma. beautiful appearance and head. intense taste, as one would expect from a 12°. However I expected more aroma.

2008 bottle.  Like all De dolle beers I have poured; its a gusher.  Pour is hazy orange with a large beige head and lots of floaties.  Aroma is rich spicy malt, orange, marshmallow, and a light metallic character.  The sweetness really comes through as it warms.  Flavor is quite spicy with a large sweet malt character.  Notes of orange and dark fruits come through with a touch of banana as well. Cannot taste much alcohol, but this beer is huge and certainly hits quite hard even after only a few sips.  11oz. is more than enough for one sitting; glad its cold out tonight.

Bottled Oct 2009.  Pours golden amber with a creamy white head.  Aromas of Belgian yeast and alcohol and spice.  Flavors follow aromas with sweet fruits.  Full mouthfeel.  Could have used more bottle aging, but I got impatient.  Excellent beer.

2009 bottle.  Hazy orange-gold pour with a finger off-white head.  Yeasty aroma with hints of apricot and lemon.  Flavors are a sweet mixture of honey, lemon, ginger and toffee that is knocked down a bit with a tart bitterness in the finish.  Lively spike of carbonation.  12% abv is very well hidden.  Definitely a sipper - and Im going to sit on one for a few years to see how it changes.  Overall very complex and interesting.

Pours a slightly murky brownish-yellow with a one finger white head, which stays around until the glass was empty. The aroma is Belgian yeast with bready malts and some unidentifiable fruit. The flavor is alcohol and strawberries. You also get some yeast, caramel malt and some sugary sweetness. The alcohol is very warming. I also got some slight banana notes as the beer warmed but they were faint. The beer gets fruitier as it warms. Medium carbonation and mouthfeel.
From bottle.  Deep copper pour with a large off-white head. Candied apples,  caramel and banana, apple, plums, vanilla, dark fruits, and mild citrusy hops flavors.   Good carbonation.

Tap @ OTH.
Pours orange, white head
Aroma, Belgian yeast giving a barnyard/basement nose, candi sugar, fruits and spices.
Flavor, candi sugar, yeast, some sweet tropical flavors; mango and sweet peach.
There is also a nice sweet floral/medicinal herb palate that becomes more present due to the high abv of this beer, offering a nice thick sugary coating on the palate.
Finish kicks up the whole warming mouthfeel, mild caramel malts and lingering notes of the yeast.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2015 The aroma is lovely, dark and deep with the promise of honey, spices and caramel malt. Spiced mead comes to mind. The spice aromas are entirely without the cliched gingerbread houses of lesser winter beers and tend toward good, fruity peppercorns. The malt packs more fruit than a farmers market, as the beer chimes in with apricots, plums, grapes and bright, sweet lemons.  The malt flavor is fairly sweet, more rich than sugary, with big, dry Belgian yeast notes keeping things in check. Theres a marvelous alcohol presence that would be best enjoyed seated by a smoldering hearth late at night.

( 330ml bottle 2003 vintage thanks to BA bosse) Pours opaque orange with yeast floaters and a ring of head. Nose of pears, apples, figs, raisins, and caramel. Taste is very sweet golden raisins, caramel apples, with no hint of alcohol at all. Finish is nicely carbonated and almost syrupy sweet. This stuff was awesome.

White grape, honey, sweet Belgian candy sugar, Belgian yeast, and light fruits in the nose. Taste similar with an emphasis on grape and especially the white Belgian sugar. Poured murky dark orange with a huge foamy white head. The foam came rushing up the bottle into the glass with huge lacing. A tremendous beer, one to be savored with friends. 12 oz bottle at Brouwers Cafe, Seattle, WA.

Ive tried Stille Nacht in various vintages and with different yeasts used, but I am rating the Stille Nacht from 2006 I believe made with wine yeast. It pours a bit lighter than I expected (sort of bright light orange with tons of yeast chunkies). Powerful candi sugar and spiced rum nose. Taste is rich with candi sugar, spices, yeast. A little spiciness from the 12%. Pretty good.

330 ml. bottle.  2008.  Pours a murky orange brown with sediment visible.  Giant white head with yellow tinge.  Rather subtle aroma, of honey, belgian spices, clove nutmeg.  Taste is literally an explosion in the mouth of good carbonation, spices, hops, with a malty molasses / honey finish.  12% is completely masked.  This is one of the best beers ive tasted in awhile.  A big thanks to Mansquito for this, one of two very unique and good beers given to me for my birthday.  Cheers.

Pours translucent  dark amber, huge white head that hangs around for a while. Smells sweet, some warm wintery spices. Taste is extremely sweet candy,  and the same winter/mulling type spices found in aroma. I was surprised how high the abv was when I went on here and saw it was 12%.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2012 Details: 33cl bottle, batch 2011, fairly fresh. 
Tasting notes: Im quite surprised that this one was very quiet and didnt gush out of the bottle even after a little rough displacement. Clear, hazy amber color with a decent head that retains itself through the tasting. The aroma is slightly  sour but mainly sweet and sugary with a nice fresh smell of fruit, some orange. Flavor is mostly sweet but has a decent bitter finish in the end, quite fresh, fruity, big malt note that is especially noticable in the dry finish. Very easy drinkable, a bit too easy for its ABV. Decent carbonisation. I am very eager to see what the effect of more aging will be.
Conclusion: A flavourful and very promising beer which has a too good drinkability.

11.2oz bottle (bottled Oct. 2009) into a trappist glass.  Cloudy/chunky orange pour with a creamy white head that lasts in more than a ringlet.  The aroma is quite boozy with some white grape lingering back there somewhere.  The flavor is nicer, though, with a strong malt profile along with more white grape, some Belgian yeast, and noticeable alcohol.  The mouthfeel is creamy yet chalky with a bit of a burn.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours a deep gold with a generous white head.  Has a lot wintry earthy notes in the nose like dead leaves on a cold day.  Lots of yeast/dough/bread as well.  Really great balance between the sweet and the bitter in the flavor.  Very smooth and easy to drink considering the high alcohol.  A great winter beer.  Would love to try it after its been aged for a few years.

2007 vintage sampled at the DC Local Tasting.  12oz gusher bottle that pours a hazy, translucent orange, amber with a ringing white head.  Aroma is booze, some tropical fruits, candy sugar, Belgian yeast.  Flavor is sweet, candy, fruits, spices.  Dry finish, a little hot.

Thanks to fata for the gem.  This is a beautiful beer.  Taste is sweet with alot of dried fruit.  Floaties are everywhere in this beer.  Looks like pepper flakes ontop of head.  This had a bubble gum taste too.  Alcohol is there, Had a great dry finish to it.  Great beer

late 2008 .. . pours a bruised week old banana brown .. has a high spritz .. different fun flavours; honey, central region belgian cellar, golden syrup, and wet malty leaves .. . beautiful full head, medium lacing .. . upbeat aromas .. great abv masking .. . i can see this guy going places.. . 

He insulted me, called me names? 
-- Like what?
Fruity ass.
-- A what?
A fruity ass.
-- What the hell is a fruity ass?

A amber beer with a tall white head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Taste is also sweet, with some yeast spiciness. Vinous and alcoholic. Notes of honey and fruity syrup. Full body and strong. Lots of sediments floating.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010 Bottled Oct. 2, 2009. Poured a  murky dark orange (almost opaque) with a creamy head. The aroma and taste is malts and dark fruits with a warm alcohol background. Great depth, complex but very balanced, sweet, mild carbonation.  Excellent beer.

Pours with lots of yeast and lots of foam, and an orange color with a huge ivory head.  It was like the foam never wanted to stop.  Aroma is very fruity, oranges and yeast with spices.  Flavors is again very fruity, dry fruits, oranges, peach, apples, a good note of gingerbread with yeast.
High carbonation, very creamy, sweet and bitter.   Very complex and well ballanced, with a little liquor finish.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a huge white foamy head.  The aroma is strong with hops, yeast, and sugar.  Flavor is quite sweet, fruity, and hoppy and has a decent bitter bite in the finish.  Has a moderately dry finish and a nice palate.  Almost reminds me a bit of Orval but fruitier and sweeter.

11 and 3/5 ounce bottle. Pours a chunky orange with a ridiculously massive ivory head. Aroma is just awesome; HUGE sweet fruit and floral aromas on top of a slightly funky sourness lurking beneath. Flavor is again very fruity; oranges, apricots, peach, then comes earthy yeast and spoiled cream reminicent of a good trappist abt. Alcohol is present but not bullish. Medium density, creamy mouthfeel. A hearty, soulful, delicious opus. Overall, excellent to world class.

2008-version, 33 cl, bottle. Blonde beer with a big white lasting head. Malty aroma, some fruits and spices included. Taste is malty, alcohol, light bitter aftertaste. It start very strong in the taste but becomes much more balanced when drinking the beer. The best winter beer I drunk so far ever.

Orange with a dense head and a lot of carbonation.Sweet and dusty aroma, with some citric notes, yeast and alcohol present too. Unexpected bitterness coming from a Belgian Strong ale, very dusty and dry, but also sweet and fruity - quite complex. The palate is just amazing: creamy!

Dark honey-coloured but troubled liquid with non-sticky small white foam. Fruity sweets and other sugars. Some acidity that in this case is ideal and needed as a taste enhancer. Too high on alcohol for the palate present. Impression that it is a bit too young to drink now. Bitter palate not very impressive. A bit overrated to my opinion. Will stocking improve it? I have no confidence in that. Okay for Christmas 2009, better for 2010, is what I have to say.

Hazy orange with lots of suspended sediment. Thin head with a very strong fruity aroma. Flavours are sour apple, orange, bread, yeasy. I cant believe its 12%. I like how dry it is, it might be the dryest beer I have ever had. REally great.
Little on the sweet side for me.  Though the bitters attempt to balance it out.  Is light and carbonated on the palate.  If you enjoy the sweeter belgiums, you will really enjoy this beer.

Split with Cole and savvy1982. Thanks for the share Kyle! Pours a pale yellow with lots of suspended yeast floating around. The aroma is sweet with hints of the dryness about to come with the first sip. The flavor is very dry, almost to the point where every sip deserves a sip of water... In a good way. Bananas, bready yeast, citrus rind, flint, candi sugar, fluoride (almost like toothpaste), and some hop bitterness in the finish. Decent mouth feel. Hides the 12% very well. Decent beer.

It looks great. Rosy and cute. A bit cheesy on the nose. Not much to it there. In the mouth it is full of fruit and sweet candy. Light boozy burn and cherry tickles. Amazingly light and delicious. Hells yeah.

2003 bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  aromas of pear, apples, alcohol, yeast and other dried fruits.  incredibly smooth and a great flavor of dried fruits, caramel and raisins.  incredibly smooth and no sign of alcohol whatsoever.

On Tap at De Dolle Brouwers, Very nice dirty copper colour with big off white head, Aroma is rich with hints of malts, barley, honey, fruits, appel; cereals and hops. Taste is soft, rich, fruity, sweet-malty with a round barley touch and ends with a nice bitterness of hops, alcohol is well hidden. A fantastic beer !

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of cereal and nutty, light perfume for the hops, moderate dough for the yeast with background notes of wine, toffee, brown sugar and dried fig. Head is between frothy and fizzy, off-white with some sediment speckling. It has a little slippery lacing and is fully lasting. Color is murky amber-orange-tan, with a thick amount of large particles. Flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, then finishes moderately sweet, acidic and bitter and just a touch sour. Palate is medium, oily with a fizzy carbonation and a heavily alcoholic finish. There is a lot of beer in this small bottle, all with great balance.

Bottle from the Bitter End Off Licence, Bromley. This one gushed out a hazy amber/orange colour with lots of wholesome sediment floating about. Beige head. Aromas of toffee, caramel. citrus, stewed apples. Flavours of barley sugar, caramel, apples, candied peel, slightly malty. Nice, warming mouthfeel. This is the sort of beer that epitomises the drink it slowly on a cold winter evening by a roaring fire contemplating the ways of the world and philosophising about how to change it. Unfortunately were having a mild winter over here in the UK and the only roaring fire im going to get here is if I set the house alight! Excellent winter ale. Finishes sweet and malty.

Faint aroma of apples. Amber color with a thick yellow head, huge chunks, and lots of carbonation, nice lacing. Half of the bottle foamed out upon pulling the cap. Apple brandy flavored with an apple core finish. Belly burning alcohol is excessive. Highly overrated beer, IMVHO.

Its really a mather of age with this beer. I prefer it a couple of years old when the body is still lively with fine-bubbled carbonation and a refreshing bright yeasty nose. Flavour is also refreshing with light cararmell notes and yeasty fruit and ends on a very balanced note. No sign of the ABV which is pretty damn impressing.

Another De Dolle gusher...Brownish amber pour with a vivacious white head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is loaded with sweet dark fruit, candi sugar, grapes, alcohol, and a moderate spiciness. Flavor is very sweet and very boozy. Raisin and grape prevail with brown sugar, light citrus, and a blatant warming alcohol quality. A mild acidity subsides into the waves of sweetness, though the brew never borderlines on cloying. Palate is thick, rich, and effervescent with a subtly acidic finish.

Pours a clear amber with lots of suspended yeast; foam gushed out of the bottle upon cracking the cap. Aroma heavy with yeast, plum, raisin, grapes, prune, caramel, brown sugar, and sweet malt. Flavor is delicious; lots of booze, candied sugars, dark fruit, along with some bitter hop character at the finish. Palate is very thick, but not cumbersome, and the shift to the dry finish is really nice. Another excellent brew from De Dolle.

Sweet with recognizable De Dolle yeast.  Opaque gold color.  Sugar, some coriander.  Lots of yeast.  Very thick, and great for sipping slowly.  Im not crazy about all of De Dolle beers, but this is a great beer.  Dry, light hop finish, but the hops are not really there until the aftertaste.
Bottle.Pours golden amber with an off-white head.Aroma of spice , grain and piny hops.Flavor is spicy with a good fruitiness ,some alcohol and yeast .Full bodied.Nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2011 2008 Bottle. 
Dark, deep golden color, tending to amber. Tall, very fine, stiff, ballooning head. One of the most impressive heads Ive seen.  Very fruity aroma: some citrus, dark, sour apples, dried prunes. Alcohol burn evident. Hops as well. Rather prominent yeast character, tending to dryness. Huge flavor. Very alcoholic, very fruity, hoppy. Interesting fruit character but it is almost completely overwhelmed by the alcohol. This needs a few years. Pears, peaches, apples, grapefruit. Slightly tangy, with strong hop bitterness, but it is really hard to separate that from the alcohol. This is way, way too boozy! Unpleasantly fiery! Definitely huge potential here, I would say, but it needs at least 2 years for the booze to mellow out.
Moderate fruit malt aroma. Cloudy light orange color with large floaters and a large off white head. Mild sour flavor. Gets slightly sweet in the  middle. Taste stays with you but not over powering.

Bottle. 12 oz. (2008) Pours an insane hazy orange, with the most epic, thick beige head Ive ever seen. The head was almost solid, with bits of spice througout. Aroma of barley, roasted malt, clove, cinnamon, and hints of walnut. Full bodied, with beautiful sedimentation, well balanced carbonation, and a heavy, powerful finish. Outstanding Beglian Strong.

Bottle split by the most gracious host in LA, Shyam.  This was an 07 bottle that had been well-stored and even after Firestone 12 this thing hit home.  Nose opens with simmering red apples thick with candi sugar and spice, pie crust and that delicate, sweet-cheese Dolle yeast character that sends every beer of theirs through the roof.  The hops were pretty gone on this bottle, but that just allowed the fruity confection of the malt and yeast profile to do dey bidness.  Color was a warm amber orange.  Flavor much like the nose with added notes of... roasted candi?  Toffee?  Mulled pear?  Sweet rum tea?  Some shit was happening in the glass that you could describe 10 different ways.  I loved all ten.  This sweet pea is now a regular in my garden.

Color is dependent upon how much of the yeast you allow. If you pour 90% of the bottle then it looks almost as clear as a pils. From thereafter it goes from belgian wit to german weiss to dark yellow cider. You choose. 

Head was minimal on my beer. Just a thin white line. Nose is somewhat faint but sweet. 

Palate is an explosion of candied flavors with peaches n pears. Very tangy, somewhat tart. I like it. 

Finish is tart and mouth puckering. Quite appetizing for the next sip and hence very drinkable to me.
Cloudy brown, creamy beige head.  Aroma is dry, sweet candy sugar, molasses, pears.  Flavor is lightly bitter, sweet candy sugar body, caramel, alcohol, and brown sugar.  Hot alcohol on the palate.
Bottle. Dark golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is spices, grain, licorice. Flavour is spices, grain, licorice, alcohol, fruit. Full bodied world class beer.

Bottle, 1985 covered in dust and cobwebs at the Erasmus, Bruges. Result! One of those beers that I remember where I was when I had first had it, at Mikes in Salford with my brother. I love the Erasmus. I love this beer. Its stunning. Rich and thick but just right. Like the third bowl of porridge Goldilocks tried. The aroma is awesome. Chocolate and sweetness, spicy, fruity, yeasty, tasty. Flavour is awesome. More toffee like chocolate fantasticness. More yeasty flavour. Alcohol is well hidden. Loved it.

This is really good.  dont know the year.  Very active beer when I opened it, good thing I had my glass ready.  Nice head.  Sweet prune with bready nose.  Rich blackberry flavor,  the alcohol doesnt stand out for 12%.  Very full mouthfeel.  Good balance for the over the top sweetness and enough bitterness.  Love the finish.  As usual, the price is always high for these great Belgian beers, but worth it as a special occasion.  I have had a lot of great strong ales,and not rated them yet.  This is one of best.

Not sure of the year on this bottle.  Interesting aroma of malt, sweetness, a tiny amount of oxidation.  The flavor is pretty amazing.  The malt & slight sourness hides the 12% quite well.  What a combination of flavors.  Its liquid candy.  Great beer.

Bottle at Lions Pride, 
Light, hazy brown pour with a sticky, offwhite head.  Lacing is lovely.  Aroma is Sweet caramel malt with some definitive yeasty character and some burnt notes.  Flavor explodes as dark candy sugars and some dark toasted malt notes.  Sweet sugar fruits such as dates and figs and Alcohol is a presence as well, warming at the center and at the finish.  Excellent.  Delicious

Rating #300. 2006 bottle. Pours a hazy chestnut brown with minimal fluffy white head. Aroma is dark candi sugars, burnt molasses, and belgian yeast complexity. Taste has a very tannic quality, quite drying on the palate with lots of vinuous undertones.
