Definite dried/aged fruit character - plums, prunes etc., as well as a spiciness not of the yeast - I assume added spices that remind me of chestnuts, nutmeg, and the holidays. Finishes surprisingly dry for such a high gravity beer. The aftertaste is not altogether pleasant, but this beer is an experience and well worth seeking out.

Bottle from 1989 at BCTC.  Pours a murky brown.  Lightly oxidized caramel on the nose.  Flavors have faint echoes of the oxidization, but lean more towards light tangy fruit, apples and candy.  Tingly on the tongue and tasty.  Has held up remarkably well.

2007 bottle. Sweet aroma, resembling the darker strong ales like Pannepot and Abbaye des Rocs Brune, a sweet ground nose. Appearance is amber with a smaller frothy head. Flavor is absolute perfect in my opinion, every taste but is carefelly taken care of in a fashionable order. Drinks away very very easy although its a pretty heavy beer. Near perfection.

05 **** bottle?  Think so.  Anyway, pours a nice slightly amber gold with thick white head, decent lacing, left most of the yeast in bottom of bottle to try later.  Flavor is of yeast, slight hops, sweet malt, banana, sugar, and some fruity esters.  Flavor matches well, but is a bit too sweet for my liking.  Alcohol was pretty well hidden, but obviously still there.  Pretty decent, but would have to try this more fresh to see if I prefer it aged or not.

Pours hazy orange with a massive white head, chunky lacing. Fruity nose, apples and light plums. Much yeast. Quite a bit of alcohol. Very warming on the tongue, spicy and fruity with banana, cloves, plums, caramel malts. A bit too boozy, but still very good.

Bottle. This bottle was about 3 years old. A deep amber coloured pour with a magnificent head. Apple, port like aroma. Sweet, dark fruits, plums, prunes, caramel taste. This beer is a world classic and tastes considerably better after many years of ageing.

33cl bottle. 2008 vintage at Hop Duvel, Gent. Pours hazy peach with a huge white head. Leaves amazing lacing. Aroma is hoppy. Some peach and herbs. Quite complex. Taste is very warming. You can feel the alcohol and the spices bitting your tongue. Head retention is really good. Taste is like aroma. Some hints of anice, cloves, banana. Finish is warm and bitter. Very complez brew but you really need to be in the mood for it. Very unique.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2016 Bottle. Ruby golden pour. Very sweet smelling aroma has dark fruit notes. Would like to see how this beer ages. Dark malt and fruit flavors with sugar and alcohol warming finish.

2008 bottle at De Dolle Brouwers, poured by Kris himself.  Deep reddish-copper color with a large off-white head.  Aroma is caramel malt, spices, and candied apples.  Flavor is all this plus vanilla, citrus, dark fruits, and mild hop bitterness.  Very complex and very good.  Palate fairly full with somewhat high carbonation.

Pours deep brown with a white/cream head that is very large. Smell is fruity with hints of orage spice and other citrus fruits. Taste is well developed with notes of caramel, spice some vannilla among others. The let down is the pallet, while it tastes good the flavor fads quickly. Overall a good belgian strong.

2008 Bottle - Thanks beerbill! - This gusher shot out the top, so Im rating half a most likely messed up bottle...pours a hazy lt copper with a fucken massive off white head...aroma is a bit cheesy at first, but mellows to display very sticky apples, vanilla and citrus...flavour is similarly syrupy, thick in the mouth and highly carbonated, boozy, tart apple in the back of the throat, spice, dough, vanilla caramel and hop flowers without any bitterness...I gotta go lie down...

cloudy orange, lots of floaties, thick frothy eggshell head.
mild aroma, lemon peel mostly, with some sweet light malt, licorice, and a bit of metal.
flavor is like everything else from de dolle, this odd metalic artificial licorice thing. not sure what the issue is, but i am not a fan. other than that theres some very bright lemon flavors and very little alcohol (12% is very well hidden), but this is not good.
medium body, too much carbonation.
as it warms it gets better, with a chewy sweetness that goes well with the citrus peel. it keeps the licorice metal finish though...
On tap at redlight.  Clear orange body.  smells really really sweet.  To be 12 percent, you would never know it in the taste.  Its so easy to drink.  Very sweet and dark fruity.  Really like it.

Original review date 3/15/2009...

11.6 oz. with a bottle date 2008. Visible floaties in the bottle. Out of the fridge and warming for about 15 minutes, then opened - not a gush with the cap off but its mildly happy to see me. I pour it off a bit into the Ommegang chalice, let it breathe and pour an additional amount.

Well, it has a classic eggshell-colored head...pouring carefully I get a full finger and then some. Its so thick its almost doughy and can see it jiggle like my beer gut when I type. There are a fair amount of floaties in the honey-copper body - as I was rather careful with this one its slightly aesthetically unpleasant. This is viscous. Looks like spent peanut oil in a deep fryer, its so thick.

The yeast is this is nice and electric with a slight...actually a moderate, sour tinge of citrus and mildly peppery spice. The grain profile is bright - not stewy or husky at all. No sense of burn - a little bit of saltiness, carbonation and mild coriander. LOTS of zest - both orange and lemon.

Theres a little bit of metallic barnyard taste here - maybe not hay and horseblanket but maybe a rusty nail that the horse brushed up against - hopefully he or she didnt get hurt. That light grain huskiness shows up here though and adds to the orange zest quotient and the huge yeastiness. Maybe not the most pristine Belgian Ive come across but its fairly complex. So thick the residual sweetness is from a light dose of maybe candi sugar and a bit of booziness. Carbonation lightens it up a little to keep it clean. Gets more velvety with warmth.

All this needs is a few minutes and it mellows out a bit to be fairly clean, quite husky and even a little on the heavy side. It blankets the palate and the back of the throat to be rather soothing - the booze burns but its wrapped in thick viscous liquid and slight residual sugar to keep it tolerable.

Hey, it ends up being a little on the heavy side but the complexity acquits itself nicely. Maybe something I wont reach for every day but a well-done effort nonetheless. Good change-up.

Aroma had some spiced cherry, biscuit and toffee. Yeasty flecks and well carbonated head for the appearance. Flavor contained molasses, chocolate, toffee and some spiced cherry. Palate was lively and fizzy. A little sweet, but delicious!

Aroma: sweet sugar, some nuttuness and spiritous. Appearance: orange/brown hazy with no head. Flavour: insanely sweet, apricot and spiritous. Recognisable hop bitterness. Palate: thick and lightly carbonated. Lasting fruit and bitterness.
Pours a nice amber with a respectable but small off-white head.  Super sweet sour cherry aroma, tart and flora dark fruit flavor.  Im sure this improves with age.

Here we go again!
Long time no review.
bottel 08, trapist glass. Very Nice elegant amber-colored appearance.
Very citric and fresh nose with heavy ginger and coriander, dense alcohol and effervescent tablet intensity. Taste is intense hazy orange, honey, ginger, lemon, Seville orange, heavy bubbled, fruity, very intense belgian duvelish yeast , spices, hints of almond and vanilla. This is good and strong! 12% actually.. i would recommand to store it several years. Maybe not something you want several bottles of in one session but still , very interesting, cheers!
bottle.  pours a hazy orange with a nice big bubbled white head.  A little fruity with some pleasant booze undertones.  notes of bread, belgian yeast, honey, and spices.  pretty good.
Latge head on an amber-colored beer. Some visible particles present. The taste has a medicinal sweetness with banana and yeast flavors.

Bottle from 06. This was an extremely interesting beer. This poured a cloudy bright yllow color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma was very sweet malts, candi sugar, vanilla and honey?, with also a residual tartness in the backround. Flavor was just as impressive. Sweet candi sugar, some vanilla and honey, jsut all around sweetness, but with a nice sour tinge in the afterthought. Wow, this is an experience.

bottle from grape & gourmet poured into a goblet. pours a light, copper gold with a few yeast floaties, a solid white head, great lacing, a long retention. aroma is very nice with notes of sweet belgian yeast, honey, clove, sweet citrus, berry, and a hint of booze. flavor was delicious as well with sweet, yeast and honey notes up front, winter spice, a tart bit of citrus, brown sugar, and a hint of banana bread. mouthfeel is crisp and sparkling with a solid warming presence on the swallow and a bittersweet, dry finish. overall, an excellent brew.

Wow, where to begin.  First of all, big ups to  Butters for providing this unique Belgian! Pour is a beautiful hazy gold with white head. Rich sweetness of honey and malts, slight alcohol. Similar taste with a nice spicyness to balance out the sweetness of this beer. Usually not a fan of sweet beer, but this really struck a chord with me!

Bottle from Swolf3, thanks Wolf. Gold pour with a nice white head. Light and fruity, a little dry as well, very nice aroma. A little spicy, more light fruitiness, and some alcohol warmth in the finish. Pretty good.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012  hazy brownisch gold blond coloured sparkling body with a sparkling white head a sweet fruity spicy aroma a sweet spicy alcholic fruity taste with a alcholic bitter finish too mutch alcholic in the taste
Pours gold in color with a thin white head. Aroma is honey, berry and alcohol. Very thick mouthfeel, very sweet with some bitter finish and alcohol tingling. Thanks to Butters for this.

2006 bottle.

Pours a hazy brownish gold with a huge 4 fingers of fluffy overactive off white head. Aroma is yeasts, candi sugar, malts, fruits, spices. Flavor is sweet candi sugar, dark fruits, yeasts, esthers, spices, the carbonation is very nice. Quite complex and very enjoyable.

[2005 Bottle] from Ygtbsm94, thanks Brad! Pours a hazy gold with a large beige head. Aroma is sweet candi sugar, malt, and fruity yeasty notes. Flavor is definitely showing its age - really mellowed out sweetness, especially off the front end. Super smooth and rich, the alcohol is almost imperceptible. I cant say that this has improved with age, but it definitely hasnt declined either. Interesting brew.
Pours a white head with a thick golden body.  Smells of honey.  Reminds me of mead.  Saffron and creamy.  note to self...drink this again.

Sampled at the Impromptu Butters 6th cellar clearance. Hazy golden orange with suspended particulate and small ring of white head.  Nose of honey and just the slightest hint of alcohol. Massively sweet honey flavor is verging on mead.  Great hidden abv has a nice warming effect but no burning.  Sweet but not cloying.  Very enjoyable candi sugar finish.  Expensive, but worth the price for a dessert wine substitute.

Bottled sample. 2005 vintage is light amber in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of cherry pits, apricot, booze, and sweet pale malts. Fairly herbal and earthy upfront in the mouth, before the semi-sweet pale malt and caramel malts flavors take over. Finishes fairly dry and mildly acidic, with a medium body. Not quite the blockbuster I was expecting, but still quite drinkable for a 12% beer.

330 ml bottle from a trade with the cheeseman. im unsure of the vintage but this bottle seemed a few year old. this one was a very slow gusher but it still left me plenty of time to catch it. it poured a very hazy light brown with an average off white head that never goes away. the aroma was of aged belgian strong ale. if youve had some older belgian ale you know the aroma of this. the yeast has ahd time to work and change the aroma and its very distinct. the pale malts were showing but there were no hops in the aroma. the flavour was absolutly huge. big and full in the mouth with the malt really shining up front. belgian yeast through the middle and a bitter end the was very american hops based. the only thing that i didnt enjoy about this was the amount of sugar. i really feel that if the clocked in at ~8%abv it would have been a perfect 5 for me. the sugar had left a ciderish note that wasnt unpleasnt but i think without it this beer would have been perfect. thanks for the bottle Dan!

Pours a golden amber with a fluffy white head. Aroma is of dried fruit, dust, spice, alcohol and some piney hops. Big body, syrupy mouthfeel. Taste is very sweet malt at the front with slight trailing unripened fruit tang in the finish. Warming alcohol is present. One of my favorites. Id think of pairing this with some stew and some good cheese at the hearth of an old fireplace on a cold winters night.

Aspecto: de un ámbar pálido con tonos anaranjados, turbio, casi opaco, con mucho sedimento. Contrasta con una gruesa cabeza de un intenso blanco. 
Aroma: potente presentación en nariz. El inicial olor dulzón deja paso a toda una amplia variedad de matices afrutados. Encuentro un ligero aroma a plátano y un fondo con algo de canela... Desconcierta la variedad de matices difíciles de describir. En la retirada se puede intuir levemente el alcohol. 
En boca: cuerpo firme con buena carbonatación que llena rápidamente toda la boca. Muy densa, intensa muy completa. 
Sabor: buena entrada en boca, algo fuerte, pero con un gusto dulce que lo tapa. Como nos decía previamente la nariz, la variedad de matices es increíble y difícil de describir. Hacia el final deja un regusto seco y algo picante que delata su elevado contenido alcohólico.

Valoración global: una gran cerveza de invierno, destaca su intenso cuerpo, su variedad de matices afrutados y su final seco, disimula muy bien su 12% vol. pero al final se deja notar. ¡No veas como pega! En general una gran cerveza para disfrutar en estas fiestas. (15/20)

2008 bottle. Orange pour with big white head with all kinds of floaties in there. Sweet, yeasty, candied fruit aroma. Flavor of rum soaked fruits, apricots, candi sugar, belgian yeast. A bit too sweet. Big, thick mouthfeel. Some dusty spice in the finish.

Pours a cloudy amber orange with a large foamy white head.  Aromas are candied fruits and yeast with some spices and hops aroma.  Taste Sweet and malty with some spicy and bitter hops flavor to balance.  I taste apples, citrus, caramel, sugar, and lots of yeast.  This beer is thick and syrupy but with plenty of carbonation.  I thought this was an excellent brew.

Bottle, thanks to WeeHeavySD for sharing! Pours a hazy amber, with a thick foamy white head. Rich boozy sweet aroma, with citrus, sugar, and malt. Taste is rich and sweet, of malt, citrus, dark fruits, and alcohol. Lingering richness. Very nice.

330ml Bottle (2006 Vintage) - Amber with a large foamy head. Slightly fruity aroma aroma, with some spicy malt and hoppy notes. Fruity and warming taste, with hops and a spicy malt element followed by a fruity and bittersweet finish.

Crushed with Jakebra.  2004 bottle.  Lots of sweet malts, citrus, yeasty sourness on the nose.  Very sweet flavor mellows almost immediately into a bitter lemon peel finish.  Very complex and excelent brew.  Wish I could try the 2000.
2008 bottle, strong gusher with a pulpy orange body and big foam, aroma is belgian yeasty and sugar, flavors of refined sugar, bitter orange and a bitter rind finish

The bottle looks very children-like, but not bad. The beer in the glass is okay. The beer starts very strong and complex, malty and alcoholic. Notes of christmas-spices. Finish bitter-dry. Very good, but a bit too alcoholic.

2007 bottle.  Let me start by saying that this beer was the most prolific gusher Ive ever seen.  Even after half the bottle had been poured, it was still gushing.  Not to mention it was one of the eeriest looking pours Ive ever seen.  Poured a cloudy orange with yeasties like crazy.  the yeast particles just hung in suspension, they didnt fall out at all.  weird looking.  Aroma is aolt of citrus and other fruits and plenty of medicinal belgian yeast characteristics.  Flavor is more of the same with some spiciness.   Easy to drink for the ABV.  Maybe it was all the other fantastic beer I had this day, but this one just wasnt doing it for me.

11.2 oz. bottle. Sour, yearty aroma features orange, candy sugar, and crabapple scents. Pours a hazy, cloudy, effervescent orange/amber with huge, uneven, cream-colored head. Beatiful appearance. Very sweet taste with a bitter bite at the end. Spicy flavor, especially pepper. Im not feeling it. Medium body. Forthy, lively, and silky in the palate. Some alcohol burn. Remarkably forgettable for such a big beer.
Bottle. Pours a nice amber color. Aroma is filled with yeast,spice,fruit and some caramel. Taste is spicey with some fruity and caramel notes. Fresh apple can be found. Nice warming finish.

not my style but a great work in brewing. aroma and taste of fruit in tea. sweet and delicious with candy properties as well as beer, coriander and banana. different than i would have expected but as good as has been reported. a bit spicy in the Belgian abbey tradition. moderate alcohol feel. really good.

2008 bottle.  Cloudy orange-brown with a half finger of dirty white head.  Aroma of citrus, dark fruits, caramel, and a musty zest.  Taste is caramel with fruits over top and a drying alcohol and spiciness in the finish.

330 mL bottle purchased from McScrooges in Knoxville.  Poured a clear, dark gold/amber color with a two finger off white head.  The aroma was caramel and dark fruits, with molasses and brown sugar notes.  The flavor was caramel and molasses, with a spicy finish.  Dark fruit was present as well.  There was quite a bit of warming on the palate as well.  This was a solid brew, and Im glad to have rated this #900.

A golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of dark caramel, with dark fruits and apricot with malts. The taste is stimulating and warm. Flavors of caramel, little sweet and some bitter, fruits like citrus and apricot and some spices. The aftertaste is sparkling with some bitter, which stays for a while.
Light amber in color and cloudy. Aroma is of spices, yeast, bread dough, and a little cider vinegar. Taste is yeasty and grainy with a strong alcohol presence.

Bottle @ De Kelk, Bruges. Pors with plentiful blond beige head. Beer itself is blond copper to orange. The aroma is strange, wine gum-like, malty and thera are ripe fruits in it. Maybe dates ond prunes? Maltiness is dominating but some spices and yeast are also present. Tha flavor is is really malty, liquour-like, sweetish and slightly sour in the finish. Fruitiness and malts act together and make this beer quite aromatic. High alcohol content is very well hidden. The palate is full bodied, very smooth and softly carbonated. Great winter warmer.

Bottle from Hamiltons.  Cloudy burnt orange pour with a small off white head.  Very sweet and fruity nose with apricot, peaches and some citrus.  Sweet malt and caramel as well.  Flavor held some yeast, light spice, light hops and is also quite sweet.  Finish is long and quite sticky.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, citrus, flowers, dust, hops, slight fruit, 
Poured amber/orange/slight copper in color with a large fluffy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.   Full of small particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of fruit, tobacco, yeast, hops, light pepper, spices, slight caramel, light cloves, and candi sugar.  Medium body.  Tingly, dry, slightly sticky texture.  Lively carbonation.  Sweet, yeast, finish is a bit dry.  12%ABV totally hidden.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 100th Belgian Strong Ale rating.---White cap with 2006 and 12% stamped on it. I see a good quarter inch of dark clumpy floaties all congregating at the bottom of the bottle. Wow. Pours copper with gold edges and thin off white head. The first pour didnt pull any of the sediment into my glass. The aroma is a smooth blended mixture of cherries, apples, raisins and then dark grapes. Wow, simply amazing flavor. It begins with a solid pulse of raisins, cherries and apples before a wave of brown sugar, faint toffee and a bit of sweet unfermented honey crashes in. The sugar sweetness approaches a creamy sensation as it mixes with persistent notes of dark grape jam and cherry compote. Into the finish it attempts to dry out but smooth slick dark fruity sweetness and a sense of toffee hang on and create an even yet rich finish and after taste. Damn fine brew with no sense at all of the huge ABV.

THOUGHTS: Wow. It didnt hide the alcohol all that well, but that works well for this beer. It didnt really say "Christmas" to me, but this was a true Christmas gift. An incredible beer that I have to try to age. I dont know if it makes sense or not, but it seemed to hide the alcohol better as it went. By the end I could barely notice the alcohol. Maybe I just got used to it.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a medium to dark, brownish orange (the color of an old penny almost) with a large, slightly off-white head that kept a thick sheet and left excellent lacing in a thick coat. The aroma was light to moderate cookie, light hops, light to moderate yeast, sour apple, candi sugar, and more sour fruit. The flavor started rather sweet and acidic, and finished sweeter, acidic and a little sour with an average to long duration. There was candi sugar, sour fruit, a little hops and a lot of yeast, some grain. Nice balance. The medium to full body was a little syrupy, but also creamy then dry with a sort of fizzy carbonation and a moderate alcoholic and light to moderate astringent finish. The body made me want to keep sipping.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2016 33cl botlte from ølbutikken, bottled 2008 no best before. but acc. to deScription at ratebeer should age well.
stile does not describe wery well how the beer greeted me when i removed the capsule.. lively. cloudy orange witha fine thick offwhite head.typical belgian aroma with yeast, spices dominating. also  honey sweetness,banana,  aroma seems to be well balanced.
flavor is sweet, light berries, spices, bitterness, very well balanced, but also sort of brutal, Not sure what my complain is, but i miss a softening character. (6,4,7,3,15)
2016-01-05 33cl   cloudy yellow, small white head. aroma is belgian yeasts, faint spices like a saison, faint herbal notes of the very best imaginable kind. Bretty notes, dangerously sweet balance, but it works, this smells like a saison with a tomahawk missile up its ass. or something. Not to be ignored... flavor is way good belgian, faint spices from yeast, sweetness from malts, but balanced,  alcohol is a bit too prominent, but overall the flavor is well rounded. faint flowery notes, notes of tea, notes of belgian yeast, sort of saison like notes.. in some weird way the heavy alc. actually takes a positive part in the overall impression. great beer.

Pours a lovely warm orange with a lasting thick head with some lacing, and great big chunky bits! Holy flocculation, Batman! Beautiful inviting funky & sweet aroma, Concorde grapes. Tastes fantastic - lots going on here; Concorde grapes again, just a hint of tartness, alcohol begins to kick in and a gentle warming finish really caps it off. Great carbonation, nice coating mouthfeel and a light creaminess. Boy oh boy, I wish I had bought a few more of these. The light citrus character goes very well with the dry hopping, the fruitiness and the warming but not burning finish make this one of my favourites from this brewery.

2005 bottle...nice honey-amber color with a thin white head on it.  retention could be much better.  lots of fine sediment.  aroma is lightly sour with citrus candy sugar, and a hint of alcohol.  flavor is immediately and abruptly tart followed by sweet candy sugar and plum.  mouthfeel is very heavy and syrupy and finish is moderately warming.  nice complex beer but a tad sweet for me..  interesting to play with aging...
Bottleworks.  Smelled skunky and poured incredibly foamy, with lots of unsettled sediment.  Tasted bitter and sour.

2008 bottle. Massive blond head. Haz pale orange color. Very nice aroma, slightly sour, phenolic, fruity and spicy. Peppery Saaz hop aroma, some cloves, apples plum and apricot.A hint of vanilla and some graiiny malt.  Big body with sugary and malty sweetness. Alcoholic bitterness is quite apparent. Long, sweet-sour and alcoholic bitter aftertaste.
Bottle. Old rating. This is one of the beers that i have sitting at Carlsens Kvater in Odense, every now and again. Just love it.

11.6 oz. bottle from 2008.  Ive seen this around forever and I could have sworn I had rated this before.  LOVE the label.  A rusty pour with tons of little floaties and a massively fluffy and long-lasting light-tan head with miniscule dark flecks in it.  Dark cherries, plums, candied sugar, bananas, and citrus in the wheaty, tangy aroma.  Full-bodied and sticky.  Very sweet and candied upfront with some plums, pears, bananas, and dark cherries.  Drying finish with some bitter citrusy qualities.  Tingly spiciness throughout.  Big alcohol burn.

33cl bottle at home, iRate: I cant believe I havent rates this yet. 2008 bottle. Pours a nice dark and hazy orange copper with a massive off white head that continues to grow up and out of the glass. Aroma of apples and pears with a dash of pepper and a sprig of green wood, garnished with a citrus leaf. Overall sweet, but with lightly tart earth green vein. Lots of pear skin. Big and bold in your mouth. Again pear and apple, but mainly the skins, ontop of a good varied malt sea. Some simple table sugar pops in right before the alcohol rolls in. Some high hot alcohol with some good warming. A bit of Poire William. Medium full body with a long boozy apple and caramel finish with just a hint of green wood. I have always thoroughly enjoyed this beer bit I have to say that it is best with a little age.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 Orange colored brew. Spicy, citric aroma. Sal ammoniak, spices, fruits in the flavor. Nice spicy flavor. Yeasty, sweet, sugar. 

X-mas 2010: De Dolle Stille Nacht 1999 vintage.
Cloudy amber, copper colored brew. Dried fruits and sweetness in the aroma. Flavor has sweetness, dried fruits, honey, spices, prumes. Nice!

2005 vintage.  A little bit of oxidation has set in.  Other than the cardboard aroma there is a nice sweet malt backbone.  Flavor is slight alcohol, candi sugar, malt sweetness, that leads to a smooth finish.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy with a some carbonation.  Overall a solid brew.  Ive got more recent bottles as well and I am guessing it will be similar (minus the cardboard) and perhaps a little more alcohol.  I will update this rating if needed.

Definitely my favorite beer of 2008.

Hoppy/sour/belgian barleywine?  Beautiful copper color, and a dense pillow of head.  Supreme retention.

Pineapple and sappy esters.  Aromas of white pepper and stone fruits.  Flavor is deep, and would be cloying if not for the infamous De Dolle carbonation.  Residual sweetness is evedent, yet lends a tartness leaving you quenched and thirsty for more.  Exquisite brew.

Cloudy deep straw color body with soft white head.  Big sweetness up front with heavy influences of belgian candi and fruit syrup. Apple and spice dominate the drink with some sweet berry components. Mild belgian yeast notes and some sweet, tart citrus on the finish.  A drink to savor.

Bottle.  Potent malty ripe fruit aroma.  Clear orange-copper body, large white head.  Highly carbonated, but mouthfeel still manages to be rather soft.  Very fruity well-balanced flavor, berries and plums, that is sweet but not overpoweringly so.  Alcohol content is heavy, but well disguised.   Excellent beer.

I did not plan for this to be my 300th rating, but I am damn glad it is! 
Notes from a tasting a couple months back. 
Pours a cloudy blond. The alcohol is strong on the nose but with some spiciness and fruitiness, certainly some apricot in the aroma. Interesting flavor, great sweet on dry balance flavors of cinnamon cherry alcohol and vanilla. One of the most delicous and fitting Christmas ales I have ever had!

This was a surprisingly good beer, especially given the 12% abv. Pours from the bottle to a hazy, orange-rust color, with foamy tan head that lingers thru most of the glass and leaves very good lacing. Nose is a mix of hoppy fruit (apples?), maltydark fruit and a hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is very full, dry and tingly. The flavor picks up the fruity hops from the nose, but also adds in a touch of malty sweetness and just a perfect amount of alcohol to fuse the hops and malts. Finish was surprisingly dry, yet sweeet, and the alcohol created just the right warming effect. 

One of the better beers I’ve had in a while, and most likely the best I have ever had with 12% abv or higher.

Bottle, Beer Ritz, Leeds. Poured into a Judas goblet. Colour was a hazy dark gold with a decent and lingering white head. Lookin the bizniz. Aroma packed a punch with an attack on the nasal passages;  oh yeah, apricot, raisin and cinnamon. Flavour was sticky sweet man with yeast, banana, peach n’ spice easing into a warmingly boozy brown sugar finish.  Some gentle hop bitterness lurking. Chewy mouthfeel, and not seemin like the 12 percent. 
To coin a cliche...a christmas cracker y’all....

moderate lacing with a cloudy pale orange. Lots of head but that might have just been the tap. Slightly sour aroma with grainy traces. Taste like a barleywine with honey and just a slight twinge of alcohol. Smooth, little trace of its strength.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 Bottle, 2005. Pours hazy and amber with a medium sized off-white head. Nose of malt, yeast and riped fruit. Sweet flavour with malt, spices and caramel. More dry at the end with warming alcohol. A pleasant brew to enjoy in the wintertime.★★★★

33 cl bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a well carbonated hazy amber color with a large off white head and a few good size floaties.  No lacing left behind as the head settles.  Aroma is quite fruity.  Flavor is very sweet and estery with a good bit of spice.  There is a nice bit of bitterness in the finish.  The alcohol is nicely hidden.  Palate is soft and smooth.  A very nice beer.

Pours a murky orange with no head but some froth.  Taste is sweet, hops and yeast, orange peel, other citrus fruits and a lot of alcohol.  Perhaps a little too strong, but a beer with a lot of flavour.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with huge creamy white mostly lasting head. Fruity and yeasty aroma. Sweet spicy flavor. Warm alcohol finish.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2008 2008 bottle from Systembolaget.
Brown-Orange in colour with a white head.
Sweet aroma with currant and a lot of alcohol.
Tastes a lot like a barley wine, perhaps because the presence of alcohol.
The rest of the bottles i bought will be cellared for a few years.

I had the oppurtunity to taste a 2004 (4yrs old) bottle. It tastes a lot of saffron and christmust spices, moast of the alcohol taste is gone. Id guess that 4 yeras is optimal but it will probably be good after 5 as well.

33cl bottle. Pours an extremely cloudy, opaque (kind of grody) caramel brown with chunky sediment drifting about (very hard to pour w/out getting sediment - lots and lots of it that is easily loosed from the bottom of the bottle). The aroma is intense at first: alcohol and spices (pepper, coriander). Dried fruit and hints of malt and sherry emerge. Flavor starts sweet and malty with toffee, caramel, and candied fruit. A very nice, toasty, bready, malt-sweet quality persists throughout. There are subtle spice notes on the front of the palate and a slight wine-like quality towards mid-palate - from acidity and alcohol. The finish is dry and quite spritzy with some malt sweetness, subtle spice and acidity, and De Dolle house yeast character (recognizable malt/ester profile from some of their other beers). The beer is warming as it goes down from the alcohol. The mouthfeel is very, very highly carbonated, but somehow it doesnt feel overcarbonated or inappropriate. It is spritzy and champagne-like but with a distinctly fuller body that begins to get chewy as the carbon dioxide is released. Overall - a tasty Belgian ale. The alcohol is very well-hidden. The chewy malts are delicious. I wish the beer were prettier though...

2006 bottle - orange color with a med-lg head.  Aroma has some pleasant citrus, a nice & soft yeastiness. a bit of sugar, and mild hop remnants.  Flavor is pleasantly sweet with some sugar and breadiness, abundant citrus presence, and a complex yeastiness thats hard to beat.  Nice feel & finish.  Always a classic.

on tap at the Essen Christmas beer festival, pours cloudy orange with a white head.  Looks great.  Smells citrousy, with notes of nutmeg.  Taste starts light with light malt, lemon and orange.  Laces well as it goes down.  The mouth is full of moderate carbonation and ends with a lingering finish of light candied sugar.  Top Notch!

Bottle into snifter. Pours a nice orange -gold, a bit hazy, with a big white fluffy head. Just a bit of particulate matter floating around in there. Nose is apricot and tropical fruits, some yeast, floral. Taste starts off with a big dose of tropical fruit and apricots, with a bit of candy sugar in there also, but balanced by a nice combination of dry, spicy yeast, and a floral hop presence underneath. Mouthfeel is a big, sharp, dry carbonation, almost exploding in your mouth - dryness is welcome, but the carbonation is just a bit aggressive for me. Definitely a sipper, but one I would buy again without hesitation. I have never been disappointed with a de Dolle beer.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2017 Bottle. 121111. Nice light matliness and with a bubbelgum freshness. Very saison like in that aspect, But its spicier and heavier. This one makes you think that its summer outside, without killing the holiday spirit! [OLD RATING: 4,2] Orange colour. Big head. Thick foam. Smells sweet of belgian yeast. Sweet, sour and spicy at the same time. Lots of fruit. Has kind of a bitter and dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2012 330ml bottle - - Poirotti Kallio, Helsinki - - 2007 vintage, I think. (6:4:7:3:13=3.3)
Rich orange, small head. Cold, not much aroma, some clove. Simple malty taste. Lively carbonation. Apple and loads of pear in the taste and retronasally. Finish, however, has a clear freshly popped popcorn flavour. Late finish is grainier, and a touch nutty. Quite pleasant, but I do not think they can justify the 12%.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam) - a toast to Jeff Cunningham - thanks for making so many great beers available to us! 2006 vintage, drunk 2012 (7:4:8:4:15=3.8)
Looks marmaladey, clearish, brief small head. Not even a hint of gushing. Marmaladey aroma, some tingly bite and red berry sharpness. Lovely aged raisiny taste, walnutty, a little woody. Lots of marmalade in the finish. And I mean *lots*. No hint of alcohol in the taste. Beautifully well attenuated from the extra years in the bottle. No stickiness. So much better than when young. Fuller an fruitier with the yeast, but I prefer the crispness from the clear glass.

Bottle.  Pours a dark apricot color with a jagged, loud, and large head.  Almost looks alive in how uneven the head sits!  Aroma of soft peach and nectarine, with notes of fine sugar and candy.  Upon first sip, I have fallen in love with how unique and flavorful this beer is.  I have never had anything quite like it.  Stille Nacht is a sensory experience, with an intense aroma, flavor and even fizzy sound.  I tasted bubble gum, sweet peach, apricot, and perhaps even some perfectly crisped crème brule.  I am so impressed with De Dolle brewers.  Palate is creamy-soft, perfectly carbonated, and finish lingers on a delicious note.

Placeholder. 88 vintage thanks to Sprinkle. Fn amazing. Sour on the front, smooth on the back. Earthy and tart, with lots of candy and sugar. Texture is almost like a honey juice. Sour and great balance. Amazing.

33 cl. 2005 vintage. Opaque, orange-caramel color with lots of turbulent activity in the glass. Big cap settles to a lasting half-inch of icing. Vinous nose includes plum, dates, and mildly tart apple/cherry, all with a brown sugar coating. Initial flavors of dark fruit, caramel and brown sugar are balanced with some cellar funk and tartness. Heavy body is smooth, just watery enough to keep from being too sticky, and finishes almost dry with some chest warming.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2008 2007 tasted in September 2008.  Cloudy golden with huge white head that lingered.  Caramel malty aroma.  Full mouth.  Caramel taste with chocolate finish.  Well-balanced and highly complex.  A winner.
2008 vintage in Dec 08, dark amber orange with big white head, big malts, orange, cinnamon, big bitter finish.

Have a case on order for the holidays. How this beer can not rate a 100 is beyond me.

it has all of these wonderful candy tastes yet it’s not sickeningly sweet.

Better than dessert in glass. Needless to say I love this beer

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Orange/amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Slightly hazy. Fruity, vinous nose with notes of  dried fruit, caramel, orange peel and spicy hops. Fruity taste with dried fruit, caramel, orange, bitter-sweet marmalade and spicy hops. Medium to full body, balanced sweetness. Warming with serious amounts of alcohol shining through. Tasty and nice. In short: spicy, bitter-sweet orange marmalade with a kick.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2010 [07 bottle rated 11.21.08] I wasnt aware this was 12% or I might have kept it for a few more years... or at-least a different night.  Pours a murky yellow/golden with a huge super thick off-white creamy fine orange tinted foam.  Strong aroma of fresh squeezed pineapple-orange juice, with some rich vanilla and a touch of alcohol, very juicy.   Medium/full creamy mouthful with lots of very fine sizzling carbonation, actually kind of sticky/sugary.   Sweet juicy first taste with a very noticeable taste of alcohol.   Flavors of orange and pineapple, some bitter fruity yeast, finishes a bit metallic with lingering alcohol.   I love the juiciness of the dry hopping and candi sugars, however I wish the alcohol was kept a bit more in check since there isnt any toasty/nutty flavors to cover it up.  So juicy.  Still an amazingly well crafted brew and De Dolle is easily my favorite Belgian brewery.   8.5.8.4.16 . . . . . . . . . . . [08 bottle rated 11.25.10] Oops, gusher, even though it was cold.  Greeted with that wonderful pineapple, vanilla, orange aroma... my favorite of aromas, slight rich biscuit, I want to make this beer so much.  First tastes brings out some harsh oxidation notes, but actually those disappear almost immediately, juicy orange, vanilla, light alcohol, take its place, sweet but somehow avoids being cloying, not sticky or sugary at all, lively carbonation, this is delicious! 9.4.8.4.16 Gorgeous

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2009 Pours a cloudy, and chunky, orange color with a big foamy head that vanished quickly.  Nice smell of orange peel, yeast, bread and a little alcohol.  Very bubbly on the tongue where the alcohol hits first.  Followed is some more citrus, caramel and a little spice.  Good beer.
Re-Rate:  This is much better than my first rate would indicate.  I dont know if my palate has changed or what!

Opaque cloudy orange with lots of sediment and a moonster of a foamy head, that almost disappeared with some lace left behind.  Alcohol, yeasty, and biscuity aroma, fairly weak.  A little bit of lemon.  Mouthfeel is good and full, a little fizzy.  Alcohol is very evident at the start.  Very nice bitterness of lightly floral hops and peppery alcohol.   Long lasting spicy and slightly metallic finish.  Great beer.

Bottle. 2006. Pours muddy amber with a fluffy beige/off-white head. Acidic and sweet aroma: Complex; fruity, spicy and citrus/orange notes. Faint notes of mint. Dry wooden notes as it warms. Complex flavour as well. Bitter-sweet; yeast; orange peels; fruits. Slightly tart. Finish is 
Medium bitterness. Notes of sweet liquorice as well as  lingering  wine-like notes. Full-bodied. A bit too much carbonation. Alcohol is well-hidden. Overall a nice and interesting beer. 31-10-08.

Bottle from South Bay. Slightly hazy dark amber in color. A lot of sediment in this brew. Big whitish head. Slightly sweet yeasty nose. Some dark fruits. Rich and roasty flavors. Dark fruits and a little spice. Quite full flavored.Hardly any alcohol taste.

Pours golden with a generous beige head which starts out big and levels out quickly.   Smells sweet, like powdered sugar with a hint of citrus and flowers. Taste is powerful,  sugary sweet with a bit of bitterness in the aftertaste.   Medium body, leaves a sticky film.  Alcohol is apparent.  Very good beer though, will buy again.

Malty caramel aroma mixed with some plum.  Average Frothy off-white head with medium lacing.  Hazy flat body with huge particles floating.  Medium brown/amber color.  Light sweet initial flavor with a acidic finish.  Medium bodied with a moderate astringent feel and a heavy alcoholic kick at the nose.

2005 Bottle opened for sharing.
Opened with a strong hiss and nice esters however the carbonation was low - poured with almost no head at all.
Looked attractive with a orange hued beer with lots of yeast
Nose included lots of sweet fruits like ripe pears, yeasty notes, caramel like notes along with some peppery spices and a touch of tang. Impressively the big alcohol is hidden well
Taste: Lots of the sweet esters in the nose show up the sugary sweetness wants to overpower the other esters.
Palate: Felt thin on the palate the lingering notes were briefly peppery and like pears before yielding to the residual sweetness.
Overall: I was a little let down I guess I had too many expectations... not a fair way to judge a beer I suppose. This one (maybe the bottle I had) came across more like an English Barleywine in all characteristics from nose to high FG than anything like a Belgian Strong Ale.

2005 Bottle from brad, thanks! Cloudy orange in color with lots of floaties, big head lots of carbonation. Aroma was light summer time fruits with some spices. Taste was orange, lemon, spicyness with a little bitterness. Average texture, easy to drink. I would of never guessed it to be 12 percent...Good brew!

Bottle thanks to GMCC2181. Thanks for sharing. Poured a hazy amber color with nice big white head and lots of sediment. Aroma was spice, fruity, and yeast. Taste is sweet and fruity with nice smooth finish with alcohol warming. I enjoyed this one a lot.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2008 Cute snowman on the bottle :) Pours a Amber colored hazy body with huge particles floating about.  Lots of sediment on the bottom. Frothy good sized off white head. Aroma of sweet malt and carmel.  Flavor is initially sweet with strong alcohol on the finish. Kiind of a sour milk finish.  Light to medium body.  Soft carbonation.  Not a bad beer.  Rochefort  was way better.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2013 Bottle, 2007 vintage, thx to fonefan. It pours a fizzy, unclear, golden body with a big off-white head. The aroma has some lovely sour notes, yet its sweetish and very fruity, with some hints of spices. Sweet, sugary and slightly yeasty flavor with notes of spices and a lovely fruityness. Some bitterness too, and it has a pleasant warmth from the alcohol. Really effervescent in the mouth, full-bodied and slighlty sticky. Really lovely, the kind of beer I could drink everyday without getting tired of it. Rating: 8-4-8-4-17-4.1. (080823)Bottle, 2006 vintage. Its more or less the same aromas and flavors as described in my 2008 rating, but smoother. Flavors and aromas more integrated than in a fresher bottle, and the sourness seems to be at the same level. Dried fruits and fortified wine also springs to mind. Appearance-wise I have to mention the lacings, they are gorgeous looking and doesnt sink at all. Ive deducted points for the alcohol being a bit more evident in aroma, and on the palate, than I would prefer. And of course to have the possibility to rate an even better beer higher. A true classic, certainly a beer to seek out if you haven¨t been there yet. Cheers! Rating: 8-5-9-4-18-4.4. 091224Sometimes youre in the mood for  a beer, sometimes youre in the mood for THE beer. The beer is Stille Nacht from De Dolle Brouwers. I have been dreaming of a more tasteful and wonderful beer, but every time it turns out Ive been dreaming. Normally I wait until Christmas time until I pop the cork of a Stille Nacht, but sometimes, in the cold Norwegian autumns or springs, a SN saves the day. Or night. Its a beer so tasteful and pleasant smelling that I dont need another one. The light, considering its 12% ABV, alcohol impact is just adding joy to the experience. The mouthfeel is wonderful, warming, silky and full-bodied. The flavor so complex and fantastic Im lost for words. Anyway, the beer is just f...ing wonderful, especially after a few years in the cellar. Let me finish my beer, and a lot of the same kind, and Ill die a happy drinker. Damn, Im in love! Im so in love Ill have another round or three right away just to express my love. 121230.

bottle thanks to DrHomolka.  Pours a cloudy copper with a white head.  Nose is of vinous fruit and yeast.  Taste is of sweet, overripe fruit - peaches or apricots - and some spices.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonated with alcohol warmth to it.
Bottle. Pours unclear orange with a beige head. Sweet aroma with apple, yeast, caramel, and spice. The flavor is also sweet with fruit and spices. Nice.

Pretty good, a little too sweet for me. Yeasty aroma. Lightly spicey and fruity taste. Sweet, very alcoholic finish was not my favorite. Very full bodied and full flavored. Would have been better with food. Not much for hops or any bitterness.

2007 Stille Nacht 12% ABV. Tap Capital Ale House Innsbrook 08/27/2008. 
Slight alchohol and Belgian yeast character in aroma. Cloudy orange amber with small white head. Spicey Belgian yeast character with carmelized malts and candi sugar. 12 % ABV and alchohol is undetectable. Bit of graininess. Full body with creamy mouthfeel. Sweet finish with residual hop/yeast spice.

Vintage 1984 @ Kulminator, part of a vertical. Deep reddish brown with nice lasting head leaving nice laces. Heavy vinous malty aroma of port wine, over ripe berries, wood and spices. Very sweet, long sweet finish with warming alcohol and some dryness.

Tap at the Blind Tiger. Poured a red amber with a thin white head.Light fruit nose. This tasted like a barely wine. Strong alcohol bite with it. Very sweet and fruity with a syrupy quality to it. Aging seems like a good idea with this.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 Bottle.  Aroma of dark dried fruits, apples, flowers, yeast, caramel, spice, and dust.  Large off-white head that diminished and left little lace.  Murky orange brown hue with lots of small particles.  Flavor is spicy, sweet, a little cloying, and a little bitter.  Palate is lively and very full bodied.  My original rating was a 3.2 but I might have had a bad bottle.  This beer was very good and did lack the raw meat and dust that I noted before.  Very full bodied.  I got this brew on a trade and I suspect its been aged for quite sometime based on the huge amount of sediment in the bottle.  Really liked this one.

bottle into wine glass for lack of tulip/snifter/trappist glass.  Very active carbonation... the first pour was 75 percent head.  It has a clear nut brown copper color with a big barely off-white head (some descent lace) and lots of little carbonation bubbles rushing to the top.  Aroma of Belgian candi sugar, wheat, yeast, coriander, delicate alcohol, and pale malt.  Lots going on in the flavor, and not in an overly flavorful/sweet syrupy or confused way - candi sugar, yeast, hops, plums, cherries, pale malt and more.  There is a definite alcohol presence, but it is complex and delicious and warm, not biting and nauseating.  I am not a huge fan of many belgians because I am not into super carbonated brews, but with a swirl or two this gy offers enough to tickle the tongue yet go down silky smooth with a medium to heavy body.  Overall: one of the most enjoyable Belgians I have had to date, and I am sure it only gets better with age.  A great brew (and a cool label too!).

Bottle 2006 edition. Thanks for sharing fonefan. Poured hazy amber with a medium head. Malty aroma with lots of spices and fruit. Heavily fruity flavour with spices like cinnamon. Bit sour with a good alcohol marker. Smooth palate that explodes in my mouth.

Poured into a St. Bernardus goblet. Dark goldenrod/grey poupon color with a sticky white head. Great lacing with ample legs. Completely hazy. Aromas of freshly baked bread, overripe apricot, raisins, and cinnamon. Flavor is very sweet, with banana and peach esters that melt into a brown sugar finish. Lots of yeast and spice, even a little hop bitterness towards the back of the palate. Full bodied, but even so there’s just too much carbonation. A couple of modest sips result in an appreciable belch. Chewy, caky mouthfeel, no alcohol flavors. Drinkability takes a hit from all the CO2. Very good beer.

05 bottle on special for $2.99 at the Ann Arbor Beer Depot.  Christmas in August.  Murky orange amber with a fizzy head that gives way to a thin lacing around the edges.  Smells of a fruit smoothie, plums and strawberries, sugar.  Instant sticky sweet until the bitter alcohol emerges.  Pretty spicy for a 3 year old.  Nice beer for the holidays.  Might go back and buy the rest of those cheap bottles.

Pours a hazy yellow with a big white head. Aroma of fruit, spice, malt, candi sugar & sour apple. Flavor is sweet at first with some caramel and dried fruit. Finish is some what tart and very drinkable. Very complex beer, I love this one.

Hey-o, this is different, even for De Dolle.  No gusher on this one, which is atypical.  Bright chunky amber pour with big bubbly white head that settles into a beautiful thin creamy layer.  Huge chunks distributed throughout but refusing to settle.  Dense!  Malt, burnt brown sugar, pineapple, peach pits, and some funky cheese on the nose.  Bit of an alcohol burn, but for a 12% beer, not obscenely so. Probably not my favorite De Dolle (primarily b/c of the alcohol), but wonderful like all the rest.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 2006 Bottle found at Beer Paradise in Holstebro. Dark amber with good head and sentiments on the bottom, Sweet malty aroma and taste with fruity notes. Very complex and hides the alcohol content very nicely. Spicy and fruity aftertaste. Very very nice
tap. awesome as usual. big fruit and spice with a great yeast strain.  candi sugar does its job in abv and flavor.  a regualr favorite.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle @ home. Reddish brown colour, beige head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of sour dark fruits, roasted malts, yeast and spice, complex. Flavour is sweet at first, brown sugar and yeast, then really fruity sour and spicy in an odd way. Full bodied, sticky. Worth a try, but wasn’t much to my liking.
Bottle from Holiday.  Cloudy copper brown with a tan foamy head.  Caramel apple and spice aroma and taste with a tart finish.

1996 vintage, bottle #1531, received via trade with PilsnerPeter.  Pours cloudy tawny with an average, fizzy, off-white head, mostly diminishing with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toffee), average hops (flowers, perfume, grass), heavy yeast (horse blanket, barnyard) with notes of light alcohol, raisins, plums, dates, cherry, and cinnamon.  Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.  I could not tell that this beer was twelve years old; if it is not at its prime, damn, send me one at its prime and it will be a 5.0!

Poured a huge whipped cream head in my snifter.  Spiced notes and quite a bit of hop bitterness jumping out of the glass.  Nice golden colour with a good amount of carbonation.  Nice zesty esters and a bit of fusel.  The first sip made me do a double-take on the viscosity.  They werent kidding that this is one of the highest densities for a Belgian.  Unfortunately, with that density comes a rather cloying component.  In fact, the more I drink of this the more cloying this becomes.  On the flip-side, this does display some nice vinuous notes on the finish.  A bit of cab, tannins, some nice complexity.  Very odd.  Alot going on here.  Some good, some bad.
Bottle shared at RBSG during the grand tasting held at Pizza Port Carlsbad in San Diego.

Bottle. Pours blond with a fluffy white head, leaves some very nice lacing. Huge nose of figs, bready yeast, bubblegum, plums. On the tongue this is sweet, doughy, tastes o f yeast, plums, apricots, dates, candi sugar, just a hint of alcohol. Gives a little alcohol burn in the chest. Amazingly light and fluffy in the mouth, especially for how big this is. Wow.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2009 At RBSG, this was one of my favorites at the Grand Tasting. Bottle vintage 1990, deep brown pour with flares of orange when held to the light. Smooth and mellow with complexity abounding. Bready malt, dried fruit, caramel, sugars, and on and on. Hiding the % as well.

A hazy orange and brown pour with an ample off-white head.  The aroma was bready, yeasty, fruity and tart.  Sugary, apple flavors mix with earthy, yeasty richness.  A bit of light chocolate as well.  The mouthfeel was medium and the finish was nice and dry.  Didn’t notice that this was 12% abv, very well hidden.
Bottle from Belmont Station--Poured a foggy yellow-orange body with a mammoth white head.  Big citrus lemon, orange nose with a deep malty caramel presence.  Great carbonic balanced mouthfeel.  Nice!

Bottle:2007: Hazy yellow colour, with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast, flowers, and some sournes in the end. Flavor has a smouth fruity mouth feeling mixed with alcynes. Nice medium body, with a medium fruity/citric finish. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Brewed in Belgium. Pours a hazy orange color with a monster foamy off white head. There was tons of sediment in this bottle !! This belgium strong ale has a wonderful citrus, caramel, and banana aroma. The taste is of figs, citrus, candy, and yeast. The 12% is pretty well hidden, and there is some nice lacing too. This is very impressive stuff.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2014 33cl, Vintage 2014, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, very heavy, cloudy, good head, good X-Mas brew

Had 2000 bottle (330 ml) at Kulminator on 6/19.  One of the best beers I’ve ever had.  Just amazing aroma of sweet fruits and caramel malts.  Flavor very sweet, but not cloying at all, with a wonderful vineous finish.  This beer ages unbelieveably well.  Just an unbelieveable beer.

Single from Party Liquors (Steger, IL). 2006 is the year. Pours a very hazy floaty ridden heavy amber with a prominent tan head that begins to dissipate. Nose of sweet fruits and butterscotch. Taste of honey sweetness, belgian yeasty / spiciness that is a little more somber, and a very boozy presence. Complex. Unsessionable. Decent, unique, but strong.

Pours a hazy orange with a ton of sediment and a huge off-white, foamy head. Thick aroma of orange citrus acidity, grains, Belgian yeast, and malt. Heavy bread in the taste with a strong acidity and tartness from the Belgian yeast. Sugar doesn’t add much to the flavor only the heat in the stomach! The bitterness isn’t apparent but does a great job leveling out the 12% ABV. Another interesting overall concept from De Dolle.

12oz bottle at Redlight Redlight (Thanks Teege). Pours a dark amber with a huge long lasting head. Slightly tart aroma with huge amounts of yeast and dark fruit on the nose. Taste is really incredible. Dark sugar, some tart apple, berries, yeast and figs. Very low bitterness, and the alcohol is nonexistant despite the 12%. Truly an incredible beer.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 I meant to hold on to this bottle till winter, but hey its only 98 degrees today. Pours a cloudy orange with a very thick and creamy white head and a layer of sediment at the bottom. The aroma is very full and rich; tons of yeast, very sweet fruit and candy canes. The taste is also quite powerful; a very sweet candy flavor, with some chocolate and tons of strawberry and prune flavors. There is a ton of alcohol warmth here, also some peppermint and cloves. Very nice. I always enjoy De Dolle and this was no exception. This beer is just what it should be.

33cl bottle. Appearance reminds me of Achel Blond with a head that leaps out of the bottle. Great funky nose plus yeast and banana aromas. HUGE flavour that is really hard to place: spicy, sweet, tart and warming alcohol. The 12 ABV barely noticeable. Great beer.

a little weird to be drinking this in June...but hey.
Pours a cloudy light orangy gold with heavy sediment and very little head. (poured too slow)
Aroma is candied fruit, apple cider, light banana  & yeast.
Flavour is sweeeet, almost meadlike at times...honey tones, spicy malt and yeast tones. Light alc. bitterness in finish which is surpisingly clean.
Very interesting brew.

Bottle.  Dank the 1996 version in 2007 its 11 years old!!  To bad this beer is past its prime the sourness and funk have died down, the acidity is low, the etoh goes relatively undetected whihc is a huge plus.  No real hop character.  Tastes a bit woody and metallic.  I am a bit unsure of how well this bottle has been kept as i blow the dust off it. I plan to rerate this at some point.

Lush velvety persistent sand-dune head. Massive floaties; otherwise, orange, effervescent. Halfway through becomes massively cloudy. Classic de dolle aroma: yeast, apricot/peachy, applesauce & cinnamon(?). Flavor is more or less the same, big, sweet, and surprisingly a little more palatable than similar ddb beers. A good try, but its pretty much clear now that Im never going to love this brewery.
orange color nice white headsweet honey fruity banana aroma slightly alchohol in nose and mouth lots of complexness very good

This is a very special, special beer. As introduced to me by Dirk and Company at the Kulminator in Antwerp, this strong belgian ale is potent! It has a beautiful, rich but lucid brown color and a little creamy head with a good pour. I drank a bottle-conditioned from 2004 last night in Malvern, Pennsylvania, which is the first vintage beer Ive had since Belgium. Truly a beautiful beer, a strong ale flavor with a boozy aftertaste.

Pours hazy amber with a thick cream colored head. There is a strong sour smell, along with some spice and malt. More malt, dried fruit, spice, and alcohol. Theres a ton going on here, but Im not really liking it all. Ok.

5-24-08 (1987 bottle) shared by Miketd - thanks Mike!!! 
Semi medium orange red amber with no head.  Smell is light alcohol and has some bold honey and caramel notes.  Flavor is sweet with a cherry suger-like finish.  Medium bodied.  Heavy alcohol is surely present in my sample.

I thought this beer wasnt going to be worth the five dollar price tag but I could be wrong.  Pours light cloudy amber with large white head.  Aroma is hops, sweet malt and spice.  This brew is powerful, in your face with flavor.  Maybe a bit much bite for me right now.  Brings hops, spice, fruit and alcohol in the finish.  Solid brew Ill have to get a fe more of these and try and lay them down for awhile.

2005 Bottle. Pours with a large, creamy, slightly off-white head covering a cloudy orange body with a couple of big yeasty particles floating around. Great retention from the head and some alcohol legs left on the side of the glass.  Aroma is complex of champagne, cinnamon, wood, orange peel, and some other spices. Taste is very strong, fruity, spicey, and a lot of alcohol with a yeasty finish. Highly carbonated with sharp bubbles. Very explosive with each sip.

1987 bottle shared by Miketd.  Thanks so much dude!
Pours rich honey amber with no head.  Smell is tart, sweetness and almost a salty twinge.  Taste is sweet and very lightly tart, but nice and malty.  Slightly full bodied and lightly but not overly syrupy in texture which surprised me for a 21 year old brew!  Pretty tasty.  Thanks again Mike!

330ml bottle, poured golden brown with a white foam head, that left some nice lacing.  Beautiful aroma of malt, dark fruit, candied sugar, and apple.  Taste is sweet and slightly acidic.  Slightly fizzy and very smooth mouthfeel.  Overall quite similar to, and on par with, Rochefort 8.  A very good beer.

Bottle, pours a hazy golden amber with a thick foamy slightly cream colored head.
Aroma, is that of caramel, cotton candy and vinegar. Taste is a powerful isopropal alocohol, touch of vinegar, a bit of citrus, sourness, and a mustiness that one has come to expect with a Belgium Ale. This beer is a great example of its style. A better beer for winter than summer... as it lacks some of the refreshment character of similar styles. A bit to heavy and high powered for a hot day. Great beer none the less.
(1996 vintag, 0.33 l bottle at Kulminator on 2008-05-22) Red wine colour. No head. Spicy and sour nose with some raisin. Medium palate with some fizziness. Sourness. Spiciness. Some caramell. Raisin.
Smell is banana, grape, alcohol, sweet, and good.  Head is huge and foamy.  Looks is hazy orange color.  Taste is a good sweet fruity belgian with some definete alcohol.  Sort of sticky.

Pours a golden honey color with a huge bubbly head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is yeast, light malts, funky sour fermented fruit and wheat. Not great. Flavor is an eyebrow-raiser - it packs a lot more in than the aroma lets on. Sweet fruits, notes of sour fruits (apples), spices, yeast, light malts and *lots* of alcohol. It hits you right away (along with the high carbonation), and while the flavor of the beer is strong enough (and good enough) to power through it, theres quite a bit of alcohol burn, here. Finishes dry, but sticky. This would age extremely well, taking the edge off the burn... but its a little too fresh right off the shelf.

Pours a light orange with a huge head, left a lot of lacing on my glass.

Smells sweet, yeasty, and fruity(mostly apples.)

Taste: Sweet with a caramel maltiness, finished spicy and dry with a bit of alcohol.
botella 330 Ml. cerveza de navidad con bonita etiqueta. no es la mejor cerveza belga que existe ni de lejos

Pours a hazy golden color with a huge white long lasting head. Aroma is a little bit malty, a little bit fruity. The flavor though. . . reminded me of some very young scotch.  All the alcohol, none of the good balance.  It got a little better as I finished the glass, but the alcohol seemed to kick you in the crotch with every sip.  Decent little bitter kick on the back end to balance out the sweetness, but the alcohol is way to upfront.  Leaves my mouth feeling sticky.

[1137-20080229] 11.6floz. "Rich and sweet" caramelized wheat germ aroma. Clear, amber orange body with a quick foamy off-white head and some floaties. Sweet balanced fruit flavour with wheat toast. Medium body. Nice and rich.
(Vintage 2003 @ Kulminator; Antwerp, BE; w/ jerc)

11.6oz. bottle, white cap, SPEC BREW 2005.  Pours clear, but packed with sediment despite careful handling and pour, golden orange in color, with a fizzy white head that dissipates to a thin ring.  Aroma is candied fruits, light spicy yeast, and some faint apple peel.  Flavor is a nice blend of the same, gentler on the palate than I would have thought, quite smooth and just the right amount of sweet; warming but not alcoholic.  Quite enjoyable, and imagine that aging will round the edges out nicely.

This is the standard all Belgian holiday seasonals should be aspiring for.  Absolutely wonderful, with a rich and sweet toffee aroma, loads of candi sugar, with some orange rinds, a hint of yeasty clove and cinnamon.  Alcohol bite comes through ever so slightly in the finish.

330 ml bottle. Dark reddish amber colour. Clear. Medium-sized white head. Lots of loose yeast at the bottom of the bottle. None in the glass fortunately. Rich sugary aroma with notes of citrus and crisp malts. Sharp spicy nose from the yeast. Lots of residual sugars, but nicely balanced by a lot of bittering hops. Really nice balance as the two extremes are both very distinct; intensely sweet malt sugars and sharp bitter hops. Lots of caramel from the malts and flowers from the hops. Bottled 2003.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Pours tan/red with white head. Nose has fruit and strong yeast after settling. Sugary sweetness dominates taste with apple in aftertaste and a little alcohol. The palate is a little sticky for my liking.

Had this on tap at State Line Liquors in MD. 
with afire and moses.  Owner came around with a trappist glass of this brew and wow what a sample!  Hazy gold with a cream foam head.  Pungent fruit mixed aroma like a fine sparkling barley fruit wine.  Sweet sour sultry mix with a unique malt smoothness makes this a top notch brew.  Who wants to wait for christmas, we want this again and soon!
golden appearance with white head.  flavor is tremendous with carndy sugar and strong malt component and a very strong spicy aspect.  an amazing beer.  tastes like a holiday tripel

Cloudy orange-honey color with thick eggshell foam that sticks.

Spicy and sweet yeastiness with a lot of alcohol. First impression is a boozy tripel.  Honey, citrus peel, spice (coriander), whiskey (bourbon).

Sweet honeyed flavor impression. Light caramel, marshmallow, citrus fruit and booze. The alcohol burns giving a very dry feel.

I thought this beer was a bit odd. It starts off pretty normal and almost boring, but builds and becomes a complex sipper.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2009 Pre-99 bottle shared by mmtmatrix, thanks Malcolm. Poured a deep copper color with a moderate beige head that diminished to a ring.  Light, sweet caramel with a nice funky yeast character on the nose.  Moderate tart entry leads into a light caramel maltiness with a nice, funky yeastiness with undertones of fruit including apple, pear, and some citrus.  Smooth on the palate, great drying finish.  Thanks again Malcolm.

Bottle, from the year 2006. Slight hazy golden yellow coloured with a huge white head. Aromas of oranges, yeast, dried fruits and apples. Flavour is fruity, sweet and with a dry finish. I know this beer just keeps getting better by cellaring, so Ill save my other sample for another time in the future. This isnt ready yet..

Ordered from Belgian Shop and it was good.  VERY good.  Nice rich amber color with a nice full off white head.  Sweet, malty and dried fruits on the tongue.  Alcohol is evident but not overpowering.  Nice brew.

this stuff was the BOMB! had it at state line liquors in MD. with two other Knights courtesy of the owner! Nice hazy yellow and thick white head. aroma of sweet fruit and kind of sour grapes. Very malty and bitter taste. Didnt notice any hops. Smooth,smooth,smooth. Did I mention that it went down smooth? Could not believe the ABV% on this and didnt notice it in the taste AT ALL! But this one will kick you in the A**
Do yourself a favor and pick one up. I will get this again!

On tap at State Line Liquors in MD. I was shopping with a couple of friends and the owner comes over to talk about some beer with us. Before we knew what was going on he was tapping us taster glasses of Oskar Blues Ten FIDY and as we were enjoying those he returns with trappist glasses full of Still Nacht. What a great store!

tapped a hazy gold color with a large creamy white head. amazing nose with so much going on that I cant even recall all of the nuances. the flavor was equally amazing with some spice, a bit of tartness that drifted in and out of the palate, some fruity esters, the whole nine yards. at no point during the glass was alcohol present in the flavor though I sure felt it by the time I was finished. one of the best beers i have ever had.

Bottle. 2007. Pours a nice hazy red-amber colour with a small but good lasting creamish beige head. Sweet raisin dark fruity malty alco aroma. Great bit sticky mouthfeel. The flavour is quite sweet but comfortable with caramel and alcohol indeed along with a nice bitterness, some dark fruits and malt. Sweet bit burning bitter alco caramel finish.

Pours a golden amber with a huge thick white head.  Hints of a light caramel, sugary, with some fruitiness, candied apples, fresh figs, with hints of grass.  Very carbonated, tickles your tongue.  Sugary, light caramel, alcohol, slightly caramelized apples in the flavor.  Very smooth,  another awesome beer from de dolle!

Bottle. Yikes. Smells like apple juice, and as it warms apple juice with alcohol, prune, and molasses swirled in. Flavor just kind of weird with these flavors dominating and never meshing. Sugary and somewhat hot. Almost turned into a drainpour, but I soldiered on and it improved to drinkable and a few sips were actually pleasant, but at the end of the day I still found it to be a bit of a mess.

Bottle.  Initially pours a clear orange/amber, but once the yeast is poured in (it doesnt cake at the bottom), the beer becomes quite cloudy.  Aroma of light fruits (apple, pear).  Flavor of these same fruits, spices, plus a strong alcohol presence.  I liked the light fruit notes in this beer...but they didnt go very well with the 12% abv.  Side by side with the Boskeun, Id say that I like the flavor of Still Nacht better, but overall, the beer was less balanced and too alcoholic at times.

This is a great beer.  11.6oz btl from Knightly Spirits.  It pours a red-amber color with a small off-white head.  The aroma is of light fruit and brown sugar and molasses.  It tastes sugary sweet with notes of citrus, nectarine, and other fruits with hits of alcohol and brown sugar tones.  It finishes softly, but forces remembrance of the alcohol.  Good stuff, and a great 100th rating beer!

Color: Cloudy, honey gold with a foamy tan ring and practically nonexistent head. 

Nose: Big and chewy raisiny notes with spicy cinnamon and caramel. 

Palate: Heavy caramel and pruny/raisin notes. Lemony pithy/pulpy notes. A refreshing effervescence and touch of milk chocolate on the finish.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 Both a 2005 and 2007 bottle from bierkoning. Thanks!2005 Bottle: Major gusher! A blowoff tube for the bottle would be helpful. Murky orange color. Pungent aroma of caramel, stone fruit and a subtle sourness. Taste is caramel, fruit and alcohol. Very nicely balanced, though a tad bit astringent. Thick texture. 7/4/8/4/16/3.9
2007 Bottle: Nearly the same color, but fortunately not a gusher. Thick head that dissipates fairly quickly. Strong caramel aroma with some astringency, a little less fruity than the 2005. Taste is caramel, peaches and alcohol. Very sweet. Alcohol is very assertive. 6/4/7/3//14/3.4

UPDATED: APR 12, 2009 33cl bottle from World of Beer Largo. Pours a cloudy amber with a one finger white-tan head that dissipates quickly but still laces the glass. Aroma: Complex sweet and sour smells; difficult to decipher completely. Perhaps some bread and yeast overtones in the aroma with a fruity smell (pear?). Well-balanced flavor with sweet, sour and bitter combining effortlessly to provide an exceptional drinking experience. Creamy mouthfeel but the 12% ABV is well hidden in the intense flavors of the beer. Excellent beer.

Aroma: very interesting, pearcake, yeasty, sourish apfelstrudel... biscuity malts. 
Flavour: nice, extremely full-bodied, yeasty, fruity, peppery, powerful, fresh & fruity. 
Appearance: superturbid greying orange w/ grey particles. Pale foam tinted toward the colour of the body. Irregular bubbles, looks heavy. 
Palate: VERY fizzy, thick, ridiculously creamy.

1996 bottle. Very hazy brownish color. Flavor is sweet, a bit of apple juice, somewhat tart, like a fine apple cider. Hop bitterness is all but gone. Just a smooth mellow sweetness left. Medium body. Hard to describe, as this is so different than most. Just a lot of smooth goodness.

1996 brew. Pours a very murky amber with tan head that dissipates to a thin layer. Incredibly interesting beer. Aroma is a caramelized sugar with tart aspects, like sour apple. Flavor has an incredible tart flavor to it. Hints of granny smith apples and cider mixed with this sweet syrup. The palate is so full of flavor it is hard to break down. Body is medium with a carbonation that lightens it. Very impressed with this.

11.2oz bottle, 2006 consumed in 2008.  Murky thick orange-brown color.  This is a really complex Belgian Christmas Ale.  Ive enjoyed this beer over the years and the taste and characteristics have seemed to vary year to year.  The taste is big and pungently fruity sweet.  Over the top richness, with a wonderful yeasty smoothness.  Drinkable at 12% for sure, I had always assumed that it was around 9%.  Hyper-recommended.

Another review in the unnervingly long series of reviews of bottles that I never got round to reviewing the first time around.  And Im reviewing this now as Im desperate for a beer after a long meeting fuelled only by Marstons Ped and Newkie Broon. Perhaps the greatest thing I can say about this beer is - 1.49 GBP a bottle. Second greatest thing - liquid easter cake. Third - the sugar has rotted my teeth and I am dribbling dentine all over this incredibly expensive keyboard. Fourth - surprise and fear, fear and surprise. Fifth - the sugar subsides to a licking candy sweetness. The alcohol warms cockles but never muscles in. So, no alarms, no surprises. In summary - the right side of que sera, the wrong side of brouhaha.

Bottle at Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium 2008. It pours hazy orange and has a begie yellow head. Aroma is distincy and loaded with lots of flavors. It´s yeasty, sweet candy, hopy, banana. Flavor is flowery, sweet and hopy.  The moothfeel is big. It´s bubby and very carbonated.

(3/10/08) Bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels. 2007 bottle. Hazy amber with a big, quickly-disappearing, off-white head. Aroma of lots of spices (too much), some malt and a bit of caramel. Sweet flavor, caramelly and spicy in the finish with some alcohol. Medium body and very carbonated.

Bottle.  Very sweet  dried fruit (cherry. apple, apricot) and nutmeg/cinnamon aroma.  Hazy amber with giant off-white head.   Sweet raisin/apricot malt and very acidic hops flavor.  Alcohol level makes this one a bit harsh but is still a very nice winter beer.

Bottle. Pours a wonderful golden filled with sediment and a thick white head. Aroma was tangy with hints of hops, fruit, spices, and sugar. Taste was clean with mainly the spices taking over, but a hint of the sweet fruits still playing in the overall taste. An excellent beer that I would recommend to all.

Aarhus
Bottled
Very alcholic beer with balanced hop flavor and some (cane sugar) sweetness

11.2 oz bottle.  Orange-amber pour with a thick long lasting head.  Slightly sour aroma.  Very fruity with notes of apple and candy.  Very sweet start, but it is quickly overpowered by the alcohol.  Lots of yeast and grain with bitterness and hops.  Did not like it too much.  The alcohol was way too intense.

2007 edition - bottle. The cap full of light brown yeasts. De dolle is so caracteristic. The nose is complex as hell with sweet fruits as oranges and pinaples, also hints of corianter. You clearly sense the special yeast that you don´t find in any other beer. Its wild and creamy and easy to drink when you think of how many percent/alcohol it holds. A great beer.

Poured orangish brown with tan head and small floaters. Malty aroma with some sweetness. Medium body with an almost effervescent cabonation. Sweet and fruity with a strong alcohol taste. Very different and good.

3/13/08: Bottle.  Orange body with a thick white head.  Chunklets in glass.  Aroma of yeast, alcohol and esters.  Flavors include sweet caramel malts, honey, cinnamon, yeast, fruit and a touch of whiskey barrel.  Finish is smooth and a bit sour.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor. Created a huge development of foam that was not easily containable once poured, it practically overflowed out of the bottle and from the edge of my glass cup. The visual of the liquid is a dirty opaque yellow that is beyond hazed with sediment and other debris. In the nose a decent proportion of spicy yeast is detected but is somewhat mild and the alcohol is almost non existent. The flavor is a tart yet tasty serving of spices and the alcohol goes undetected. Impressing Belgian ale that I havent ever seen available before.
Cloudy Orange hue, full of yeast sediment and alcohol.  Sweet, fruity flavor that is very abrupt on the tongue.  Good warmth from alcohol makes this a nice sipper...

Bottled at Beer Circu, brussels.
Hazy golden with a lot of yeast-particles. White head.
Sweet and malty aroma; some toffee, slightly sourish.
Yeasty flavour with perfume-ish notes and a warming alco-feel.

Bottled. Hazy dark blond color on the pour, with a lot of yeast sediment floating around. Great lacing with a big frothy head. Fruity phenol notes of pear, clove and banana in the aroma with biscuit yeast tones underneath. Orange and lemon citrus packed into the flavor with light malt, honey and candy sugar follow behind. A bit of a bread-like finish with a strong alcohol content. Pretty damn tasty, but I really couldnt distinguish major differences alongside the 2005 Reserva edition.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 As originally reviewed on 3/16/07:

"Specbrew2005" vintage

A big breakaway from previous Still Nachts, the "Specbrew2005" moniker found on the cap designates the first vintage using a more alcohol tolerant, attenuant, and slightly lactic yeast. The alcohol level has been boosted significantly, and the beer has become much drier and more complex. Gone is the cloying sweetness from the past, and drinkability is through the roof, limited only by availability and your wallet.

Pours dark gold, hazy, with fine particulates in suspension.
Significant sediment left behind in the bottle as well.
Off-white, tight head rises modestly upon a carefull, angled pour.
Head retention is minimal with all but edging and a center whisp remaining after 2 minutes.
Color is noticably lighter than the standard Stille Nacht, hinting at a more attenuated density.
Nose is Flandersesque, with residaul sweetness, but not overwhelming in either aspect.
Honey and some mild mulled apple notes work well with a highly phenolic profile.
Aromatics finish warming with light spice notes, coriander, orange blossoms, and dried cherries.
On the thick side of medium bodied, slightly syrupy and quite sticky. Carbonation is lightish, but enough to add some crispness.
Pallet is hugely Belgian, loads of fruit candy-like essense and honey. Alcohol is significant but not hot. Bitterness is right on, smooth and balancing.
A myriad of fruit mingles with juicy malt and rum-soaked bubblegum.
Pallet finishes long and warming on the back of the toungue, with none of the cloying residuals of the previous Stille Nachts.
A stronger, drier, more complex and drinkable version.
Extensive aging should be a real treat.

4/24/08 cellar check of "Specbrew2005"

The carbonation seems a bit subdued, with a one-inch head at best with a long pour. 
Candied green apples making a stronger presence as this one ages.
The mouthfeel could use some carbonation to keep things lively.
