Slightly dryer yet on the pallet, but still a fair amount of juicy malt and esters.
Alcohol is under the radar, and the beer drinks fast.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 Bottle at the Beer Circus, Brussel, Belgium. Cloudy light amber with yeast particles, large creamy off-white head. Fruity and perfumy aroma with marzipan and touch of alcohol. Medium bodied and smooth, a just a tad too sweet.

In short: Sweet/syrupy ripe fruit concentrate.  Just ok.
How: Many bottles, various aging.  This rating for a two year old bottle.
The look: Very cloudy dark-orange body with lots of particles.  Small white head.
In long: The main flavour is very syrupy sweet ripe fruit taste.  Something that reminds me of a cross between a can concentrated juice (before adding the three cans of water) and the liquid in canned fruits (Del Monte kind of stuff).  Cranberries, bananas, grapes, peaches, etc.  Just too syrupy.  A little milk chocolate and some candy sugar.  Lots of small bubbles.  Alcohol is somewhat apparent.  Cruelly lacking in hops.  Gets sickening after only a single little bottle.  I really wanted to like this beer as this is one of De Dolle highest rated beer, the dudes that make some of my favourite beers (arabier, oerbier, etc.).  But every bottles I had, fresh or aged, were just ok.  This was my last bottle and Im giving up on it after giving it more chances than a small town submissive wife to her drunk unfaithful husband.

Pours a cloudy cider color with ample white head which sstays its course. Fruity nose of apples, bananas, cardamum and baking spices with a peppery alcohol note. Fruity onset of banana with a touch of sour and a pleasant alcohol burn. Spicy herbal hops finish it off.

2006 bottle, 12%. Sweet, spicy, malty, peppery, yeasty aroma. Hazy orange colour, some floaties. Very big creamy head, subsiding after a while and leaving good lace. The flavour starts a little rough and biting. Turns very peppery and vinous with some yeast notes. Very nice warming feel from the alcohol. Unpolished, I should have probably left it in the cellar another few years.
Pours murky dark golden with a smallish white head.  Heavy Carbonation.  Aroma is very sugary, sweet, oranges and some hops.  Kind of light on the palate, not very complex, big alcohol finish

Pours cloudy dark golden with a small off white head.  Aroma of alchohol, fruits, sweet malt, belgian yeast.  Taste is all alchohol up front, followed by some caramel malt, candy sugar, and a nice, very subltle fruit hop bite in the end.  Almost too cloying, but I could handle it.
Pours a dark, hazy, golden orange with a smallish head. Aroma of sweet sugar, yeast, fruit, a bit of the hops also. Very nice flavor, sweet, a bit of bitterness and some spices. Excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 bottle 07... pours a deep golden, slightly murky tan with a thick white head which becomes a thin lacing.  strong spicy and fruit filled aroma... sweet, spicy and fruity flavors dominate the palate which is overly numbing when the beer is too cold... once it warms up, the palate is wonderful... medium body, average carbonation and full of dynamic flavor.  It finishes strong...
I tasted this beer before I got my account with ratebeer, so I cant really remember all the flavors.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2008 A lot of sediment. Dark golden, with a white beige serious thick head. sharp carbination, alcohol slightly present. A strong beer. Spicy flavor.

2005 bottling. Hazy layered orange yellow color with a fleeting white head.  Intense yeasty citrusy nose with pit fruits. Medium/full body. Huge, complex flavors dance on your tongue, back and forth malt yeast pit fruits herbal hops, never a dull moment with this brew. Excellent. 13007
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Outstanding Belgian strong but a little typical. Aroma was big. Strong light fruit and spices. Melon, cantaloupe and corriander. Pour was perfect. Nice hazy orange with a 2 finger white head and sediment....oh sediment. Looked like someone put a cigarette out in the glass there was so much floating in there. Taste was extremely sweet. Too sweet actually. Light fruit, spice and candi sugar with a hint of yeast. Hides the alcohol perfectly. Tastes like am 8% beer. Great beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours cloudy amber with a thick billowing head. Needed to let it sit for a while to let the head stop growing and settle. Lots of little flotsam and jetsam floating carelessly around the glass. Aroma is banana, yeast, raisin, and slight alcohol. Taste is fruity, dark fruit like raisin, medium body, very smooth. Some candi sugar to balance, but not overpowering. Very apertif like. Alcohol comes through at the end with a little hint of banana. Really good.

Bottiglia da 33cl comprata al beershop "In Bocca al Luppolo" di Alessandria; versa colore ambrato chiaro con schiuma enorme, incontenibile. Laroma è strano, per un momento temo che la bottiglia non sia a posto, ma poi lacido un po vertiginoso si armonizza e assume toni fruttati di albicocca e pesca. Difficile resistere allassaggio, ma per i primi sorsi è solo schiuma, che comunque mamma mia è pure buona!!! Quando si arriva alla birra mi confonde il corpo, denso ma frizzante e lalcool è non poco presente nel sapore, ma un non so che di vinoso ne mitiga lassalto mentre si disvela una complessità mica male. Prima esperienza con De Dolle, fra qualche giorno (o settimana) proverò la Dulle Teve, che sta al fresco sotto lasse del tetto :)

11.2 oz bottle, served as an aperitif at the Free State 19th Anniversary Beer Banquet.  Pour is gold-amber, slightly hazed, with not too much head.  I thought it looked quite a bit like a Tripel in the glass.  Aroma of strong, sweet fruit - plums, bananas, oranges.  Some hops in the nose as well.  Alcohol is quite present as well.  Taste is a nice representation of the aroma, big sweet fruit flavors, candy sugar, with a heavy malt backbone and some nice hop spiciness towards the middle and finish.  The finish also revealed the alcohol burn.  Body was medium-full body.  This was nice, but wouldnt mind having it with a bit more age on it (I assume this was a pretty fresh bottle).

dark amber color, good white head, great rentention, and lacing. Aroma is full of ripe apples, and plums, and a nice yeastiness with a touch of alcohol. Mouthfeel is velvet, and super smooth. Flavour is very smooth, and silky, almost creamy, with big notes of apple, caramel, plums, and bready yeast. Wow, super nice beer, Cabonation is a little high, but otherwise outstanding.

bottle.  pours a hazy honey color with tons of floating funness, and a giant gushing eggshell head that has a halflife of about 30 seconds, never completely dissipates, and leaves some pretty soapy lacing.  smell is all kinds of good:  very pleasant fruitiness, combined with a bready and sort of honeyed malt.  lots of dried pears and apples and figs and white grapes, and what seems to me to be a floral hops smell topping it all off.  a bit candied.  really good stuff, if a bit more subtle than my favorite belgians.  my initial impressions upon tasting:  wow thats good and wow thats got a lot of alcohol!  spicy bready malt notes hit first, followed by a deep fruit bouquet.  lots of pears, white grapes, dried figs, honeydew, some flowers, all spiced up and tasting like they belong in a bread.  very warm, with significant alcohol presence, though it isnt necessarily present in the flavor.  light hop bitterness, and very mild sweetness, with lingering dried fruit and oak flavors, and again very warm, though not sharp enough to call hot.  tons of carbonation for a very sudsy, creamy mouthfeel, to go with a pretty full body.  i had high expectations for this one, and it delivered:  complex but not overwhelming, amazing smell and taste, noticeably high in alcohol, but not to the point where it has any effect on the flavor.  lots of fruit without the beer being fruity.  just great.  i just wish the abv was lower so i could drink more.

Pours dark hazy orange with big frothy head.  Aroma of yeast, honey, candied sugar, some spice, citrus hoppiness.  Flavor contains citrus notes and dark fruit such as raisin and plum, an abundance of candied sugar, yeast, and some nice hops to really balance this one out.  Long but dry finish.  Another great one from De Dolle.

Bottle. Fizzy short lasting off-white head on top a cloudy brownish-orange body. Aroma you might expect from a beer such as this: light booze soaked fruits, candied fruits, coriander, lemon zest, yeast and light sweet malt. The flavors go right along with the aroma: boozey lightly sweetened fruits, dry pale malt, yeast, spices and citrus zest. Medium bodied, sturdy carbonation, mildly sweet and dry in the front with a dry, earthy, bitter finish. Well made brew that hides the booze well even though elements of it come through, they do it gracefully.

Bottled, not sure of the vintage year but it sure tasted quite fresh.  Kick ass appearance with a HUGE frothy head and sediment swimming throughout.  While there is a lot going on in the flavor - I just cant hang with these cloyingly, cut throat sweet beers.  Dripping with candi sugar and honey - just too dominated by sweetness to enjoy.  Could only handle a handful of sips and that was it....bummer.  A beer that I cant finish deserves an appropriate rating.  I have a feeling I need to sample this thing with several years of age.
Bottle. Clear dark amber colour with a nice big head. Aroma and flavour of sugar, hops, spice and fruit.

Very unique hazy bown/yellow look with a huge head, like every other brew from De Dolle ive had. Aroma is an intense of fruity esters and vinouse alchohol notes. The esters range from sweet mandarine and oranges, to darker fruits like figs and plums. The alchohol is really something for my liking aswell. Flavor is strong alchoholic in a balanced way. Makes it a sipping brew. Dry hobby finish, really enjoyable!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2010 Bottle (vintage 2008). A cloudy pale to medium amber beer with a huge. frothy, rocky, fully lasting white head. The aroma is moderately malty and moderately yeasty. There are notes of toasted grains, bread, honey, dough, dried fruits, candy sugar, cloves and alcohol. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly sour, lightly bitter. Full body, thick texture, lively carbonation, verey long finish with almost medium bitterness, moderately alcoholic. Lightky sticky mouthfeel, but its not disturbing, very warming, and flavourful. The sugar is evident but well balanced by a reasonable bitterness. I need some bottles to age. My favourute Christmas beer, almost perfect.

Flaske. 2007.  Kæmpestort skum på en øl der ligner en lidt rødlig saison. Ingen tegn på rørsukker eller alkohol i næsen men en del frugt. Smagen er sød men mest af alt hot. Meget hot. Men tegner godt for en lagring.

Draft. Ginger Man, NYC. Despite its heavy sweetness that could easily ruin a lesser beer, this strong ale had so many aromas and flavors that it was a solid, enjoyable beer from beginning to end. Nice frothy head atop a dark amber body. The aroma is filled with scents of strawberries, raisin, apple, peach, plum and clove. Behind that are hints of pine and earthiness. Some malty caramel and cookie notes are also noticable. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly to moderately acidic. The full body has a comfortable velvety texture and lively carbonation. A slight tanginess in the finish. The alcohol is noticable in a nice warming sensation. This goes down very smoothly. Outstanding.

Bottle.   Pours a hazy amber color with a decent sized of white head.   Aroma of caramel, yeast, sour apple.   Flavor is spicy, apple, yeast, carame, light floral notes, alcohol.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes sweet and warming.   very good, though I think a few years on it would help it .

2005 bottle at Microbar, Clapham, 8th Jan 08, with tashi. Pours a cloudy amber with a white head. Heady aroma of sour fruit, caramel, toffee and apples. Awesome flavour - toffee apples, pepper and spices layered over a perfect balance of malt and hops. Lovely tart finish with a good mouthfeel that is suprisingly uncloying. Fine, fine beer indeed!

2006 bottlle.  Lots of yeast floats around an otherwise picturesque belgian.  The aroma is remarkable with sweat fruits of peach, apple and honey.  The body is round and full but too highly carbonated.  Flavor was a major disappointment being almost sickeningly sweet with an unmasked sharp alcohol abrasion.  Maybe I should have let this one cellar.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2008 Pours clear dark amber. Vinous, medium sour and acid aroma. Flavor is initially lightly sweet and earthy, then sharply spicy and the finish is a bit like candy. This is a very intriguing and enjoyable beer.

Nice hazey dark apple juice color with big head.  Apple juice aroma with apricot, yeast, spice/pepper, honey, and a considerable amount of alcohol.  Taste is similar with fruity element and alcohol.  Clumps of yeast and what not despite a careful pour.

SN 2007 is now back to its higher levels...
Orange body, incredible thick foam, little bit cloudy. Usual complex DD nose: chewingum, citric, fruit (mango?), pepper. Mouthfeel and palate is very interesting, with alcohol in evidence but rather complex taste: fruit (orange, mango, grape, ..), sweetness, little sourness. Endless aftertaste. Maybe little bit too young, will probably improve further?

2007 bottle. I know I should have left it until next Xmas, but I couldnt help myself, having tried it in t Brugs Beertje last week and tasted nothing (flu). Pours red amber with creamy white froth. Saliva-making aroma of oak, apple juice, marmalade, soap, just a teaspoon of something acetic, but not quite vinegar. Massive peppery alcohol, heady raisiny fruit, and intensely bitter hops. An amazing, sweet, cereally aftertaste of....I dont know what. Wheat? Corn? Honey Nut Loops? Buttery, malty, toffee-dipped popcorn. Glowing oesophagal fire, orange and strawberry fruit so fat, bulbous and humming itll take your head off. Chewy, fat and soapy throughout, but returning to that sweet buttery aftertaste 20secs after the swallow.Cornflakes, fresh bread, Rodenbach Vin De Cereale. Dont know where the sourness went, its all punishing bitterness and sweetness beyond the first intoxicating sniff. However many times your head is smashed against the canvass, you keep coming back up for another tender bludgeoning PUNCH IN THE FACE. Unbelievable complexity, headiness, balance, length. All the hallmarks of a classic Belgian ale. Dont bother ageing it, DRINK IT NOW.

Bottle 33 cl. pours an almost clear orange with a medium white head and a banana sweet and alcoholic aroma. The taste is intensely sweet with a huge amount of ripe fruits coming from all directions. Candy sugar, spices and offcourse alcohol are to be found in here too. The finish is first spicey and later on bitter and then warm alcoholic. This is a real winter-warmer. Merry christmas!
This is a big beer in every way.  Lots of taste.  Extreme sweetness but balanced out with aflowery bitterness.  The alcohol really hits you.

33cL bottle, 2006 vintage, consumed 1/6/08.  Poured at room temp, huge rocky white foam, very nice retention and fantastic lacing.  Huge ripe fruit and candy sugar nose.  Flavor is huge on the ripe fruit again, subtle booziness and a nice hard candy-like bitter finish.  What can I say, Im a sucka for a strong Belgian blonde.
Pours hazy orange with thin white head.  Minimal lacing.  Aroma very sweet of candied sugars with a touch of apple juice.  Have had this in years past and was much better than this.  Way too sweet.

Oh man.  2006, trappist glass.  Pours a murky chunky orange amber with major head; even after lengthy refrigeration nearly came bubbling out of the bottle.  2 inch thick off white dense head with icebergs for lacing.  Nose is dominated by typical de dolle sourness, fruity tripel esters, fresh cream.  Lovely and full on the palate, goes down extremely smoothly, initially a melange of complex fruits: pears, oranges, granny smith apples, simplifying to caramel sweetness tempered by oaken sourness and a suggestion of wooden hops.  yeah, really really good, my favorite beer this winter season.

Jan. 2006 - Beer poured golden color with nice head and lacing. Aroma and flavor were really, really, really, really sweet. Sickly sweet. It tasted like I was drinking some kind of apple syrup. Just too much.

2005 bottle. 


Man, this is one freaking amazing beer.  Im not a fan of Belgians at all but this is without a doubt the finest Belgian Strong Ale that Ive ever had. 


This pours hazy orange and is full of floating debris.  A little disconcerting but nonetheless....

Smells very sweet and yeasty and a little like a nice fruity wine.  

Mmmmm... What a wonderful taste this has.  I cant begin to tell you how pleasantly surprised I am with this beer.  I was this close to trading this off without trying it and I am so glad that I didnt now.  Hell, theres no doubt that I will be getting this one again and I dont usually like Belgians.  This was simply amazing.  Perhaps its the age on it that has made this so wonderful but whatever, it is actually one of the tastiest beers that Ive had in a while and that includes some pretty high quality beers.  

What a pleasant surprise that this turned out to be...

11.6oz bottle dated 2006 poured in a trappist glass.  De Dolle Stille Nacht pours murky orange with tiny pieces of beer pulp.  the head is thin and fine.  The nose manages to have both acidic vinegar and sweet fruit.  The hops are subtle but promise to make an apperance.  The body is thick and greasy and hits your chest with another promise, this time of heartburn.  The flavor is complex.  I detect alcohol, pear and malt vinegar.  This is an exceptionally well-done beer and deserves its place in the top ranks; however, I dont believe I could drink many of these a year.  It is a no-holds-barred beer that will be best appreciated during the holidays only.

Mine had no head which I found surprising. The alcohol is nice and very good at pulling out the flavors the beer has to offer. Much like De Dolles others, but more traditional, as in without much of a vinous or super sweet character. I missed that in this one, but this is still a world class brew.

Bottle 2005. Very strong smell of yeast and sparkling wine, a little bit sweet. A relativly big white creamy head which stays very long, cloudy orange body. A little bit sweet which gets more bitter later on and finishes more alcoholic; medium bodied wiht a rather dry and creamy texture, not much carbonation. The aftertaste is bitter and alcoholic.

2004 Bottle: 
Pours a dark golden in color with very little head at all.  Smell is lots of candy sugar, some banana and a little clove.  Taste is all the same with surprisingly a good amount of heat from the alcohol coming through.  Medium on the mouthfeel with absolutely no carbonation to speak of.  This is a very good beer, and a treat to have on Christmas.

1996 vintage.  Sweet and tart.  Nice balance between the two.  Im really not sure if thats how the beer originally was or if it was the 11 years of aging that was on it.  Either way, this was definately a wonderful treat.
Very citrusy and sweet.  Overall, the best beer we tried out of 3 different winter ales.  Will definitely buy again, even though it was $5 a bottle.
Citrus flavor with very full body.  Sweet aftertaste, almost too sweet.  Some suspended solids in the liquid, but very delicious!
2006.  pours a cloud clear gold.  spicy sweet yeast aroma.  spritzy yeast with good and sour finish.  bannana in the background.  good full bodied.

This golden-amber ale poured with a massive off-white head, eliciting a sharp fruity aroma. Since the head did not show any signs of dissipating, I sipped it off the top until I reached the liquid. The beer is initially bitter, but the candy sugar eventually creates a sweeter flavor followed by a hoppy bitter finish. This is a very complex brew that would certainly benefit from aging.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2009 bottiglia del 2007 color dorato carico buona schiuma piuttosto persistente considerando il contenuto di alcol ottima sentori speziato zucchero candito alcol in bocca riscaldante piena dolce contrastata da un forte luppolatura ed una lieve acidità una birra complessa
2009 un po meno complessa piu tendenza dolce

bottle poured cloudy appricot with a few yeast chunks floating in it. Nice thin white head Aromas of appricot, belguim yeast and some alcohol nice medium to thick mouth feel, flavors of sweet fruit honey spices with a light touch of hops, the alcohol is well hidden in this one of 12% this is a wonderful winter sipper.

33cl bottle, 2006 vintage, rated Dec. 7, 2007.   Hazy honey-amber with a massive white head that climbed out of the bottle and glass.   The aroma was somewhat sour at first, but this faded and yeast started to dominate along with honey and alcohol.   At first, the alcohol was very well hidden in the flavor, only making itself known in the throat after swallowing, but farther in it started to be more pervasive, although never too distracting.   Sweet citrus and peach flavors as well, with lots of spicy yeast, and a bitter finish that keeps it surprisingly light feeling for the strength.   The body has plenty of carbonation, but it softens noticeably.   Also a little sticky, though not too thick.   Enjoyable, but a little over the edge with the alcohol flavors toward the end for me to really like it a lot.

330ml bottle. Murky toffee colour with an off-white head and some floaters. Aroma of honey, cinnamon, floral hops and yeast. The flavour had plenty of candy sugar and spice with a slightly bitter finish. Perhaps the alcohol was a bit too pronounced. Enjoyable.

Bottled in Delirium Cafe, Brussels. 2006,  Hazy dark yellow, amber color. Thick foamy beige head. Scent is sweet and fruity. Aroma is full of sweet fruits and a bit of alcohol. Flavour spicy and fruity and here alcohol makes u feel what u r drinking. Prefectly balanced, very nice beer

Im pretty sure this is a 2005 vintage. Anyway, pours out a rusty colored orange, very hazy and cant see anything through it. Little to no head to speak of, a bit of orange fizz for a second but then melts into nothing. Taking a deep sniff reveals, plums, cherries, light spices, and tart cherries. Really nice blend of aromas they have going on here. Upon first sip I realized this is a beer that needs to be slowly sipped and respected. Very complex beer here. At first I get a wave of cinnamon and clove then tart cherries and deep prunes. Apricot and pears as well. Im really digging this fruity and tart blend with a hint of light spice. Very well made beer. I wish I had another one.

Bottle. Not sure on age but seems like a fresh one. Pours a cloudy and yeasty orange with little head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity and very belgian like but with a candy sweet intesity. Flavor is sweet, full of ripe peaches, plums, apricot, and candy apple. There is some light spiciness that almost takes the mind off the heavy dose of alcohol and sweetness. Finish is medium, warming. Syrupy mouthfeel with some stickiness and very little carbonation. This is a big strong candy like freak. I like it though. I may head out right now to get a bottle to age.

had in the pub of hotel Erasmus in Brugge.  Bottle was aged many years per the barkeep, seemed to be - bottle was very dusty and label was worn thin.  powerful brew with too many flavors to describe but overwhelming taste of cherries and prunes.  Bubbled off the tongue on first few sips then mellowed out after a little while.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2008 Bottle at Backdoor Café (Ghent). (And bottles at home in rerating)
Appears as strong as it tastes. Orange golden with a strong head. Complex aroma with all kinds of hints but it is hard to destinguish them seperately. Definitely sweet fruit. Gives a very lively and warming mouthfeeling almost as a warning to be drunk carefully.
Overall very interesting beer, I’m aging a crate to see how it evolves over time.

orange looking with lots of lacing. very intense first taste, almost overpowering. but after third taste or so you realize how complex and how good this beer is.

bottle from city beer san francisco.
bottle. Unbelievable that this is a 12% beer, soo freakin good and smooth. Somewhat sweet with plum caramel and clove taste to it. I enjoyed it from the first drop till the last.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange color.  Very thick white head.  Aroma is very yeasy, with a sweet/tart fruit hint to it.    At 12% the alcohol is present in the beverage.  The flavor to the brew is very complex, and actually quite hard to totally pin down totally.

Hazy orange with thick enduring white head.  Aroma is pears, apples and cloves. Taste is sweet with lightly tart apple and thick with light biscuity hint-o-caramel finish and alcoholic warming. Carbonation is nearly perfect. Small bubbles, and lots of them.  $5/12oz

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007 2006 bottle at Eulogy in Philadelphia, PA. Pours a hazy golden with a nicely rententive white head. Aroma of yeast, candi sugar, and pear. Medium bodied with a soft but lively texture. Subtle complexities in the flavor, in which I get yeast, candi sugar, pear, clove, and apple. Earthy finish, in which you can sense the alcohol, but not taste it. Not a bad beer, but I was really expecting a standout here. This seemed rather ordinary to me. Perhaps I had an off night.

Glowing orange color, amazing frothy white head--looks like what you get on a well-made cappuccino or beaten egg whites.  Simple aroma of yeast, orange, apple.  Creamy, almost warming mouthfeel, taste has vanilla, alcohol, grapes, spice, snappy hop finish.  The carbonation you can see flowing up the glass is strong but not overwhelming.  Doesnt drink like a yellow beer, not really sure what to think but I like it.

Bottle, bought @ Kolding Vinhandel. [Vintage 2006][my 1900th rating]
Pours a cloudy pale yellowish amber with little yeast particles floating around. The head on this monster is exqusite, extremely creamy, long-staying and very sticky to the glass. Aroma is very complex, oranges, Belgian sugar, vinious, raisins, cinnamon and cardemum. Mouthfeel is round, creamy, yet lively. Flavour is equally complex for a beer this light in colour. Sweet, vanilla, cardemum, oak, apples and a very warming touch through its non-too-apparent alcohol. Wonderful!
Carbonated, light mouthfeel, but a little sticky.  Sweet and mellow, complex.  Hints of spice, but overall very well balanced and done.  Alcohol is nowhere to be found.  Very good.

Poured from a 2006 vintage 11.2oz bottle, and served in a tulip.  This ale poured a cloudy, glowing amber/brown with a thin, beige head.  The head was tight and displayed very nice retention, lasting the entire duration of the glass.  Some uneven, runny lace was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of orange peel, candi sugar, raisins, light sourdough yeast esthers, and also some toffee.  The taste was similar, but also included notes of sweet and sour apples, cherries, and also some alcohol in the finish.  The mouthfeel was slightly creamy and full-bodied with very crisp, fizzy carbonation.  The combonation of the high alcohol content and the lively carbonation created a nice tingly warming effect on the tounge and throat.  This beer was a very nice Belgian with a nice variety of complex flavors.  Very tasty, but I would really love to try an aged bottle.
ruby/brown with a decent bubbly head. yeasty aroma with a touch of citrus and spice. flavors of sweet bread, yeast and spice. alcohol is hidden but still present  in the finish.

dark brown with a slightly fizzy darker tan head. very rich aroma of dark fruits, malt and complex belgian yeast. flavor of a rich belgian strong such as roch10 with a helping of sour to add to the complex but harmonic mix. a great beer. I cannot bring myself to drink the 2000 reserve I have been saving....

Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a murky tan-amber color with a large yellow-white head. The aroma was yeasty, spicy, peppery and had a citrus element. The flavor was dry, spicy, peppery, citrusy, and very yeasty.  The finish was long, dry and yeasty with a bit too much alcohol showing through.
Vintage 1993 at Chez Moeder Lambic May 2007. Pours red with a small white head. Vinous aroma with hints of madeira and port. Flavour is quite vinous too and very harmonic. Did I say madeira?

Bottle. One of my favorite Belgians.
Totally awesome flavors of fruit, caramel, yeast and bread. Alcohol is very subtle. Nice aromas as well. Just the right amount of carbonation which gives it a lively palate. Worth seeking out and it pais very well with good cheeses.

Bottle Id had aging.  Lots of sediment in this one.  Smells very apple-y, which comes through in the flavor as well.  Finishes very thick, & the burn of the alcohol is just at the end as the liquid evaporates from the back of your throat.

Pours a dirty burnt orange with a huge white head, no matter how slowly I pour.  Aroma of apple juice, green sour apple candy.  Under that, theres some caramel, white wine and a slight hint of cookie dough.  Very strange.  Some pepper as it warms.  Initially, this tastes very sweet, with lots of caramel, sugar, white chocolate, and a whole bunch of sour apple and other such fruit flavors.  Some yeast pungentness gets through.  Plenty of hop flavor in the finish (toast, earth, nuts, etc.) which is a welcome touch.  Good flavor, but overall a very strange beer.  Thick and overly carbonated, yet still a bit too slick and too hot.  Points mainly at aging potential, cause its just odd now.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2007 Dont always shout out but I loved this one so thanks Eugene. 1996 bottle. Even though I got a pour towards the end of the bottle this is still amazing. Nice belgain flavors and rich and delicous. Aroma very sweet with some alcoholic strength. A little rich but love that body. Smooth malt with some fruit. Not much hop as desribed but this bottle has aged a bit.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2007 1996 bottle into a tulip.  It feels like im opening a very special brew.  Aroma of alcohol, sweet candy, some light malt.  No head whatsoever, just some bubbles around the  edge.  Medium brown translucent, not too much carnonation it appears.  Wow, taste is so sweet and smooth.  Not very clingy, wslightly syrupy, absolutely enjoyable. Slight alcohol warming in the finish.  Very clean taste, with candied fruits very prevalent.  Great beer.  Could have used a bit more carbonation in the palate, but great beer. Have one more bottle, but Im going to pick up a few more tomorrow, too good not to have again.

1996 bottle Shared at both the Jimmack Invitational07 and CaptainCougar Comes to NY @ JoeMcphees. Pours clear amber with a small head. Strong aroma of strong sweetness (Belgian candi, as well as sugary sweet candy), light sourness, and some oxidation (cardboard). Taste has stronger sour notes and lower on the sugary sweetness. Pretty alcoholic in nature. A lighter side of medium body, making it quaffable but a slightly syrupy mouthfeel. Some roast in the aftertaste. Still I would not guess it was 11 years old.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text:
This was a 1996 bottling. 
Pours a medium-dark reddish orange, with a thin and bubbly head that stayed almost the whole time. The aroma has some great fruit notes, with that unique Belgian yeast quality there as well. The flavor was complex and refreshing. The same fruit notes from the aroma were there in the flavor, just stronger. The sourness mixed with the sweetness of the fruits really made it work. A great truly great beer that Ill be drinking again and again.

Pours a slightly cloudy amber brown with some head. Nose is like rotten apple skins, but not in a rancid way. Flavor is extremely sweet with almost a brown sugar flavor to it. Strong and pungent. Definitely a winter beer. I just want to light a log and throw it on the fire and sip this thing for the next hour....or two. Mouthfeel is a little thinner off less carbonation than I like, and also syrupy due to its style, but the drinkability is very high even though it is a "sipper". I could go for these all night...especially on Christmas Eve as I stare at presents under the tree with someone very attractive next to my side. Hey, baby. Whats shakin.

Hazy copper with a small off-white head. Notes of spices, fruit and flowers.
Sweet with lots of fruit and malt taste.
Full body with a sweet finish.

Bottled in 96, how did I find this in a store? Murky brown caramel pour, with a tiny almond head that stays. Aroma is very sour with apple cider notes. Flavor is sour as shit, with a huge apple cider taste, brown sugar, and honey. Full body, with a dry aftertaste, and warming alcohol. Lots of sugary sweetness with more apple cider. Maybe at 11 years this is how it turns, Id like to try it fresh.

06 Vintage..Loudest pop Ive ever heard from a cap or cork. Pours hazy copper with a foamy tan head. Light semi-sweet aroma of fruity esters, honey, light spice, and a touch of floral hops. Flavor is very hot upfront and all the way through the finish to the back of the throat. There are  nice fruity notes buried under the alcohol, and some floral hops make a nice appearance towards the finish. Palate is full, dry, and alcoholic. I expected much more from this, but I guess Ill have to try again in a few years. Alcohol is just too strong right now. Got pulled away before finishing this rating, and had to add when the yeast is poured this brew does mellow out a bit, and the fruitiness is a bit more forefront.

11.2 from sams chicago. the color is a very dense and cloudy orange/brown. the head begins to form very early in the pour.  it raises high and fluffy white, and is long lasting. aroma is surprisingly light. all around very mild. a smidgen of alcohol, some esters and touch of wheat grain are all i can find.  maybe a little floral hop. mmm...what it lacks in aroma it makes up for in flavor. very smooth, with a palate like white wine and a kick that would match. fruity with a rich malty sweet middle and a long vinous finish
Bottle picked up at Binnys in Naperville, shared with Duane.  Pours a hazy copper color.  Spicy, fruity aroma and flavor.  Very sweet as well.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Glad I picked this one up.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 
Date: November 18, 1998
Mode: Draft
Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs
Appearance: hazy amber
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma with a hint of floral hops
Flavor: rich cpmplex malt flavor, lots of sweetness, touch of bitterness

Date: January 12, 2004
Mode: bottle
Score: iii to iiii
Appearance: opaque orange, headless
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma
Flavor: big malty flavor, fruity, slightly alcoholic, richness lasts through the finish

Date: February 11, 2010
Mode: bottle
Appearance: cloudy orange, fine white head
Aroma: sweet and spicy aroma, nice and oaky, touch of tartness
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, plenty of spicy phenols, touch of oak

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Date: December 29, 2009
Mode: draft
Vintage: 2009
Words: bsp
Appearance: clear orange, creamy off white head
Aroma: lightly sweet aroma, drying spicyness
Flavor: sweet candy malt flavor, phenols and Christmas spices come in to add a drying effect, candied appricots, touch of peppery alcohol

Cloudy, unfiltered golden amber appearance.  It practically glows in the glass when held to the light.  Small white head that settles to a neatly groomed edge with a wispy film.  No lacing at all.  The aroma shows lightly caramelized sugar that intensifies significantly with each additional degree of warmth.  I also picked up both light and dark fruits, including bananas, apricots, and figs. Some alcohol is detectable on the nose, though its not unpleasant.  The flavor profile starts with candy sugar and caramel, evolving to include figs, mild spices, and faint traces of muscat.  The palate is medium in substance, smooth and sweet.  The finish leaves a long sugary fig flavor on the tongue.  I really dig this beer!

Pours a cloudy golden color with a large white head and great retention.  The head stuck around the entire tasting and would bubble up higher with a swirl.  The lacing coating the trappist glass and left rings in its absence.  The scent was malty with notes of dried fruits, nuts, barley and yeast.  Excellent mouthfeel and feel on the palate.  This is a tremendous strong ale, very complex, getting better as it warmed.

Hazy golden colour, large foamy white head.   Sweet fruits, bread and yeast in the aroma. Taste is yeasty, warming alcohol, and underneath this some fruits are noticable. A balanced bitterness makes sure this beer keeps drinkable despite the high ABV.

@ Chucks aged ale tasting, this one tastes more like a barley wine until the bitter end when it has the traditional belgian style yeasty flavor, i would age for a few more years, let the alcohol burn mellow and kill some of the sweetness.

2005 bottle. Pours a dark orange almost copper color with a thin white head. The aroma is of sweet fruits, caramel, and candy sugar with a little bit of spice in there. The smell almost reminds me of a barley wine. The taste follows the same with big malts and candy sugar sweetness with some fruits in there. I get a little bit of alcohol warmth up front, but it is very well balanced for being 12%. I think the hops have mellowed out with the age of this one. A full sticky mouthfeel that had a long finish to it with all the sweetness left on the palate. Really well balanced with the fruit and sweetness in this one that makes it easy to drink. This one is very enjoyable and great for Christmas time or any time. Another great brew from De Dolle. These guys are one of the best.
Another beer option I miss from my Michigan days. Every now and then Id treat myself to this one. A complex beer. Nice body.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2008 Tried this one at the Kulminator pub in Antwerp and really regret not having taken more detailed notes. I did scribble in cryptic doodles that it was an excellent and memorable beer. Re-rating from bottle in 305: fun and fruity, nose not as rich as I remembered and alcohol not as well-integrated but still lovely beer. I would drink DeDolles piss if they bottled it...

11.6 oz bottle.  SPEC BREW 2005 on the cap.  Hazed orange honey with a brief white froth and tiny floaties.  Spicy caramel, brown bread and orange liqueur.  What the nose hints at is delivered big time with the first sip.  Intense depth of flavor with layers of maraschino cherry, strawberry preserves, lime sherbet and pink grapefruit.  I found myself taking smaller and smaller sips to draw out the sublime red fruit sweetness.  Yes, the alcohol creeps in but still incredible.

after drinking the De Dolle Oerbier the day before, I was afaid this would be another over-carbonated Belgian beer I would not like.  boy was I wrong.  pours a hazy orange with a decent head and lacing.  aroma is spicy and sweet.  flavor is more fruity than I expected with a sticky sweetness, more spice and some yeast notes.  well hidden alcohol and soft carbonation.  well done.  thanks for sharing Jeremy.

Courtesy Knightly Spirits from a rampage beer run. Pours enigmatic-orange, 1 cm of white cap. Flowing lace. Nose is stale Cheerios cereal and caramel. Enormous caramel on the tongue. WOW! Very misleading judging from the color. Smokey, fireplace-style oak, X-mas spices,  pronounced oatmeal and caramel candy sticks to the palate. Incredibly rounded mouth-feel. Alcohol is hidden well. Full-bodied, delicious, with the right amount of carbonation. Takes me to that special time of the year--the greatest month: December.

Tasted 2007-04-07. 2006 version, 33cl. It looks like bog water, but it has an unexplainable charme to it. Its not pretty though, but its also not unappealing. The head dissappears as quickly as it appears. Aroma: Very powerful: Alcohol and fruits and yeast! Taste: Yeast, yeast and yeast! Some acids and some bitterness at the end. Very complex but also very raw. Im sure this will age gracefully!

Finally entering all my "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07 results.  An aroma of cereal, dark fruits, and strong alc.  Amber appearance with small white head.  Flavor is sweet and mollasses and alc.  Okay body but you feel the burn.  Will have to rerate.

Bottle enjoyed off-season @Plan B, Copenhagen. Huge fluffy lasting white head. Excellent lacing. Slightly unclear light brown body. Amazing aroma, a fruitbomb! Also scents of bubblegum, caramel, chocolate, spices and yeast. Taste is candysugar, malt-sweetness and fruit-sweetness. Not cloying at all, only a fresh and inviting sweetness. Christmas-spices, fruity acidity, yeast, refined hops and alcohol to balance. Very complex and filling. Fruity and spicy and gently bitter end with long duration. This beer was made for me. I love it!

De Dolle Stille Nacht poured a hazy golden colored body with a white head. This beer was cloudy! The taste was sweet with hints of clove, orange peer, and honey. This beer is REALLY sweet. I found it enjoyable, but even I as a fan of sweet beers thought it could be toned down a drop.

Pours a yeasty, slightly hazy glowing orange with a small white head.  Pretty fruity aroma but with a noticeable spiciness to it.  Alot of orange peel, some coriander, and malts.  The flavor is very sweet and malty, almost sugary.  Syrupy maouthfeel, with a long finish.  Just slight on the fruit, but heavier on the malt with some spices.  Kind of a subtle earthiness to it, that makes it easy to drink and enjoyable.  Nicely done.

Pours a very hazy and cloudy gold color.  The aroma is spicy with bread notes, malt, and slight hops and maybe even some sweet honey thrown in.  Taste is a complex balance of sweet and spicy across the nose, and this beer executes this complexity in a very subtle way.  There is also a hint of clove and earthy notes thrown in for good measure  Great winter beer from De Dolle, a brewery that rarely misses.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 bottle Thanks Olso! Poured a very cloudy golden color with a lot of sediment present.  The head was a large light tan.  Aroma was wonderful with honey, spices, and bread.  Taste was very sweet with a nice spicy finish.  I will definitely drink this again.
 2006 bottle.  Pours hazy dark gold with a light white head that sticks around.  Aroma is very sweet and yeasty, with a lot of vinous smells, pineapple, raisin, butterscotch, and sweet rolls.  Some toffee also makes its presence known.  The taste is similar to the aroma with a lot of sweetness in the beginning, with flavors of toffee, candi sugar, raisin, butterscotch, which changes more to a dry white wine flavor in the finish.  There is also a lot of bready yeast on the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium with a lot of carbonation like all De Dolle beers.  This beer is as good as it was the last time I had it, and Im always consistently impressed with this brewery.
[Bottle] Poured cloudy amber with an enormous light tan head.  Aroma was very sweet and consisted of cloves and honey.  Taste was yeasty, spicy, and sweet.  Medium body. Very nice beer.

bottle.  barely there head, into cloudy yellowish-orange body.  aromas are strong of ripe fruit also some malts and spicyness are also present.  alcohol is well hidden but warming is present.  long finish.  good good stuff.

Syrupy hazy golden blonde pour with a frothy white head.  Sugary candied malts are evident on  the nose as well as sugared fruits, raisins and figs.  The body is syrupy and sugary, smooth without much carbonation.  I cant recall ever having such a sweet beer, its lip smacking-ly sweet, however this is not altogether a bad thing.  There are some robust sugary, honey malted flavors, and a dose of alcohol which warms the throat and eases into a long drying finish.  Silky smooth mouthfeel, good brew, worth trying

The color was golden, hazzy, and had orange hues.  The head was foamy, creamy, laces well, and frothy.  The aroma was belgian yeast, alcohol, tart, and dry.  The flavor had an alcohol nose, belgian yeast, dry, and a lot of activity.  The palate was thin/medium bodied and smooth.  The finish was warm and dry.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 06 bottle:  100th rating.  Cloudy orange color with big, quick diminishing white, fizzy head.  Aroma is very sweet.  A big rock candy quality along with very subtle citrus tones and an apparent maltiness.  Smooth as silk; it has a wonderful texture and dense candied sugar flavors with a strong malt presence.  Can definitely notice the alcohol, but not in a bad, overpowering way.  This is a wonderful beer and Im glad I chose it as my 100th.  Bottoms up!

12 oz bottle.  Pours cloudy dark yellow color with white head and lacing.  Smells yeasty, sweet, a wee bit sour.  Taste is complex... fruity, spicy, very sweet.  Kind of sticky-tasting.  This is a unique beer.  Good for Christmas maybe, but this one wont be a regular one for me.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2011 Mmmmm, what a beauty this is. A deep ruby-to-brown body with a tight layer atop. Its got a very lively body and a yeasty freshness like a tripel, but backed up by rich malts and some spice (but not over the top like so many yule beers). Dark but not too syrupy, crisp and hoppy for measure. A truly fine beer.

Almost no head.  Clear, but with some yeaties floating around despite a careful pour.  Good aroma of grass, heavy yeast, raisin, pepper, and alcohol.  Kind of syrupy with a light carbonation.  Long finish.

Hazy hay in color with a this white head.  Aroma is sweet fruits, banana, candied malts, alcohol, oranges, and pears.  Thick and creamy body.  Flavor is sweet, fruits, caramel, yeast.  finish is sweet with a medium bitter bite.  Strong, rich, sweet, and delicious.

pours golden with minimal bubbly head.  aroma is spicy with some banana, pear, booze and candied sweetness and maybe a tiny floral hop note.  taste is initially tingly with strong sweetness and fruitiness.  it becomes very sweet by mid-taste finishing in a spicy booziness.  enjoyable stuff but not a whole lot to it.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Aged 3 - 5 years this is one of my favorite beers on earth.  Ive had it many times over the years, in the U.S. and in Belgium, in the bottle and on tap, fresh and aged.  There are variations over the years, but this is always a wonderfully complex, super rich, sweet and flavorful strong Belgian malt monster.  Fresh it can have an overly strong alcholol taste, not beautifully balanced like aged...but after 2 or 3 years it starts to mellow out with rich malts, sweet fruits like dates and raisins, caramel and cognac, oak and cane syrup.  Wonderful aroma of malts and sweet fruit; dark amber-orange color.  Comparative beers include aged (Swiss) Samichlaus and Thomas Hardys.  Whats bad is when you know it needs aging but you just cant wait, like Im doing now, drinking it too young, knowing its so much better later, but ooooh, its also so good now!
Pours a pretty amber color with a 1 finger white head. Aroma of fruit and some alcohol .Yeasty and Fruity with a nice alcohol warming. Very complex and full bodied. Beautiful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2008 495yen 11.6oz 2005 bottle from Takanaya liquor in Tokyo. Pours a light amber color with little head, and microscopic cloud of white floaters if you look closely in the light.  Clean aroma of orange and some other fruitiness.   Wonderful mild sweet flavor, with the subtleness of orange peel bitterness in the finish.  Mild and spectacular. I would describe it as a grande fermented orange.  Alchohol is well hidden.  I love it.  Good by itself, or with anything.  Must buy more for storage and special events.  I know Im rating it much higher than others and I dont care.  This is great!  4.6 is probably too low. 10,3,9,5,19:4.6
1/10/07:  Tried again a Churchills side-by-side with the reserva after trying a darkness.  The Darkness was much, much better.  This beer tasted a little bandaid  at first, but then I think this is more an orange spicy flavor associated with the yeast and the beer.  Leans sweet and nice. 7,3,8,3,17: 3.8
Averaged the two ratings

2006 bottle. A gusher. Lost a few ounces before it got it to the glass. Once in, hazy apricot with a huge layer of frothy milk white head, settling in sticky lumps. Rich, stewed fruit aroma, mint, menthol, pears. Alcohol vapor is very present, but in a rather alluring, concentrated way--like whisky. That translates in a pretty direct way to the flavor: the strength is quite apparent, but the flavor concentration is equally strong. Leathery dried fruit, a nice full bitter bite. Yeasty, herbal. Very bright, but not aggressively bubbly. (Apart from the initial bottle opening.) This continued to get more interesting as it warmed, even starting from just barely cool. A sipping beer. A beer to meditate on. Yum. Thanks so much Fin for the bottle!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2008 Pours hazy orange.  no floaters in mine.  Light head and little lacing.   Aroma is a light lemon and malts.  Very sweet on the mouth feel.
Bottle from the raleigh times, nc

2006 Bottle in Duvel glass.  Pours slightly hazy orange with big orange-tinted, lasting head and lace.  Some floaters.  Mild aroma of tart lemon, bread, and malt and some alcohol.  Sweet flavors of honey, candy sugar, then mild tartness with a dry bite in the finish with slight lasting bitterness and alcohol.   Medium-full soft mouthfeel.  Very complex and delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2008 Man how is everything by De Dolle so good? Started off with a very nice pour, hazy thick amber with a thick creamy light tan head. The aroma was sweet, smelled like candy, had a very definitive dry vinous grape smell, exhibited noticeable wine characteristics, tart sharp acidic smell. The flavor was very sharp, warming from the alcohol, tasted like a dry white wine, a slight hopped character, sweetness, didnt really have the typical belgian earthiness, very sharp and acidic. The palate was very warming and dry with crisp carbonation and it went down dry and warm. I loved it.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2009 33cL Bottle. Aroma gurgle forth in lathers of sherry-tinted foam. Bathing the drinker in brandied bread-pudding, with golden raisins, spicy fig sauce, Australian cheddar, and an earthly delight of piquant yeast, bread crust and cracker. The voluminous silk foam sits atop a mildly hazed golden-amber liquor, percolating nicely. Explosive in the mouth, with an airy perfume of carbonation, shattering a cascade of perfect pale flavors throughout. Apple, cognac, watered down lychees and herbal citrus marinades, fresh and garden variety. Slightly warm and full of esters bordering on medicinal, yet staying this side of overbearing. Phenomenal texture with an evaporative quality, and a lingering pungent dryness that carries the smidgen of hops through with a bit of apple skin and grape seed. Exquisite and complex.

Bottle 2005 vintage. Pours cloudy dark orange with a fair amount of sediment floating around. Pretty nose. Like being in a confectionary shop. Lots of caramel sweetness. Nice balance on the palate of creamy and carbonation. Beautiful complexity of flavor. Spicy sweetness. Rich malt. Caramel, toffee, raisins, candied fruits. A bit of yeasty sourness develops. For all the sweetness, it finishes rather dry.

A sweet sticky beer with a dominante alchol character perfect fro cold winter nights. Dense in flavour with rich caramel malts, figs, honey, oak, mollasses and rich fruit cake.  As the complex flavours swirl in the mouth a sublte mulled wine and port flavours sping to life. A gorgeous sooth mouthfeel giving a sweet-dry finIsh.  I will need to try the reserver 2000! This is amazing

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2008 Rerate, 11.6oz bottle, 1996 (?) vintage, at the Brick.  Pours a murky, dark orangish-brown color; huge, textured, medium-bubbled khaki head with solid retention and lacing; more retention and this would be perfect.  Enormous, generous nose: honey, dried fruits, lightly toasted oak and wood; just dense, viscous, restrained malty sweetness; nowhere near as sweet as when fresh; well-integrated dry caramel presence from the oxidation, but even this seems alive; hints of apples and alcohol at the edges.  Full mouthfeel: gorgeous balance between the dry caramel notes, dense dried fruits and honey, and the balancing presence of the acidity; gorgeous presence in the mouth, such that I went through this like pilsener; layer upon layers of stacked honeyed maltiness, brown sugar, and cotton candy, with sweet caramel at the perimeter; lively carbonation; soft edges; a beautifully aged beer.  Ali wants me to buy a fresh case of this and bury it.  Lengthy finish: honey, toasted malts, red fruits, and cereal.  9.4.9.5.17=4.4

11.6oz bottle.  Pours a murky, orangish-apricot color; off-white head with minimal retention.  Dense, apricot and honey aroma; dried fruits and yeast.  Full, sugary mouthfeel: apricots, honey, and yeast in a dense pot of goodness, erring on the side of immense density and sweetness; great dessert beer, but just a little too much of everything.  Lengthy, sugar and honey finish, coating ones mouth. 8.3.8.4.14=3.7

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2014 clowdy orange colour ... big foam head ... lots of fizzy bubbles ... rich orange peel nose ... Little cloves ... deep and rich and smooth.... 3.6  1996 Bottle Deep brown ... sour woody nose ... sweet very fruity little woody sour ... plums and raisins ... tart cherry 3.6   2008 Bottle at home 20.11.09 ... bit of a gusher ... copper big white short lived foam head ... lots of detritus ... sweet rich fruit peel nose ... solid and rich ... little bitterness .. but a deep rich spicy fruit... i think 3.6 is pretty much spot on

bottle at NWAF ... golden hazy amber ... thin white head ... sweet fruits ... soft yeast ... soft banna nose ... juicy fruits ... big sweetenss ... juicy orange and  banana ... soft spice ... juicy frutis ... soft floralnes... lovel ... 3.9
actually really rich mellow sweet and fruity 4.1

 bottle at home .. copper ... thin white lacing ... soft sweet fruits ... soft floral sweet ...big juicy raisins ... soft fruits ... big sweet raisins ... juicy fruitss ... big rasisn and candi suger 4.0
11.6 Bottle. Pours hazy golden color with small white headand lots of yeast floates. It has a whiskey and sweet aroma. Has a complex, malt and sweet taste with a dry finish.

Smells kinda like whiskey & rum; very alcoholic.  Hardcore belgian nose, some butterscotch.  Pours a hazy clover honey, no head whatsoever.  Tons of yeastmen floating about like sea-monkeys.  Very sweet flavor with hints of dried fruit and butterscotch topping.  Not much acidity, sweet peppery bready finish.  The medium body is syrupy and soft.  Too sweet and alcoholic for my palate.

Bottle, 33 cl. Tasted last on 13 febr. 07. 
But see now my notes. 
Dark amber color with good head. Aroma fruits, caramel, and alcohol. Full bodied. Taste is complex malt, sweetness (caramel, honey?), and alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2007 This is a difficult beer to rate, as different bottlings yield drastically different results.  Three different years:

2004 - Nice, rich flavor, dominated by sweet apples.  Pleasant, but not very complex and quite sweet.

2005 - Hazy apricot pour, sometimes with a massive head.  God, it is so soft and chewy, it is just to die for.  Red wine, apples, oak, vanilla, caramel, banana, pear, candy sugar, AMAZING.  Rich, creamy, smooth, haunting.  Profoundly majestic and almost perfect.

2006 - Has some characteristics of the 2005 but the bottle I had was thin and overly carbonated.  Lost alot on these merits, as the 2005s mouthfeel was so much of what made it beautiful.  Hopefully, it will improve with some age.

Sticky sugar and alcohol.  Light fruity peach flavor counteracted by dense candi sugar.  Very well hidden alcohol considering the abv.  Definitely a cheese flavor in there, maybe a provolone or romano.  The aroma is mindblowing, but the flavor is dominated by that candi sugar in the same way as a the tripels I dont care for.  I can see how this turns into the beauty that is the 2000 Reserva, but this isnt quite it.

Bottle.  Thanks to either Mcbackus or the Perfect 10 trade.  Pours very hazy, dark orange, with a big white, long lasting head. The aroma is musty sour fruit with caramel.  Flavor is lightly sweet with dates and plums, molasses and apples.  There is a fair amount of complexity to this one and I had a tough time placing all the flavors, I also noted caramel but I may have been stretching since I cant really recall that flavor now.  Creamy medium mouth feel and solid carbonation.  Not bad.

Holy criminy!  This is a thick, rich ale that doesnt pull any punches or try to cleverly hide its ABV.  You get all 12% with that delicious yeasty flavor that these folks seem to have mastered.  Absolutely delicious, tauntingly dangerous.

A wonderfull brew with taste evolution.
I had a vertical beer tasting of 8 different years on the same day. I had 8 different tasts. Since that day this is one of my favorites

Bottle, 1996 vintage, at the Kulminator, Antwerp.  Beautiful amber with a two-finger, big-bubbled white head.  Huge bouquet here in the nose - very malt-centric and almost reminiscent of a barleywine, no doubt because of its age.  Toffee, caramel are the main components as well as a slight spice presence in clove and maybe even some citrus. It has a sweetness that, again, reminds of good barleywines as well as a slight alcohol note.  Taste is a lesson in balance - definitely a testament to the age on this one.  Assertive malt is rounded off by a dark fruitiness, spiked with spice notes and a very slight alcohol.  Caramel, toffee, but light and fragrant instead of cloying and overwhelming - sweet but not annoyingly so. Slight sour note in the finish, with a sweet and long lingering aftertaste. Very, very slight metallic component as it warms. The palate here is really interesting and shows the most change because of the 10+ years of age on this one.  It still retains high carbonation but is very delicate and light on the tongue - the beer has definitely thinned out in the cellar, but the thinning is pleasurable and interesting instead of rendering the brew insipid or watery.  This is really good - a day after the Westys, still this is nothing like Ive ever experienced.

Saaaweeeeettt!   Hazy, golden amber color.  Two finger white head that took a while to dissipate.  Flavored immensely by the candi sugar with a light malt, somewhat yeasty flavor.   I love it.  Alcohol ever so slightly present.  Mmmmm Mmmmmmm good!

Very similar to Stille Nacht Special Reserva 2005; very, very similar, except the flavors were not as distinct.  Cloudy amber with giant head that wilted away after about 10 minutes.  Aroma of yeast, malt, grapes, and wine.  Flavor was similar and very crisp.  Somewhat dry on the finish this was very unique and fun to drink.  The alcohol was not noticeable until after the second bottle.

Bottle. Cap says 2005. Pours hazy amber/gold with a small beige head. Aroma is potent ripe fruit, pears, cherries, raisins, wine-esque notes, a bit of hops, and sweet maltiness. Flavor is very sweet, full of raisins, and the stong fruity notes as well. Finishes very warm from the alcohol and sweet fruits linger. Very interesting beer.

Pours a rich copper with lots of particulate matter. a thin dense white head.  Kind of off putting, but the nose is nice.  Creamy caramel, alcohol, orange, cloves.  Like a creamsickle flavored barleywine, only well done, and not as shitty as that sounds.  Well balanced.  On the palate this is thick and sticky.  a real sipper.  Some alcohol burn.  A bit of that Belgian funk comes in fairly strong although its over a big ass alcohol, orange, and herbal front.  This balances some very big sweetness, though the caramel is less so present.  Some major diacetyl, but here it works.  I mean, this is just a wall of fucking flavor.  Maybe a hint of coriander.  Deifnitely tangerine peel finish and coriander(?) with alcohol coming on strong in the triple sec aftertaste.  Big hops, big malt, big alcohol.  quite a brew!
Medium amber with a thick body.  Lots of spices on the nose but a wonderfully sweet malt body with some more spice.

Beer sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits Friday evening beer tasting. Pours an medium amber topped with a thick, quickly disappearing head. Very good lacing. Aroma is of sweet caramel, smoked pork, citrus of lemon peel, and some pine. Taste of sweet and sour malt with a slight raisin aftertaste. More of a barley wine than a Belgian strong ale.

Bottle, 2005 vintage, poured a cloudy pale orange with a nice white head.  Very complex aromam, stone fruits, yeast, spice and a bit of earthy hops.  very sweet flavor balanced nicely with spicy qualities of the esters and phenols.  Excellent mouthfeel, nice a tart with a crisp refreshing qualiy.  A very nice beer and I still cant believe its 12%.  You cant taste it or smell it, but you sure feel it.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 Pours nice dark gold color.  Looks rather unassuming.  Then you smell it and realize what your in for.  Taste is huge, so many things going on, light fruit, pears, grape, spice, exotic fruits.  Too much to describe.  I absolutely love this beer.  Amazing big and complex flavor.  One of my favorite belgians.  I think this is under rated.

This beer poured a peachy/gold color. Very nice. The head also sticks around for a little while, which is great. The beer smelled of fruits, some light summer fruits such as pears, and peaches. The ABV gives a nice bite. What a great beer. It warms you up and this is April 14th. I also live in Georgia so there is no need for the warmth, but I still appreciate the ABV. What a well-rounded beer.

(Bottle @ t Brugs Beertje, bottled 2005): Pours a golden fizzy, dark yellow color.  Humungeous head, lasting, white.  Hoppy grapey bitter aroma, fresh-lots of grape.  Coriander, fresh bitng taste, sour, wine-ish.  Can taste some of the alcohol, warming.  Warming up, a more fruity aroma, fruit punch.  Also more fruit punchy taste.

11.2oz 2006 bottle from Kingdom Liquors in Brandon. Pours a hazy blonde with orange highlights with a large long lasting white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt, alcohol, yeast spiciness, herbal hops, and a little acidity at the end. Flavor explodes with sweet malt, exotic fruit, alcohol, spice, a good solid bitterness, and a little tartness. Full mouthfeel that finishes dry, which I think was due to the high hopping rate and wild yeast. I cant wait to see what aging will do for this beer.

The aroma was sweet candy and a light bit of DMS (corn) character. Alcohol wafted from the dense head, and as the head fell a nice caramel presence emerged. Light Belgian spice filled the aroma as did just a hint of diacetyl. The beer poured into the Oerbier tulip golden with some particulates and a white frothy head that retreated slowly and laced the glass. The flavor was malty and fruity and well done. The fruit was exotic and had mango and papaya with some green raisins. The flavor had a sweet nature which was candy and caramel, but was nipped in the bud by alcohol and a substantial enough bittering and alcohol presence to steer the direction of the beer toward dry. Some well achieved Belgian yeast spice presence was notable as well. The finish was dry with lasting Belgian yeast spice and fruit character long and pleasantly into the aftertaste and beyond. The body was medium full and with the high carbonation was a bit creamy in the mouthfeel. The alcohol presence after consumption was extremely high and although the finish was dry the sweet impression lasted for days. A really interesting and great beer in the flavor. 11.6 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle at Kulminator, 2005 vintage. Beatifull, hazy, orange color and a growing (even after minutes) cremé head with effervescent carbonatation. Enormous, huge flavor attack. Peaches, oranges, amaretto, sweet, syruppy, almost jelly maltiness nad a very slight alcohol burn. Massive. Full MF, explosive and filling, warming flavor. Not cloying at all and subrepticious at 12%. Fruity orangey aroma, although good, doesn´t matches the rest of the beer. Outstanding. The punch of flavor more than compensates all other shortcomings.

Small bottle, pours dark gold with amber, some yeast and dry white wine sour scents, bees honey with wax scents, my uncle was a Apiarist (Bee Keeper), this beer reminds me of times I was in his warehouse helping him process the honey, there are caramel sweet fragrances, pale malt and bread fragrances, the alcohol is in behind all of these fragrances barely noticeable to my nose, lots of sweet flavor with a tartness on the tongue, bitterness in the mouth, some caramel and pale malt flavors, the alcohol is stronger on the palate then in the nose, felt the alcohol flow down my throat.  I thought the ale was a little to sweet, needed more bitterness or malt taste to balance the sweet, nice mouth feel, this is definitely a Winter Warmer drink.

Thanks to RagallachMC for the bonus bottle. Hazy orange with an overflowing head. Aroma of tart plums and grapes. Tangy, warm taste; somewhat vinous. Tongue  biting bitterness. Wish this wasnt so expensive in America, because its so very fine!

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 bottled. Ive been waiting a good 10, maybe even 15 minutes for the head to settle. Hmph. Wonderful bright hazy orange - sort of glowing - with a patient white head. The wait was worth it! I got so lost in the aroma, I dipped my nose in by mistake. Getting that close isnt necessary - perfectly pleasant aroma of oranges and spices, caramel and cream. Taste (and texture) is reminiscent of dreamsicles. Spicy cloves and sweet oranges. Well balanced. Soooooooo good.

(33cl bottle) Purchased through the Bieropholie Private Imports. Pours a medium, lofty almond-coloured head and a cloudy, orange, sediment-filled body. Nose is very citrus, peppery and alcoholic. Flavour is unbalanced with layers of extra malt. Very sweet. Very Seville orange marmalade and a wave of overpowering malt. Decent but leaning too far in the one dimensional category.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2009 (Bottle, vintage from 2000) Pours clear dark amber. Vinous, medium sour and acid aroma with red berries and apple vinegar. Well balanced malty sweetness. Pretty deep and complex. Fruity notes with some citric acid.  Hints of cheese, vanilla and almond paste. The flavour is well balanced  between the sweet and acid. Vinous with notes of fruits and berries, mostly cherries but also some apple vinegar. Really Flemish sour like. Very different frome a fresh Stille Nacht. Soft, silky and rather smooth mouthfeel. A bit dryish finish. Good body and the sourness always staying within the frame. Lovely.

This is a version 2003 and now its November 2005. Its a warm golden beer with a lot of chunky sediment, making me think of snow. The aroma is sweet and fruity, and the flavour is sweet with notes of candy Sugar, caramel, fruit like peach and citrus and quite a bit of alcohol, that is slightly burning. Its harmonic and nice, but with a bit of edges...

11.2 oz bottle sampled at "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" Blind Tasting 07.  Clear orange body with some floaties underneath a fizzy white head.  Moderately malty aroma, bread, carmel, raisin, cherry, oak, brown sugar, allspice, and bourbony alcohol.  Sweet flavors, brown sugar, all pear, red fruit,  strong flavors, doughy, tasty .... and then it gets worse, the alcohol becomes strong and its losing points.  Heavy alcohol finish.  Hmm, Ill be back to sample this again.

bottle from Premier Gourmet. Shared with Nice Guy Doug. Was waiting for the right time to enjoy this one. 2am on a Tuesday night with my severly drunken tenant was not what I had in mind. However, really enjoyed this. Surprsied when I read the ABV here. Very smooth, crisp. Expecting a keg of this @ Coles today. wil rerate.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2007 Bottled at Bier Circus, Brussels.
Smells like you have entered an enchanted forest. Pine, moss, busy gnomes shuffling around.
A barley wine vinous feeling. Rahter easy-drinking but with a seasonal warmth. Some Christmas spices around the edge of this one, but, for once, it does not cover the strength of the beer. Opens up as it warms up. I can see why this has been proclaimed a great beer!

2005 bottle. Pours cloudy amber with a good head that never really went away.  Aroma was of fruits, caramel, and a little alcohol.  Flavors include fruits, malt, sweetness (caramel, honey?), and alcohol.  This beer is full bodied and is very enjoyable to the palate.  I am looking forward to tasting this again in a couple of years to see if it ages like I think it may.  Right now it is a very good Belgian ale.

2006 bottle:  Many of the characteristics of the 2005 are found in the 2006, however the 2006 version is not as well balanced as the previous year.  There is more of an alcohol burn and less in terms of the complexity of flavors.  I will lay a couple down and try again later.

Pours into a tulip cloudy orange with a monstrous beige head.  Nice, fruity aroma.  Taste is smooth and fruity with the 12% masked incredibly well.  This is quite an exceptional and well balanced beer.
2006 Bottle:  Hazy orange colored pour with a never ending head.  Sweet, spicy nose with a nice spicy, sweet, malty finish.

Extreme gusher on pouring and apricot color is full of sediment and is completely murky with a totally retained egg white head.  Aroma is of honey and pears.  Flavor is quite a melody.  Flavor is initially lightly sweet and earthy, then sharply spicy and the finish is a bit like candy.  This is a very intriguing and enjoyable beer.  The mouthfeel is absolutely perfect as if the brewers have achieved a molecular composition of the beer that is found in only the most wonderful Belgian Ales.  Delightful.

Reminded me of a carmel apple with alcohol.  What an aroma for this masterpiece, apples, honey, that spicey/yeasty smell.  This is a great beer, full of flavor that makes your mouth water after taking the first sip.  Strong, so you cant take too many.  Very sweet if young, so let some sleep for a while.

Huge pears in the nose, some alcohol. Very drinkable and light for 12%. Nice body, smoothe and crisp palate. Alcohol is hidden exceedingly well. Apple flavor with lighter fruits like pear, grapes. Finishes tart, slightly sour.

Bottle. [Vintage 2006] Incredible thick foamy white head that mostly lasted. Excellent lacing. Body was cloudy with a pale hazy amber hue. Aroma was fruit, caramel, liquorish, yeast, nutty, cinnamon, orange, spicy. Full bodied with a texture with some alcoholic notes to be felt in mouth. Average carbonation. Flavor was moderated sweet, with some bitter hoppy notes to balance it. Slightly sharp alcoholic finish, that lingers in mouth for a long time. Impressive beer, now I want to try the Stille Nache Reserva 2000 even more. Unfortunately I am properly not going to be that lucky. Still this was a great encounter and one I am looking forward to redoing soon.

2006 Bottle. Aroma is hops and pears. Very much pears. Some sweetness. Darker fruits, figs and plums, come out as it warms. Extremely hazy dark amber with huge white head. Flavor is fruit, alcohol, some dark malt hints. Sweet but balanced. Complex fruityness- peaches are there along with plums and figs. Very nice creamy but slightly sharp palate. Well balanced and drinkable for the abv.
Amber colour, medium white head. Floral and fruity aroma, orange peels, coriander, apple, alcohol. Orange flavour, sweet, malty coffe finish.

Dark fruits and alcohol dominate the aroma.Pours a very murky brownish orange with no head to speak of.Caramel malts,dark fruits and alcohol stand out in the flavors.Full mouthfeel with a big sweet finish.

11.6oz - 2004 Edition; Large bubbles form a fleeting head over a cloudy, yellow/orange liquid.  Starch on the nose, like cooked pasta.  Ripping alcohol burn, like a bad Scotch Ale, on the front, and it doesnt change much after that.  Not for me.

sampled at blind "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07. pours clear amber-orange with small white head. nose is toated nuts, cereal, plum, and hints of bourbon. flavor is pretty sweet, toasted notes, brown sugar, cookie, and not balanced well at all.

Sampled at Issacs . Cloudy orange pour no real head to speak of but there was serious carbonation. Fruity alcohol aroma, possible sour apple/ apricot. Candy/ fruity flavor that is not overly done. A decent brew.

What have they done to this wonderful beer? It used to be a brown-reddish one and now I watched amazed while poring a golden apricot beer. It still pus a good head that lingers for a while, but aroma and taste has many differences.
Ill rate the 2004 vintage. I find a like champagne smell, with orange and vanilla, where I used to find chocolate, dark fruits, dates, prunes and honey.
In the mouth, I notice sherry wine, oranges, coriander, hints of something like clove or maybe cardamom, caramel, peachs and vanilla. I used to notice ind the dark versions raisins, chocolate, honey, and it was so think that reminded me of a cake.
Its a great and complex beer yet, and probably will be better with age, but... please, brink back the old Stille Nacht, one of the few beers I would have rated in the top.

19/2-2007 (vintage 2005)Cloudy golden yellow/pale with a "Dolle"-thick and creamy head. Ekstremly lively in the glass. Caramel, cane sugar, hops, fruit, malt and spices. Its complex and full bodied with a really high carbonation.

Hazey, golden pale with a small white head. The aroma is golden raisins, toffee, tea, sweet and herbal. The flavor is tea, tobacco, apple pie, candi sugar and pepper. Medium/full body with high carbonation, prickly and effervescent.

Pours a cloudy orange brown.  Nice orange peel, candi sugar sweetness with hints of ripe fruit on the nose.   Mouthfeel is very creamy and shows off the orange peel citrus character as well as a little piney floral bite to balance out the light candi sugar maltiness.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 Cloudy straw colored pour with a white foamy head, fair amount of floties.  Nose is fruity, spicy, and and slightlyfunky.  Lightbodied and refreshing mouthfeel.  Flavor is a bit tart and spicy followed by slightly swwet fruitiness.

Tart aroma of stone fruit and spice, along with some must and yeast. A hazy orange apricot color with no head. It starts slightly sweet, develops a thinnish stone fruit flavor, and suddenly there is a burst of caramel sweetness. Then there is citrus peel, and the finish is malt accompanied by hop. The mouthfeel is medium but quickly thins. The alcohol does not really show until the long finish. Then it becomes noticeable in the esophagus.
12% is surprising.  However, it does make sense with the sugar taste present in the beer.  It was shockingly sweet at the beginning.  Age may definitely help here.

Pours a hazy golden color with a surprisingly thin head for a Belgian beer.  Aroma smells fruity with notes of green apple and sweet malt.  Taste is more of the same with a good amount of green apple and other bright/tart fruits.  A lot of hot alcohol and an abundance of residual sugars remain.  Eh.  This beer is kind of a mess.  It just seems like the major flavor components are very disjointed at this point.  As it warms it becomes even more cloying and hot.  It tastes like they just mixed some wort, cider, and vodka together.  Im not even going to finish this one, and I havent done that in a long time.

The first sip is saccharine. The second is smoother and somewhat more complex. From there on the tastebuds are duly warmed and respond merrily to this brews orchestra of peppercorn blend, ascorbic acid, coriander, key lime zest, fresh caramel...and a few notes that defy description. An unquestionably top-tier Belgian strong.

Bottle, Spec Brew 2005 on white cap.  Slightly cloudy light orange-brown color with white head.  A hint of tart funk in the aroma along with some spice, but the overall impression is one of sweetness, which becomes stronger as the beer warms.  Palate is medium-thin and well-carbonated.  Taste is a play between the tart funk and the sweetness, and the sweetness and spice win out, but the taste never even approaches cloying.  Doesnt even taste anything near 12%.  Would like it funkier, but this is still very drinkable.

Pours a Hazy peach with a quick qispy white head.   Smells of cinnamon, apples, barnyard and cloves.  Tastes sticky sweet.  Oh yeah!  Theres alcohol front and center on this one.  A certain winter warmer.  Nice and spicy.  I wonder how this one is when served at warmer temperatures?  This one has a lot of promise with aging.  Shame I have to go all the way to Florida to get this beer.

Bottle.  A cloudy orange swirl of a pour.  Small white head that was quick to depart.  No lacing.  Aroma of simple surgars, grapes, and citrus.  It is an interesting balance of acidity and sweetness.  Round fruit flavors combine with the sharpness of citrus, clove and alcohol.  It isnt heavy.  It is spicy.  It is quite good.  (Purchase from Johns in Iowa City)

Bottle. pours a hazy bronze hue with floaties and a small white head that fades quickly. The aroma is complex and citrusy sweet. Notes of pineapple, cloves, leaves, dough, are among the plethora of scents. The mouthfeel is on the lighter side for an ale of this alcohol strength. Plenty of complex citrus notes and a fair level of malty sweetness make up the body. A bit of cloves, honey, coriander, hickory, mostly slightly acidic, spiced flavors are here. This is a pretty good treat, maybe not as dense as Id like a winter brew to be. Jeez, Im just nitpicking now. Excellent beer, well done.

Pours with a thin white, creamy head. Cloudy, brown/tan coloring. Aroma of apples, peaches, and white grapes. Sweet flavor of similar fruits, brown sugar, and caramel, with an alcoholic warmth. Spectacular, excellent beer.

Bottle (2005 version) at home - in the glas right now !! It comes with at big head - a very lively beer - really wanted to get out of the bottle.... Unclear amber/ brown - big white head. Aroma: Spicy fruity, yeast, pepper. Taste: Malty, fruity, sweet, yeast, brown sugar, pepper, licorice, and lots more. I think the 12% alcohol just shows in the finish -  sharp and slight burning, but still a very nice and pleasant beer !!

Spec Brew 2005.  Appearance is hazy orange with a pretty good white head.  Aroma of spice, yeast, citrus, fruit, and banana.  Very nice flavor of spice, dark fruit, banana, raisin, sweet malt, and fig.  Awesome belgian.

Bottle:  Hazy orange with a small, fizzy white head.  Nose is very fruity and sweet with plenty of citrus.  Taste is sweet from fruit, citrus, apple cider?, raison, and caramels.  Sweet, yet tart.  Syrupy on the way down with a light alcohol presence.  Overall I was pleased.  Thanks Bert!

NorCal tasting Jan 07 - Wow this was sweet. A fantastic after dinner beer, this can be sipped forever. Definitely not for those who dont like sweet beers. An aroma of sweet fruits, brown sugar and whiskey. Appearance was burnt orange color and hazy with a huge head. A fantastic mouthfeel full of soft creaminess.
