Flavors were sweet, sweet and more sweetness! In fact I believe I have found my threshold on how sweet a beer can be before I turn against it. This was it. Strong alcohol taste on the finish. Incredible beer that deftly balances between being almost a perfect beer and a cloying piece of junk.

11.6 oz Bottle-2005 special brew ( on cap). Poured a cloudy orange color w/no head & moderate lacing. Classic Belgian aroma. Had a few floaties in the glass. Strong, sweet, floral, fruity aroma. Sweet, cotton candy flavor w/traces of citrus, banana, dates, apricots, figs, raisins & spice. Very good, not quite as good as the Reserva 2005, but close. Long smooth finish.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2007 similar to oerbier in appearance, but a bit lighter which kinda makes it look a little disgusting.  such a yeast slushie/suspension, despite my best attempts to decant.  served too cold, but still tons of aroma. apple and pear rinds. caramel. similar to oerbier in taste but quite a bit sweeter.  tons of candi sugar, though for once i actually detect a ton of flavoring hop presence balancing it out.  maybe a bit underattenuated, though at an impressive 12% those yeast sure did their best.  alcohol hidden tremendously well.  i guess the description given for the beer is pretty spot on: bittering hops and acidity are well balanced and noted..  de dolle makes some pretty awesome, complex beers.  too bad theyre $4 a bottle.  though maybe thats why i waste so much time actually tasting their beers.  anyways, happy birthday to me, im going out.  get laid or bust.... RERATE: thanks cmubeerman for the altered yeast version.  ridiculously candy sweet aroma.  banana esters, bready.  some tartness way into the finish.  gonna throw in coriander.  really good.

Pours to a cloudy, dried apricot color.    Aroma is a heavy slathering of caramel, banana and rum.  Tastes much the same with a powerful but approachable sweetness coating everything.  Cotton candy, more banana, apple.  Nearly hidden spice flavors, less hidden than its alcohol which I hardly noticed until it was gone, at which point I couldnt help but notice it.  Its a tower of thick gooey sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Pours deep, cloudy orange.  Aroma is heavily sweet.  Flavor is also very sweet.  Tastes like honey and fruit, apples mostly.  Good in small doses.  12 oz is too much.  Alcohol is fairly well concealed, but the mouthfeel doesnt do much for me overall.  Induced a headache, but I cant knock it points for that, cuz I think that was on its way anyhow.  Not bad, not worth $5 and I cant see how wine barrel aging (for the Reserva) would make this better....  I dont get the big deal about this one.

Pours a murky orange with a swirling head.   Sediments floating even after holding a 1/2" in bottle.  Scent of vanilla and candy sugar.  This is possibly the sweetest beer I have tried.  I noticed some honey, butterscotch, orange, peach cobbler, alcohol, and a dry bitterness.  Full bodied beer, syrupy and very sticky.  Tongue tantilizing spices linger.  An intersting ale to say the least.

#800 -  Pours deep copper with a tremendous amount of carbonation feeding the frothy off-white head.  The aroma is spicy and effervescent with Belgium earthiness and sweet thick malt.  The beer is medium bodied and quite slick when it is not eclipsed by the enormous amount of carbonation.  The taste begins with thick candied malt that is joined by vineous traits and smooth nectar fruits.  The sharpness from the carbonation offsets and compliments the thick smoothness of the flavors.  The finish intensifies the carbonation and the alcohol becomes more pronounced, but still doesnt seem like it is 12%.  There is also some sharper light fruit tastes and a spicy bite on the finish.  Great beer that with just a little less carbonation would have been over the top wonderful.   Big thumbs up for this "hitting a milesone" beer.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 Bottle brought back from Belgium. Poured an orange brown, with a huge head.  Aroma of yeast, clove, dark fruit, and alcohol.  Was a pleasant surprise.  Huge sweet flavors; but not overpowering.  Balanced by the complexity in the beer; dark fruit, hops, alcohol, spice, yeast.  Some warming on the finish.  Lingering aftertaste of belgianish yeast.  Will have again.

Bottle 2003 at Dilly Deli.  Poured reddish brown color with a huge fizzy head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex dark fruit and yeasty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium fruity balanced flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of long duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a standout beer

2005 Bottle; Nose of sugary sweetness, cloves, and yeastiness; very cloudy yellow gold with a huge, long-lasting yellow head; flavors show tartness, bananas, cloves, anda little alcohol in the medium body, the alcohol warmth lasting to the finish.

2006 bottle at Paters Vaetje, Antwerpen. Cloudy golden with a modest head. Alcoholic and fruity aroma. Flavours are more complex, fruity, warming alcohol, well-balanced, never too sweet. Well-carbonated, full body. Full of potential, but better a little aged?

2006 Bottle, my 75th Belgian.  Aroma of hearty yeast, cloves, lemon, light citrus, light honey, touch of green apple.  Beautiful rocky lacing tan head on a richly carbonated golden-amber body, with little chunks of sediment floating happily by.  Taste is all about the Belgian yeast and candy sugar with strong warming alcohol, super-full body, syrupy orange flavor, caramel, honey.  Dry yeasty aftertaste.  Well-crafted with De Dolles fingerprints all over it.  Oh how I love this brewer!

11.2 oz bottle from Sams in Chicago. Hazy pale golden colour with a mostly diminishing frothy off-white head. Pineapple, citrus peel, yeasty, and candy sugar aroma with light alcohol notes. Sweet orange, grapefruit, candy sugar, yeasty, and alcohol flavours, finishing with a light dry tartness plus more alcohol. Full bodied, warming and dry mouthfeel, but easy drinking for the alcohol level. A tasty Christmas Eve treat.

Bottle. Hazy yellow with white fluffy head. The smell of yeast, bananas, funk, corriander, and other spices. Some alcohol flavors were also noted. The taste was yeasted and smooth with the above flavors. Very easy drinking flavorful beer.

This is the 2005 version with the white cap marked SPEC BREW 2005. It is the regular Stille Nacht bumped up to 12% abv(from 8%) not to be confused with the Special Reserva 2005, which is the barrel aged version with a yellow cap and background colors.
Appears a hazy, dense orange with a creamy white head that quickly fades into a film and collar. Hearty particles are suspended throughout.
Smell is of oak, vanilla, light funk, golden raisins, tart apples, brown sugar, mild peach...very addictive.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas in a slightly sweet/tart mix that makes me want to run out and buy this up whenever I see it.
Mouthfeel is of sweetness up front but superbly balanced all in a medium, funkadelic mix.
Dont be shy, friends. Do this brew. Embrace it. Life is good and De Dolle Stille Nacht is a suppliment for the long, joyous journey.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2007 Pours deep gold into a tulip.  Head quickly subsides to skim rim.  Sweet caramel and pit fruit aromas.  Quite sweet -- would make an excellent apertif; but also stands well alone.  Belgian strong is definitely a wide category...

Bottle of 2005 version pours deep blonde w/ a small head w/ great retention.  Candy sugar sweetness in the aroma and in the finish.  An excellent beer.  Overly sweet w/ alcohol spice in the finish.  Best Belgian brew rated to date.

Pours a hazy golden-brown color with a rapidly dissipating head.  Some light bubbles remain on the surface.  Sweet malty and yeasty aroma with dried fruits (dates, raisins, cherries), fresh fruits (apples, pears... a hint of pineapple), spices (coriander, nutmeg).  Huge sweet malty/yeasty flavors with more fruitiness than in the aroma:  fresh apples, fresh pears, dried dates and cherries, heavy spiciness (coriander, nutmeg, clove), and a hint of alcohol--almost goes unnoticed.  The alcohol just intensifies the flavors and gives the beer a serious punch, contributing to its overall hugeness.  Soft, velvety, creamy mouthfeel with a dry hop-laden alcoholic finish.  A real gem.

Bottle from trade with Boutip. Thanks Phil! Pours a hazy orangish amber color with a fair size off white head. Aroma of yeast, apricot and hops. Taste is sweet and malty. Has a complex finish of hops and fermented fruit. A very nice beer.

Glorious light amber color.  Botrytised, honey aroma reminiscent of sherry or a late harvest desert wine.  Very intense, thick, and rich.  Honey, maple, and light hops flavors.  The sweetness is pleasant but becomes slightly cloying.  The bitterness at the end could be less, but is somewhat refreshing after the many sweet flavors.  This would be best as a desert beer served in small quantities due to its intensity and sweetness.  A great beer for wine lovers.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 Very enjoyable, smooth velvety on the slide, with a well hidden alcohol...definitely recommended..just a little too sweet
Very vinous aroma, with just a hint of sherry.  Complex flavor with elements of maple syrup and honey and a steak of herbal hops.

From bottle: very good beer, extreamly complex, dirty orange with loads of yeast floting, huge staying head with fantastic lacing, very thick and full bodied, almost like a milkshake, the aroma is very yeasty, bready, somewhat lemony, some banana, nuts and cloves, the flavor is fruity, sweet caramel and sour, spicy and yeasty, some warming alcohol, some bitterness, pretty dry finish. The perfect christmas beer.

This is a fantastic beer! Having said that, it is also a very dirty looking beer and its murky and looks like filtered dishwater with a orange hue. But as soon as the fantastic aroma of yeast, mellow fruits, cloves and coriander tickels the nose, you no longer pay any attention to the flaws in the appearence. The flavour is full of spices - mostly cloves - and it has a malty and fruity body thats well balanced by the lingering bitterness. It ends quite dry and with a slight sour tang and as with all De Dolle beers, its very drinkable due to the relative light feel. Its a very interesting and balanced beer. And it bears close resemblance to my homebrewed Christmas beer...

11.6 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy honey gold with a thin head that was quickly chased away. Quite aromatic with lots of barrel syrup, yeast, citrus, and sweet malt. The flavor is sugary sweet with no noticeable bitterness to offset the sweetness. I like sweet beers, but I didnt care for it in this one. Heavy alcohol burn. Im glad I tried it, but this one was not my cup of tea.
33 cL bottle. Pours orange colour with long lasting head. Strong smell and taste of alcohol and yeast with some spice notes beneath. Sweet and round moutfull. Strong alcoholic aftertaste.

Bottle, vintage 2005. Cloudy amber with an off white head. Aroma of syrup, caramel, cellar, citrus, raisins, malt, yeast and alcohol. Sweet flavour with lots of warmth going down. Again a touch of syrup with citrus, caramel, nuts and the ever present alcohol, which balances nicely between pleasant and too much. The older this beer gets; the better!

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2007 On tap at the Kerstbierfestival in Essen. Sweet, golden barley wine with healthy citrus notes. Aroma of oranges, mild orange and grapefruit in flavor, some bitterness to balance the alcohol. Wish it more a bit less sweet, a bit more bitter. But tasty.

RE-RATE July 17, 2007, with notes from a 22-year-old 33 cL bottle. Strange experience. Muddy brown with red highlights. Huge nose of port, sweet brandy, honey, lemons. Still some off-white head sticking around after more than two decades. Very sweet like tart apple candy, with this bizarre, smoky backdrop. I dont know why it was smoky, only that it definitely was--like smoked fruit and honey. Bizarre and tasty to me--it repulsed the non-geeky casual drinkers with whom I was traveling. Strong stuff. Only a touch musty in the back. Interesting experience.

Bottle (from Bitter Virtue, 2006 bottling). Fruity nose with coriander and lots of clovey alcohol. Intensely sweet in the mouth with hints of orangey hops and huge amounts of alcohol. The full on alcohol and sweetness werent really my thing. Leaving it a little longer to mellow may improve it but Im not sure it needed to be this strong.

33cl bottle. Pours a hazy orange colour. Fairly good lacing. Lilght carbonation. Strong alcohol yeast aroma with some spice notes. Sweet and syrupy flavour. Tastes like it is strong. OK, but not my favourite style. I actually didnt finish the bottle. Bought at Beer Paradise, Holstebro.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2006 2003 vintage from Bottletje, Oostende. Loved the label. Pours a hazy amber with very little head at all. Aroma is so strong of candy, but reveals some wonderful Christmas spices, toffee, rum and raison too. Flavour is so sweet and sticky, with some high bitterness levels and lots of yeast, fruits and alcohol. Sweet fruity warming finish. A special beer, but maybe just a touch too sweet.
Bottle: Poured a coppery brown with white head. Nice fruit aroma. Taste was slightly sweet but nice dry smoked oak aged malt, left with nice zing.

Pour is a very murky, copper penny color; head is small, white, pillowy, and fizzy with it being somewhat lasing.  Nose is a very unfamiliar compilation of smells.  Notes of vanilla, mustiness, plum, sour apple, and dusty yeast with some perfume.  Flavor is sweet with lots of vanilla, some earthy oakiness, and faint apple.  Palate is viscous and full, with a chewy character, and almost a flat carbonation.  Finishes SWEET with vanilla and fingernail polish.  Not a lot of "Belgian" qualities in this one; and the sweetness is too overwhelming.  Really reminded me more of a strong German-type beer with a massive vanilla charcter (maybe from oak aging???).  Intersting but not worth trying, just too sweet and unappealing.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2007 Hazy golden with a large thick head and dense & webby lacing.
The aroma was huge with loads of vanilla, liqourice, pistachio, bourbon and alcohol, but also bretty sour/tart citric notes, brown sugar, and some dark fruits like fig & plums. The taste brings a huge malt profile with liqourice, dark fruit, slight yeast funkiness, and a strong grainy bread dough note in the long and sticky finish. Plusome alcohol, and sweet (almost cloying) vanilla/nuttiness. Great mouthfeel,  thick and smooth, but also with high carbonation. Over the +-5 months, the liquorice notes increased and the mouthfeel got slightly thicker. This will continue to age nicely, no doubt. Well made, very nice.
Bottled. Golden orange coloured with a medium sized head. Very powerfull and complex. Feels a bit young though - must really benefit from aging. Fruity, alcoholic, yeasty and slighly citric.

Hazy dull toffee-like amber.  No real head developed, but some sticky lacing is present.

Glorious baking spice nose, with plenty of vanilla to round things out.

Frankly sweet on the attack, with a heavy, sticky palate presence.  Perfumey in the nasopharynx, with lots of vanilla and a candylike sensation.  Finishes slightly bitter but still sweet.  Some fruity tanginess is there, struggling to balance out the sweetness.  A bit of herbaceous and grapefruity hops on the finish.

A very sweet beer, for dessert only.  I cant get into this style personally, though.

At Akkurat in Stockholm we found the Stormaktsporter too expensive and picked a bottle of this one instead. Very spicy and smokey to the nose. Has got a hazy, dark orange colour and the head is not more than only a small ring of foam. Complex brew with both sweet and dark fruits. Banana and some citrus fruits come through in this full bodied brew. Dry and yeasty in the end. Very well hidden alcohol. A bit too sweet and fizzy, but still an honour to drink (Shared with Finn, 01.12.2006).

Amazing aroma, alcohol and belgian yeasts, soft orange color, nice white head, looks thick and milky, thick body, hints of grapefruit, pear, sugary sweetness, less carbonation and acidity than i expected.

Bottle at No. 5.
Dark amber with a large white head, fine lacings. Aroma heavy malty (fruity, citrus), light hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet, light bitter. Medium/full body, lively carbonated, strong in alcohol.

11.6 oz bottle, purchased 11/23/05 and kept refrigerated.  Pours a hazy golden amber with lots of yeast floaties especially at the bottom of the bottle.  The head is small, off-white, and fizzy.  It quickly diminishes to a thin collar that leaves a little lacing.

The aroma is musty yeast, sharp cidery apples, oak and alcohol.

The flavor is sweet and sugary malts with fruits and alcohol and a decent bitter finish that helps balance things out.  The mouthfeel is full and velvety.

Overall, a fine Belgian.  Normally I dont care for sugary sweetness and alcohol, but it is well blended and balanced here.

[Vintage 2003, sampled 2006] A dark amber beer with quite a lot of sediment floating around under a light orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of stored fruit, dusty hops, and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is quite sweet, and very complex, with notes of fruit syrup containing oranges, peaches, and a bit of prunes, as well as a spicy note of cinnamon and cloves, soon after the very smooth and fruity start, the alcohol makes its presence know by a warming fealing, which grows just a bit in intensity and burns slightly in the long lasting after taste. The after taste also has notes of the fruit and spices lingering. A monster - I love it.

Bottle. Very funny looking bottle. Golden brown colour with a very huge head. Aroma nice with notes of coriander, citrus and grass. 

Taste good and filling the mouth very much. Sweet with caramel and long lasting. Still there is something, that I´m not so fund of. I´m not quite certain of what it is.
On bottle 0,33l at Akkurat, Stockholm 1 Dec 2006. Golden coloured. A tiny head. Fruity and spicy aroma. Sparkling fruity flavour. The alcohol shines through. Sweet sourish aftertaste.
bottle from Knightly Spirits in Orlando - cant tell if it reminded my of icewine or a port - alcohol well hidden.  Very rich with citrus and spices - delicious!!!

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2006 Bottle.  Good yeasty aroma and very cloudy orange look with very thin head that left a ring in the glass. Flavor is very smooth and mild at first with a slight alcohol burn. As it warms the yeast presence takes over. Finishes great. Good strong ale!

Update: Bottle Cap - (SPECBREW 2005)
What a difference. This version is so smooth compared to the other bottles Ive had. Very satisfying ale! Taste is outstanding!

One of the driest beers to ever have come my way, Stille Nacht really feels more like a brut champagne than a beer. The sweetness talked about by others to my mind disappears completely in the face of the massively dry, yeasty profile. Its a wonderful experience, though, with a tremendous mouthfeel and long aftertaste. Not at all what I was expecting and all the better for it.

A hazed peach pour. A light off white head.An aroma that says alcohol and bread if that is possible. A sour fruitiness and a tad of yeasty flavor with a alcohol push. A very spicy flavor that is almost amazing. No wateriness with this beer the carbonation that you would expect a very good beer. Everything about this beer is good.
Bottle at Bier Circus, Brussels. This is a huge, bold beer. Fruity, sweet and complex. I will hunt down this beer again.

Bottle. 2006. Unclear golden color with a nice off-white head. Fruity alcohol aroma. Surprisingly sweet flavor for such a strong beer. The finish is long and there is a decided alcohol warming sensation that develops in the finish.

Bottle: Pours a dirty orange color with visible yeast sediments.  Its very well crafted, nice blend of banana, ripe fruit, caramel, and malted barley.  The aftertaste feels like you just got done eating candy.  This beer is excellent!

Bottle.  Cap says SPEC BREW 2005. Pours a cloudy orange, with a creamy tan  head.  Sediment swirling around the bottom of the glass. Smells like bananas, and tastes the same. Quite sweet, and just a little alcohol burn.  Very tasty, good christmas brew.

sampled with crackedkettle at the cracked kettle store in Adam:  A truly lovely Christmas beer.  Pours a hazy orangeish yellow with active carbonation and a nice head.  Amora is much like a hefe with banana and spice dominating the head.  The flavor is really nice and complex.  Lots of sweetness, and balance similar to the Mad Bitch, but a bit more potent and delcious.  The sweetness gives the flavors of over ripened fruit, buble gum,  but the hops are nicely present in the back of the mouth.  I wish a had more.  De Dolle rules

Bottle. Pours an opaque orange with a thin white head. Aroma is quite complex and is comprised of sweet toffee, citrus fruits, figs, and lots of alchol. Flavor is similar with the alcohol coming on strong early and lasting until the end. Very complex and although quite good, not a session beer by any means. Body is very full and it seems to take a few swallows ensure it all went down. Overall its a very nice brew that would definitely benefit from some aging. A little on the sweet and syrupy side, but its pretty good.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a large mostly lastin creamy white head. Rich aroma and taste of hops, fruits and spices. Great beer.
Very complex.  Raisins and bananas in the nose.  Very carbonated.  Some sour fruity notes in the flavor.  Biscuits and jam permeate a thick, almost gelatinous mouthful of beer.  Awesome.

Pours a cloudy orange gold hue with a very frothy white head. Aroma is a mix of earthy fruits and caramel with a bit of booze. Upon tasting your mouth is greeted with an awesome bouquet of tree fruits followed up by a very sweet but somehow balanced caramel. Its like a candy covered apple. Bitterness is there at the end, but that is the only presence of hops. Alcohol is very well hidden. One of my favorte Belgians.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2007 Bottle....brownish color, mixed berry aroma woah! caramel!! wow...texture is light with a malty texture...from the aroma and color I never expected this taste...again wow....ohhh and ahhh its like a caramello bar with fruit...
Tour sour and malty in the aroma. Mostly, like the dulle teve, for me the alcohol is just way too present.  I mean, I appreciate 12% as much as the next guy, but more when its a little hidden.
1 finger head. pours a golden brown with a white frothy head. has an aroma of apple and orange. very sweet after taste.

11.6oz, SPEC BREW 2005.  Pours a cloudy golden caramel with a 1/2 finger creamy eggshell head.  Aroma of peaches, pears, lotsa candy sugar, yeast, a little white wine.  Taste is quite sweet and yeasty, some peaches, spicy dusty hops.  Dry finish.  Some warming alcohol in the back of the throat.  Moderate carbonation, full body.  Quite good, though I dont think its my favorite from De Dolle.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 1, 2007 12OZ bottle via csbosox(thanks!). Pours a hazy amber with a small white head.Fruity/spicey aroma with notes of cherries, vanilla, and alcohol. Wow, this is about the sweetest beer i have had in awhile....puckeringly sweet. Vanilla, cherries, melon, peaches....even grapes. Lots and lots of fruit in this picture. And a strong malt backbone. This is tastey for a sweet beer. Best i have had since DFH Immort Ale, which this reminds me of, but this is unfiltered, has a fuller body, and unique in its own right. World class stuff here....
spiced apple, almost cider-like. brown sugar and raisins. super-light efervescience, medium body with a sticky sweet mouthfeel.  Packs a punch. Delicious!
very very sweet... like the blood of newborn babies is sweet.  mead like but with a very nice belgain character
Truly delightful.  Heavy raisin flavor and a brilliant finish that made my lips smack with joy and delight.  Amazing dark fruit aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 10/19/200633 cl Bottle at Akkurat, Stockholm.2000 Vintage.Clear dark copper color, white to tan head. Vinous scent, sweet raissin and alcohol. Thick mouthfeel and a bit wine, alcohol and sweet aftertaste. Very nice and rather complex, but still a bit hard to describe.8/4/8/4/16=4.0RerateBottle at a beer tasting in Göteborg on July 4, 2008.2007 versionShady orange color, yeast particles, white head. Acidic, lactic, apricots scent. Smoke, fruity, strawberry yogurt taste. Warming alcohol. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/7/3/13=3.3Rerate33 cl bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on December 22, 2012. 2010 vintage.Cloudy orange color, small off-white head. Sweet, grainy, fruity scent, also lactic. Very sweet, figs, grainy, alcohol taste. Sweet, alcohol, grainy aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium low bitternsss. Warming alcohol.8/3/8/3/15=3.7

Excellent beer. Pours a mirky orange with a foam lace ring for a head. Aroma is powerful fruity esters carried by alcohol. Flavor of apples, pears, dark fruits, raisins and sweet candi sugar, very nice and warming.
nice brown colour, sweet and highly alcohol y slightly spicy not harsh maybe some white wine flavour

UPDATED: APR 14, 2008 Bottle, The Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium, 06-10-06. Tried the aged 2000 version of this after a Westvleteren 12, whilst not quite up there with the that beer it really pushed it hard and was truly a stunning beer. Poured a light/mid brown colour, aroma of toffee, sweet with a touch of spice lingering in the background, taste was just sublime, gloriously warming and burnt sugary sweetness mmhhh, lovely the alocohol was noticeable but wasnt harsh in any way and like the mouthfeel had probably softened somewhat with age, there was malts, fruits oh crikey all sorts going on in this thing really top draw beer that I thorougly enjoyed. Had this again 12-04-08 Once again most wonderfully enjoyable but for some reason it didnt quite hit those heady heights again and so I give it  4.2

This was a good one, but Im not sure Id give it over a four like others.  Ive had this a few times, but usually Im too drunk to feel I can do it justice in my rating.  So this time I had it as my first drink of the night, and it turns out, it tastes just like I recall it.  Very very very sweet nose and taste.  The aroma is dominated by raisins, carmel, perfume, and floral scents.  The flavor is dominated by candi sugar and mouth-puckeringly sweet grapes, offset by a hint of grapefruit and tangerine.  There is a slight hint of lemon but not much.  Some tart apple and white grapes in here as well.  Insteresting, just dont drink it too fast cause damn.  The alcohol aroma will knock you on your ass before you even take a sip...
05 smells like urine and a little sour and sugery sweet. taste sexy good balance alcohol is hidden i liek this very much soem bitterness in the aftertaste

Bottled.  Pours a maple syrup brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma was salty, bready with Belgian yeast, caramel, floral hops and powerful alcohol.  Taste is very strong and alcoholic yet smooth at the same time.  Citrus, candy sugar, raisin and grapes are in the taste as well as caramel and currant.  Very strong beer.  Make this one of your last drinks if you drink this because I guarantee you it will kick the shit out of you.  Good stuff none the less.

Bottle.  Light chestnut brown color with almost no white head, lots of suspended yeast.  Salty, bready, and yeasty aroma with plenty of citrus, floral, and alcohol notes.  Light and sweet malts.  Flavor is very sweet with a grapefruity tartness almost.  No bitterness to speak of.  Yeasty and alcohol throughout.  Thick, syrupy, and oily palate, hardly any carbonation.  I can appreciate this beer, and I know that there are some nice complexities here, but I just am not a huge fan of this beer.  I am glad that I had it though.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy orange with a large, off white head.  Carbonation is very lively, with alot of yeast floaters getting moved around the glass.  Aroma is heavy tart citrus, alcohol, earthy yeast, some malt, and alcohol.  Taste earthy yeast, light tart citrus, sweet malt and candi sugar, and alcohol. earthy throughout.
Too yeasty for me and the alcohol dominates  much. Ester, chemical, but also very complex. Maybe I find it better in some years!

bottle.  Aroma:  Strong tart aroma followed by an equally strong aroma of fresh bread dough.  Sort of reminiscient of a sourdough starter.  Behind all that, a pleasant peppery spiciness, some soft alcohol, and a bit of caramel.  Appearance:  Dark amber with a strong orange tint.  Hazy with some yeast floaties.  Head was off-white and small.   Flavor:  Big malt sweetness with strong candi sugar character.  Honey, raisins and grapes, and more of that bready yeastiness.  Slight sourness from the aroma comes through with a lemon-like quality.  Getting some spiceiness and floral flavors from the hops.  Alcohol comes in right as it finishes.  Alcohol is strong, but not hot or overwhelming.  Palate:  Medium-high bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Finish was a little too sweet for me.  Overall:  This is not a beer to drink on an empty stomach.  12% and Im tasting all of those percentage points.  Its strong, but still a good, complex, and very drinkable beer.

Bottle. Not sure of the vintage, 2005 or less. Pours a hazy dark orange with tons of floaties and an average size quickly diminishing white head. Pours with tons of fizz too. Aroma: whoa! I wasnt expecting that. Funky and sour fruit with some spices and alcohol. Flavour: oh yeah, I like that much more then the aroma, its delicious. Fruity and sugary sweet (but never overly sweet) with caramel malt, yeast and spices and some hops in the finish. Alcohols there but for the most part Its hidden very well. Nice medium body with a syrupy mouthfeel. Simply put, this tastes phenomenal.

82: 10 5 10 5 10
Pours a dark brown with a cream coloured head. Aroma is spicy brady. Taste is yeasty, spicy, sweet, complex. No alcohol burn at all. A divine beer.
96: 9 4 8 5 18
Pours a dark brown with a creamy head. Aroma is spicy, burnt sugar. Taste is spicy, candy, almost cola like. Soft mouthfeel. Very good.
00: 8 4 8 5 17
Pours a light brown/dark golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet spicy. Taste is sweet, some yeasty spicyness and soe alcohol burning.
From a vertical stille nacth tasting with Sahlholdt on Kulminator June 2006.
orange with a small head.  lots of suspended yeast.  orange citrus aroma.  sweet, yeasty, and fruity.  very sweet.  alcohol is quite strong though.

dark orange color and nice white head.  The smell is sweet, with hints of orange peel, and brown sugar.  The taste is sweet and full of just the right amount of hops.  Definitely one that you want to drink at the right temperature, as it gets better and better as it warms.

Wonderful, big head covers a hazy golden orange body.  Aromas are strong of citrus, white grape and bread.  Flavor is sweet and caramelly... creamy and smooth texture.  Im not picking up the lemon/citrus from the aroma as strongly as expected, but the white grape contributes nicely to the overall sweet characteristic.  Comes together well and burries the alcohol brilliantly-still a little sweet for my tastes.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a hazy amber color with a small white head. Smells very sweet and fruitty with a little alcohol. Very sweet upfront with a grape/raisin and rock candy. Some backend alcohol warmth to keep it from being too sweet. The lack of heavy carbonation makes this way too easy to drink.
Utterly fantastic. A personal favourite, and I have my eye firmly fixed on this small brewery.

Bottle. Pours orange with some yeast floaties and a small, tight white head. The aroma is raisin bread, sweet orange, and traces of wood. The flavor is raisin, a lot of sweet fruit, and just a bit of sourness. It gets slightly mead-like as it warms. The finish is cookiedough with a little bit of alcohol, and gets drier as I go, developing a potpourri tinge. Pretty good.

pours a hazy, dark caramel color with not much head to speak of.  smells of honey, apricots, caramel, and figs.  taste is quite sweet with notes of caramel, honey, mild hopcitrus.  great full mouthfeel.  delicious beer...cant wait till i pick up a few more.

Pours a beautiful bright, lighter shade of gold w/ medium sized creamy froth. Aroma is of sweet lemony herbs. Full nectar / soft residual effers. Flavors of sweet lemon drops, caramel, slight leather w/ a kick ass asprin burn on the finish to balance  out. Very complex. Its a sweeter brew but the big hopy asprin finish acts as a palate cleanser. I just wanted to keep drinking it. Not a trace of flavor from the 12% alcohol. Amazing. Highly recommended. If you like Dogfish head 120, youll love this one at half the price.

Bottle-8/4/06 Purchased at The Market Basket in Rockport Maine.  The beer pours with a very small head, and is cloudly gold with lots of carbonation.  The taste is quite sweet, and easy to drink with no noticeable aftertaste.  The alchol content is certainly hidden, as other 12% beers are far more overwhelming when compared to this fantastic brew from de dolle.
Kulminator, 23 May 2006. 2005 Bottle. Cloudy just above straw coloured body with tight beaded head. Lovely soft caramel taste with a touch of spice and candy sugar. Peppery alcohol on the nose.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2007 Sweet fruity smell.  Dark golden color with a white head.  Fruity, spicy flavor with a bitter finish.  Has a notable alcohol burn.  Nice winter beer.  Might have to buy some to cellar.

Pours cloudy medium amber with a big head. Aroma is malty with a hint of alcohol and spice. Flavor is sweet with some fruity undertones.  A mild alcohol presence which isnt surprising for an ale with such a high gravity.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 The aroma of this one is strong fruits, and I also get a hint of apples.  I also get some very sweet candied sugar smells coming from this brew.  The taste is pretty good.  A lot of the the same flavors translate over.  The alcohol was present in the taste, but it is 12% so that is somewhat expected. I had a year old bottle of this beer and it was still fairly carbonated in the mouthfeel.  Overall a pretty good beer.  I can only imagine what the reserva edition would taste like after letting this beer sit for over a year in boeurdaux (sp?) barrels.

Rerate:  1987 Vintage  What a different beer than any of the more recent vintages of this beer.  Not much carbonation, but still a little bit present in the pour...but I wouldnt expect much carbonation from a beer over 20 years old.  Much darker in color...more along the lines of a reddish wine color than the yellow color of more recent years.  Aroma of sweetness, fruits, grapes, and sugars.  A little bit of sourness that is certainly welcome within this beer.  This beer is remarkably reminiscent of a port wine or red wine melded with a great belgian strong ale.  Fantastic Brew!!!!  Thanks Mike!

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2014 2002 bottle sampled July 2006.
The cap pops off with a substantial whoosh. The beer pours orange amber with a great big though short-lived low-density head. 
The aroma is complex: a barleywine fruitiness lays down the backbone with strong apple cider notes on top, even venturing in the direction of vinegar acidity. Pineapple and a hint of tangerine fill out the fruit flavors; leather and wood lend a certain sophistication to the nose; strong caramel hints at a sweet beer to follow with the first sip. Alcohol is abundant in the aroma, especially early on.

The flavor, four years in, is very nice. Somewhat sweet but not overly so, dark caramel and baked apples before the taste twists nicely and plenty early into well-hopped finish. Pepper and again some leather add interest midway, along with a cognac and golden raisins.
Unfortunately, the aggressive carbonation detracts from the mouthfeel, making this beer - which seems otherwise perfect for savoring on the tongue - hard to drink in that way. The alcohol is prominant; this one tastes every bit of its 12 percent ABV.

I came to this beer with high hopes, and Im not disappointed. It loses a few points on the palate especially, and I can guess that this one would be better aged a few years like mine was than it would be fresh. So I guess I better set a few aside in the cellar...

2005 bottle sampled December 2006. Splendid. While this might do well with additional age, theres nothing wrong with this at a year plus. This one is not so heavily carbonated as the previous sample, and the aroma is marvellously perfumy in addition to all of the description above. If anything Id rate this even higher; a 9/4/9/4/17=4.3 is not out of the question.

Bottle.  "Special Brew" bottle cap.  Orangeish pour with a head that didnt stick around.  The head did something really interesting.  I usually notice the way a head leaves a ring around the edge of the glass.  Instead this one pulled to the center and left a small dime size dot right in the middle of the glass and stayed there for the entire drink.  Very interesting indeed.  Aromas were a little hard to dectect.  My wine drinking buddy pretty much had the enitre area permeated with sour grapes that it was all I could smell.  But the flavor was outstanding.  Dark fruits and wood.  Alcohol and some sort of fruity spice.  Very good and very satisfing.  I really liked this one.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel, dagrumes et dépices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde orangée avec une faible densité de bulle. Saveur: Très bon goût dépices et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Explosion dépices en arrière goût. (Rating #539)

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2006 Bottle - Vintage 1998. Poured a nice amber color with a nice white head. First tastes to come to my mouth were fruit with a nice spicey kick at the end. Peaches and caramel. I am not sure if I would like one that was not aged. Overall a very enjoyable belgian.

Bottle at HopLeaf, Chicago.  Cloudy golden amber body with a very small white head.  Sweet, fruity aroma.  
Flavor is very sweet with notes of peach and caramel, with some spiciness.  Delicious.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2016 Cloudy amber color with small white head. Scent is a unique sweet spicyness. Very thick and syrupy body which tingles the palate. There is an acidicness to it with a smooth alcohol warmth and amazing complexity. Very sweet in flavor. Very fruity with a spicy element as well. Flavors of figs, dates, maybe even a peachyness with even more i couldnt identify. With warming has a hint of toffee.

Re-Rate: Bottle: Hazy golden pour with a voluminous white head. Great complex aroma. Vinous, fruity, champagne-like, a touch of leather and earthiness. Also a soft fruit sweetness. Frothy body with a warming alcohol pepperiness and lively carbonation. Flavor is fruity and spicy. Lots of fruity phenolics and complexity. Minerally as well. Complex and fantastic.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 330 ml bottle

A very well done Belgian strong ale that hits all the right notes.  If only   it werent so overpowering, it would be outstanding.  Perhaps with some years   on it this one will mellow in character.  Overall, one that everyone should   get a chance to try.

Aroma / Appearance - The first thing to hit my nose was an impression   of butterstotch, lemons, fresh orange peels, caramel and toffee.  There was   also a vinous alcoholic scent underlying everything.  The body was a wonderful   cloudy caramel color with traces of sediment lingering in the glass.  A sticky   lacing made it clear this would be a beer that held none of its alcoholic   punch back.

Flavor / Palate - The initial taste consisted of a combination of   caramel, toffee and a strong alcoholic bite.  Latter sips gave way to a   wonderful sweet butterscotch with citrusy undertones.  Somewhere towards the   middle of the glass semi-sweet dark chocolate appeared on the back on my   throat.  Overall, every sip revealed a new facet of the rich complexity   hidden in the glass.  The honeylike finish left me wishing there was a little   more although the consistant alcoholic bite made me glad the glass was   finally empty.  Still, this was excellent - if you can get your hands on this   one, buy two.  One to try immediately and another to age for a few years.

Peachy colour with foamy white head, boozy and yeasty aroma. Taste of fruity yeast and spices and eggy kiche.Sweet nutmeg and pepper and cinammon. Noticeable carbonation, fine, refreshing above average Belgian. Medium mouthfeel.Easy to drink if you like Belgians.

Pours a cloudy amber.  Aroma is sweet fruit and spice.  Flavor is very sweet, sugar, honey and apricot.  There is also some mild sourness. Plenty of spiciness.   The high alcohol content was barely noticeable. Very complex flavor, but I found the sweetness to be a bit over the top.

Deep, cloudy amber -- think-lloking, like a suspension.  Slight ring of white head leaves some lacing.  Aromas of apple cider and sherry.  Thick, sweet, vinuous mounthfeel.  Grabby on the tongue.  Sweet dessert wine flavors with plenty of sweetened fruit and demure alcohol.  Hops are present throughout, kind of a muted piney green grapefruit.  Very interesting beer.  Just one will do!

From bottle.  Pours cloudy orange with floaties, no head.  Nose is vinous with light fruits and honey suckle.  Some sourness is apparent under all that sweetness.  Flavor is sweet, follows nose with a bitter finish.  Smooth palate with no noticeable alcohol.  Well done.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 Bordeaux-cask aged vintage from 1982 (which basically means this is 1982 Stille Nacht Reserva).
Consumed at Kulimator in May 2006  Deep purple colored body with a still white filmy head.  Very robust nose full of scotch, port and sherry, with notes of black cherry and old oak casks. Thickness and texture, while expected it to be huge, is silky, tannic and wine-like.  Rich, silky, oily, resinous... PERFECT palate. Was told that this was the favorite beer of Dirk Van Dyck, who runs Kulminator, and I can see why.

My ratings of the 2004 vintage are probably in the 4.4 - 4.8 range.

My ratings of the 2007 vintage (tasted young) are probably in the 4.0 - 4.3 range.

Pours a golden brown.  Looks like a glass full of honey when not in motion.  Aroma is a bit sour, with fruity notes with bits of spice.  Difficult to discern anything beyond that.  Flavor is sweet, with touches of wheatiness, and bits of honey.  VERY smooth, just glides across the tongue.

Vintage 1982 - Very dark brown body, big bubbled light brown head disappearing quite fast; This nose is big (not huge), very deep, but could be more complex (it is already very complex). The beer is old and the nose has a lot of aged character to it. Right when served,  dust is overshadowing almost everything else, but it unfolds beautifully with just a little time in the glass: lot of burnt caramel, mixed with all kinds of dried fruit, date, fig, prunes, but actually also fresh red fruits like strawberry and fresh sweet cherry. Great nose. I have had this beer before and do actually remember the nose even bigger (like HUGE); The beer only has very little carbonation and a nice oily texture, a little sourness that combined with a small amount of salt gives the body a very pleasant balance; that flows smoothly into a very long finish unfolding nicely, starting out very soft and sweet, but quickly gets a little fruity sour that balances the finish perfectly: dried and fresh fig is standing strong, overripe cherry, sweet overripe orange juice. Well this beer just goes on and on and is very, very great.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2008 1996 Vintage, bottle into glass.  Pours a beautiful darker golden amber brown color with a thick white tan head with many sediment floaties pouring from the bottle shifting around in the beer.  Aroma consists of a very sweet, yet spicy and fruity as well.  Flavor brings out an AMAZING complex sour and hoppy, sweet and fruity taste to the palate.  Almost tends to bend on an apple cidery type brew.  The finish hangs in the mouth with an beautiful apple spice note.  1996 vintage is absolutely wonderful!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2008 Re-rate, sampled 2008 bottle: A quite different experience from the first, pretty nicely done, some bret character and lots of carbonation, much better attenuated than my first experience, sweetness settled down a lot. The alcohol was a tad hot, though, and there was an odd almost medicinal aspect to the aroma (but not the flavor). Fruity w/ some faint sourness, caramel malts. Good stuff, rating getting bumped a bit. Original rating: Sampled 2004 bottle. This one poured a dark amber-orange-brown color with a nice little head that settled to a thin covering that remained throughout. Lacing was decent. Aroma was spicey and sweet. The flavor, unfortunately was REALLY REALLY REALLY sweet (and I normally like sweet beers). The spices came across strong in the finishing flavors, almost at a hop level. This seemed almost like a triple attempt with a dark colored malty sweet base with the way it finished. The mouthfeel was really heavy: body contributed some to that, but even moreso the sugar and sweetness left the mouth feeling thick. I dunno, a bit overpriced and the other De Dolles Ive had (Extra Stout & Oerbier) were far superior.

Bottle.  Cloudy orande, sediments, thin white head.  Sugar, candy and soap aroma.  Very acidic and candy like taste and bad aftertaste.  

Bière de couleur orangé troubles avec des sédiments et un mince collet blanc.  Odeur de sucre, bonbon et savon.  très acide et astringante avec un goût de bonbon et un mauvais arrière goût.  infecté?

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy coppery/amber color.  Thick and syrupy.  No head to speak of.  Aroma is sweet, yeasty and hoppy.  Flavor is packed full of the same with some trace fruitiness and maybe some honey.  Very thick.  You can taste the alcohol (as would be expected at 12%) but it does not detract from the overall experience.  This is not a beer for the faint of heart - this is a serious brew.

12-oz 98 bottle courtesy of after4ever. Pours amber orange with a diminishing white head. Aroma of apples and spice. Medium body with fizzy carbonation. Taste is sweet caramel, apple, spices with a sweet warm finish. This is a desert beer.

12-oz 98. 8 yrs bottled. Pours coppery amber with a diminishing white head. Lots of candi on the nose, with a bit of red apple (closer to Red Delicious, say, than Gravenstein). The attack is fizzy and tart, which would usually turn me off more than most, but the softening of the years has served this beer beautifully. Its still intensely sugary, but theres fruity sourness in close association with the sweetness. The big cannon shots of fruit, white sugar, and acid harmonize, instead of stepping all over each other and leaving you feeling like youve been mauled. Theres a tiny whisper of hops, too, but nothings domineering or clamoring for attention. If Ive learned anything here, I think Ill stop rating sweeter Belgians when theyre too young.

Dull brown murky appearance  nice head, does not last long nose of over ripe apples, cinnamon  heavy to medium body  initial taste is sweet candy apple a little sour, with some fresh baked bread  nice creamy body- aftertaste smooth apple goodness like natural cider

330 ml bottle poured a cloudy orange amber with a small lingering off white head. Aromas of sweet carmel, apple, spices and pepper. Palate was medium bodied and slightly syrupy. Flavors of sweet carmel, apple, honey and spices with a warming lingering sweet finish.

bright golden color w/ a tall fluffy white head and lots of visable carbonation.  Definatelly belgian in aroma some good spices w/ peppers as well, some good sweet notes of sugar and touch of light fruits (fig).  Palate is full and creamy.  Flavor is GREAT.  Full of lots of sweet plums and figs and apricots and maybe even some honey.  Very sweet very delicious.  Picks up some bread notes in the finish as it warms up and maybe even a touch of bananna.  This is damn good.  WIsh I could get the reserva now.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2006 [Bottled. Sampled at Turisthotellet, Ljungskile, 1 hour north of Göteborg]
Ha! At first they had no bottle left. Luckily on my prompting to help them find one, there it was on the shelves. 2004 Vintage. Dusty. Left in total oblivion? Dark amber. Rich cottony/creamy head. Wonderfully complex aroma of chocolate, licorice, tidbits, candied sugar to name a few.Silky soft mouthfeel with notes of chocolate, sweet licorice, candied sugar and small notes of tidbits. Superb lingering finish.

Beautiful dark orange pour with a with thin creamy head. Yeasty ester aroma with citrus fruit and spice present as well.  Complex flavor of apricots and honey and coriander and cake.  A strong bitterness is very present in the flavor of this beer but it is a thick malty bitter quality.  Full bodied and very sweet, this one will draw flies like nothing else.  Overall this is a beer with an amazingly complex and delicious flavor that is somewhat compromised by its cloying sweetness.  If age takes away some of the syrup similarities in this beer I could definetly see rating it a solid 5.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a hazy apricot-orange beverage with a small white head that diminished almost entirely (not surprising considering the high alcohol content) and left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was quite fruity with notes of fermented apricot and peach some apple and the presence of citrus in the background. There was also a bit of spiciness as well. The body was quite full with a smooth, soft carbonation and a slightly slick oily texture. The flavor bursts upon your taste buds with a fruity, soft sweetness initially. As the flavor matures a slight bitterness develops on the sides of the tongue. The finish is long and there is a decided alcohol warming sensation that develops in the chest at the finish.

I believe that the USA produces the best beers in the world, but this undermines my argument.  Pouring a cloudy golden-orange, the flavor was just incredible.  A little citrus, maybe some banana, warm honey, and that healthy dose of yeast that all Belgians seem to have, I couldnt get enough of it.  Sweet without being obnoxious, strongly alcoholic without the bite, I think Im in love.
Robe cuivrée surmontée dune mousse blanche mince qui persiste. Arômes de pain, de levure, dalcool et dépices. Saveurs de liège dalcool et de pain.
Bottle. Small white head. Unclear golden body. Fruity alcohol aroma. Surprisingly sweet flavor for such a strong beer. Bitterness at the end though.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours hazy golden-orange with a white head. Aroma of citrus, fruit, alcohol, sweet malts, and spices. Flavor is sweet, alcohol, fruit, carbonated.

Les particules se font très nombreuses. Odeur de raisin?, dalcool et dépices. Couleur brun-roux. Très très rond en attaque, mais mince en finale. Très peu deffervescence. Le goût de lalcool est très très présent, même trop présent à mon goût.

Bottled (2005). Hazy orange/nutbrown head, with huge white foamish bubbly head.  Aroma of sweet fruits and alcohol. Also caramel and yeast noteable. Flavour is stinging alcohol mixed with spices and fruits. Wellbalanced, since the alcohol mixes in well, especially as it has been in the glass for a while and becomes a bit warmer. Different Xmas beer, and I think it will get better if kept in cellar for a few years.

Big white head and a beautiful gloden orange color. Very smooth drinking to me, didnt seem anywhere near that high an ABV. And while I could taste the the fruits and spices, they werent obvious and overdone, as in many holiday beers.
Wish I had more to cellar.

After allowing some time for this beer to settle and warm slightly, the aroma opened into a powerful mix of maple sugar and ripened fruits.  The head was never large, yet it did remain present after several minutes of settling.  The flavor is very powerful.  Malty, syrupy, and yet with the dry finish of a desert wine.  Overall a very enjoyable flavor experience

Aroma:Apple,sugar,citrus...
Appearance:hazu-orang cooper,small chunk of yeats inside,small head...
Flavor:alcohol,apple sour,light sugar flavor....strong...

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2006 [bottle] Smells sweet, like apple cider. Pours a reddish yellow color with plenty of floaties in the glass. Flavors are immediately sweet. Dense, complex dried fruits, candi sugar mellow out to a nice malty finish and a smooth alcohol burn. Delightful.

Bottle from Super Saver in Somerville, NJ.  From the name, I expected this to be a dark impy stout.  I tpoured hazy orangish with a 2-finger uniform of-white head.  The aroma was caramel malty, with canteloupe, citrus and tropical fruit, heavy citric cobwebby hops, and some spicy florals.  The taste was malty, very fruity in a cabernet sense, with the big spicy floral hops and tropical fruit.  The palate was extremely complex and dense, like a barleywine/cabernet hybrid that has been concentrated.  To me, this is a HUGE barleywine, but Ill accept it just fine, and give it just as high a rating, for the Belgian strong ale category.  We really need an Oakes forum about how the lines between styles are becoming blurred, and that isnt always a bad thing.  Bravo, De Dolle, as usual!

Pors a deep gold, with minimal head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is sweet grapes, aromatic hops and some citrus.  The sweet grape aroma is definately present in the flavor along with lots of honey.  Nice hop balance, but needs a bit more to really balance the intense sweetness.  Some brown sugar notes.  Wonderful full and almost syrupy motuhfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 Either you hate this or you love it. Orange dark with very little white head. Incredibly sweet (caramel, sugar & spices) and little carbonation.. unfiltered and unpasteurized- good for saving in the basement! Very filling and has a long lasting finish! Very interesting and different. Try it.

Bottle, current vintage, poured into Westmalle Chalice.  Nice aromas of tropical candied fruit, marzipan, and bittering hops remenisent of lime zest.  The first sip leads into a sweet malty, juicy fruit chewiness that is foiled nicely by balanced hops. The ph of the beer combined with the snappy carbonation lighten the malt body on the finish for a smooth taste.  Abv. very well intergrated.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2006 from the bottle, poured a cloudy honey with alot of floaties and with a small white head that left a thin layer of lacing. aroma strong hops followed by lemon and and malts with a nice sugar sweetness and a sweet navel orange. flavor the sweetness was like cotton candy, than the hops and malts came out nicely followed by just a touch of alcohol along with some spices. nice smooth mouthfeel enjoyed drinking this. good beer.

From Bottle, poured at the 2006 Pizza Port 12 Hour Belgian Beer Party.  Beautiful orangish copper coloring with a nice, short brilliant white head.  Full of bubbles, which churn the yeast into a flurry of snowy cornmeal.  Aroma of fresh orange blossoms dancing with sourdough bread.  Nice creamy mouthfeel and texture on the tongue.  Tons of clove and white pepper spice tingle my tongue.  Final hoppy smack of fresh grass, coriander, and other Belgian spice characters.  Delicious, classic example of my favorite style of beer.

Bottle, 33cl. Funny label. Hazy amber colour with a beautiful and creamy white head, mostly lasting. Some residue. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and alcoholic, but nothing very strong. Flavour is wonderful, sweet and malty, very rich and with a touch of alcohol in the aftertaste. This beer is very good but lacks something to be exceptional. Perhaps if the sweetness wasnt so pronounced....

Aroma was a spring time honeydew melon and carmel apple,cloudy amber orange body,big fruity Belgian sugar sweet taste,with all those wonderful Belgian yeast esters,not quite as smooth a the best,hard to believe its 12%

Yeasty aroma fizzy very Belgian very tart fruity sweet acidic highly alcoholic lasting big head excellence in brewcrafting a real SIPPING beer highly candied flavor goes down smooth as cream consuming slowly highly acoholic sipping beer smiles.

Pours a deep amber with a flat head, only small lacing from a heavy pour. The bottle contains a ton of yeast particulate. Aroma is of sweet bread that has been caramelized, dulce de leche. Heavy body with almos t no CO2. Very sweet. Caramel and vanilla with some butterscotch and fruit cake. Pretty damn tasty. A true desert beer. Would have been a hell of a lot better if it had just a bit of CO2.

About as good as it gets for me.  It is sweet, but carries the most amazing mouthfeel, with a little sip engaging every taste bud.  A beer one could easily drink over 45 minutes, learning more as it warms and reveals its complexities.  I originally had this in a small bar in Ghent, and didnt like it the first time because it just was too flavorful.  However, a second tasting revealed more flavors and the warming satisfaction of a good Christmas brew.  Ive had a bottle aged well over a year, as well as fresher batches, and the aging does improve the palate, with a more consistent and well balanced flavor.  Also, something about the home made look of the bottle, with a crooked label and a plain white cap just seems to announce that it is a small batched masterpiece, and the contents follow through on that.

Pours a particulate-laden golden with a fleeting-yet-creamy white head. A delicate lift of carbonation stirs the sediment like a lava lamp. Upon opening the bottle, our immediate aroma is (quite simply) a box of raisins. In the glass, we find more of a spiced-hop-and-yeast presence with dry, woodsy-pine, faint bananas, exotics and low campfire-smoke. First taste screams, "Yes, you fool... this is a Belgian Strong Ale!!!" (followed by evil, maniacal laughter). Intense, Belgian candi sugar-sweetness is tempered by parching astringency through the obvious alcohol presence. Yeasts show with a touch of sourness, but cannot compete with the sweet. I feel the entire beer coating my brain with numbing alcohol then rushing to my gut to sit and burn awhile... all the while laughing at me from behind the mask of sugars. An excellent holiday brew, but more suited towards Halloween as this is a devilish Trick within a Treat.
<font size=-4>Purchased from <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/chicag Wine & Spirits, Chicago, IL 60614<font size=-1>

Bottle from Premier Gourmet, Buffalo - shared with tupalev, jerc & HogTownHarry. Golden colour with a small white head, lots of little floaties. Aroma is funky, with lots of yeast and tart fruit. Flavour starts quite sweet - caramel and icing sugar - followed by notes of lemon and yeast, warm spice, and a somewhat dry, noticably hopped finish. A really unique beer, I quite liked it.

tastes and looks just like caramel, looks very complex there are different colors in different parts of the glass. totally a treat to any drinker. would be very good as a desert or just a start or end to an evening.
Bottle.  Seriously fizzy and bubbly.  In a word:  Loud.  Right out of the bottle.  Looks fantastic.  Tastes heavenly.  First ever of this and I am a huge fan already.  Silent Night indeed.
pours hazy golden-orange with a minimal white head, aroma of citrusy fruit, alocohol, sweet malts, belgian spices. flavor is sweet, alcohol is present, fruity, carbonated, good body good brew.

Bottle, shared with Hogtown Harry, Blankboy, GregClow, and Jerc.  Not sure whose bottle it was.  Dark yellow, small white head. - very hazy.  Wonderful sweet, fruity, and yeast aroma.  Taste of alcohol, fruit, and lots of hops.  Spicy peppery hops.  The alcohol is burning but in a pleasant way.  Very sweet and tasty with lots of yeast, I quite enjoyed it.

Bottle (330ml).  Poured bubbly murky deep orange with an average fizzy white head.  Aroma of rich spicy malt, apricot and mango, alcohol, oak, with some yeasty belgian weiss backbone.  Rich sweet yeasty malt flavour, pure maple syrup, winter mulling spices, almost candyish fruit (apricot, peach, apple, pear) and enough alcohol to make my ears tingle.  Sweet, thick, syrupy body and a spicy long linger - a winter treat and I really wish I could find the special reserva version - a fine treat!

thanks to FM15 for bringing this to Bootopia, a 94 vintage.  had to knock an appearance point for the flatness, even though i know it was a result of the age.  pour was a hazy dark amber with a decent amount of particulate.  citrus, tons of caramel, and spices.  this was soooooo old that it was as smooth as silk, perfectly blended, amazing flavorful...too bad it takes 10 years for a regular bottle of this to make it this status, since i can buy cases of it.
Stong fruit malt hop floral aroma. Murky golden colour with poor head and lacing. Sweet malt spiritus flavour with fruit and flowers. Flat palate.
2005 vintage. Ex. Cel. Lent.Fruity aroma, oranges and spice. Cloudy, spotty light gold with bubbly head. Full, fruity body. One of the most enjoyable beers Ive had.

pours a brownish orange with a little head and good carbonation. nose is very powerful--sweet candied sugars dominate. flavor is very similar. almost too sweet/syrupy for my liking, and you can taste the alcohol as well.  Not bad, but not my favorite type of beer to consume.   That being said, I am glad I tried it and will try again later.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2007 A rather average appearance with a quickly dissipating white head over a cloudy gold pour belies what lies ahead. Inviting yeast bread aroma doesnt quite hide the alcohol. A tongue coating medium full body with a certain chewiness provides perfect support for the sweet fruity flavor. A little hop bitterness in the finish balances nicely, and there is a lingering alcoholic warmth that adds to the whole.

bottle, pours hazy orange, with medium white head. aroma of orange and some yeast. flavor is awesome, so much going on. orange, spice, coriander, floral hops and other things i can quite put my finger on. quite sweet, but not in a bad way. reminds me of gulden draak, another of my personal favorites. very thick and heavy, but not syrupy like DFH 120 or some other barleywine types. awesome, will definatly buy again.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2006 (2005): Lots yeast in the bottle, its almost impossible to pour it with without getting a lot of it in the glass... sweet and spicy aroma, with notes of oranges, hops and some alcohol Lovely palalte with fruits, sugars and hops. Very nice medium bitter finish. A very good winterwarmer!

(2005, tasted 20 dec. 06): Still very good, however the aroma is not that spicy. But still hoppy aroma. I really like this beer!

Aged approximately 2 years by Argo0.  Nice strong floral aroma.  The color is a cloudy apple cider-ish brown.  Very little head.  This is a very smooth beer, it imparts a small alcohol burn on the way down.  There is some caramel in the taste, as well as a touch of orange.  The mouthfeel is sticky, and it finishes with a touch of bitterness.  A very nice beer.

First waft is very bready and yeast, then a little apple-like alcohol.  Flavor is yeasty, a little metallic, little alcohol.  I can taste a little hops which is nice.  Very fizzy short-lived head to no bubbles anywhere on the glass.  Texture is lightly carbonated and pretty smooth.  Overall, an above average, well-crafted BSA.

Ive had this several times and never knew the ABV which is there but not in your face.
 As for this beer,WOW!  Semi sweet,sticky,white grapes,mild malt,vinous,great mouth feel. Nice sipper. Ill have to find the $ for a case and let some sit.
Heavy citrus aroma with a light gold body.  Minimal carbonation leads to a small head.  Good grapefruits and sugar give it a sharp taste that ends smooth.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2008 On tap at Capital Ale House - Innsbrook on 08/27/07, adding details to original rating on 02/10/06.

Bottle. Hazy amber body with a creamy off-white head. Sweet candi sugar aroma. Sweet candi sugar flavor mixed with spices. The alcohol is almost unnoticable with the sweetness to mask it. Medium full body with moderately high carbonation and a syrupy sticky finish which hides the high alcohol surprisingly well.

2005 bottle...pours a pale orange and a beautiful big belgian head.  Smell is intensely fruity...banana and bubble gum and a little yeast.  Flavor is hugely sweet, a bit acidic, and fruity...lots of raisin.  There is also a surpising and excellent bitterness balances the sweetness of this beer nicely.  Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and dry...a bit starchy.  Im at all upset about my decision to buy 6 of these.

i had case of the 2004 vintage and it didnt finish the final in bottle fermentation.  quite a shame.  anyhow, 2005 is much better, but im sure that 2004 is making my opinion biased.  it
pours a cloudy golden with a thin white head.  it has a sweet fruity aroma.  its a bit syrupy and very fruity.

(Bottle (2005) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co.) Hazy orange pour. Fizzy white head that mostly but not totally disappears. Aroma: banana, slightly gluey. Very fine lacing that melts away. Mouthfeel smooth, a little syrupy. Pretty darn sweet tasting, some banana in there as well. Tastewise alcohol was pretty well-disguised for a 12% but I definitely felt it. Not a huge fan of this style but I recognize the quality.

)  This beer has a sweet prune aroma.  It is a sediment filled butternut brown solution that has no head.  The high amount of alcohol in this beer can be detected immediately upon its touching of the tongue.  This beer is heavy and spreads well throughout the mouth distributing a sweet mild caramel and prune taste that fades slowly leaving a nice sweet sensation lingering in the mouth.

Big, off-white, creamy head; hazy dark orange body. Sweet vinous aroma with overtones of bread, yeast, and citrus. Powerful, sweet, vinous taste of lemon and spice, with a spicy, dry aftertaste, which lingers. Noticeable alcohol warmth.  A great beer!

(bottle - 33 cl) Thick and hazy orange color with a very thin white head and some sediment. Aroma is very malty and sweet with a tangy and spicy note at the end of it. The flavor begins with a very sweet taste then moves to a sweet and spicy middle with a spicy and yeasty finish. Aftertaste is spicy with a hint of alcohol, but surprisingly not much considering its strength. Medium-bodied with a nice alcohol warming afterwords.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2008 330ml bottle - Pours dark golden with a fully receding white head. Aroma of apples, cider, high alcohol, clove, sweet yeasty esters, honey, and toffee. Taste is sweet with notes of peach, bubble gum, oak, and honey. The acidity lends a citrus quality. Mouthfeel is quite heavy with lush carbonation. Really tasty, and the alcohol is well hidden. This would be a great beer to cellar. 

On tap at Rich Os - Pours hazy opaque orange with a thin off-white head. Aroma of pineapple, banana, peppery, alcohol, esters, bubble gum. Taste is pineapple, bubble gum, tropical fruits, fruity acids. Mouthfeel is full bodied, lighty sticky with slight alcohol burn, lush carbonation. Sticky, sweet, and alcoholic (needs more time). But still delicious. Surprisingly my bottle and tap ratings were exactly the same!!

Thanks for sharing Kevin! Hazy yellow pour, great white head, ansd lots of chunkies in the body. Honey and prunes in the nose, and Im also getting some pine and fruity malt aromas. Sweet honey/mead-ish, yeasty, bread and spices. Strong finish, very warming. A great beer!

bottle. 2003. Thanks a lot for sharing this Kevin! pours an orange-copper body with big yeast specks floating around and a medium white head. the aroma is top-notch - notes of berry fruit and yeast sweetness. this is very very sweet but somehow manages to not become cloying. lots of warm, comforting alcohol. a lot of fruit flavour and sweet caramel malt. finish is rich with an interesting note of pineapple. very tasty, Id like to get my hands on some more.

A brown-orange beer with a white head. The aroma is sweet and fruity. It has a taste that is yeasty, sweet, fruity and alcoholic. Not a bad taste but a very bad aftertaste, maybe a bad bottle? (Bottle 33cl)

17 Dec 05 (2004 vintage - Purchased from Kulminator and lovely bought back to Oz in our hand luggage) - Herbal, apple, caramel spiritous aromas.  Cloudy medium brown colour with no head or lacing.  Sweet and big spirit hop malt flavour.  Tangy bitternes with a fruit finish and it is suprisingly well balanced.

Ugly dark gold/light bronze. Small, white head with loads of bubbles in the glass. Sharp aroma of pungent yeast, dough, sugar, banana, subtle spices. Same  flavor, sweet with a nice warming alcohol finish. Full, smooth body. Dangerously easy drinking. Excellent winter brew. One of my favorite breweries.

Had this at BJs Winter Ale Fest. The beer poured a murky, dark yellow color with a small, creamy, white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma was very complexI had trouble pulling my nose out of the glass before the next sample came around. It was composed of moderate malty notes of toasted grain, light hop notes of apricot and moderate yeast notes of cellar and bread dough. Miscellaneous aromas were plentiful and contained light peach, honey, candy sugar and lightly smokey peat. The flavor is heavily sweet and lightly bitter with an average-length, lightly sweet finish. The body was medium-to-full, the texture was syrupy and the carbonation was soft. The high ABV was well tucked away like a soft candle light. I will be having more of this one.

Wow. Poured a cloudy, burnt orange with a good sized white head. Aroma had that fruity belgian smell with a bit of hops. Great flavor hops come through along with the yeast. The alcohol has a subtle warming finish that does not over power the rest of the beer. Fantastic.

Bottle.  Poured a clear medium amber with quite a bit of yeasty sediment.  Crisp ligher fruits, Belgian yeast, alcohol, and a bit of grassy, dry hops.  Flavors were similar to the aroma, but more potent in all regards.  Well-placed alcohol and dusty hop bitterness were complementary to the fruits and mildly funky yeast.  Smooth middle with alcohol astringency at the top of the finish.  Showed its power, but did not allow it to distract from the greatness of the other components.  Warming and satisfying.  Great beer!

Bought @ Steilacoom Wine and Brew. First, I was suprised to see that this was a light colored beer!? Poured from the bottle with pristine white head that lasts. The nose is alcohol, fruit, citrus and very floral. Mouth is great! floral, citrus, honey, and lots of alcohol if you take too big a sip (whoops). Other than that I am very compelled to like this beer, I am sure it wont appeal to everyone but I have enjoyed it on many occasions and will eagerly wait for more in my area...
Bottle.  Bronze beer with a perfect head.  The aroma is very fruity, warming and spiced and the flavour is very warming, very strong and liqourice.  Overall a very good beer.

Bottle (2004) from the Bartons Arms, Birmingham. Very strongly flavoured, with a whole host of hints and tones jostling. Covered my tongue and throat in a rich, honeyed biscuit flavour, with prunes and some smooth, dangerous strength on the finish. Tasty, but a little heavy and pillowy.

Vintage 2003 Lots of yeast at the bottom of the bottle, clear redisch amber colour, small off white head. Huge aroma, sweet alcoholic, some light madeirisation, port sweet taste, smouth; some carbonation. Finish is smouth, burnt sweet alcoholic, somewhat bitter. Very special, unique beer, and strong.

this was a one-of-a-kind....this beer was most unique in many ways....its pours orangish brown with no head....aroma is of sugars (especially strawberry), fruits, citrus hops, spice,caramels, and ends with a crisp old ale style aroma...just awesome!....flavor is great as well, just a tad strong in nature...this beer will knock you on the floor with its complexity, and its fierceness...very sweet and spicey, full of honey, and tea-like...a major tangy flavor for the finish..very nice, but a bit overwhelming.....great palate, and quite an awesome experience with a truly unique brew

This beer is really interesting, and different from other Belgians Ive had.  It pours out a deep orangey-amber color with a small white head.  The aroma is sweet and complex, and grows on me more and more as I drink it.  Very sweet flavor, but well balanced enough.  The 12% alcohol is very well-hidden.  Very good overall.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2007 Draft.  There was not much aroma to this.  Poured with a thin white head that quickly dissapated.  A very sweet beer that covers its evil alcohol tracks well.  Not a session beer, but a nice beer regardless.

Nice head and medium lace.  Bright copper in color.  Deep apple cider notes with hints of Cognac and dried apricots.  Rich tartness and Calvados tastes, with an acidity that cleans up your tongue, unlike a unaged one, almost like an apple icewine.  Could drink this everyday...if I had anymore!  Wine like complexity...could go on forever about this one. 96 vintage.

33cl bottle. 2005. pours a hazy brown with no head. looks like apple cider and has a bit of a sweet apple smell to. Flavor is very sweet fruit- almost like pie filling. just as you start to think its too sweet, the hops kick in and give it the perfect amount of bitter to balence it out. Slightly acidic with a little bit of carbonation. Alcohol warming in the finish, but no strong booze flavor. Totaly unique brew. Ive got one more Im going to celler, but Im not sue I can restrain myslef from having another one.

Aroma: sweet sugar, some nuttuness and spiritous. Appearance: orange/brown hazy with no head. Flavour: insanely sweet, apricot and spiritous. Recognisable hop bitterness. Palate: thick and lightly carbonated. Lasting fruit and bitterness.

11.6 oz bottle  Pours a cloudy amber orange, looks like cider a little.  Aromas are wonderful lemon citrus, flowers, perfume, grapes, raisins, plum, aaple, and port like wine.  Has a sweet taste with a bitter and acidic aftertaste.This is a taste explosion.  Getting differnt tastes every sip.

(bottle, Brouwsel 2004) Hazy orange to amber colour with yeast-particles floating around and a moderate foamy, slightly yellow head. Strong and sweet toastmalty aroma with orange rind/English marmelade, yeasts and spice, vinous and slightly woody. Sweet and lightly acidic flavour, medium to full body, thick and creamy mouthfeel. Initially sweet malty and very fruity taste, then alcohol comes through; sweet malty, bitter and pepper-spicy lasting finish. Very tasty brew, although my sample was quite young.

The colour is amber, slightly cloudy. Not a huge head, but initially quite fizzy. Aroma reminded me of cider. Expecting instant sweetness, I was surprised the first taste was quite acidic. Then the sweetness explodes, followed by a long bitter finish. This beer seems to have everything - except a grown-up label.

Bottle @ Akkurat, Stockholm. Vintage 2004Sour/acidic aroma. Sweet, sweet, sweet. Very unbalanced and not to my liking. Too sweet and alcoholic. Clearly an over hyped beer. Maybe if it gets to mature for 5 or more years.

Draft - minimal aroma.  Mostly just sweet malt.  Very little head, but what there was was white.  The body was nearly orange-yellow.  Very pretty.  Flavor is nearly honey sweet malt.  Fairly one-dimensional, but very nice.  A desert beer for sure.  The 12% is very well hidden, but this is no session beer.

Sampled at a 2005 Christmas and Winter beer tasting at Delilahs, Chicago, IL. 2004 vintage. Hazy amber ale having a small diminishing white head. No discernable carbonation. Sour cherry aroma.  Full bodied that starts with sweet malt, cherry, and toffee flavors.  Finishes with light malt aftertaste. Heavy textured sweet beer without cloyness.  This is an amazing winter brew beer that is best served alone after a meal.

Sweet intense citrussy nose. Full sweet taste, fruity, wellbalanced but didnt seem too complex. Despite the high ABV, it is far from cloying, alcoholic or syrupy as one might expect. Finishes a bit grainy. I wasnt too overwhelmed, though this was a very young one

33 cl bottle, brewed 2005. Beautiful amber colour with a good haze; vivid sparkling; frothy, fragile structured but unexpectingly stable white head with good lacing. Sweetish, slightly perfumed aroma with cinnamon, raisins (freshly baked raisin bread), grapes and some alcohol. Spicy, a bit peppery and light fruity taste with surprisingly little sweetness. Strong, long, bitter aftertaste. Yet Im missing some complexity, the taste is somewhat flat. A very dry and very warming mouthfeel with some teasing.

Aroma of raisins, fruity licorice and a light bit of spices, very nice.  Cloudy orange with small floaties and a nice white head.  Flavor of dried fruit, chewy caramel and toffee, brown sugar. Very sweet and buttery with a slight hint of cinamom in the finish.  The flavor just lasts and lasts.  Lively mouthfeel with a nice oily texture.  I am a fan.
Lasting head and strong aroma. Dark orange colour.  Heavy, warming taste. yet soft on the palate One of the best Christmas ales Ive had!
Bottle 0.25 L. Creamy white good mosltly lasting head. Cloudy orange colour. Powerfull aroma with lots og hopps and citrus. Heavy bitter flavoir and long finish. Cremy palate and soft carbonated.

Bottle.  Poured out a cloudy orange amber color with no real head but laced the glass almost like a wine.   The aroma is very sharp, full of candied fruits, marachino cherries, a little yeast, a little malt and maybe even a touch of pungent nail polish.  The flavor is very sweet with candied apple, cream soda, champagne notes.  Plus there is some yeasty bread dough and a touch of malt in the taste. Just a bit of bitter and some warming alcohol in the finish. The palate is syrupy with just a touch of carbonation.  My wife likened it to Asti without the harshness, to me it almost tastes like a carbonated sauterne.  Delicious beer, not something I could drink regularly but very nice to have a couple throughout a holiday season.
Strong alcohol flavor -- very full palate/mouthfeel.  Good stuff, especially on a winters night.

Bottle from 04. Poured with no head and no apparent carbonation, not sure if this bottle had been stored improperly before I bought it last year. Alcohol strength seems hidden by lots of roasty candi-like sugary malt character, but this was just too syrupy sweet for my taste so to me the palate was poor.

Deep reddish amber- slightly viscous with little head. Aromas of overripe fruit, candy, fantastic yeast esters and the flavor follows through but with a nice hint of tartness. Will develop wonderfully as it ages.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2007 Pours a slightly hazy orange amber with a small lacing off white head.  Also some small floaties.  Strong aroma of prunes and other dark fruits.  Some red wine characteristics, caramel, honey and an overall nice sweetness.  Flavors of the same with some slight roastiness and a general overall sweetness.  Very smooth and creamy.  Great palate and a great overall winter warmer. What a treat.  Alcohol was very well hidden, felt more than tasted. 8-4-9-5-17
