Re-rate.  I had this next to a 2005 Special Reserva and I had to knock down the flavor some.  Just too sweet next to the Special Reserva although I dont feel the Special Reserva deserves a 10.  So thus a score change.
Well made and fun to drink. The 12% is not evident. Tastes more like an 8% beer. Funky on the nose and palate, but not too sweet. Very fruity.

Bottle.  Pours an extremely cloudy, dense, yeasty gold. Very little head, but the bubbles are sticky. Aroma is moderate, a fruity malt.  Alcohol is well concealed for a 12%.  Fruity, sticky buns, baked sugar spice apple.  Feels like a heavy belgian in the mouth, doesnt burn, but you know the alcohol is enough to get you if you drink it too fast.  Which you should not do, incidentally.  wonderful little label adds to the fun effect.  Long, long finish that I could still taste a half hour later, with enjoyment.
Pours a clear golden color.  Smells sweet and spicy.  Well carbonated and acidic.  Malty smooth taste with hints of caramel.  Sweet and sugary golden goodness.

Finally popped open at Bootopia.  1994 vintage.   Aroma was spice,sugar and fruit.  Pour was golden with a light fizzle.  Flavor was damn good, sweet candied orange and peach.  Had some definite wine like qualities.  Palate was great also, finish was very clean.  Overall this was just so yummy, it brings a tear to my eye that I drank it and have none left.

2005.  Bottle from The Offie, Leicester.  Aromas are sweet candy with bready yeast.  Fruity with spiced oranges and banana. Some sourness comes through, too.   Flavours are regular bubblegum with xmassy spiced orange, sweet candy and lots of yeast.  Quite honeyed and smooth in its malt body.  Alcoholic liquid candy floss.  Another great De Dolle beer.

Bottle 2005 at Kulminator.  Cloudy, dirty orange/gold colour with tight lasting beige head.  Typical yeast aroma of de dolle.  Lovely citric aromas including tangerine.  Good hops too.  Slightly sweet in mouth with some toffee on end.  Really good bitter hops as well as you would expect from this brewer.  However, the golden syrup flavours make this a tad too sweet.

Poured from a bottle into a tumbler. This beer is definitely an ass kicker. Pours a fairly clear yellow color with a minimal head. Interesting banana aroma combined with an ominous punch of alcohol and the distinct aroma of fresh baked bread. The alcohol presence is felt more than tasted in this beer. I got  the sensation of warming on the first sip even though I served this beer at around 40 degrees. As the beer warms, I feel that the beer tastes like bananas drizzled with honey while the slight hint of hops keeps this beer from being too much.  The aforementioned flavors are complimented  with a slight cherry flavor that I dont usually expect from beers of this hue. Initially this beer is a shock on the palate. Extremely thick and syrupy with an instant alcohol sensation. As I adjust to this beer over time I find myself cursing De Dolle and their tendency to outprice me with fantastic beers that I would prefer to keep onhand year round. Unlike most De Dolle products I was pleasantly surprised to find that this was not overcarbonated and actually went down rather smooth. After I took my last sip I let out a belch and was left with a lingering banana type thing that I would take with me to bed if I wasnt about to try one  more.

Orange with lots of floaties and very little head. Aroma of a sweet cake baking. Very intensley sweet, with a honey and banana bread flavor that can be too much at times. Thick palate which hides the 12%.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2005 Bottle at The Bier Garden, Portsmouth, VA. Yellow-gold color, small head. Nose and flavor are complex, somewhat flowery, very fruity. Sweet, lots of floaties. Very smooth! Wish I could get some of this to cellar...

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Almost no head.  Very light hay yellow color.   Light floral fragrance.  Intense floral flavor that expands as it goes down.  Almost like honey and honeysuckle tempered with souring bready cheese yeast.  It was well worth the wait for this one.  Too bad it comes out once a year.  Bought five to savor the experience!

Dark and cloudy, with an aroma of spice, licorice and citrus. Complex flavors blanaced well with the alcohol.  Notes of caramel, fruits (plums & banana), and strong presence of malts.  Finishes dry and remarkably smooth.
Thanks to Firemoose 415 for sharing! Spicy, fruity aroma.  Almost no head.  Dark amber color.  Sweet fruity taste-peaches, maybe orange.  Dry slightly bitter finish.

Thanks to Suttree for sharing1
Medium hazy yellow with a fleeting white head.
Bannana and bubblegum aroma with a slight bit of alcohol.
Light citrus flavor with a dry finish.

Pours a hazzy deep golden color with hardly any head.  Sweet aroma smells of peaches, honey, raisins, apple, and spices.  Wonderful complex taste of apples, vanilla, sherry, caramel, spices, and peach.  There is a hint of balsamic vinegar in the finish which is tart, slightly bitter, and warming.  There is a hops bitterness that balances the sweetness of the beer very well.  Has a syrupy, creamy texture and goes down smooth.  Excellent winter brew.

Bottle, from Juios. Good nose, sharp and sweet. Fruity, apple, lemon, caramel ( in a baked way), White wine, little of a honey nut thing or the way french toast can smell as its cooking. Clean orangy brown color, small head that faded to a ring. Sweet flavors, ABV dominates. fruitiness in basckground. Real sharp. Medium body, lite creamy mouthfeel, Dry sweet finish. Nice brew, grew on me as it warmed. Has kick. Like to see what would happen with this with age.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Cloudy orange, loose, foamy head. Citric, musty, smoky aroma. Yeasty, banana/bubblegum flavor is noticeable up front, with a bit of alcohol heat, too. Hint of spices at the finish - nutmeg, cinnamon, and coriander.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Rerate 9/8/07:
This bottle is a 1996 vintage - a nice find! As soon as I opened it I got an incredibly potent whiff! I would have rated this beer highly by virtue of the smell alone: sweet potato pie, caramel, pineapple, lemon zest, along with more vage earth and wood scents.
Poured with a substantial, dense head (how can that be? the new beers dont have head) that faded quickly to a modest ring. Color is dark, caramel, red-brown. Tastes like a real christmas beer should, with green apple, caramel, raisins and funky earth flavors merge together like a port wine. The ageing really helped tame the disparity between the dense sweetnes and sour apple tang. Ageing also contributed to a more soft,, hazy mouthfeel. Mmmmm. HIghly recommended.

Poured kinda thick. Looks like caramel.
Very rich, sweet and tart. Reminds me of a caramel granny smith. 
Certainly a wintertime drink. Very drinkable despite its abundant flavor.Overall a very good, bold beer.

(bottle) Poured an orange/red color, without the massive head I usually find in De Dolle beers. Aroma much more massive and much more complex than their other offerings. Along with the standard Belgian apple tones, I also got what Ill call cherries and apricots. Did not taste like it had 12% alcohol in it.

Unknown vintage, prob. 05.  Tulip. Funky aroma; very yeasty.  Nose of alcohol and many complexities (apricote?).  Golden/amber in color w/ peach hues covered by a very small white head.  Cloudy w/ yeast, of course. The two most noticable qualities are its sweetness and alcohol level (yet still mild for 12%).  Very candi-like w/ apple notes. A great beer.

Bottle at LCRBM, inside the Kulminator. this is a gem that needs to be aged, so from now on i will cellar a few every year. aroma: sweetish, dark fruit, peach, vanilla. taste: also sweet, sourrish, malty, fruity, citrus. finishes long soft and bitterish. a wonderfull full and complex beer. i love de Dolle Brouwers.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2005 [bottles from kulminator: 1984, 1996, 2003 rating for 96] Pours cloudy light brown colour. The aroma is sweet, honey, candi sugar, raisins,sherry, apple, slightly spicey with just a flutter of balsamic. Full bodied and creamy, the finish is sweet with a little tartness. Every vintage was amazing but I felt that the sherry notes in the 84 were just a little too pronounced and that it had lost some of the complexity whilst the younger vintage hadnt developed a the slight acidity of the older vintages and was a little sweet.

No#6. Rated vintages against each other here. (2003, 1996, 1984). 2003, too sweet. 1984 too old. 1996 rating. Aroma is lightly sour with soem hopy character and sweetness there too, nice. The taste is quite sweetish with sour red wine vinigar hints. Very nice to taste them all against each other.

This was an absolute pleasure to drink.  Evident alcohol, with a sweet lingering aftertaste.  A sharp, almost pointy taste.  Impressive offset of its huge sweetness with a brassy acidic taste.  The palate acts to optimally bring out the taste to its fullest.  

Beautiful appearance, yellow gold with small whitish head. A nice head, but not too pillowy.  

Smell has an almost vinous character, caramel, grain, damp, oaky alcohol.

A wholly interesting and unique beer.  Like a yellow malt candy drink.  Huge barley wine body without the bittering hops.  Very interesting aroma, reminiscent of a lambic blend or a sour brown.  The tartness is missed on the palate, overpowered by a syrupy sweetness.  Maple brown sugar flavor.  Im not getting the alcohol bite that others mention.  But that could be due to my tolerance  and preference for 100 proof bourbon.  Dessert beer, to be sure.  I would like to age a few.

Orange body, small head. Aroma was huge candy sugar with yeast and alcohol. Basically that sums up this beer. There is some fruit there like apples as well as caramel, but the alcohol prevented this from being fantastic. Still a very nice and powerful beer.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Im proud to say Ive never been in a fight because of alcohol.  Until last night.  My French friend and I sat down for another pedantic beer review session.  It was a calm, autumn evening and the last light of the day was retreating out of the apartment.  Fine conditions for beer tasting indeed.  Everything seemed tranquil, almost deceptively so.  We uncapped the Still Nacht, poured it, looked at it, smelled it, wrote a few notes down, smelled it again, discussed the smell, made fun of the label and jotted down a few more lines.  Then we sipped it.
I still have a black eye.  The Still Nachts name is pure chicanery.  Theres nothing still about this beer, and theres certainly nothing calm about it either.  Its like wrestling with an irate grizzly bear, armed only with a nail file.  Before I elaborate on the shellacking this beer gave me Ill start with the relatively harmless color and smell.  The beer pours a  beautiful orange color, deep, emotional and pensive.  My friend pointed out that the yeast particles are held in stasis the beer owing to its surprising thickness.  One might believe it was a glass full of orange marmalade.  There were also some fun little yeast circles in the head, though Im reminded that yeast cant form any formations of their own volition.  The smell resembles the taste minus the great, bestial claw of alcohol.  Sweet and tangy orange come out first, followed by a little grape juice.  Here we come to the part where I take my first sip and fly out of my chair.  The alcohol is immense, it is angry and it hates me.  It screams and theres nothing the rest of the beer can do to silence it.  My ears bleed.  Seizures begin.  It is a cacophony of relentless pain and noise, noise, noise.  Finally the taste clears from my throat and Im red faced and back on my chair.  Commence the second sip, where Im a little more prepared.  Ive fashioned a crude harness of duct tape and couch foam to endure the impact and it works.  With all the attention Ive saved from not falling to the floor I can pick apart the flavors a little more.  I find mostly orange marmalade, akin to the color.  Most interesting to me was the rate at which the taste dissipates; a lovely decrescendo after a mighty clang of 12% alcohol inundation.  The fight was a little one-sided, and hobbling out of the kitchen I shake Still Nachts hand for being a good sport, and at least a unique beer.  However I think its a bit strong for my feeble tastes.  Everyone is talking about how they had this beer after several years of aging in a cool basement.  I only had it under my bed for a day.  Maybe thats the problem.

Pours a syrupy thick orange marmalade with a  nearly non-existent bubbly head. Small lumps of yeast levitate in the glass validating the extremely high density of this brew. The nose is sweet with fruity notes reminding of white grapes, melon, orange and grapefruit. Some sour apples and Champagne mingle providing an acidic background. The first sip seems like drinking cough syrup or a cordial straight out of the bottle. The sticky cloying sweetness emphasizes oranges, corn syrup and more alcohol than I would ever want in a beer. Not sure how old the bottle was, but from what I can tell, it was probably a couple of years too young for me to drink. I want to believe this beer will get better with age but until Im proven wrong its as bad as the label.

2003 bottle, aged 2.5 years:  Pours a hazy gold. decent head and belgian lace.  Aroma is awesome, sweet honey and hop spice, coriander, and a refreshing citrus aroma.  Flavor is ungodly alcohlic.  Ive had 101 proof bourbon with less bite than this.  Im going to assume its the age, but damn, it bites hard.  Flavor is bright and sweet, citric with mellow apricot undertones, alcohol dominates, belgian spices, and a bitter, alcoholic finish.  I feel tipsy halfway through this.  Obviously needs more than 2 years to mellow.
pours out thick, almost syrupy. Smells delicious. Definently some hints of caramel and fruit. The taste is also to my liking. Creamy and satisfying belgian that hides its alcohol well. Bravo!

Pours a thick copperish color with a beige creamy head.  Smells very complex, with a prominent bitter fruit detection, mainly lemon and orange.  Taste is rich and thick with a bittersweet citrusy prominence.  Excellent belgium beer with the alcohol hidden well.
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2006 Sweet sweet aroma with a hazy orange appearance.BIG jammy flavours that totally masks the alcohol.So many aromas and flavours bounce around the glass....so sweet yet so good.

Bready/corn syrup-like aroma. Poured very nice a rich amber with a decent head that started three finger thick and settled down to pinky thickness. Sweet malts and up front alcohol. Very bready and while not quite spicy it has a minor crispness to it in the finish. But there is something that tastes a little like dirty dishwater in the finish and that really hurts the beer.

Vintage 2003
I had read a million times that this beer was very sweet and syrupy so I thought that some aging might do the trickUhhhhhhh NOPE 2 years in the cellar! The one thing that aging did do is relieve the alcohol heat and burn. 
 Pours a beautiful syrupy dark amber body with very little head. The aroma is largely sweet:  a mass of candied sugar and sweet bready malts, like drinking fresh wart. The flavor brings a mass of fruits, pears, red apple, plums, dates, maybe even some blackberry. The yeast isnt overly pungent a bit rustic, suggestions of leather and biscuit. It is almost overly sweet a nice woodsy smokiness from molasses but too much like pancake syrup. The palate is rather oily and especially sticky. A terrific nightcap for the very cold winter months. To bad Florida never really gets that cold. 
 Ill age another bottle. But this time Ill let it sit for a couple more years and see what happens Ill shoot for 5 this time.

Cloudy dark orange with no head and some floating particles. Aroma of honey, sweet dark fruits and apple. Syrupy sweet with notes of candy apples, caramel, toffee, brown sugar and then plum, figs, raisin and pear. Has some moderate hop bitterness at the end with a slight alcohol buzz. Smooth, syrupy mouthfeel with very light carbonation.

Aroma for this one was of fermented fruit. Body dark gold/orange with no head. Flavor was sweet to start with but alcohol seemed to be overwhelming in the end. For me this beer went from medium to little harsh on the palate.

Bottle poured a dark orange color with a yeast and citrus aroma.
Flavor is yeasty and sweet with a nice sweet alcohol finish, although alcohol is very well hidden for 12%

Bottle. Youve got to be kidding me. Way too much residual sugar. Tastes more like a rum and coke. Rich deep amber with no head. Sweet, yeasty, spicey aroma. Sweet malt flavors with lots of brown sugar and candy sugar. Some fruitiness - plum and peach. Too sweet. Theres a lot going on, but its all buried by the sugar. Some alcohol present (but that sugar cube they dropped into my beer did hide it well). Should be aged.

Has a deep golden color but no head.  A malty aroma with an alcohol hint in the background.  On the initial taste there is a touch of apple flavoring.  Latter the malty sweetness becomes more prominant and a syrupy texture is apparent.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 8-21-2007: 1996 bottle, just bought today in NYC. This has likely been sitting in this unconditioned store for all 11 years. Bottle #1430. Pours a rather deep ruddy brown with a ton of yeast. There is a surprisingly large amount of carbonation and head still with this beer. Up front he nose is slightly sour, old, licorice. Licorice and tart sweetness really come through in the taste, lots of complex oxidized malts and pure fruit juices. Tartness is very nice, and evidence of Rodenbach from the yeast is slight but apparent. Remarkably complex, with elegent, balanced sweetness and acidity and a perfect body. This has aged BEAUTIFULLY. I do need to try a fresh one again though, as my original rating (below) was very early on in my beer rating, and I had never had a sweet beer.

8-17-2005: 6/3/6/3/3.1: Am I missing something here? I first thought this bottle was infected due to the enormous amount of floaties and the overbearing sweetness, except thats all the same stuff other people say about this. Im strongly considering pouring this and grabbing something else, except the $5 price tag is holding me back.

Im positve I had a pretty old bottle, barely any carbonation at all, no head at all, alcohol flavor totally gone, no particles, incredibly sweet, and easy drinking, tasted like a glass of riesling. Smoothest beer Ive had, delicious! Bought at stuffed sandwich.
It was more than I could handle. I had a 2001 vintage. The alcohol level was very high, imo it killed the flavor of the beer.

cloudy hazelnut with a white tan head. grape, apricot, and graham cracker aroma. sweet doughy fig taste with sweet raisin and plums. lingering banana bread notes with an alcohol finish. a strong angry, beautiful beer.

Bottle at the Capital Ale House (Innsbrook) in Richmond. Pours dark orange with a very small head and a lot of crap floating around in the glass. Aroma is Initially very buttery, but calming down to vanilla, malts, and sweet candi sugar. Very sweet flavor, quite winey. Finish is somewhat alcoholic, but doesnt give away the 12%. Good Belgian, if a little on the sweet side. Like a much better Delirium Nocturnum.
Bottle. Notes of fig, brown sugar, cookie dough. Very, very sweet like a barleywine. Really too sweet to really enjoy.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2006 (Bottled, 2005 vintage, sampled 09/2006) Very hazy orange color with a large, lacy head. Strong, grainy-malty, yeasty, salty-licoricey aroma with clear alcohol presence. Very sweet-syrupy, Dolle-yeasty, quite hoppy and salty flavor with evident, but not intrusive alcohol. Very full-bodied, syrupy, definitely warming - yet not burning palate, thanks to the high gravity and sweetness. An extreme beer, but a bit disappointing as the 6-year old vintage was not any better. On a long winters night, this will, however, surely satisfy your appetite for a nightcap.
(Bottled, 2004 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Cafe, Brussels, was 8-4-8-5-17=4.2) Very hazy, dark orange color with a smallish but tight and lacy, lasting head. Earthy, oaky, tart, malty aroma with dried fruit. Flavor of dried fruit, syrup, rye-pudding, spices and hops. Very full-bodied, oily and port-wineous palate with little carbonation for a Dolle, and a warming alcoholic twist. A very delicious brew that seems ideal for long cellaring. Finally got to taste this one!
(2000 vintage, 8% ABV, sampled 3/2006) Coriander-spicy aroma, Spicy, grainy-malty flavor. Sticky-syrupy palate. Its hard to say whether I liked this or not. Not really that balanced, anyway.

33 cl Bottle. Dark amber colour, with a rocky head. Great aroma of some caramel and yeast. Unfiltrated. Very big mouthful with some nice malt taste and hints of hops, and is some winery, very tasty. Big body.

bottle - pours cloudy amber with a short foamy offwhite head.  Aroma is of dough and a touch of orange.  Flavor is grapes, orange, some vanilla, and a sugary sweet finish.  On the palate this is medium bodied and smooth.  The alcohol is completely covered except for the warming that you feel after each sip.  Six months in the cellar certainly didnt hurt this one any.  Very mellow for such a big beer.  Christmas in July is fun!

This was a nice beer sampled at the Brickstore. A dark orange apperance with a minimal head. The flavor is very sweet with alot of oranges and vanilla. A sugary mouthfeel with some alcohol showing. If you could imagine a creamcicle in beer form you have this beer. It was a nice experience.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2005 Pours a light amber, clear and very effervescent, with a small white head.  Strong aroma of sugar, grapes, acidic lemon or orange, and alcohol.  Taste is sweet and very spicy, with touches of vinous grapes, citrus, and a strong retronasal alcohol burn.  Strong and sweet but more dinkable than I though it would be.  Nice.  RERATE: 1994 vintage, opened at Dickinsonbeers House.  The ctirus has come through even more so and the alcohol has mellowed quite a bit, making this very drinkable.  Excellent!
Orangy amber with some chunky suspended particles and a very slight haze. Great aroma and the flavour is incredible.

Bottled. Golden/amber colour. Small head. Nose is full of maltiness, toffee and a cognac-like alcohol aroma. Tastes very sweet and alcoholic. Apart from that it has vineous and fruity notes, mango and orange. Quite sugary. Overall a nice, complex beer, but unfortunately overshadowed by too much sweetness and alcohol. Many thanks to Bierkoning for this.

Pours a hazy pecan color with pieces of floating yeast cake and a thin head. Tart fruity aroma with some toasted bread, yeast, light caramel, yogurt. Very sweet with an upfront vitamin flavor. I dont get much in the way of hops, except some bitterness. Interesting fruitcake flavor. Opens up as it warms. Kinda grows on you.

I got the bottle from State Line in Elkton, MD and it immediately hit me with a perfumey aroma coupled with a fragrance of sweet oak. I tasted hints of malt, oak and breadiness. The alcohol was definately noticeable. It seemed a bit too syrupy and spicey so I had trouble sipping this one. It seems good in small sips. I found it interesting but my wife detested it.

Bottle thanx to Jannik Salholt. Orange colour with lots of floaties. Medium white head. Dark fruits, raisin, prun aroma and a sweet fruity alcoholic taste. Medium to full body and a sweet alcoholic finish. To much alcohol in the taste, but wery good.
A bit sweet, but nicely heavy. Slight bitter sweet after taste. Great deep coloured appearence, what else can someone wish for x-mas. (number 2 in my top 10)

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 Sugar and spice and everything nice in the nose.  Murky orange with a foamy white cap.  Good lace.  Very sweet with loads of sugar.  Fruit cake.  Very full bodied for a Belgian.  Alcohol abounds.  Watch out for this one.
Bottle.  Thick looking orangeish appearnce.  Very murky and lots of chunks float in this pour.  Delicious raisiny, figgy, sugary, syrupy flavor.  The alcohol is very well hidden in this brew.

Bottle:  Transparent orange/amber, nice carbonation, plenty of floaties, with a white diminishing head.  Aromas were of white wine, slightly tart fruits/citrus touches, some caramel, faint alcohol.  Flavor was syrupy sweet (though not textured that way), tart fruit but not overly done, raised, ever so slight alcohol touch.  Short lived aftertaste, thicker body with a warming finish.
Bottled:Aroma is full of malt, sugary. Sweet candy notes, sticky, quite too sweet but aromatic. Some fruitiness.

A cloudy orangish amber hue when poured.Very thin head that laced up in the middle and stayed for the whole ride.Definately taste the alcohol has i feel the belly get warm.Raisins, plums, kind of sweet leaving my mouth with a little tingle.Overall it was a little heavy but definately drinkable.

A Mes rate:
Chunky sweet and full of toffee and carmel and hard alcohol. Not sure if I should have started the night off with this cheeky little number but we shall see. The body is as orange as I have seen. Looks more like a heavy cider. The head was great... while it lasted. RIP head. Slight lacing not over the top tho. The nose is all sugar and toffee. A slight hint of something disturbing, detergent? Palate is awesome. Just how i like it. Thick and creamy with perfect amount of carbonation. The alcohol is hidden well. It drinks like something much lower in the hardcore list. Very stong tasting and not for the faint hearted. orange and peach with a full on hit of candy sugar toffee caramel and candy apples. Spicey orange finish that lasts and lasts. Not the best thing about this one for me but I will let it slide. Well its almost gone now and it slipped down very well indeed. My 4th or 5th bottle (NOT tonight!!!) of this. Much more will be had me thinks.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, medium amber with a frothy white head. Nose is candy like. Cinnamon, dried fruit, very sweet. Mouth is very sweet and full. Cinnamon again, lemons, astringent, cherrys, apricots. very nice after dinner beer.

(Bottle 33 cl) Chestnut brown with a huge "dirty" head. Lots of impurities all over - as usual by DDB. Very spicy with sweetnsour flavours - perhaps the sweetness is most pronounced - from the added honey and sugars. To be enjoyed in small quantities. 060994

Pours extemely cloudy with strong aromatic notes of musty plum, bourbon-soaked peaches, port, bubble gum, sweet candy, spice and grain alcohol.  This has a very thick mouthfeel that severly lacks any carbonation.  Lots more creamy fruits in the body - and the alcohol is hidden quite well.  Really sweet throughout, which is a slight turnoff for me.  Also, a strong cherry cough syrup taste emerges as this continues to warm.  Really unpleasant and bringing back bad childhood memories!

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 Couleur ambrée vers lorangée, presque translucide sous une dense mousse blanche.  Arômes levuré rappelant la levure de pain et le pain doiseau.  Après quelques instants, les fruits noirs (raisins secs, prunes) sexpriment au travers des malts caramels, rappelant même légèrement le sirop dérable.  Quelques vapeurs dalcool émanent du verre à leur tour.  Corps de densité moyenne, douce effervescence très plaisante.
Bottle.  Cloudy golden ale, with a big thick creamy head.  Lots of fruits in this one:  apples, pears, and apricots; hints of vanilla and banana.  One-of-a-kind silky creamy texture.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2005 Golden caramel orange body with floaties and medium offwhite head.  Citrus, dust, sweet aroma.  Sweet creamy taste of dark fruits, raisin,  caramel and pepper.

Orange with a small off white head that diminishes quickly. Yeast settled at the bottom of the chalice. The aroma is buttery and sour white grapes. Flavor is sweet, fruity, and yeasty with a slight hint of spices. Mildly bitter finish with some alcohol noticable as well.

11.6oz bottle. Served at 54­° in my NB worthy glass. (Better at 60°) Poured hazy, gold tinted orange with just a slight hazy head. Nose is spicy, wildflower honey, alcohol, with a citrus acidity. The mouthfeel is really big and creamy. The initial taste is orange marmalade, sweet and juicy, with some spice and a slight sourness. Midtaste is somewhat bitter and refreshing, with some spicy notes that remind me of the dulle teve. The alcohol is present at the finish, but it is far from overwelhming. The finish is more warming than anything, with some nice residual citrus flavor. I like the citrus flavor of the beer and the sweet and sour balance. Good stuff.

This bottle showed a bit more alcohol than the last one i tried, i think the previous bottle had aged a bit longer. Pours a clear orange/amber with just a thin white head. Very sweet caramel sweetness throughout, with lots of fruit, apples and spice. The texture was very heavy and really clinged to the palate. Very nice warming brew, but best to sit for a bit and let some of the alcohol settle down.

Translucent orange color.  Galaxy-like swirls for a head.  Small patch of sediment that landed in the center is causing a fizzy black hole that endured for the entire tasting.  Aroma is of apples, dough, anise and cinnamon.  Flavor is very sweet, cloying.  Apples, vinegar, dough and pepper.  Like a tart apple cobbler.  Heavy, sticky and harsh on the palate upon entry, but then pleasantly subsides with each swallow.  Sweet, sweet malts.  Finish is light, bready and sweet.  A unique experience.  I dont think Id do this on again, but Id welcome Reserva.  I know, twist my arm, right?
Golden/caramel coloured with a great off white head. Very vinous with lots of alcohol, fruit and plums. Delicious and very complex
Golden with big offwhite head. Nicwe aroma with hints of yeast and alcohol in the good way. Full bodied complex taste with sweetness, bitterness and nootes of spices. Fruity dry aftertaste.

pours brown with an orange hue. thin white head that stays with the beer. aroma is fruity, spice and malt. taste is very good. malt, apricot, spice, alcohol and mabye some caramel kind of sweet. glad bought four bottles of this.

Bottle Pours orange and cloudy with a small and quickly dissipating head.  It does leave a good lace, though.  There was quite a bit of sediment at the bottom of the bottle.  At first the aroma was very vinous and little sour (in a good way).  The smell of alcohol was present (but quickly faded).  There was some orange peel, banana and citrus fruits lingering in the background.
At first sip, the alcohol really presents itself, but like the aroma, fades into the background.  Its slightly fruity and astringent while still cool, and it hits the back of your throat with a dry bitterness that goes all the way down, and warms you from the inside out.
Around midbottle, the flavor really takes off.  It becomes sweet without cloying.  You can really feel the candy sugars along with some dark fruitiness (cherries and oranges).  After it warms, the finish becomes very smooth and fruity-sweet.
This one will put you in a good mood, instantly.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2007 Thin, frothy head.  Settles quickly to a thin foam with very light carbonation.  Lots of floaties in there although I tried to pour very easily.  Sweet candy aroma with a little bit of fruit, yeast and spices.  Some honey and caramel also.  Color is a medium golden orange.  Quite thick and syrupy palate but very smooth and very good. Lively palate.  Little sweet with lots of fruit and spices.  Big alcohol kick that warms as it goes down.  Hint of coconut in there.  More caramel and honey.   Finish is clean and smooth and nicely warming.  A very good and heavy belgian strong ale.  Wish I had more.

Pours a hazy "Belgian brown" color body with some interesting bubbles clinging to the side of the glass and a small white head.  Nice, sweet spiced apple aroma.  The taste is quite sweet at first but mellows fast keeping the sweet undertone with a slight hop bite and a little alcohol sneaking through.  Very Good!

What a nice little beer this is.    Nice sweet aroma.  Appearance is a great golden color Flavor is very sweet initially followed by a mellowing bitterness and alcohol taste.  Which actually works pretty well.  Id drink this again.

Clouded reddish amber hue, no head formation. Sweet malty aroma, raisin, caramel, apple, fairly fruity. Sweet rich malt palate, syrupy with caramel/toffee middle and a slightly bitter fruity finish. Alcohol hits at the front of the palate but mellows as it spreads.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 (Rerate 8/4/2007, prev 4/4/2005, 8-4-9-5-17) Dark orange color, cloudy appearance. Little lasting white head. Fruity, caramel, sweet, spicy aroma with thin licorice, alcohol, grains, yeast and lemon, rich aroma indeed. Near full bodied, excellent palate with nice warming alcohol. Flavor has medium licorice, sweetness, strong fruits and spices, woody nutty tones, raisins, also medium alcohol comes up. Sweet raisins and alcohol in lasting aftertaste. Excellent brew!

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2005 Golden red pour with no head.  Starts off fruity and spicy before a sugary sweetness kicks in.  What saves it from being too sweet is how the fruit, alcohol, and a touch of bitterness come back at the very end.  A brilliant ale.

2004 bottle.  Pours a orange-amber color, with little head.  Aroma of tart apples, vanilla, and peppery yeastiness.  This is one thick beer, bordering on syrupy.  Sweet flavor of banana and raisins, with alcohol and vanilla in the finish.  A good sipping beer as sweetness can get cloying if consumed faster.

Bottle slightly chilled and aged until 4/05. The aroma is somewhat like a fruity cheesecake with brandy in the mix. Color is a medium cloudy brown and even though the head was small thats forgivable since its a Belgian ale. It did leave some lacing though. Taste is complex and covers the gamut of flavors in most European ales. It is sweet, fruity, bitter, malty, acidic and high in alcohol. (Maybe a little too high since it comes off as way too bitter) It has that wonderful quality of tasting different at the start and finish. (more beer like to start, more wine like in the finish) In this ale I detect bananas, pears, and apricots. Aftertaste is a surprisingly good combination of a little smokiness matched with a beautiful sweet sangria wine that is hampered only by a biting bitterness. Almost perfect save the bitterness.
Okay I received one nasty bottle when I bought this. Not only did it have no discernable aroma it tasted way to sweet as if this bottle had been sitting a little too long.

Pours an orange-amber color with a small white head.  This beers nose is alcoholic, containing raisins, apples, and very sweet mead with spicy hops.  Very sweet, spicy, alcoholic flavors.  Chewy and smooth.  Hints of raisins, cinnamon, black pepper and mint come through.  The alcohol is not well hidden, but I didnt expect it would be at 12%.  Great mouthfeel that reminds me of a barleywine.  Aftertaste is dry and full of spices and pepper.

Its a flat looking, brownish-orange ale with a slight head, soon no head.  The first scent to leave the glass is that of dark candy sweetness.  This is quickly followed by a sharp hop bitterness, then alcohol and a peppery spiciness.  The drink is thick, acidic, alcoholic, and flavored by sweet, sweet malts, spicy fruits, white peppers, and alcohol.  Plenty of alcohol.  Its got a long, dry, warming finish.  I need to buy more of these so that I can age some bottles.

Orange brown pour with a thin off-white head.  This is looking very similar to a barleywine.  With an alcohol percentage this high it would be very difficult to hide...but it is cloaked very well behind the big malt,  candied fruit sweetness, spiced  apples, grapes, and bready, with a touch of a well balanced spice bouquet...mainly cinnamon, but others  are there.  Finish is sweet with a warming, peppery, alcohol burn.  It is sweet but not overly so...very barleywine like in several aspects.  Thick and syrupy...a good tooth coater.  Flavorful and blended well.   Difficult to describe and do it hardly the justice it deserves.
Brass coloured with loads of sediment. Huge head. Fruity, zesty yeast-aroma. Sweet and warming flavour with notes of marzipan. Alkohol-bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2006 Aroma: light molasses cookie, raisin, apple, corriander.  Appearance: homemade apple cider, copper color, good lacing, cloudy, bubbly.  Flavor: moderate sweetness.  sweet/sour apple finish. honey and maple syrup.  Corriander or cinnamon. long finish.  Palate: medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation.  7, 4, 8, 2, 13 = 3.4

Rerate on 5/15/05.  Thanks Chuck.  The beer pours to a bright golden body that is glowing.  Nice white head.  The aroma is apples, oak barrel, alcohol, cinnamon, gingerbread cookie.  The flavor is nice.  Sweet honey, maple syrup, apples, apricots, Calvados.  The palate is really warming, sweet, syrupy, nice lingering feeling/flavor.  Much better.
big malt . roasted caramel and raisins with figs and bananas brandyish and coples candied fruits and nuts, pecans? lovely beer

Pours a cloudy amber with almost no head. Tons of yeast in the bottle. Sweet, but surprisingly balanced. Bananas, apple mix with the candi sugar. Slightly bitter after taste. Alcohol is well hidden. Smooth and best served warm.

HUGE amount of yeast at bottom of small bottle cloudied the glass quickly. First sip is silky smooth with hints of apple and lots of yeast. No hint of the high alcohol. Very smooth and very satisfying. Remains smooth and remarkably satisfying. Truly delicious. Slight caramel hints begin to reveal as the glass warms and the alcohol hits my cranium.

Had this in the De Gare bar in Bruge. Couldnt find a spare table for my son and I but this Belgian gentleman gestured that we could share his. He was drinking this very slowly, amost with a degree of respect. He finished and then left. Obviously I had to try this one. There is a cloudiness to this which simply says unpasteurised, a good thing. The head stayed well in my glass, probably due to the skill of the glass washers. The nose is quite strong with a great deal of estery flavours coming through, especially some banana. Mouthfeel is huge and I can taste a sticky date pudding in a glass. Excellent. The aftertaste is dry and mellow at the same time. Merry Christmas.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Cloudy amberish beer  with a tiny quick ending white head. Sweet aroma of fruits, malts, yeast & candy. Full bodied and taste of honey and caramel. The aftertaste is somewhat hoppy and bitter with notes of fruit!
Way too sweet, some spice and bitter, but it cant touch the sweetness. Alcohol completely hidden. Not for me.

Poured a very cloudy amber with a small white head which goes away after a short while.  Sweet, fruity, malty, yeasty, candy-like.  Very interesting.   Mouthfeel is much thicker than anticipated....I like....very full bodied.  Flavor is even better...lotsa caramel sweetness with some honey-like notes.  Yum.  Nice hop bitterness comes through in the end.  Nicely complex.  I love it even more as it warms.  The finish is still fruity and provides a nice alcohol warmth.  Reminds me of how much I enjoy Belgian ales....and how much I miss living over there!  Ill be sure to get more of these!  Thanks Cornboy!
the best belgian christmas beer in my opinion! very sweet, but not to sweet. with the years, the taste keeps getting better!

Bottle:  Aroma is very sweet and has lots of apple.  Pours a dark hazy amber with lots of sediment.  Not much of a head, just a white ring around the edge of the glass.  Wow this sweet!  Tons of apple and sugar.  Its like drinking overly sweet apple juice.  A little alcohol is noticeable in the finish, but its more of the warming than actual flavor.  Too sweet for me to give this a great score.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2008 This is an entirely different brew from the 2000 Reserve already rated.

The appearance is a lighter orange than either the standard Stille Nacht, or the 2000 Reserve. 

The nose is laden with cloves and bananas, with a light underrpinning of citrus. There is also a cedary/sandpapery note. The head is substantial, and longlasting, and there is a wonderful lace.

The body is chewy, but not so much as in the 2000, and certainly nowhere near a bottle of 96 I had the good fortune to try, recently.

The palate is banana and clove, with a strong mandarin orange/orange peel undertone, as well as a "tight" array of spices, which are "holidaylike" in nature, but difficult to delineate separately. There is DEFINITELy a stronger hop presence than I am used to in Stille Nacht, and also a sour dryness, and woodiness that is almost austere enough to put me in mind of Calvados. Perhaps it was aged in those casks, since that seems to be a trend, of late.

At any rate, this was a challenging, different flavor, but on the whole, a very rewarding one.

Had it on Christmas Eve with my family.  Cloudy and sediment filled but still a nice orange with large full creamy off white head that produces very nice lacing.  Very fruity presensce on top of a yeasty base aroma and a spicy sour fruity presense.  Astringent feel, active on the palate.  Sharp and spicy light fruit.  Grapes give it a wine like venious flavor and feel.  Supprised that there isnt much yeast flavor.  There is a sour, slightly alcholic wine finish.  Nice set of complex flavors.
On draught.  Starts out cloudy with a nice modest head that lingers a while.  Nice malty taste with a slightly bitter finish.  A great arly winter beer best suited to late November/early December.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2005 just fantastic (bottle from brickskeller).
huge aroma: fruity, malty, evidence of the alcohol content, a little woodsy-ness. pours a clear amber with beautiful lacing.  Flavor is simply excellent.  Maltiness is dominating, but the complexity of the malt notes, the addition of the yeasts characteristics.  excellent brew

second tasting: clear amber,  aroma is alcohol, malt, a little fruit...peach/apricot.  flavor is a wonderful blend of spice, alcohol, malt, and milt hop bitterness to offset the intense sweetness.  great

96 bottling:  completely different beer.  pours a cherry rose.  aroma is winier, but still figs and bread.  flavor is an explosion: tart, sweet, full.  the tartness dominates...i know there arent cherries in the beer, but it really tastes like there could be.  phenomenal.
nicely done belgian.   hops, alcohol and malt with some hints of fruit intertwined in the nose and taste of this brew.  overall very tasty.

A pungent, hoppy and incredibly complex tasting beer perfect for a cold winters night.  Strong alcohol content with hints of scotch-dipped cherries and copper-kettle baked apples.  A bit of coriander and orange as well.  Packs a punch!

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2005 2004 on tap at Old Toad in Rochester.  Had no expectations when I tasted this beer but was pleasantly surprised when I took the first drink.  Aroma of Spice and hops with a nice amber hue with fizzy head that dispersed quickly.  Strong flavor with first sip that takes you back at first but then the natural apple spices combine with other various flavors of the season to make a delicious brew.  Yeast had a very strong presence that masked the alcohol.  I made a special trip back to the bar the next night just to get his beer again.  I think they put cocaine in it or something because the flavor was addictive.  Need to find this beer again!

2004 Version. 
Loaded, dense and veiled color. Dense foam much and long-lasting one. Great persistence. Sturdy, strong and decided aroma. Great structure, much liquor with apple notes.

Shiny to deep orange color.  Little to no head. Spicy and alcohol aroma. Thick and Chewy mouthfeel.  Fruity upfront flavor with a dry alcohol finish.  This beer definitly continues to grow on you as you drink.  Good Stuff.

Bottle.  Even though I left a crapload of yeast in the bottle, a crap load of it still made it in the snifter.  Hazy burnt orange, small speckled head.  Sweet malt, carmelly tones, yeasty and some banana.  Flavor pretty much matches the nose.  Heavy on the tongue, but not oily or overly viscous feeling. KInd or boring mouthfeel, it just kinda sits there.  Aftertaste is long and strong and bittersweet.  Good beer, but a little too sweet.

Hey now. This is a very flat, almost uncarbonated beer, thats a kind of pale orangey-brown. Its really sweet and fruity, almost tasting like a gueze lambic. Its not completely sweet, as it has a classic Belgian bitterness that lingers a bit to counter the sweetness.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2005 Original Rating (10-Jan-2005, 6-1-8-2-13=3.0): Apricot, plum, peach (sugary tinned fruit), raw flour, doughy, alcohol, vinous aroma.  Unappealing appearance is opaque brown-orange with no head whatsoever.  Very, very sweet, fruity (orange, apricot) and alcoholic with a pleasant dark malt bitterness to counterbalance.  Still and sticky in the mouth.  Id really love to resample a fresher version of this as it seems like there is a wonderful beer here but I was just a bit too late for the party.  Bottle (2003) sampled with MartinT and Rastacouere.  Thanks, Kawa!Rerate (8-5-8-4-17=4.2): Dark fruits, alcohol and yeast figure prominently in the aroma.  Deep orange-tan with a generous and lasting off-white head that leaves beautiful lacing.  Dark fruits mingle with caramel and toffee-like malts with some hints of alcohol an a light tangy tartness.  Medium-light body with moderate, fine-bubbled, softly effervescent carbonation that carresses the mouth.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT, Olivier_MTL and Rastacouere.

Bottle Clear, orrange-amber body.  White fizzy-creamy head, which lasts mostly.  Spare lcae.  Banana and malts in the nose.  Lightly bitter, lightly sweet initital flavour.   Heavily bitter, lightly sweet finish.  Fully bodied.  Oily texture.  It was long time ago, I had a new splendid beer like this.

Pleasant fruity aroma. Flavor is malty and sweet with hints of fruit throughout. A sour twinge in the end. Very enjoyable by itself and no mor ethan one in a session makes this a brew I could drink the year around.

53.9F
Lovely aroma -- hangs itself in the air.  Smells like middle of the season apple cider ( cider with a good mix of variety apples) steaming on the stove with a dash of orange juice.
Tastes of dried apples, dried, unsulphured peaches.  Umm, peach jam with brandy.  Theres an alcohol sting-ray flying bout with a clove-studded orange (what the hell is that called -- email me) tied to its tail, and whipping my mouth.  Nice and oily on the glass, and palate.  Color of pie pumpkin guts.  I likee.  Man, its been half an hour since I finished the 11.6 oz. and my review, and Im still drunk. Dont expect to drink one of these and drive.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2007 i poured the b.s.a. into my chimay glass and recieved hardly any head and a body that was a beautiful hazey orange.the aroma was very sweet with hints of cottn candy,honey,and caramel.i was blwon anway by the first sip.belgian yeast,candy,honey,malts,and a bit of hops rushed to my tastebuds.i could taste a tad bit o alcohol but @ 12%,im not complaining.go out and get a bottle of this if you have not had it.its serious stuff!!!!
RE-RATE:BOTTLE AGED FOR ONE YEAR...poured  a super murky orange with no head at all.aroma had gone a bit sour and seemed close to a lambic or gueze.flavor was still boozey and sweet and didnt match the aroma at all.alot of the hops and carbonation are gone.2004 re-rate on 5/9/2007.this is still a little sweet and id like to see more sour notes come out at this point.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2007 2005 bottle. Murky golden copper, huge white head, lasts awhile. Aroma has tons fruity esters and candi sugar. Banana and sugared plums. Chewy/yeasty bread. Flavor much the same. Big fruit esters, candi sugar and yeasty bread. Some faint sourness is starting to creep in, this is good, might bring another dimention in the future. Slight alcohol kick, dries the beer out near the finish. Heavy/oily mouthfeel, works well with this. Glad I revisted.

Hazy medium brown color with a bouniful head.  Sweet yeasty aroma almost sourlike.  More sweetness and bitter in the initial taste.  Alcohol is there from begginnig to end, not to subdued. Very flavorfull, smooth mouthfeel.  Sweet and fruity till the end, very nice.

Bottled, 2004 Vintage 
Hazy orange with floating yeast particles. Decent creamy slightly off-white head.  Aroma has sweet banana, grape and yeast. Sourish, bitter, lots of grape with underlying sweet fruity tones. Hides alcohol quite well but it gives a good backbone to body.  Nice hop character. Complex and interesting.

Amber colour with some haze, the head is small but lasting, off-white colour. Sweet malty nose with some fruit and yeast. Lots of malt in the flavor, again with some fruit and yeast. Hints of the alcohol in the finish.

33 cl bottle (2004 edition); orange, hazy with wonderful tight off-white longlasting head, that drags belgian laze down the side of the glass. Unfortunately massive gunks off yeast also pours into the glass. Excellent smell of marzipane and fruit. Taste is beyond anyting Ive tasted recently: Complex, spicyness with massive licorice taste??? Flavour is sweet, but not too sweet for a beer of this strength - far better than the "Bush" of similar strength. Good mouthfeel with adequate carbonation. A small masterpiece in a bottle!

(on bottle, 2004 edit.) At last a non-beliver in the belgian hype, gets a wake up call. This is most definently the best belgian I´ve ever had. Opens with a( wonder wy, with 12%) alcoholic nose, witch soon blends in with the sweetnes of rotten apples and pears. Pure delight goes in the mouth, beer lifted to a smoothness of vanilla, muscat and whiped cream. All that is lifted with a perfect carbonation and thoughness af serious malts. Thanx for this to the screwed-up-brewer(or something like that ;)

2003 sample.Pours a dark honey colour with no head whatsoever. The aromas were rich, honey, apples, plums, alcohol and very sweet smelling. The flavours were massive and intenesly lingering big sweetness up front followed by apples, plum,malt,cinnamon, and a nice alcohol kick in the end, very thick mouthfeel. An enjoyable sipping beer but due to the near overwhelming sweetness 1 will do just fine.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 2002 tasted 2004: Rich malty aroma in an almost overwhelming sweet beer. Pleasant drinking but not more than one.
2003 tasted 2006: Orange with a lasting off-white head. Caramel and some butterscotch, dried fruits, wood and walnuts in the aroma. Sweet and full flavour with nearly no alcohol presence.
2006 tasted 2006: More citrus in the aroma. More alcohol presence.

Bottle dated 2/21/04: Pinkish amber color with a small white head (1st time Ive seen a small head on a de dolle). Aroma: sour, fruity, barnyard, leather, candy, spice, honey.  Taste: surprisingly sweet after the aroma, honey, apples, pear, clover, sweet light malts, with a nice lemon/apricots tartness in the background, finishing with an alcohol kick, sweet malt, and fruits.  Need to try this after many years in the cellar.
1998 bottle.  Poured a dark golden color.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with hints of honey.  Flavor starts sweet and turns to sour tart apples.  Long fruity finish.  Light to medium body.
Pours brownish with no head. Fruity aroma with a malty initial taste. Followed by a slight alcohol twinge. Next up was an extremely pleasant, sweet aftertaste. The aftertaste makes this beer great.

This beer has an  amber body - hue apperance and a coarse white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had no carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is sweet with a very strong afther tast.

Off white large mostly lasting foamy head. Dark amber color. Aroma is moderately sweet, malty, fruity (apricots) with candy and light spicy notes. Flavor is moderately sweet, fruity with banana, peach and light caramel and alcohol tones, ending in a dry, moderately fruity finish. Full bodied.

Amber colour with a huge off-white head. Sweet spicy aroma with notes of yeast and alcohol.
Nice sweet flavour with lots of spices and fruit, well balanced bitterness.

Very cloudy, pale orange colour with floaty bits. The aroma has marzipan, candy floss and noticeable alcohol volatility. A bit sweet in the mouth. Reminds me of cherryade. Bittersweet finish. Interesting, but not entirely my cup of tea. Bottled at the Beer Circus Croydon (Christmas beers festival). I noted this as 12% ABV.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 Bottled 11.6oz.  Pours murky orange- brown with no head. Sticky sweet aroma.  Notes of cherries, raisins and sugar, maybe even honey.  Almost as sweet as a barleywine.  Syrupy mouthfeel thats coats the mouth.  Spice and candy notes along with a bit of vanilla.  Aftertaste is sweet with an alcohol warmth.

Orange red beer with a thick light yellow head that lasts all the way to the bottom of the glass.  Yeast floaties in the glass.  Aroma of caramelized sugar, candi sugar, cherries, fruit, oak and earthiness.  There is a light acetic acid aroma as well that strengthens as the beer warms.  Flavour is quite sweet and fruity up front showing flavours of cherry, white grapes, honey, and candi sugar.  This initial talste lengthens into a light sweet and syrupy flavour before a spicy hop finish.  Moderate bitterness rounds it off.  Seems like a cross between a Belgian Strong Ale and a Flemish Sour Ale.  Incredibly good.

Cloudy brown color with no head.  Aroma is full of cherries and dark berries.  Sweet malt taste with more of the delicious cherry, blackberry, prune, and raisin taste.  Damn fine and my favorite De Dolle!
Brown/Orange Coloring With White Ring. Yeast Aroma. Instant Warming..Trademark of De Dolle...Syrapy Sweet..Bread Dough..Prunes..Thick Body..Fruity.  Very Enjoyable!!

Bottled.  A sweet fruity yoghurty aroma including the raspberry pips to this amber coloured beer with a whitish head.  The alcohol comes through together with strawberry blancmange tastes.   Very nice

Medicinal aroma with some port notes. Alcohol and citrus ther too. Amber with a tan lasting head. Sweet slightly sour. Spicy, sugar, plums, fruits and cough syrup. Smooth full bodied. Quite warming. Nice.

11.6 fl oz bottle - Market Sq. Liquors - Tallahassee, Fl.  Pours an odd, vegetable broth like murky orange pour with little to no head. Tart, slightly citrusy aroma with traces of kids vitamins. Flavor has a bit of an acidic taste to it, some citrus notes and alcohol and the same kids vitamins flavors found in the aroma. High alcohol content is apparant and just a tad distracting.  Mouthfeel is thick enough. Had better Belgians

Hazy, maple syrup-colored beer.  Bad label. White head with a tan particulate roan. Vinegar, apricot and Belgian yeast aroma.  Lively flavor profile, a woody-fruity affair, mildly astringent.  ABV apparent - I was guessing 8.5-9% before I saw the content here. I didnt like the way that this turned over in the mouth -- it became too bitter and astringent -- almost pecan or green apple bitter, with a sugary sweetness that didnt cover the bitter.  Some pruniness at times.

A hazy, honey color with an internal cloud floating within and atop.   Hmmm, specks of black?  What the hell is that?  Nose is sweet and a bit pungent, like candy being burnt.   Big sweet, yeasty flavor, a bit fruity with orange peel and molasses, followed by a great deal of alcohol warmth.  This one is big, but nice.

33 cl bottle. Served in snifter. 
2004 edition. Apparently, this has now been bumped up from 8% to 12% abv. Hazy orange w/ plenty of sediment. OK head. The aroma is very sweet w/ obvious alcohol presence. The taste is huge: very sweet, alcoholic, yeasty and very full. Long, spicy, warming finish w/ assertive, firm bitterness that balances the general impression nicely. Thick, full, lively mouthfeel - very nice. Surprisingly easy to drink. 
Way better than the 2003 edition (according to my ratings, at least). The increase in alcohol really have done wonders for this beer.

Bottled 11.2 oz. Copper colored Fruity sweet aroma. Fair amount of alcohol taste  mixed with sugary taste. Has potential but has too many tasted competing against each other instead of working with each other.

Hazzy thick amber color and not much head.  The aroma is full of orange peel and cloves.  The flavor is very zesty, giving quite the interesting mouthfeel.  There is a uniform bitterness keeping this beer fresh on the tongue throughtout its sweetness.  Aftertaste is sweeter and has hints of oranged and apples.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2004 <Re-Rate> 1998 - 12oz. from Bottleworks.

A *totally different* beer aged for 5+ years.  The age yields a vinous, sweet and acidic beer that is less complex.  This (turned)white grape elixir matches the way I like beer - malty, sweet and warm.

2003 vintage - Burns the Nose with caramel and  toffee heat.  Taste of Butter Rum (spiced). Nice sticky finish.  A sipper and a warm friend.  Being curled up with her is a good thing.

copper color.no head. smells like candi sugar and elmers glue. really its elmers glue, remember drinking this stuff as kid.this is a really good version of it. This is sweet, sweet,  sweet with a very alcoholic finish. Sweet is not my thing but i am enjoying this in a wierd way.

Hazy, orange/copper color with no head. Sweet aroma of candi sugar, malt and wood. Flavor is very sweet. Belgian candi sugar, dark fruits and an alcoholic bite at the end. Full bodied with very little carbonation. A bit too sweet for my taste, but very good regardless.

Siilent night, stiiill night, all is warm, all a delight, round yon brethren round the fire, hoooly brew so malty and bright, drink in heavenly peace, driink in heavenly peace.    (in german!)  Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!
Alles schläft; einsam wacht
Nur das traute hoch heilige Paar.
Holder Knab im lockigten Haar,
: Schlafe in himmlischer Ruh! :

2004Cloudy and orange. Small head reduces to the typical Belgian layer of film resting on top. Lots of candy sugar in the nose along with what reminds me of raisin bread. Alcohol unfortunately is a bit strong in the aroma. This is a young one though. Nice body, really smooth and sticky sweet. Flavor is sweet and malty with lots of candy sugar here too. Almost barley wine-ish with the sweet maltiness. Some herbals in the finish are nice. Overall another good one from De Dolle. This should age very well.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Reddish amber, cloudy, lasting white head, potent aroma ranging from sugar to white grape to honey, flavor equally impressive with sugar, yeast, honey, date, apple all present. complex and delicious , although a little too much sweetness near the end for me
woody aroma with hints of raspberry, dark orange with zero head, strong and syrupy hints of maple with lots of candi sugar, alcohol very prevalent and some spritzy nuances near the finish

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2005 Looks like a glass of apple cider.Sweet fruity alcohol nose but the taste was overly sweet.I have had many of these and only rated this one so I am feeling strange here as this seems sweeter then the rest.

It is hard to pull my nose out of the glass with this one. Lots of brown sugar, fruit and maybe some spices. Tiny head with a different looking lace. It has a nice aged copper colour that is very cloudy. The taste is terrific. The first sip is malty, with lots of sweetness. The imemense sweetness follows with a acidic ending where the hops just barely shows through. It has a lingering taste that coats your lips. Defintaly begs you to drink more.

33cl bottle labled "98" from Bottleworks...meaning vintage 1998, 6years old...Brings back some memories!  This may be the beer and the year that I fell in love with Belgian beers!  Back then I got it mailed to my door from Johns Grocery...this beer was simply unlike anything I had ever imagined, as was Oerbier.  So how can I fault it now?  Overripe and fermenting fruits billow out of the glass followed by sweet maltose...after  6 years in the bottle, this puppy is still quite bubbly, although the inside of the bottlecap was black!  I think if you combine this beer and Oerbier reserva you get something like Speciaal Brouwsel?  This is the best overtly sweet bier for me, the only balance is the fairly tart presence in the finish, like a good Granny Smith apple...perfumey aroma...It plays elegantly with my head, probably best as a nightcap or dessert beer.

Pours a cloudy copper/gold. Aromas of brown sugar, malt, fruit and a little spice.
Flavor is sweet, with malt, brown sugar, fruit, and just a bit of hops. I think this needs more time to mature.

Pours a nice reddish brown color with a tiny lacing head. It has a big fruity aroma that smells of brown sugar. The taste is very sweet and somewhat malty with almost un-noticible hop flavor. The finish is almost too sweet...not a bad brew, but Ive had better.

Poured a murky brownish/amber with no head. Smells a touch spicey, though mostly of bread dough, sugar and Barbecue sauce. Definitely do not notice this "extra bitterness" in the nose or the taste. The taste comes across as way tooo sweet, with wood, vanilla, and fruit. Smoked candy is there, as is terriyaki chicken. I guess the hops come in in the finish, as it is pretty dry, considering the sweetness. In all, I am not impressed, perhaps even a bit disgusted...

Poured hazy orange with almost no head...smelled a little spicy but just very very sweet and a touch of alcohol...maybe some citrus...taste was just sweet and alcohol though...not impressed...the pour, carbonation, flavor, and finish all were strikingly similiar to a mediocre barleywine...

Bottle.  Pours a murky light brown.  Head is small, slow to form.  Lacing is slight.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Nice smooth mouthfeel.  Perhaps a little sweet.  Flavors of fruits and malt are indeed balanced with hops.  Will drink more of this one.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2007 Rustic Orange. Nice color. The head was barely achieved and mostly diminishing. Very little lacing. 

The smell is very sweet from the white candy sugar. Very fruity with fresh oranges, tangerines and honey. The aroma is wonderful. Its in your face, very acidic and pungent. 

This is one damn tasty beer. The mouthfeel is the first thing that I noticed. Its so damn soft and velvety and just seems to glide effortlessly across every taste bud, soak it and then leave. Numerous Fruits. Cherries and Raspberries first. Raisins next, then plums, now dried plums. Very sweet throughout. Cinnamon like spicyness after the fruits.

This beer has probably been brewed with the most candy sugar out of any beer I have every had. It is very very sweet and is very cloying on the finish.

Im hoping to visit De Dolle Brouwers in July. Great Brewery.

 

After several samples and different vintages, this could be my perfect beer.  A brilliant example of phenomenal freshness and ageworthinesss.  It just seems to age so well and all the batches are so good.
A very sweet malty Christmas brew.  Didnt detect any spices but the flavor was really sweet and malty.  Had this on tap and it poured a cloudy brown.  It tasted much better than it looked.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 Bottle @ Collins Bar. Not a bad brew at all. A bit sweet and not as peppery as Id like but very smooth, malty and sticky.

Hazy golden orange color, with microscopic floatules (what Im calling them these days) buzzing around the edge of the glass, and a most impressive head that took up 3/4 of the Duvel glass the brew was poured into and then still wanted to bubble over: large and lasting, solid, but creamy.
I put my nose in this soft, enticing foam and was exulted: fresh, fruity, dazzling, sugary...Im thinking "tripel" but I know that theres more in store...slightly spicy, light, elegant, ethereal, divine.
Taste has a zing and a zip and dazzles with intense fruit flavors (orange, peach), so rich, juicy, and tangible that I can nearly taste the pit and the seeds!
Im put into heaven here...its simply sublime...malt is huge with sweetness and fruit, perhaps too much so, and theres not a nod from Mr. Hops. A pity for that would have provided sufficient balance and given an extra dimension to this ale.
As it is, its still amazing. Ah, theres nowhere to go from here...a perfect nightcap... a suffficient summation of goodness in a glass.

Euro size bottle with 03 marked on the cap.
Pours a red/gold color that's pretty clear until I dump some yeast chunks into it. Head is an off white with poor retention and sticky lace. Aroma is wine-like, astringent and cidery. Mouthfeel is full bodied and syrupy with some effervescence?intense. Flavor is sweet with some hop bite. Quite one-dimensional. Musta gotten a bad bottle?

Pours a orange-brown with very little head.  Smells freakin delicious; malt, spices and a bit of booze.  At first sip it is all sweetness, however its glory is revealed in subsequent drinks.  Sweet candi and malt are most prevalent, but there is a spicy yeasty component that rounds out the flavor.  One of the richest Belgians Ive had; the mouthfeel is stunning.  Pleasant alcohol comes through also.  Very well done!

bottled: unkown year
pours orange brown haze with little carbonation. small tan bubbles if you pour rapidly with sediment.
nice nose of earth and dark fruits.  the palate is a bit different then the nose more sweet rock candy malt with figs and a huge alcohol sting.  no where on the bottle does it say the abv. if i were guessing i would have said at least 10 or higher. somewhat surprised to see a 9....maybe we do need to age this one. not nearly as enjoyable as the other rates advised for the bottle i had.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 I swear to god I entered a rating for this stuff based on a ten year old bottle I tried in Belgium but its gone. This is really a major point of concern for me considering I cant see myself trying another aged-for-ten-years bottle of this stuff within the next ten years and the only place where my notes were stored was RB. Ho hum....
This is a big malty, Belgian monster. If you have a problem with that, leave me alone, I dont want to talk to you. Pours brown with no head. Nose is huge with malt and spice with a nice tart note. Its that tart note that really makes this beer interesting and worth spending an extra few dollars to drink. It compliments perfectly the raisin and dried fruit flavors and the easily detectable alcohol presence. Hopefully, some day, Ill be able to keep one of these around for ten years....

Nice amber color with a thin head. Geat aroma of spices, alcohol and what seems to be candi sugar. Great flavor of spices and candi sugar. Full body, sticky mouthfeel. Very good beer, deep, complex, sweet but not cloyingly sweet, very nicely done !

UPDATED: APR 6, 2005 At the KULMINATOR in Antwerp. Outstanding bottle of Stille Nacht 1998. Old-golden color with warm dark-orange shine and extreemly fluffy head. Beautyful bouquet varyously descibed as heavenly creme bruleé,vanilla, honeyed, whiff of Coxs oranges peppins and fine malty touch with freshness. The taste is very complex
and perfect in balance. It has a round taste with a sexy fruityness and a great fullboddied feeling of malts, fresh custard, almonds, ripe apple, honey and dried white fruits. This is TOP.
Also at KULMINATOR the 1982 Vintage. Nice red-brown beer with a very creamy and frothy light colored head. Deep aromas of raisins, marsalla, portwine (Vintage), ripe red fruits, soft spices, sweet bread, good malty accents, nutty touches, the ensamble is so well melted together. This beer is 23 years old and appears still so young and lively. The taste is even more impressive. Fantastic balance between sweet and sour. Lots of fruits, great body=Malty , cake like, sweet breaddy, some touches of nuts. Then the fruity side is very wine like, has hints of cherries on alcohol, vintage port, pear sirup, dry figgs and dates and a very good intgrated accend of soft asian spices. I give full marks to this monumental and legendary brew. Tasted with Jeppe (Bierkônig) at the Kulminator in Antwerp. To me a 20/20. Re-tasted 3 weeks later and i can confirm the 20/20 !

first off- i must say, this was a VERY bad choice for a beer to smoke with a cigar, it was almost repulsive until halfway through it.  however, i did drink this before i started smoking, and i thought it was a damn good beer.  poured dark orange colored, with almost no head at all.  very little carbonation in this too.  taste is fruity and very sweet, much more sweet than any barley wine ive had, without the hops.  this is still a very nice brew that i enjoyed, but im sure there are much better out there.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2005 Poured amber in color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of apples, plums, spices, sugar and malts. Nice smelling. Starts of sweet but ends with a light bitter touch. Nicely balanced. Some alcohol pokes through but does not detract from the smell or taste. Another very good beer from De Dolle (I even liked the bottle and had my wife stick the empty in her purse).

Viscous orange/gold no head or bubbles.  Cream, orange, smoke, yeast, baked apple, apricot and more nose! Syrupy sweet but well balanced by hops that clean off the palate. Very thick, with high alcohol, almost schnapps like.  Very interesting...I do wonder what will happen with age...

Bottle conditioned (330ml). Served room temperature in a chalice. Young sample, a 2003 I think. Clear in the bottle, the yeast obviously wont hold still when it comes to pouring, it pours hazy orange with small, patchy white head, that starts thin and stays that way down the glass. Typical Belgian yeasty aroma, apple, alcohol. Im not sure if sugar has any aroma, but you can sure as hell feel the sweetness when you smell this one. First taste, thick, like neat Ribena, sweetness thats matched with lots of hops. I want to love this one, but its so cloying it cant say I love it. Its good, no question, just not worthy of my love. Heartburn in a bottle.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2008 Re-Rate.Bottle, Hop Leaf (Chicago); sampled in a Hop Leaf tulip.  This is my second re-rate, but Im including it because it was a more recent bottle than the 1998, and my impression was that it was better than my first rating.  Head was ridiculously thick and foamy, and would revive with a couple of swirls of the glass.  The flavor overall was not as sickly sweet as I remember, and the spice was so much more evident.  Very nice dry finish, with a bit of hoppiness in it too.  Still not near as good as the 1998 bottle, but much better than I remember.  Ive adjusted the appearance up one and the flavor down one to reflect my new impressions.

Re-Rate. Bottle (1998 vintage), Heeren van Liedekerke, Denderleeuw.  I was informed by my waiter that in 1998, De Dolle was using Rodenbach yeast for the Stille Nacht.  Whenever I start homebrewing, I need to get my hands on some of that yeast, because every beer it touches turns to dopeness.  As you can see below, I didnt enjoy a more recent rendition of this beer.  The score above is a slightly lowered version of this vintage rating.  Clear golden brown with yellow-tan head leaving a thick dusting and an arch of lace where the head used to touch the side.  A few sparse collumns of tiny bubbles visible up the side of the glass.  Aroma is stiff: buttered raisins in a banana cream sauce made with Madiera.  Deep cherry flavor predominates on the sweet body (must be the Rodenbach yeast).  Malts taste like sweet butter with pure cane sugar blended into it; theyre strongest in the very beginning of the finish.  Golden raisins and over-ripe cherry flank the strong cherry middle, the raisins trying to take over the taste a couple times.  Finish is kind of disappointing after such a flavorful body, its mostly an echo with alcohol dryness on the top of the tongue.  Some sweet apple shows up late.  Hops are very subtle, adding a bit of orange citrus in the finish and dryness.  Dope.  10/4/10/4/18 = 4.6

Re-Rate.  I had this bottle at the Hop Duvel Cafe, Gent.  I thought it was the Stille Nacht Reserva 2005, which is what the guy told me, but he was wrong.  I bought some bottles to bring home, and was told that it was some other special version of Stille Nacht from 2005, but not the Reserva.  Since there is no seperate entry here on RateBeer, Im putting it here for the time being.  Murky orange with brown-red glow in the middle of the glass; thick dusting of head with an island on the side of sudsier bubbles.  Tight lace creeps up the side from the surface, pretty sticky.  Bubble rivulets up the side of the glass.  Smells bready, malty, with lemon grass and a tinge of corriander.  Full and warm in the mouth, the alcohol starts warm and almost burns toward the finish.  Flavors are orange peel, over-ripe plum and apricot; it reminds me of a Thomas Hardy style barley wine in the middle, but instead of golden raisin being dominant, the flavor is lighter (like dried apricots and banana chips).  Mouthfeel is not light: syrup of pure cane sugar.  Seems like it needs a few years in the bottle to smooth out and mellow.  Three seconds into the finish is where this shines, when the flavors reach peak intensity and roundness; the fruits taste fresh and lively, with sourdough maltiness over the top of it.  The end of the finish is dominated by alcohol in the throat; it also evidences black pepper and corriander spiciness.  Very interesting contrast between the middle and end, Im very intrigued to see what this is like three years from now when it has pulled together.  Not dope yet, but has potential.  7/4/8/5/16=4.0.

Original rating. Bottle into tulip glass, Hop Leaf (Chicago) 7/2/04.  I was excited about this one as Id had the Reserva with Quiroga a few weeks back, and it was dope.  This, however, was sub-dope.  It poured with absolutely no head (I even tried holding the bottle about a foot and a half above the glass as I poured.  Nothing.)  Golden yellow, yeast very visible in little tiny shards, suspended in the glass and not circulating or settling on the bottom.  That was the first clue.  This stuff is beer syrup.  It was so sweet and viscous I could barely finish the glass (I thought it would be rude to take it to the Hopleaf bathroom to drain pour).  Still, before the grossness overpowered me, I caught some nice fruity flavors: grape, a touch of annis, and a very subtle hop bitterness (didnt even come through on every sip).  Maybe next time I have pancakes or waffles, Ill try another bottle.  Im guessing this one has to be aged, so that yeast can ferment some of the sugar out of it.  6/2/6/1/8 = 2.3

1999 bottle drank in 2004 at Kulminator in Antwerp. Poured a hazy medium brown beer with a super huge head with perfect retention. Carbonation is perfect with bubbles still present 10 minutes after the beer was poured, which is a bit surprising considering the age of this beer. Aroma is a quite strong mix of plums, sugars and roasted malts. The taste of this beer is one of the most wonderful things I had the chance to drink in my lifetime and consisted of a mix of roasted and sweet malt, plums and a sweet bitter finish. Alcohol was well hidden and didnt break the overall perfect balance of this beer. Body was really thick. I must now must find more of this since it is so incredible.
Light amber color with some yeasty particles and a white head. The taste is very nice and sweet with a complex fruity pattern and notes of spices. Very nice.

Pours with a fairly loose white head, albeit short-lived. Reddish-amber in colour, with a strongly alcoholic aroma and a thick, tongue-coating feel. The initial  sweetness of the candy sugar stays with you throughout, and a resiny, alcoholic hit leaves you feeling nicely warm inside. Unfortunately, the sweetness is too overpowering, leaving me struggling to finish it. I suspect it could have benefited from a couple more years in the cellar.

Bottle, snifter.  Average, frothy, white head is well lasting.  Body is a hazy amber.  Cookie, caramel and toffee malt (H); flowery hops (M); musty yeast (M); light alcohol, clove, pear, peach, pineapple, butterscotch, maple syrup, and coriander aromas.  Harshly sweet flavor becomes a lightly bitter, heavily sweet and short finish.  Full body, creamy texture, sfot carbonation.  The bottom line is: over the top candi sugar aroma...sickeningly sweet flavor...could not finish.

Copper with no or a very thin big bubbles white head. Cloudy as well. Nose is yeasty wheaty but not there really, quite subtle. Taste is great. malty rich and creamy fruity sweet and a full syrupy body. This is a killer.

Vintage 2002. Dark orange colour, light hazy body, with floating yeast in the glass. Large, thick head, creamy-coloured, excellent lacing. Strong flowery aroma, spicy, fruit preserved in liquor, medium honey aroma, weak yeasty and alcohol notes. Taste of preserved fruit, heavy caramel, smokey aftertaste. Syrupy but never cloying, no bitterness feel but light acid/sour feel and dryness in the upper rear side of the palate, maybe also due by alcohol . Full body, creamy texture, very well balanced strong ale.

Very unusual.  Poured a murky orange with little head.  Looks like a glass of unfiltered apple cider.  The aroma was very, very faint.  Subtle note of fruit.  Nothing potent or impressive.  The flavor was BIG.  Fruity, sweet, cider-like.  Syrupy, smooth mouthfeel.  Delicious.  Excellent.

Bottle at Toronado, 05.22.04  Pours beautiful, dark, dark, amber; halo of a head.  Aromas of sweet cherries, brown sugar, bourbon.  Flavors are sweet, sweet cider, tons of chewy malts, no hops evident until very late when a vague grapeskin astringency appears.  Reminds of a Spatlese reisling, apple juice.  Finishes wonderfully sour.  Palate is full, chewy, syrupy, coating, perfect for the flavors.  Great beer!

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2006 Original - 6/1/2004 - Good sized frothy off white head... med-dark brownish orange color. Aroma has apples, non-offensive foot odor, sugary melon, and something that reminds me of pen ink (e.g. Bic).  Extremely heavy flavor, but the texture is still a bit thin. Very warming alcohol feel in the belly and I wish the carbonation wasnt as harsh. Oak, spiced apples, mead dominate the taste. Very sweet. Also very delicious. (8 / 4 / 8 / 4 / 16) 
Update 5/15/2006 - Very nice and full aroma. Some caramel both in there and flavor. Mmm... man, this is great. Great flavor...

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2009 Pours a deep orange/amber that is a little cloudy with no head, but a bunch of micro bubbles can be seen in the brew.    Aromas of wild yeast, apples, and honey.   WOW... The mouth feel is thick and tingles the taste buds with a smooth, winey, oaky honey/mead taste, with no after taste.  Alcohol is barely noticeable and spices make it a perfect evening brew.
