Pours orange-brown,  slight carbonation. Aroma is of fruit/winey.  Apples and yeast in the flavor.  Very complex, but a little young at this point, so the sweetness hides some of the complexity.  Great ale.

It pours a murky amber with almost no head. It looks still. This makes the bridge between an english barley wine and a belgian christmas ale. Aroma is rather complex, very yeasty and sweet, but also full of fruity esters. The honeyish malt profile is extremely fruity (peaches, apples, vinous grapes, oranges, pears). Aroma is also quite spicy (mint, cloves) and alcoholic, a little less would have been appreciated actually as at times you feel almost like you're having a scotch. A faint bitterness fails from balancing the almost cloying ravaging sweetness. Palate is yeasty, extremely sweet and with more of those fruits dancing on the tongue, well supported by a medium body with low to medium carbonation. No doubt this is complex and full-flavoured, but the balance is just lacking when its so sweet and a bit too much alcoholic for its own good. I must say I feel a bit let down, not only cause I love De Dolle, but also because there are plenty of things going on in this beer, but they dont seem so well blended while it has a fairly good reputation.

Pours with hardly any head that settles to a white ring.  Cloudy amber color.  Virtually no carbonation.  Medium bodied.  Nose is sweet raisins.  Starts and finishes sweet almost a little too sweet.  The high ABV is not really noticeable. Pricey - $4.85 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2005 2003. Pours deep murky orange with a little white head, but its unfortunately fast disappearing.
Fruits, apples, grapes, oranges, alcohol, candy sugar and sweetness in the nose, complex aroma i think.
Goddam... This is fucking sweet, not too cloying but it has extreme sweetness. The flavor is all about candy and fruits. Later on it turns out abit acidy and dry.
Its just so full with a nice touch of alcohol. This is a wolf in sheeps dresses, you think its a easy and nice beer, but it attacks your palate with extreme sweetness and leaves you all confused.
Very nice brew, i could drink this pretty often i think... With a big chunk of good chocolate!

2002: Murky tangerine hue with large fluffy head and good lace. The aroma has notes of Belgian candi sugar, toasted caramel malts, cardamom, clove, allspice, ripen fruit, and honey. The initial taste is extremely sweet and fruity. Undertones later of some mild bitterness and woody character. The finish displays a spicy note with a touch of acidity. The mouthfeel is full, lush, and sticky. Alcohol very well marked. A nice beer but lacks the full balance of the Reserva. Thanks Matta for the bottle.

Deep murky orange, quickly disappearing white head.  Sweet nose of brown sugar covered oranges, honey, and spices.  The Belgian candi sugar shines thru in the flavor, with additional notes of spiced orange rock candy, dark fruits, and all things sweet.  Full bodied, syrupy, sticky sweet finish.  Its very good, but one per year is about all I can do.  Would probably turn into a gem with a few years of cellar time.
Threw it out! I love Belgians.  But this is too syrupy, sweet, and funky for me.  Calling it beer is a bit of a stretch.  Yet I must admit, the alcohol is very well masked.

Huge fluffy orange tinted head. Cloudy orange body. Subdued Belgian yeast aroma with strong orange scent and candi sugar around the edges. Heavy orange/peach sugary taste. Alcohol and hops are well hidden under the syrup. Perhaps better as a desert beer or in a milkshake. Reminds me more of Florisgaarden than a Beligian Strong.

what a weird pour, almost NO head!? anyway, aroma is out of this world, hoppy, outhouse and very spicy! taste is .. well, let´s just say that they were not kidding by saying that this has "taste evolution" , very very sweet, with a spicy finish. It´s complex with some deep fruity undertones, with a nice balance of malt and hops, but candy sugar is dominant. The flavor really is quite ludicrous but very nice.  It´s so thick that it´s just completly absurd but ohhh so right!! I feel like chewing this rather then drinking. Candy candy candy .. this is special! incredibly masked, and I mean that. The most special and craziest brew I´ve sampled!

Very dark copper. No head in my tulip glass. Honey, hops and grass aroma. Flavor is complex, but overall very sweet. Bananas, cinnamon, clove and a little alcohol bite all come together. The sweetness is distracting like many Belgians. There is some hops, but it does not balance out well. I wouldn't want more than one.

This beer poured with virtually no head, hard as I tried; it has a candy apple aroma with pineapple and pear notes; thick, silky mouthfeel containing  a wonderful sourish-sweet, tart carmel flavor like nothing I've tasted before: honey, oak, clove spice, cotton candy, all come to mind; alcohol flavor is there, but doesn't have a chance over evrything else; a bit overly sweet and somewhat cloying, though there is some hop bitterness and balance by the tartness. Wild.

Coming out of the bottle, the golden yellow river coalesces into a murky honey brown with the tiniest of carbonation bubbles clinging to the side, and the thinnest wisp of a head on top.  The aroma inspires dreams of monks surrounding brewpots and chanting.  The scent of alcohol is overpowering at first, but gives way to hints of fruit and oak.  The flavor envelops the tongue in this sweetness that is both joyous and solemn at the same time.  It fades slowly, revealing the tang of alcohol, the strength of wood, and the bitter of hops, each in their own time, all underpinned with a luxurious butteriness.  This... wow... this is awesome.

Wow, just wait a few minutes and let this one sink in and captivate you.  Pours a dark garnet brown, with a tiny white frothy of a head.  The aroma is sweet and spicy, tingling your senses, with a taste that is a whirlwind on your tongue.  Very sweet and surprisingly light in the mouthfeel, then the alchohol catches up with you in the aftertaste, and like a true winter warmer should you feel it throughout your body and a smile captures your face.  Wonderful banana and clove, with some sweet cinnamon, brown sugar and honey sweetness.  Never over the top and perfectly balanced.  Superb!

Pours orangish with little head.  Aroma is a very complex blend of alcohol, fruit and slight hops.  The first sip has a warming sensation that can be felt to the toes.  the complexity of the beer is superb.  Great winter warmer.

Vintage 2000.  Pours hazy copper with robust white head.  Aroma is sour and fruity.  I smell green apples namely.  Start is very sweet.  Sweet throughout with some mild hops in the middle.  Very sweet and VERY enjoyable.  AWESOME.

Bottle...vintage 2000.  Pour is a cloudy amber with a large white head.  Aroma is phenolic, with banana and clove.  Typically belgian on the nose.  Creamy on the tongue, nice banana, nice clove spiciness.  Delicious beer, very drinkable.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 Pours with a huge head that takes a while to fade. Aroma of honey, raisins, and other dark fruit. Flavor is of honey and dark fruits with a medium alcoholic warmth. Seems like a light port. Very nice beer, great for winter.
(Bottle) Pours an orangish-brown with no head.  Has a yeast and alcohol aroma.  Not quite what I expected from this Belgian.  Had some some unique flavors of sweetness and fruit.

pours golden orange with a rocky head, cloudy with tiny yeast specks.  candy sugar, alcohol nose.  other fruit notes I couldn't grasp - all sweet though.   initial taste is very sweet. then alcohol, then medium hop bite.  lots of other things going on here, but the sugar and alcohol are hiding it from me.  good stuff, but a little too sweet for me.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2004 Complex Aroma, almost like mixed fruit, with cherries.  Foggy copper color.  Thick head to begin, ends up be thin but lasting.  Very sweet, then the bitterness stops the sugar from kicking in all the way.  Extremely complex.  Pretty good, but wayyyy to sweet.

Courtesy of Kahn's in Indy: This brew is a dark golden brown/orange color with a very thick off-white head. Thick and sticky lacing. Complex aroma of alcohol, sweet fruit, vanilla and malt. Medium-bodied and borderline cloying at times, but with a satisfying array of flavors. The different fruits like plum and apple are at the forefront. There is also a nice malt, spice and alcohol presence. The finish is very sweet with a lot of yeast. Taking your time with this one is the way to go. A very nice beer.

aroma is very alcoholic, very much like a red wine.    hits your mouth startlingly sweet, then turns alcoholic, and then stays sweet and yeasty.  holding it in my mouth i feel like i'm taking a shot of rum and chasing it with sugar-water.  i should have saved this one for dessert.  interesting, to say the least, but it doesn't taste like your typical belgian.

I think I finally settled on my personal dictionary reference for cloying. I wanted so to like it. Actually I did. Found pear covered in a syrupy sauce along with other luscious and delicious flavors, but I just couldn't continue w/o thinking I almost couldn't handle another sip. Desert that should be dealt in small doses. I longed for a really astringent geueze or very bitterly hopped beer. After making my way past the half-to-three-quarter mark I succumbed to the temptation to try a Big Nacht. Took a bit of Still Nacht and poured it in a new glass and added an equal amount of Bigfoot. Nice. I admit it. I have no way of knowing, only having had this so long ago what is "normal". All I know is that there was not the acidity or extra hop bitterness in this to keep me from enjoying this combination more than the original for an endured period. Great beer within limitations.

many thanks to duff for bringing this around to look after me while i was recovering from my knee reconstruction. aroma of raw sugar and a nearby orchard with some cookie dough. ridiculously thick and chunkous, not that i mind. surprisingly bitter - apple peel bitterness and some light pepperiness. pleasant warming sensation in the gut. if it's lacking one thing it's some yeast complexity but that's maybe being a little pedantic

The beer pours a slightly hazy and deep amber color with a frothy bright white head that piles high upon the body, as it desiccates the lace forms an encircling sheet upon the glass. Nice cotton candy sweet nose, caramel, ripe fruit dominate, fresh and crisp, a real treat for the senses, start is moderately sweet, perfectly malted and the top middling in feel. Finish is timidly acidic, the hops benign in their bite, sweet and sherry dry aftertaste, a fine beer and one I enjoyed immensely.

Cloydy brown with some highlights of orange. Medium sized beige head. Sweet aroma of burnt sugar, pear, orange-peels and spices. Sweet malty flavours of pears, candied black currant, sweet nectarine, honey and toffee. Spicy and warming finish.

The first thing I noticed about this beer was the lack of head when poured. Not great. Second thing, almost not aroma. Very nice color, however. Tastes very dark, with a very nice bite right away melting into a fruity full flavor. Very pleasant. Overall, a decent beer. I enjoyed it.

(bottled 2003, 8% ABV) Cloudy amber body, with a small whitish head. Warm and spicy aroma, strong caramel, fruit, a hint of vanilla. Wonderfully complex, sweet, very sweet... maybe too sweet! Honey and raisins are balanced by some yeasty notes leading to a slightly peppery finish. Full and creamy mouthfeel. A beer to be enjoyed in slow sips. I just found it a little bit cloying, otherwise it would have been perfect.

Dark Ale maybe in taste, but not in color which is softly glowing and thickly clouded; dark pale yellow with a small brownish tone to its body. You can kinda see the yeasties a bit floating around in there. No head was produced during or after the pour but a very thin ring sits along the edge the whole glass through. No real lacing either, some thickly drippings leaving miniscule specks. Aroma is warming and sweet with nice dark fruity esters and floral tones. Some notes touching on plum, darkly savoring juicy oranges, raisins, sweet toffee, dark fresh honey, and caramel swirl about with some soft spice and phenol hints. Taste is immaculately displayed with great, easy, and very yummy flavors of sweetish dark fruits and heavy liquored candies. Yum! Oh my, this is nice. Exceptional thickness. Its got a great heavy creamyness and feel thats loaded with great dark caramel and toffee candy laced with intermingling sweetened and ripe dark fruits of yellow raisins, plum, dates, and dulled orange. Notes of honey dart across the finish along with slight floral herbalness and a lingering darkened sweetness resides as the thickness just keeps sticking within and coating every pore in the back of the throat. A late warmth sneaks up into the nose clearing the senses a bit. Incredible for 8%, usually that amount doesn't offer up so much warming attributes but this stands on its own. Absolutely yummy and thick with a nice added oommff of warmth. Ohh so nice... lovely brew. Recommended!

Looked pale and thin with some floaties, if I judged it strictly on looks, it wouldn't be good. But the flavor really came through with brown sugar and spice and some ripe fruit too. Slight alcohol burn in the finish.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 33 cl bottle, 2003.  Very small (for a Belgian anyway) head, golden particle-speckled body.  Enormously complex nose by turns sweet apple, apricot, vanilla and whiskey.  On the tongue, extremely sweet (honey, apples, cherries) and quite alcoholic.  Very thick, syrupy mouthfeel, pepper on the finish, slightly drier towards the end.  Just a little too thick and cloyingly sweet to be truly great; just doesnt have enough acid or hops to balance.  But still very very good, if only for when you want candy in your beer. 

December 2005, on tap at The Maproom in Chicago.  Wow, my first De Dolle on tap!  This one has so much depth and so many layers of every kind of sweet imaginable....orangepeel, molasses, vanilla, honey....but it has just a touch more sharpness and is definitely more drinkable.  On tap an overal 4.2 vs a 4.0 bottled; rating is an average of the two.  Im just blown away that I liked the tap version more than I already liked it bottled; cant wait to try more from the spigot from this greatest of all breweries.
8%ABV. Dark amber with nice off-white head. Sweet, over-ripe fruit (apples, figs), butterscotch, alcohol. Soft, smooth, full. Very nice.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 2008-02-29. 2003 Vintage. Dark amber-brown body with a small fading white head. Sweet caramel malt aroma, lightly fruity, alcoholic overtones. Sweet fruity flavour, sweet sugary malt and ambiguous but rich fruit. Lingering sweetness with alcoholic undertones. Smooth average palate fights above its weight. Really hit the right note for me - damn good! Bottle at Kulminator, Antwerp 8/3/9/4/18 - 4.1
Feb 2006 Hazy golden brown body with a small white head. (3+) Fruity alcoholic aroma, muted malt. Flavour is similar, fruit highlights over sweet light malt and sugary notes. Medium palate. Nice but fails to live up to my mental picture of the previous sample. 7/3+/7-8/4/15 - 3.8
Feb 2004 So Im an idiot... Knocked this one out of the fridge while reaching for another beer, and just barely saved it with my foot. My sigh of relief lasted about two seconds before realising that the bottle was fizzing. I grabbed a glass and popped it open hoping to save it which simply allowed about half the bottle to explode into my sink. Sigh... I rescued enough to have a bit but it was a tragic loss. Thanks to IPfreely for picking up this 2001 vintage bottle for me from Premier Gourmet. Good size white head on a hazy amber body. Aroma is big sugary malt, and foretells of the massively sweet but not quite cloying flavour has a bit of alcohol and a slightly bitter finish to balance it off. A fine beer that I am going to have to try again in honour of the fallen portion. Perhaps a younger vintage to pay tribute to the lost.   7/4/8/4/16 - 3.9

Hazy amber/orange color with some sediment, lightly carbonated and a scant head. Assertive fruity aroma, apple cider, pear, lemon, some caramel or cotton candy with a background metallic vinegar note. Very sweet and sticky on the tongue, malty and warm, a sipper alright, with honey and citrus flavors and some kind of curry spice. Long sweet finish with some bitterness and a boozy note.

Malty, candy sugar and alcohol aromas. Beer poured with no head. Dark copper color that had floaters (bottle conditioned?). Very sweet malty and candy sugar flavors with some alcohol. The beer isn't as sweet as it could be based on an O.G. of 1.108! The hops listed on their description do help counter would could've been a very sweet cloying beer. I like this beer and think they did a wonderful job on it.

11.6 oz capped bottle:  Pours fairly clear dark amber with a swirly, thin light brown head.  Aromatic fruity yeast, with a peppery pears, alcohol laced raisins, green grass, and lemons.  Alcohol overly noticeable on the soft palate, but the flavours settle into fresh pears, sour apples and spicy cloves.  Finish is wonderfully moist, full of fruitiness: white grapes, plums, brown sugar, bitter honey, and chewy caramel. . . what a beauty.

2002 bottle, a little more than a year old.  A dark golden ale with a powerful, fruity, and spicy aroma, with a definite alcohol presence.  Lively, tingly, and medium-bodied, with intensely sweet, yet sour, flavors of cherries and green apples.  The alcohol kicks at the finish, and leads into a lasting aftertaste.  Memorable.  I can see how this would continue to improve in the cellar for years to come.
A great and big beer. Lots of alcohol, lots density. But nothing else. Too much alcohol

Bottle.  Pours thick, cloudy and the color of candided oranges with almost no head whatsoever.  Aroma is tart and acidic, almost hints of vinegar with fruits and spice.  Flavor is sweet and rich, citrus, honey and a lingering bitter finish.  Thick, full body, syrupy with little to no carbonation.  Definitely a unique and tastey ale experience.
Sweet, boozy, and undercarbonated.  Apples, reminicent of english barleywine.  A touch of sherryish oxidation.  Quite sweetwith a lingering alcohol note.  Will resample.

Bottle conditioned. 2003 edition, label marked 8% abv and 12%. Chestnut bronze with a slight unavoidable haze. Poor thin white head and relatively low condition. Roomfilling aromas of apples, candy sugar and damp wood mingled with a typical sweet barley wine note. Thick and chewy in the mouth, but not over sweet. Tastes like a good English barley wine with a slight spicy edge and a fruity berry note that lingers in the mouth and leaves an oily mouthcoating of sweet malt and a long bitterness. The confusion over the abv cannot be cleared up by just drinking this exquiste beer, the alcohol is just so well hidden.

A wonderful aging experiment. This puppy was bottled in 1996. It has aged well...mostly. Looks like a cloudy dark orange marmalade. Very full, oily mouthfeel that just explodes with sourness. Then it retreats to clove and coriander. Wow. Only problem is its syrupiness (?). I wish I had more to test!

Smells of pears, apples, and Pinot de Charente or any wine based liquor...Apple cider brown and hazy, with almost no head or carbonation. Makes up for it in the mouth, sweet candy sugars, with pear purée, warm alcohol, with a body which reminds one of a jam! Thanks to MaibockAddict for this gem.
(draught) good frothy white head, very dark brown. Aroma/taste sweet: brown sugar, although very sweet, a bitter after taste. different but good

2002 edition in bottle.  Pours a dark orange/light brown color and is probably one of the most carbonated beers I've ever seen.  Very rocky, uncontrolled head.  Had to wait to pour the whole bottle in.  Very sweet aroma and taste, but hops come in toward the finish.  Definite Belgian flavor, alcohol is clearly evident.  An appley sort of flavor seems to dominate.  Certainly a unique flavor and worth a try.

Brewed 2003.  Pours a rich amber with very little head.  The aroma reaches out and grabs my nostril hairs with clenched fists of sour apples and caramel.  I take a small sip and an overwhelmed by the sweet alcohol flavor.  Raisons and toffee bombard my mouth.  Unique but the balance of flavors seems a bit off as it reminds me of a sherry.  I'll keep the other bottle for a while and try this again after it has aged.

Smells like alcohol, yeast, and apple cider.  Looks pretty good, no head, though, despite a pretty sincere effort to pour one.  Tastes pretty good, *really* sweet, though.  Nice palate, not too thick or too thin.  Overall it's pretty good, though not usually what I go for.
Alcohol aroma with yeast.  A thick sweet taste and feel.  I did not care for this at all.

I would think this is a fairly,old,bottle. The yeast is caked to the bottom. Anyhow,brew pours a oarnge/brown,with a small ring of white head. Sherryish aroma. Lots of malt,nuts,toffee. The very little acohol in the aroma adds to it's vinous character. Full,thick mouthfeel. Big body. Lots of raisin,old malts(good way),soil, and bread. Absolutely,sticks to the tounge. Lots of fruitiness going down before the earthy finish. Lots of earthy hops,and sweet malt in the finish. Slight sourness in finish adds some complexity. I would guess this is at least 3-4 yrs old,and it could still rest more. Not a hint of oxidation. Killer! I love De Dolle!

Not pretty, lots of floaties in an oily amber body, little head dies hard and fast.  Strong sweet aroma with some sour notes, odd.  Strong, thick malts reach out for you, and then something distinctly Belgian enters what starts as a barleywine in the mouth.  Flavors of raisins, cassis, and some hoppiness to balance on the finish.  Odd, but not bad.  I can see how some would really go for this.  Would be very interesting to age.

Light cloudy amber color, very small white head. Aroma of sour apples and alcohol. Starts out very sweet with sour apples. Finishes with raisons, syrup and some alcohol. It is pretty complex, but I don't care for it.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2006 Rating#300: Cloudy peach color with a very modest head that faded quickly to a halo. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Flavor is richly sweet with hints of green apple, orange, some spice and maybe peach. Finish is moderately sweet with a light bitterness. This brew is complex, smooth and very rich. An excellent holiday brew. Happy New Years 2004.
9/30/06 Bottle from OBriens:  Pretty much as I described it above, but I didnt detect the green apple. Flavor was over ripe apricot and fresh valencia orange with a hint of yeast and alcohol.

The color of apple cider with the matching cloudiness.  Fruity flavors and aroma.  Weak head and some lacing.  At $4 a bottle I only bought one, but it is a very memorable brew.  The commercial description is amazingly accurate and not over hyped.

Pours orange-brown, almost flat (very slight carbonation). Aroma is quite winey, lots of fruit in there as well (apples and plums.) Apples and yeast in the flavor, very very sweet. Could use some aging, this was a fresh bottle. I'll keep the other one I bought for a couple of years and see what happens.
Very cloudy orange gold color. Big mouthfeel with hints of green melon, apple, yeast, vanilla. Slight warming alcohol taste. Starts to get a little sweet then stops just in time. Unique.
light amber in color with a large tight foamy white head.Yeasty spicey aroma with a touch of malt.Warming alcohol mouthfeel with a complex yeast flavor.

Tastes better than it looks or smells. Resemble an unfiltered apple cider. Clovey and yeasty malt body with some vanilla overtones. Like candy in the sides of mouth towards the end - rather sweet, then turning tangy. Pretty fat and chewy.
Nice banana and vanilla nose. Dark orange, nearly brown. Vanilla, cinnemon, banana and alcohol flavor. Long lasting. quite like a dessert vine.
Complex fruity aroma, lots of esters, alcohol, and pale malt.  Pale blonde color, good head.  Flavor matches the aroma, quite sweet.  Very full bodied.  A sweet, complex, fruity Belgian with a kick.

Peachy amber in colour, off white creamy head.  Aroma of peaches, apples, yeast and some cream.  The flavour was smooth creamy, yeasty, apples, bananas, candy sugar, full bodied and complex.  Finish is long and tangy.  Wonderful.

Apples, and quite yeasry and wheaty. Mine was too young 2 months. I want to buy some moer snd store them for a couple of decades. Then I can imagine the beer will be even more fantastic than it already is.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2004 Swirling, murky deep copper body, poured strangely flat until a thick creamy head was summoned from the depths. Hoppy and leathery aroma with some baking soda as well. Interesting combination of honey sweetness, spice, and leather. This beer brings a striking combination of sweet and bitter which produces an effect akin to chewing on a bar of decorative soap. Too sweet and cloying.

Poured completely pellucid bronze/ruby with NO head and NO lacing. Aroma at first was slightly tart with notes of green apples, honey, and candi sugar. Flavor is overwelmingly sweet, but this hides the alcohol a bit. Huge citrus flavors with the sweetness, cloying is a word I would use at this point. I believe this is a fresh batch, about 5 years aged and this might possibly be a masterpiece, but from this initial tasting, it was too unfermented. The finish is metallic, like sucking on a penny. Lingers in your mouth for a while. Lick your lips and you'll think you've just tasted schnozberrys. Interesting. If they would have upped the bitterness to match the sweetness this would be good from fresh to aged. As the sweetness ages away, the hops fade, therefore it would maintain a balance always.
1996 bottle. Apple flavor is apparent throughout the palate, and lends some sour notes as well. Slightly spicy. Very easy to drink and smooth. A fine beer.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 Bottled 8% ABV: Golden coloured. White medium lasting head. Malt, spices, yeast, sweets and fruits in the aroma. The flavour is sweet, yeasty, fruity and has some alcahol notes. The alcahol is well hidden though. Has a dry sugary finish and ends up with a alcahol burnt. Very sweet beer, but not unpleasantly sweet.Had the 1996 vintage at Kulminator Oh boy was that great (9-4-10-5-19). Dark reddish brown. Huge light brown head. Aroma of yeast, dense ripe fruits, light alcohol, loads of spices and some sugary sweetness. Flavour is even better. So balanced, smooth and full. I could sip this all day long. Again the smooth ripe fruits, sugars, alcohol, spice and some liqourice. Full bodied. Ends on a warming spiced fruityness. World class. Wonder how that 1982 taste like, that Jeppe talk so much about.

caramel color, no head, moderate carbonation. has a combo aroma of citrus and new car smell(which i wonder if that is a combo of the sugar and the light alcohol presence?). mild hop presence in the flavor, but WOW this mother is sweet. is it possible to taste the candi sugar in this? i most definitely think i do.

Cloudy brown color, no head, very yeasty.  Malt, banana, and clove in the aroma.  Overpoweringly sweet, with a fruitiness and a lot of alcohol.  It could be much better if it wasn't so sweet.  Finishes alcoholic.  The sweetness was to the point of disgusting, and I couldn't even finish it.  Hate to drain pour a beer rated this high, but I really didn't like it at all.
Pale brown color, absolutely no head. Sweet, bready, malty aroma. Flavor is strong in alcohol, pretty sweet with belgain sugar. Thick and sweet, slightly cloying.
Smell is a little citrusy, sweet aftertaste.  Maybe a little butter scotchy.  Great taste, great beer.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2006 My rating for this one sucked big time, so now it is erased and I will write a new one next time I try it, the liquid of angels!

Wow. This would be catagorized as an exteme beer in my book.  This beer is simply too sweet and too strong for my liking. major adjunts floating with an extreme carbonation.  I am not a fan of this beer at all.

A fiery orange Belgian, with nary a head.  Abundant yeast floaties cry out for life preservers.  Plum, grape, and strong candi sugar aroma.  Flavor is very sweet, almost cloying, with candi sugar, wood, musty earth, grapes and alcohol swimming in the murky body.  Sticky mouthfeel in the sense of watered-down corn syrup.  Minimal carbonation enhances the syrupy, fruit juicy palate.  Dense and tasty, this would serve as a nice dessert sipper.

(2003?) Hazy orange color with no head retention, very little apparent carbonation, but does have alcohol legs that cling to the side of my snifter.  Grape and sweet malt aroma @ first sniff; musty, earthy, and woody notes follow;  also peppery spice, yeasty, and a buttery diacetyl as well as alcohol as it warms.  sweet malty w/ woody, maple flavor, vinous raisin, and yeasty breadiness.  Sweetness is almost sticky and cloying to me, but does have a hop flavor in the finish and aftertaste to balance.  The diacetyl int the aroma does not translate into the flavor, but there is added fruitiness from the alcohol in the flavor as it warms.  Very low carbonation w/a warming alcohol, but lightly astringent and very full bodied.  As with the Oerbier Reserva, I like the complexities, but not really wild about the characteristics of this beer just yet.  To me, it's borderline cloying even for a self proclaimed malty beer lover such is myself. I've got another bottle or two to see how it ages.

Cloudy amber with a very thin white head.  Extremely sweet aroma filled with caramel, honey, apricot, banana, pear and a hint of alcohol.  Medium thick creamy and syrupy body.  It coats the mouth and has a nice alcohol warmth.  Extremely sweet flavor as well.  Lots of caramel, honey and apricot with other fruit flavors and spice in the background.  A little too sweet for my tastes, but still a very good beer.

Orangey yellow with big sticky particles everywhere.  Turbid, roaring carbonation  Small whitish head.  Extremely sweet, a big yeast bomb, I definately get a blueberry note here as well.  Candi sugar makes this sweet and syrupy, witha big yeasty finish...YEAST BOMB!

Cloudy orange with a nice fine off-white head. Bubbles are very lazy. The head disapates rather quickly. Sweet fruity aroma. The nose is not nearly as string as expected. Very sweet, a bit too sweet for my taste. Tons of candi sugar producing honey and blueberry flavors. Body is massive and syrupy. Not one of my more favorite Belgians.

Bottle pours a hazy burnt orange with no head but with some lace.  The aroma is light, but sweet.  As it warms, the aroma starts to resemble clover honey.  The flavor is like apricot jam, candy, very small hop spike, and some alcohol notes.  The palate is about as close to syrup as any beer I've had.  Actually, this really needs some serious bittering in order to be as balanced as it is; as it warms and you get used to the flavor, you begin to really taste the hops that went into this.  Overall, this is a perfect winter seasonal.  Wow, this is a rare treat.  Thanks to Blue Max Liquors!

Nice ruby hued pour with a thin layer of small bubbly head.  Sweet malts in the aroma, with a tiny bit of hops, not a very powerful nose. Big sweet malt flavors that taper down into a nice hoppy and bitter finish. Huge, syrupy body, with a nice palate that isn't too cloying for how thick it is.

11.6 oz. slender brown bottle. This beer is 12 % ABV, not 8 %. Poured out a hazy apricot color, with not much head, probably due to the extremely high ABV. Cloudy from the yeast sediment swirled up by myself. I wanted all the flavors this beer has to offer.
Aromas are of medicinal phenols, candi sugar, Belgian yeast, and caramel malts. Smells like a caramel apple. Fruity, aromatic, and it changes as the beer warms up. Slight aromas of Nugget hops way off in the background. Tastes of caramel malts, slight biscuity taste as well. Hops make a sharp but brief appearance in the middle of the taste, but the malts & alcohol simply overpower it. Stinging, peppery alcohol bite to it as well. Finishes dry, and sweet, but not cloying at all. Lingers on the tongue for quite awhile.
This is a beer you can only drink one of, and a small one at that.
Version 2002.  Orange, hazy, thick white head.  Aroma of yeast, bread, sweet candi sugar and hops.  Flavor is mainly sweet like brown sugar, with some bitterness.  Finish is dry.  Excellent Brew
UPDATED: NOV 23, 2003 Nice and golden in color. Very good and flavorful christmas beer. Strong in alcohol. Very malty. Nice warming beer for a cold night.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 Update: Had a 2000 version. I will leave the rating the same but have to say that this beer really smooths out with time. Well worth seeking and or saving. 

************************I am pretty certain this is the latest version. Nice golden color, with a spicy aroma. Big malt, and I mean big malt stickyness that explodes with flavor. Noticable alcohol. I think the best way to describe the circus in your mouth would be to liken it to the malt character of DFH 120 min IPA, but without the hops. Would love to lay some of this down for a while.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Lemon is foremost in the nose.  Honey and spice rule the taste with citrus.  Certainly not something I drink often, but probably my favorite Xmas beers.

i had a bottled specimen of the '96 (courtesy of indra).  the label probably deserves some ridicule, but i decided it's SO primitive and garish that it actually achieves-- ahem-- distinction, so we'll let it go at that. (the brewery owner probably lets his kids design the labels, which is sweet, isn't it?). the pour is as plump and pulpy as a georgia peach in a glass, canary golden at the edges and deeper pie-crust orange brown within, sporting a modest soggy head.  within the bottle is a murky haze loaded with yeast--is it some of great-grandpa de dolle's cremated remains?  it's thick and fiery in there, and when brightly back-lit it's  like the burning skyline of civil war atlanta, with sooty pillars of yeast rising like smoke, taking the form of ghastly apparitions apparently trying to get out of the bottle. nose of hard cider and peach schnapps, a little sandalwood incense, balsamic vinegar, white pepper, lemon, and a vague sour note.  enormous fruity sweetness-- this seems to be a lightly carbonated apricot wine, medium to full bodied and sweetened to the culinary specifications and preferences of a six year old.  spritzy sweet apple goo, like the carmelized apple syrup that oozes out of a baked pie.  it was too much for me: i recapped it and had the rest later-- after i'd buzzed around like a hummingbird for a couple hours and seriously considered flying south for the winter.
Copper color with a large white head. Sweet grape and citrus aroma. Very sweet and tart flavor, full of citrus, grape, and clove. Nice crisp palate.

Cloudy amber color with a huge (too big) white head. The aroma was full of fruity tones...grapes, apple...bready, sweet. The flavor was very citric...full on grapefruit, grapes, and apricot...very yeasty and sweet. The feel was too carbonated...very gassy, spritzy.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2003 Best before 2005. Raisins and peaches in the aroma.
Brown, flakes of yeast big fluffy head.
Raisins, sweet brown sugar and 
a slight citric aftertaste.
Very warming - the perfect winter beer.
This bottle was a little bit too sweet - aging will probably do a lot to this beer.

Poured a cloudy copper orange with nice foamy head.  Aroma is robust although I can seem to nail down exactly what it is.  Spices, fruits and sweet malt?  One word comes to mind with this beer and its 'sweet'.  Very candyish, like cotton-candy.  I could almost feel the sugar rush as I drank it.  Luckily for me I enjoy sweets.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2006 Poured an amber color with a small white head.  Had a fruity grape and alcohol aroma.  It had a sweet, candy sugar, plus alcohol taste.  Also had a slight taste of cinnamon to it.

2000 vintage stored at shelf temp.   Complex array of fruity pale malt flavors throughout with big funky yeast notes at the start and nice hoppy notes finishing it off.   Alcohol is apparent, but welcomed in such a big, complex beer.  Awesome every time.

Cloudy, golden-brown, olive color (deli mustard-like), with an abundance of yeast floaters.  Head is a huge froth of off-white bubbles that remains for quite awhile, leaving a fair amount of lacing.  Smell is mostly fruit malt with a vinous, chardonnay grape presence; also, cinnamon and other indistinguishable spices arise.  Taste is very big and sweet, with grapes, apple juice, yeast, and carbonation.  Aftertaste is spicy, fruity, and far too sweet, to the point of being cloying.  Sampled from an 11.6 oz bottle purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA.

Beautiful frothy head over a copper body.  Strong fruit aroma - robust winter spices, with a touch of vanilla.  A little too syrupy-sweet in the flavor, more like a barelywine, but the carbonation is perfect.

The best word to describe this beer would be, fruity - cloudy orange, pillowy white head - intense aroma of apples and pears - flavor steps up the intense fruits in the aroma - sweet citrus flavors (grapefruit with sugar on top) - apples and raisins - toastiness comes in late, with some cinnamon notes, wintery spices - toastiness lingers into the finish, with a dash of hops to cut the sweetness - this is a very original beer - top marks.

Cloudy orange appearance with a lot of sediment.  Immense fluffy head that left nice lacing.  Complex aroma yielded candy apples, yeast, raisins and plums.  Taste combined all the sweetness a beer could deliver with some spiciness and a lot of alcohol.

2000 bottle. Massive off-white head with little brown speckles which I'm guessing are bits of carmelized sugar. The head ended up looking like Cinnamon Toast Crunch on top of the dark amber beer. Very sweet aroma with some spice, fruit, and sugar. Very sweet flavor as well. I liked the sugar/sweetness but it might be a little too much for some. Slight alcohol burn, typical of De Dolle beers. A very interesting winter beer, good though.
Bottle.  Amazing large and foamy head with an amber color. The nose is spicy, a little malty, and sweet/fruity.  The brew is fairly complex and interesting on the palate. Yeasty. Quality.
Tasted in DC at Brickskeller.  Candy scent.  Sweet citurs smell and flavour.  Dark yellow colour with nice white head. Spicy finish, with earthy undertones.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2004 Sampled January, 2004Incredibly well carbonated, creates a prodigious off white head.  A pretty clear red-copper color.  Fruity aroma with notes of apple and a hint of alcohol.  It is amazingly clear for a Stille Nacht, most are quite murky.  Pretty light bodied, with a crisp apple cider bite in the finish.  There is a hint of astringency and alcohol in the finish as well.  Rich notes of caramel and a slight bit of acidity.  Over all a very fruity beer.I liked it a bit more when they were getting the Rodenbach yeast; the acidity brings a whole other dimentsion, that this beer is currently missing.  I have heard rumors that they will bring back the old yeast culture back.  I certainly hope so, cause I love the acidity.  Still a world class beer and one of my favorites.  This was one of those beers that I had towards the beginning of my beer journey.  It has held up well and I will always want more of this than I can get.
Various Samples prior to 2002A deep golden color, with amber notes to it.  Pours with hardly any head at all.  It looks quite thick as it is poured into the glass, and is very lightly carbonated.  Smells of honey and a general fruitiness.  Tastes thick, complex, sweet, with a strong honey note to it.  This beer is also lightly sour which balances wonderfully with the sweetness.  This is a world-class beer, and is incredibly well balanced.

Bottle.  A little much for me.  Light-brown, hazy, very generous head that's as clingy as a teenage girl in her first relationship.  Sweet alcohol, very strong.  Maybe some hints of cologne in the aroma, or maybe that was mine?  Tastes like a pear that is skinned and has holes poked in it, and is allowed to sit in a bucket of Boaka Vodka for about a week.  Ouf.

Super big, coarse head with brown sediment speckles on the top of the head....looked like cinnamon.  Murky reddish brown in color, lots of sediment.  Aroma was harsh...smelled like a solvent.  One of the boldest beers Ive had in some time.  Spicy on the tongue, fruits and alcohol all over with a very harsh, bitter finish that did not set well with me.....just too much going on here, didnt come together well.

Yeasty tripple like aroma with some spice.  The flavor is huge.  It hits you like a ton of bricks.  there's a lot going on here.  the head is its own living entity.  I thought I was going to have to call the feds because it kept growing out of my glass like it wanted to take over the world.  Yeasty, fruity alcahol taste.  taste is the best part.  Very unique and complex.

nice mellow creamy yeast flavor, the appearance of this beer takes the cake... the head stuck right out of the glass it was so huge, whoa.. what a wince this thing gave me.. extremely bitter and extremely sweet, not very well balanced at all

2000 Vintage:

The beer pours out with massive head, completely white in colour, and the beer shows a nice golden colour with orange highlights. The aroma is very nice, definately sweet because of the ripe fruit, apples and grapes come to mind as well as some yeastyness. Very thick mouthful and very sweet initially. This fades a bit with time, but the sweetness still overwhelms the malt. The hops show through a bit in the end, but the malt is simply left behind. Regardless of how sweet it is, the complexities arise well after the beer has been sipped. The palate starts drying out and the flavours linger in the mouth. Truly a great beer, and i'm really looking foward to my next 'De Dolle'! I bought this 11.6 ounce bottle at Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Thick dense head, very lively. Very yeasty and fruity aromas. Huge body, fairly sweet and lots of alcohol.

Bottle from 2000. This poured a huge, huge fluffy white head. The body is a golden orangeish-brown color. Sweet ripe fruit, yeasty aroma with very subtle hints of hops and alcohol. Hits the tounge with a candy like sweetness, transitions to malty and fruity flavors. Alcohol is quite apparent on this one. A tad to sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2016 2016-10-14, bottle, vintage 1990, 26 years old, 5-3-6-2-11Mushroom smell. Sweetish, some Marsala, very low character, a bit fruity, but also dusty; no apparent oxidization though.2016-10-14, bottle, vintage 2008, 8 years old, 8-3-7-3-15=36Murky brown color. Quite strong notes of tobacco, old wood furniture, nuts, sugarcane, mild raisins. Its losing some sweetness now; drier in the finish. Too oxidized, but still good.2015-12-19, bottle, vintage 1990, 25 years old, 8% ABV, 7-4-8-3-16=38The aroma starts showing some oxidization, but its also fruity. Sweet, liquorous, Marsala character, very fruity, with light acidity, and almost no bitterness.Very interesting, still.2013-11-19, draught at Mikkeller and Friends, Copenhagen, vintage 2010, 3 years old, 12%, 8-5-8-4-17=42Hazy deep blond color with greenish hue; generous compact head. Belgian aroma, a bit spicy, sweet, white sugar, with subtle fruits; seems very elegant. Smooth mouthfeel, but also with a strong alcohol perception that affects it; moderately sweet malt flavor, lean though, with a clear fruity side; correct bitterness.Chamaleontic beer, very nice. Not for everybody, got to appreciate it.2013-11-14, bottle, vintage 2008, 5 years old, 12% ABV, 7-5-8-4-16=40Dark amber color (very dark), hazy, with large head reducing to a small layer. The aroma is mild but elegant, with a note of wood and fruit. Good body and mouthfeel, with light residual sweetness, malt and caramel flavor; it starts developing a light woody acidity; the bitterness is quite low; the alcohol is warming.A very good sipper, dynamic.2013-05-02, bottle at Kulminator, Antwerp, vintage 1987, 26 years old, 8% ABV, OG 1200, 7-5-8-3The color is dark chestnut, hazy, with some carbonation that provides a creamy head. The aroma is peculiar, raisins and parsnip/pumpkin, freshly cut ashwood. Good mouthfeel, round, with soft carbonation; the malt and caramel flavor is still rich, with a fruity side, and a very light sourness that fits well; the bitterness is very low; raisins in the final, but also a light dustiness.After so many years, its still in pretty good shape.2013-03-22, bottle, vintage 1995, 17 years old, 8% ABV, 8-5-8-4-16=41from De Heeren Van Liedekercke; OG 1200Bright amber color, clean, with huge head. The aroma is powerful, there are some esters, light vinegar, wood, sugar, glue, no oxidisation, and a funky touch. It still has a good body structure; the mouthfeel is round and smooth; nice malt flavor with a pleasant fruity touch; there are still quite some sugars for this age; the bitterness is expectedly low; as the alcohol may have gone up a bit, it can be perceived through a gentle warmth; there is a mild woody astringency too in the final.Pleasant and complex, different from other vintages, with no sings of age.2013-02-09, bottle, vintage 2011, 1 year old, 12% ABV, 7-5-7-4-15=38Nice amber-copper color, with a few particles, and generous compact head, persistent. The aroma is deep, with the classic Belgian spicy malt, and lingering fruitiness. Full bodied, and very smooth mouthfeel; the malt flavor is rather sweet, with light fruity touch, some more spiciness and correct bitterness; very light vegetables.Very good, sweet spicy and fruity; although the alcohol perception is a bit high.2012-11-02, draught at Ørsted, Copenhagen, vintage 2011, 6-5-6-2-11=30Dark brown color with red shades; small creamy head. Light aroma of caramel and vegetables, very light cheese too. Reasonable body strength; anonymous caramel flavor, moderate residual sweetness, traces of Parmesan and rubber. Barely2010-12-30, bottle, vintage 2004, 6 years old, 12% ABV, 7-5-8-4-16=40Properly stored for years, it pours the most beautiful amber color, with a medium sized frothy head, reducing to a thin but persistent layer. The aroma is mild, with some malt, spicy, light alcohol, and a nice fruity vein. The mouthfeel is very smooth, it has a good body strength, fair malt flavor supported by a mild sweetness; the alcohol is clearly perceived, but the warmth is comforting; its a bit spicy and lightly fruity, complex, mature and it doesnt show signs of age. Powerful. Very good.2007-08-02, bottles, vertical tasting at Moeder Lambic, BruxellesVintage 2006, 1 year old, 7-5-7-4-14=37Beautiful golden color, huge whipped head, persistent. The De Dolle yeast has turned the malt aroma into something peculiar, effervescent and fruity, with alpine flowers and a touch of juniper. Medium mouthfeel, thinned by a strong carbonation; the flavor has some dry malt and its really spicy. Quite strong bitterness, at the end, and the alcohol is warming the mouth. A good beer, with its originality, but it doesnt maintain the De Dolle promise.Vintage 1990, 17 years old, 10-5-10-4-19=48Splendid dark amber color; big head, reducing to a thin creamy cap. Huge aroma, everlasting, of caramel, ripe fruits (plums, soaked raisins, sundried apricots), fromage à pâte molle, very light hazelnuts, Pedro Jimenez wine. Thick body, very sweet flavor, but also very elegant, with malt dominance, complemented by sweet fruity notes; even sweet tobacco and a vanilla touch. The bitterness is very low, the alcohol non existing, tonight. A dream.Such a beauty! This version deserves to mark my rating, even if difficult to find such bottle.2003-07-09, vintage 1999, 4 years old, 8% ABV, 9-5-9-5-18=46Beautiful amber color; creamy head; fine, turbulent perlage.Strong aroma, malty, sweet; honey, lightly fruity (apricots, pineapple); light wood and old hops.Velvety, very good malt, perfect texture; sweet in the front, immediately corrected by a unique light sour-astringent note, similar to the Duchesse de Bourgogne but more bitter, balanced and complex.Long final, smooth, still quite sweet.Impressive for its deep balance; wonderful: with this one, every day is Christmas!

Light brown to dark amber in colour.  Thick cream lacy rocky head. Complex malty aroma with estery notes.  Very sweet and rich and soft.  No edges in this one.  Just malt and esters.  It has a nice viscous feel but I found it too sweet for my taste.

I ditto thedm on the size of the head that this beer poured. The head was off-white with medium bubbles. The nose was that of clove, fruits and some sweetness. The carbonation was fizzy and the lacing was excellent with this beer. The taste was that of alcohol. This is definitely a beer to be sipped and enjoyed due to the presence of the alcohol. The body was murky and the hue was pale orange. The mouthfeel was a burning sensation in my throat as well as a warm sensation as it was digested. All in all, a good brew that I really enjoyed having the experience of drinking and rating.

Wow!  This brew just poured the largest head of any beer I have ever seen.  Not a half inch og liquid in the mug and the head was to the rim of the mug!  Otherwise, the head was a creamy one with many many fine and medium sized off white bubbles.  Its body, heh I can't even see it in the mug yet haha, is a cloudy orange amber brown.  It has a mild sweet malt alcohol aroma.  Oh and wow is the flavor strong too.  High alcohol flavor with notes of clove, malt, port, spices and a burning alcohol mouthfeel that eventually mellows into a cacophony of flavors.  Wow this is one potent beer and it take balls to drink it or it will surely pu a pair on ya!  hell I may be drunk off of just one beer!  WOW!  Hmmm lemme see if I can remember the song.  Please pardon my spelling!

Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!  Alles schlaft einsam wacht.  Nur das traute hoch heilige Paar.  Holder Knabe im lockigen Haar, Schlafe in himmlischer Ruh.  Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!  Gottes Sohn, o wie lacht.  Lieb aus deinem gottlichen Mund, 
Da uns schlagt die rettende Stund.  Jesus in deiner Geburt!  Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!  Die der Welt Heil gebracht, Aus des Himmels goldenen Hohn, 
Uns der Gnaden Fulle lasst sehn, Jesum in Menschengestalt!  Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!  Wo sich heut alle Macht.
Vaterlicher Liebe ergoss, Und als Bruder huldvoll umschloss. Jesus die Volker der Welt!  Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht! 
Lange schon uns bedacht, Als der Herr vom Grimme befreit 
In der Vater urgrauer Zeit.  Aller Welt Schonung verhiess! Stille Nacht! Heilge Nacht!  Hirten erst kundgemacht Durch der Engel Alleluja, 
Tont es laut bei Ferne und Nah.  Jesus der Retter ist da!
Slightly sour, sweet nose.  First taste was extremely sweet with nothing else to balance it.  The sweetness really just did me in with this brew, and I am a big fan of the style.

Sour, fruity nose. Apricot colour, pours the largest, noisiest custard head I've ever seen. The bubbles look like pearls. Continuous fountain of carbonation, a few good sized floaties, and pretty lace. Flavour of plums, figs, currants, warm bread with marmalade,  some grapefruit and blood oranges. Even the foam tasted great! Gorgeous rich buttery texture, warmth of the alcohol is married with a wonderful dry, bitter finish. 
 Majestic!!
Bottle. One year and 6 months before best before date. Big head. Alcohol. Sweet. Soft. Nice range of flavours. Big alcohol and intense sweetness over-rides all else. Not my thing.

Dark amber colour, huge creamy head, really lasting. Sweet aroma of pear and alcohol. Initially the sweetness in the flavour is owepowering, but, as it warms, this beer becomes much more balanced: taste of pears, caramel and honey. The finish is slightly alcoholic. Really nice and dangerously drinkable.
soft creamy nose that reminds me of a Jamba Juice store.   amber color.  overal very sweet with alcohol playing a very nice and apparant part.

This beer was recommended by my local beer/wine purveyor and he was right about this amazingly complex beer.  I agree to let this one warm up and breath a bit.  Its flavor starts a bit sweet, but then again its a x-mas/winter ale.  The flavors range from citrus, vanilla, clove, pepper and on and on...  really a nice treat after a good meal.

1996 Vintage
Pours with an amber body topped by a medium thick quickly disappearing head with a good amount of lace.  Sweet caramel malt aroma with a smoked meat background and piney notes.  Sweet and sour malt flavor with strong winey/raisony notes.  The finish is sour and grapey.  Full bodied, tingling on the tongue and a touch warming.

Remember kids, don't chill a beer, let it warm up and then open it, especially a highly carbonated Belgian like this. Large misshapen head is out of control. Peach, lemon zest, salty. Alcohol a little too noticeable and the sweetness is a bit cloying. Surprisingly bitter finish.
Very subtle aroma; somewhat sweet and somewhat alcoholic. White head. Beautiful dark amber tone. Wonderful lace. Very high in alcohol. Very fine. Wonderful sipping beer. Almost like a barley wine.

First time I've had since the ATF let it be shown that the snowman can drink.  Near orange color with a mammoth light beige head. Definate apple aroma with a touch of vinegar, sauerkraut and coconut.  Sweet and sour.  Add this to your General Taos Chicken or sweet sour pork.  Lots of flavors swimming around, but the sweet candi comes back every time and makes the mouth water for more.

Pour created a monsterous white  head that wouldn't quit, far too much for my liking (80% of the pour was head, and that was only 1/4 of the bottle).
Cloudy amber, lots of tiny bits floating about, and millions of tiny bubbles racing to the top.  Aroma is big and fruity, apple and pear mostly, some alcohol showing, too.  Flavor is super sweet, mostly apple, ends with the alcohol poking through.  Medium body, alcohol becomes more and more prominent towards the middle and end of the bottle.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 Bottled 1996: Smells of apricots and sugar. Beutiful gold orange in color.  Decent head of a short duration.  Tastes of ripe fuit offset by a definate sourness.  Finish is very short with a strong brandy aftertaste.

Bottled 2009 rated Jan. 2010.  Sugar and apricot aroma just as before.  Lively head with short duration.  Sweet taste of dried fruit sollwed by a bitter finish.  Bitter in a good way not over the top.  The high alcohol is masked well.  Will have to keep a bottle for a few years to see how it ages.

Pale amber colour; thick, creamy-coloured head. Nose of overripe grapes, raisins, dried fruit and some alcohol. 
First bitterness in the taste, then follow liqueur, very much sweetness; light bitterness again  AND some sourishness.
 More dried fruit. Retronasal, the acidity is more outspoken. 
Very full-bodied, slick-oily mouthfeel. In the aftertaste, sweetness reigns and gets the aroma of a vintage port.

FOAM OVER!!!! Call the fire department, call the paramedics, call OSHA...cuz this isnt good. Took nearly 8 minutes to fully pour this monster into my glass. It pours a cloudy orange color...slight hints of reddish browns in there with a HUGE and i mean HUGE degree of yeasty deposits at the bottom of the glass....big one's with big point teeth!!!! The aroma is really strong and sort of awe inspiring with hints of banana, orange, pepper, grapefruit, and cloves being apparent. The taste is very peppery and spicey with banana VERY prevalent. Some grapefruity acidity in mid taste...very bittersweet, some candy, banana, orange...and spicey spicey spicey. The carbonation level is pretty vigorous adding to that prickling banana, clovey, spiceyness. Pretty good overall...way fruity, and superbly tart.

Pours a cloudy amber color with a big, off-white head that lingers. Very strong aroma of hops, yeast, and some spiciness with hints of pepper and alcohol. It has an intense flavor of malts and sweetness with a good balancing from some hops. Very bready and yeasty, with some sugary undertones. This damn beer leaves candy on the lips after every sip. This stuff is fantastic, I could drink it day after day and be a happy man.

This beer poured a copper amber color and formed an off white bubbly head that left circular lace as it subsided. A heavy aroma of malt and fruit with almost wine like aspects to the aroma. The flavor was of malt and fruit and an interesting finish. I have trouble figuring this beer out because it seems to be trying to be an dessert wine more than a beer. I would consider this a night cap kind of beer.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2003 big lumpy bumpy frothy bubbling masses atop what seemed at the time a very strange and subliminal orange transparency with strange semi see-through particles swimming around..smells a tad like the air above freshly cut granny smith apples and slightly yeasty and citrusy also..onslaught of mouth punching fizziness which continues its onslaught down into the throat..or maybe thats the alcohol burning on its way down..i dont know..it still hurts though like heart burn..trying to look beyond the insane carbination, i see some yeasty notes, malty apples, alcohol..the finish has a sharp bitterness to it too...it still burns though from maybe a combination of the peppery alcohol and the intense carbination..maybe some subtle raisin sweetness noticed too..alcohol is loudly prounounced..the carbination of course subsides as it sits in the glass for a while and the flavors have a chance to speak uninterupted..which is nice....re-rate: Much less carbination, thus more enjoyable.

A slippery smooth aroma of toffee and fresh oranges gently caresses my nose. Some beers just grab you and don't let go. I can't stop sniffing this, it only gets better over time. Looks like a solid chunk of amber that should have some ancient insect embedded inside. The carbonation is intense, floating up rapidly as the meager head hangs on for dear life. Starts off with smidgen of tart, then warms into a blossoming balloon of warmth and sweetness, caramel covered sour apples dipped in brandy. The end brings the gentle spirits of long gone hops that drift away into the night...leaving you warm and wanting more.
Liked this one a LOT. Very distinctive flavor among belgians...an original and high quality Belgian strong, and a worthy purchase!

poured a cloudy light amber with lots of sendiment and large sticky white head. aroma of yeast, apples , and hint of alcohol. taste was that of a caramel apple, with hints of raisins, a touch of pepper spice. malty with a very slight hop finish, wonderful mouthfeel. truly enjoyable
Dark amber with a small head. The aroma is sweet, spice and plums. Taste varies a bit with age and this had some port wine character. A wonderful beer.

Huge white head, golden body with a hint of red, fruit, yeast and alcohol in the nose. A slow pour. Lots of suspended sediment and rising carbonation. Very sweet, slightly woody, a hint of sourness. Somewhat syruppy; no alcohol presence. Interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2003 Big alcohol nose. Super carbonation that is really champagne-like. Dry bread malt flavors; alcohol warmth; fermented cider notes; also seems to have a "hot" spiciness to it. Carbonation seems to explode in the mouth like a cement mixer; very lively to say the least. If you can get past the heavy carbonation, it's pretty well-balanced and well made. RERATE: Well, strangely, this bottle hardly had any carbonation at all -- quite opposite from the last bottle I rated. Slowly rising bubbles barely formed a head at all. Heavy, syrupy-sweet malts exuded with a sugar-water sweetness. Very little bitterness at first, but it finally showed up in the aftertaste in the form of an oily, flowery and grass-like bitterness.

Almost looks like apple juice on the pour. Heavy apple and raisin in the nose. First taste is heavily malty, then candy aple, caramel. Finishes with a dark fruit and honey sweetness turning sour near the end. Warming alcohol presence completes this great brew. I REALLY dig the sweetness mixed with slight sour in this beer. One of my new favorites!!!!

2000 bottle.Reisling sweet sour aroma with a hint of cocoa.Thick viscosity.Sweet sour radiating flavors of tropical fruit and bitter peach with mild chocolate at the finish.One of my top five favorites.

This beer poured with a truck-load of foamy head, seemd to be overly-carbonated, had some fruity aromas witha little bit of an alcohol kick in the nose, hazy orangish-amber color, strong & complex fruity & malty flavors, full bodied, sweet & malty finish, very drinkable beer, excellent Beglian strong

Bottle.  A golden amber color with a huge foamy white head and lots of rising bubbles.  Loads of candy in the aroma along with fruits (apples, pears, and citrus) and spice (cinnamon and coriander) and yeasty notes.  This beer is very lively in the mouth and warming to the body.  A caramel base in the flavor to add to the citrus and cider like qualities.

Getting sloppy at the Archer Ale House in B-ham, this beer has a large head with a golden brown color.  A caramel/malty sweetness is quite apparent and it rolls around on your tongue for a while after swallowing.  This bee is very Belgian and very interesting.

Definately a hard brew to describe nice long lasting head ,flavor had some fruit with a very slight hint of alcohol it.Definatley sweet in the taste and finish not a bad brew in anyway but if your not into sweet beer this is not for you.

The aroma is of fuzzy fruits, apples, Wonder Bread, alcohol and Winter spices.
This hazy, deep copper colored beer has a large, rocky white head with excellent lacing.
The flavor is of warm, soothing alcohol, sweet Belgian malt, caramel and honey up front. More alcohol and a slight, mildly bitter and pungent kick from the hops on the backside.
Full bodied with a syrupy and fizzy mouthfeel. Long, lightly bitter, tart and sweet finish.
Good Stuff!

Whoaah...let me gather my face, its turned into a freakin prune. This is beyond sweet. I like it, I think it rates well, but I cant drink the rest of this, I would get a stomache ache like some fat kid after a night of trick-or-treating. Theres a trinkling of specific Belgian qualities: fruity esters and yeast, but the atomic caramel/brown sugar bomb in this beer has left me kind of bewildered. I cant even taste a hint of the alchohol in this 9% brew...damn.
Good ale. Yeasty malt and fruity flavor.  Strong alcohol presence.  Recommended
Cloudy orange w/ an enormous, long lasting head. Very full mouthfeel, w/ lots of bite on the tongue & back of your throat. You can definitely taste the sugars in this one.
What a smooth and flavorful beer. Rich & strong but not terribly alcoholic in taste. Sweet but with the right amount of that Belgian tartness.Excellant!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 Very impressive. Seemed more potent than 9% to me. Strong alcohol scent in the aroma. Heavy spice and floral taste along with a hint of fruitiness. Brownish blond and hazy when the sediment is mixed in. Great winter warmer. Worth seeking out. Recommended.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2007 SPEC BREW 2005 sampled on 3/17/07: Pours a clouded very yeasty copper orange with a large, frothy, spotty-lacing white head.  Sweet, rich, light caramel Belgian malty aroma has some biscuity notes and a touch of complex light fruitiness and tartness.  Body starts rich, viscous and sweet with some slight toasty biscuity notes, fruity complexity and some warmth toward the finish with lingering bready peppery yeast.  An age-worthy Belgian classic.

Rerate of a 1998 vintage on 12/11/04 courtesy of skaughty: Pours a murky caramel color with a thin whispy white head.  Aroma of dry, slightly oxidized grapes, cherries and strawberries.  Body has nice complexity but much more acidity and fruit than would be found in a fresh version.  Almost a completely different beer, but still enjoyable nonetheless.  

Original rating 12/26/2002: Pours with a thick, creamy pillowy head that lasted til the bitter end.  The onset of flavor is sweet, really sweet, perhaps even too sweet, but it does a great job of hiding the alcohol.  There was a touch of sediment suspended upon pouring, but no noticable taste came from it.  Finishes very warm and soothing.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2003 Poured with a huge humongus head.  Palate wasn't quite as thick as I expected.  Very fruity - big time Johnny Appleseed flavors in this (along with other subtle fruits).  This was just overly sweet by the end. I can handle the occasionaly cloying taste, but this pushed my limits.

Cloudy orange pour with a huge white head. Bubble gum nose with hints of sweet tropical fruit. Very lively on the tongue. A little sweet but big with flavors of fruit and spice. This is a good brew but Im really looking forward to the Reserva 2000.

Draft:   Beautiful dense white foam leaves behind magnificent cobweb lacework.  Crystal clear auburn liquid.  Dynamite aroma of bubblegum, maraschino cherry, wood, and a faint sign of mustiness.  Trademark De Dolle feel:  Superbly slick and soft.  Borderline complex flavors of sugar, rich sweet cherries, which nearly resemble cough syrup, and a touch of bread in the finish.  Too much emphasis on the cough syrup flavors, and not enough cleanliness.  Also, not an easy drinker, but a fine after dinner sipper, and thats about it.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Deep eclipse orange (Cant see thru) color.  Enormous white frothy head. Aroma is fruity, oranges and apples, and a little yeasty. Big candied fruit and yeast flavor that is so typical of Belgian ales. Flavor is apple-ish and spicy.Sweet and tart. Very intense flavor and carbonation. The 9% alcohol is very evident, but it sort of blends together with all the other stuff going on here. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is a little yeasty with an pronounced alcohol bite.

Pours with a huge amount of thick, sticky, white head floating on bright, hazy orange body.  The aroma is phenomenal.  Sugar, honey, spices, caramel, oranges, and sweet pineapple.  The flavors dont quite come together like the aroma.  Its a bit to sweet and quite sharp.  The alcohol is not overbearing, but certainly evident.  The finish is interesting, warm and soothing, but also sweet and full.  I was told it was like the 20th anniversary brew but without the old yeast.  This is a good beer, but its nothing like that.
On tap at Rich Os. Too sweet for me. Took over an hour to drink it. Hints of cherry and tea. Sharp alcohol bite. Not unpleasant but unexpected.

at Richos (www.richos.com)
hazy orange, complex, sweet, did I say SWEET. Nicely carbonated,, not a drink for Dinner, maybe a drink for after, your call on this one.
I had the 96 - not as much carbonation as the younger ones - apple tart, raisin sweet, cinnamon spicy; alcohol present but  not overpowering in taste.  Nice.

2001 version, sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden in December 2002.
Reddish amber. Candied apple aroma. Sweet, fruity, malty and estery. Syrupy mouthfeel and full body. Lingering caramel and honey finsish with just a note of hop nitterness. A complex candy beer to savour.
Cloudy amber, huge frothy white head. Citrus nose. Citrus yeasty flavor

Citrus, wine/champagne aroma, sour cherry. Sweet malt and tangy hops. Estery. HOLY HEAD!! Huge, slightly off-white head, big and foamy. Beer is orangish-tan clear color. The beer hits your tongue like hydrogen peroxide on a cut - expands in a burst of fizziness. Medium-thick body - a joy in the mouth - clean palate. Taste is surprisingly sweet considering the sour aroma. Alcohol. They must add sugar - the sweetness sticks around the syrup despite the lightness of the body. Sweet finish and after. Nice taste that takes some getting used to - though still a little too sweet for my tastes. Still very enjoyable.
cloudy red-brown colour, beautiful head, raisin, green apple aroma, yeasty, sweet, very smooth, strong alcohol presence, touch of sourness, long dark fruity aftertaste  won-der-ful !
Way too carbonated. Tart and sweet with a slight phenolic character.  The alcohol hits you full bore, but leaves no aftertaste.  Maybe some apple in there too, little if any spice or maltiness,

Not the beer to have when you are having more than one.  Not my style when it comes to Christmas beers (I prefer Anchor), a little overpowering, but someone knows what they are doing; but to much carbonation.
Cloudy, nice white head with orange body.  Aroma is sweet fruity (blueberry), slight alcohol, Belgian yeasty.  Taste is rich, sweet blueberry, pepper, slight alcohol aftertaste.
Guh.  Wow.  Astounding nose.  Very vinous and rich.  Fruity, lightly peachy, peppery and spicy also.  Flavor is both fruity and sour.  Tastes like a slightly apricot-flavored gueuze, a nice combo.

If this was just a little bit less sweet, this would be the one.  Incredible rocky head, and wonderful malty aroma.  I need to find an air freshener that smells like this beer!  Like I said, take just a little of the sweetness away and you have a beer for the ages...

Another superb dolle brew, they are just never disappointing! :) I never have rated a dolle below 4 I believe and this one is gonna end up higher too.
Beautifull head, dark clear colour. Strong  spicy and malty aroma. taste is more sour and fruity, bit spicy palate. well balanced lovely beer.

Rerate: I have to recall on my original rate of 3.0. This years batch is not as alcoholic as last years. That definitely improves my drinking pleasure. The typical Dolle taste, with its subtle sour refreshing note, becomes more obvious, and that is definitely something i  like!
Original rate: Floating yeast particles everywhere. Malty aroma. Alcoholic taste and palate, as in a lot of Christmas brews. But this one could not enjoy me much.

Belgain Specialty Ales can run the spectrum as far as gravities, aromas, flavors etc.  As a belgian specialty ale, Stille Nacht was, well, eye opening.  Nothing like Orval, Stille Nacht had a very malty peppery aroma.  The flavor was very sweet, not malty, but sweet and had a strong flavor of currants.  Some alcohol was noted in the finished, but the beer was overly balanced to the sweet side.  While the currant attempted to balance the sweetness, but rather overwhelmed the palate.  Not a beer I would buy unless I was really, really wanting a change.

Possible explanations for some of the bad ratings of this beer:
a)De Dolle changed the recipe and it used to be really crappy; b)old or infected bottles; c)you guys are on crack. 

I found this to be an extremely pleasant beer, not at all sour, with a very nice sweetness, hints of spice, a pronounced flavor of apples, and a good bitterness to balance things out. A great Christmas time beer.

This is one beautiful beer!!  Melissa just laughed at me as I sat across the kitchen from our bar with my mouth hanging wide open staring at this beer.  Incredibly cloudy orange to copper color with floaties all over the place and a 1 inch tall, rocky, bone-colored head that lasted and lasted.  I wanted to take a picture.  Nose is pretty subdued, with some apple peel, yeast and acidic qualities.  Flavors are incredible.  Gala or Fuji apples dipped in caramel with a slight toffee character up front and towards the middle.  Finishing with a sweet and spicy quality (cinnamon and ginger?) and hot alcohol.  The finish dries out and becomes more astringent as the beer warms, and alcohol becomes a detraction.  A wonderful dessert accompaniment except for the hot alcohol.  Heck, this could BE your dessert.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 Initial rating 2003: Great googley moogley this is good stuff.  Can you say Granny Smith?  Nice transparent orange color.  This is a very complex beer, and it sure is enjoyable and I guess that is all that really counts.  The best offering so far from this brewery 3.8
Rerate 4/9/11. Attractive orange beer with a tightly beaded foam.  Yeast, apricot, and orange in the nose. Alcohol, yeast and breadiness comprises the flavor and a mouth filling effervescence helps this stay fairly light.  I must say,  I really miss the sourness from the old batches and it really affects the rating.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2013 Scrumpy-like apple funkiness, with wooden inclinations, permeate this strong ales doughy yeast and sugary feel...Alcohol imposes its presence amidst the fluffy carbonation and sugary lengths...A stairway to airways high above...

Sometimes though, carbonation disappears, aroma is of unfinished pie, with flour, sweet fruit jelly and all...Flavors are very sweet (maple syrup, mead, canned fruit) but do not blend well with the alcohol bite in the end...Apparently, effervescence is necessary to marry its constituents...Rating above is an average of both experiences...

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2013 2013 bottle from Olbutikken, Copenhagen. Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting.
Body is hazy dark yellow to light amber, bottle conditioned.
Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie), lightly hoppy (flowers), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of honey, Juicy Fruit gum, dried mango, banana, dried pineapple, alcohol, pepper, mint.
Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.
Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.
Been a long long time since Ive seen a fresh bottle of this, but wow, Kris still has his game on for some of his line up (whereas some like Oerbier and the Export Stout are always infected or dull). This and the Dulle Teve and Arabier are all still quite nice, and this is the best of the three. Candyish but ridiculously complex and attractive...tons of tropical fruits, just insane. Surprisingly balanced in the mouth...Im used to this being too syrupy sweet in years past, but the finish on this batch is surprisingly crisp and bitter. Quite boozy but tolerable thanks to the rich body. One of the best barleywines out there...and that from a guy that tends to hate barleywines...I certainly never crave sweet boozy beers like this, but if forced to choose one, this might be #1 in the list.
Ive had regular and vintage (96) and have found to be very tasty!  Nice flavor, spices and aromas.

Deep,dark,hazy golden/orange. Explosive head and sticky lace. Yeasty,sour aroma with hints of malt,caramel,corriander, and others. This is very unique. Medium to thick bodied,creamy with lots of carb. Starts off sour then turns very caramelly sweet, then yeasty sharp again, finishing with tons of caramel apple sweetness.  Nice interplay between sweet and sour but the sweetness is too much for me.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2005 Bottled in 1996, sampled in 2005. I tried this one a few years ago and wasnt really impressed. But this aged sample really changed my opinion. Superb smooth flavour, very complex. Still, id like to try a fresh sample again to compare.

Merry Christmas. Fall is in the August air today, so, why not? As always De Dolle creates a beer worthy of examination. Beautiful, almost iridescent orange color w. a small (by De Dolle standards), creamy head. Delicately carbonated w. a few streams of fine bubbles rising lesiurely to the top of the glass. Packed w. malt aromas. Also, oak, or other seasoning wood, and cherries. The beer is simultaneously a near syrupy-sweet liqueur  and a crisply tart red ale. Extremely full mouthfeel with spicy cherry-chocolate flavors dominating. Finishes sweet, but clean and woody. I dont think there are any hops in this, with sourness replacing bitterness as a finisher. Nice beer.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012     Cloudy golden body, large frothy head, great retention. Spicy citrus/apple aroma. Spicy and sweet  malt body, notes of cinnamon apples, honey, candy sugar. Soft mouthfeel, some citrus notes and hints of nutmeg. Very smooth finish for the abv, some sourness, maybe a bit sugary but overall a great brew.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2004 Very tasty Belgian. Sweet marmalade, apricot nose, lots of yeast in the aroma aswell. Unmistakable yeasty Belgian nose. Sweet palate, almost like a dessert wine, bit of a citric acidity in there aswell towards the end, lots of flavour, and unique. Liked it the second time i had it a little better than the first. Soft yet assertive at the same time, lovely.

Slightly hazy orange brown with sub-mm yeast flecks. Large mid-tan lasting head with some light ring like lacing on glass. Awsome rum eggnog tasting foam - best tasting head on any beer Ive rated. Other aromas include, spices, muscat raisins,  plums and something that reminds me of the tangy substance used in instant chicken noodle soup! Medium bodied with a smooth sweet palate but not too cloying and balanced with enough bitter to make it interesting. The alcohol comes through imediately and quickly warms the edges of the ears but, hey, this is a festive beer so what do you expect. Other flavours also along the line of festive spirits including, rum and raisin, vintage port wine, burnt sugar and dried apples. The body is medium and the finish is mainly alcohol and sweet lingering alcohol. I love this stuff. Its not for every day drinking but as a festive drink I think its outstanding! My uncle Bob would definitely quaff himself under the table at Christmas (or anytime really) on this one if I let him.

Huge foamy, frothy head that lingers, is the first thing you notice, then...............Apples!  Thats what you think when you taste this beer.  Its a very sweet, appley-beer thats quite strong but hides its punches well.  This is, without a doubt, my favorite De Dolle beer.  Though I really dont care for their products, generally, I truly respect De Dolles creativity.  Each beer is very different from the others.
A very fruity, but not sweet beer, very interesting taste

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2012 Very sweet taste, bit tart. Raisins and porto. Very full bodied, almost buttery and oily. Storing the beer for a few years brings out more tartness, makes the beer more complex, lessens the sweetness and further improves carbonation.Re-rate: vintage 2003. Orange color, thin but steady head, cloudy. Buttery, somewhat yeasty aroma. Thick. Buttery flavor with pear and mango. Some roasted malt, alcoholic. Gets tastier and more buttery as the beer warmens up. Probably needs more time to develop. Still a good quality beer, but lightyears away from the Stille Nacht 10 years ago, that would easily score above 4.0.
2004 version, tasted dec 04: Firm and lasting head. Vinous, somewhat dusty aroma. Immensely powerful. Some hops, alcohol. Full bodied, edgy and sharp. Hints op pepper, endives, dust and roast. Needs storing.
2005 version, tasted december 05. Mandarin Napoleon aroma, citric with a hint of butter. A bit sharp and alcoholic on the tongue and surprise, the very first signs of an upcoming sourness. Hints of butter and band aids. I am very curious how this beer will develop. Will definitely store a few bottles.
2006 version, tasted januari 2007: orange golden color. Malty aroma with figs and peach. Sweet, buttery flavor with vanilla. Rather alcoholic. Peach. Powerful and likeable (7 3 7 4 14 = 3.5)
2007 version, tasted december 2007. Orange blonde, hazy with floaties. Raspberry, honey, butter and yeast in the aroma. Full bodied, alcoholic, yeasty and buttery flavor. Mango.
